Authors: Dallalzadeh E., Guru D.S., Manjunath S., Suraj M.G.
Title: Corner-based tracking of moving vehicles in traffic videos
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Department of Studies in Computer Science, University of Mysore, Manasagangothri, Mysore - 570 006, Karnataka, India
Authors with affiliations: Dallalzadeh, E., Department of Studies in Computer Science, University of Mysore, Manasagangothri, Mysore - 570 006, Karnataka, India; Guru, D.S., Department of Studies in Computer Science, University of Mysore, Manasagangothri, Mysore - 570 006, Karnataka, India; Manjunath, S., Department of Studies in Computer Science, University of Mysore, Manasagangothri, Mysore - 570 006, Karnataka, India; Suraj, M.G., Department of Studies in Computer Science, University of Mysore, Manasagangothri, Mysore - 570 006, Karnataka, India
Abstract: In this paper, we present a feature-based tracking approach to track moving vehicles in traffic videos. Vehicles are detected by background subtraction method and Gabor filtering is used to segment the detected vehicles. We propose corner-based tracking approach to track moving vehicles. The detected corner points of a vehicle are grouped using a rectangular search grid and they are labeled with the corresponding label obtained the previous frame. The proposed approach is able to track vehicles under variations in complex background, illumination, motion, position of a camera, different moving direction and occlusions. The proposed method represents the trajectory of the vehicles and thus can be used to measure the traffic parameters such lane changes and illegal U-turns. The precision rate is 97.23%. The speed of tracking of the vehicles is measured to be 90.91 frames per second in low traffic videos and 25.64 frames per second in moderate traffic videos.

Authors: Anil Kumar K.M., Suresha
Title: A two phase semantic approach to detect web users' opinion
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Department of Studies in Computer Science, University of Mysore, Manasagangothri Mysore, India
Authors with affiliations: Anil Kumar, K.M., Department of Studies in Computer Science, University of Mysore, Manasagangothri Mysore, India; Suresha, Department of Studies in Computer Science, University of Mysore, Manasagangothri Mysore, India
Abstract: In this paper we present an approach to identify opinion of web users from opinionated texts and to classify web users opinion into positive or negative. It is found that a few texts even though opinionated are falsely classified as neutral by opinion detection algorithms. When an opinionated text is subjected to opinion detection algorithm, it yields a value that is lesser or greater or equal to the threshold. If it is less than the threshold, it is classified as negative opinion. If it is greater than the threshold, it is classified as positive opinion. If it is equal to the threshold, it is considered as neutral opinion. Different approaches can be considered to obtain opinion from these computed neutral texts to classify texts efficiently as positive or negative. We propose a two phase semantic approach that uses patterns and keywords in detection and classification of users opinion from opinionated texts. Our approach is effective in detecting opinion and reducing incorrect classifications. It is found to better than the other implemented methods on six different data sets.
Author Keywords: Affective computing; Artificial intelligence; Opinion mining; Sentiment analysis

Title: Shape from an endoscope image using extended Fast Marching Method
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Department of Electronics and Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Guwahati, Guwahati-781039, India; Department of Computer Science, Chubu University, Matsumoto-cho 1200, Kasugai 487-8501, Japan; Department of Computer Science, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, BC, V6T 1Z4, Canada; Aichi Medical University, Nagakute 480-1195, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Neog, D.R., Department of Electronics and Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Guwahati, Guwahati-781039, India; Iwahori, Y., Department of Computer Science, Chubu University, Matsumoto-cho 1200, Kasugai 487-8501, Japan; Bhuyan, M.K., Department of Electronics and Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Guwahati, Guwahati-781039, India; Woodham, R.J., Department of Computer Science, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, BC, V6T 1Z4, Canada; Kasugai, K., Aichi Medical University, Nagakute 480-1195, Japan
Abstract: In this paper, 3D shape recovery from a single image is attempted along with the removal of specular reflections and also, treating multicolored images. The approach aims to generate a uniform diffused reflectance from multicolored specular image using color clustering with the scalar quantization in RGB space. The uniform reflectance is obtained by assigning the same reflectance factor for two neighboring points which are located along the boundary between two different color reflectance regions. Then extended Fast Marching Methods is used recover the shape under the conditions of nearby point light source illumination and perspective projection. The new approach is demonstrated on real endoscope image.

Authors: Srivastava P.R., Chis M., Deb S., Yang X.-S.
Title: Path optimization for software testing: An intelligent approach using cuckoo search
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Computer Science and Information System Department, BITS, Pilani - 333031, India; FREQUENTIS, Romania; Dept. of Computer Science and Engineering, C.V. Raman College of Engineering, Bhubaneswar, India; Yang, X.-S., Department of Engineering, University of Cambridge, Trumpington Street, Cambridge CB2 1PZ, United Kingdom
Abstract: Software Testing is one of the main important and complex steps in the software development lifecycle. To fully test a newly developed software package, either black box (specification based) or white box (code based) testing must be performed. White box testing depends upon structure of code and its control flow graph. Identification of independent path is a complex problem, so the aim of the current paper is to present a simple algorithm for independent path generation, based on the recently developed cuckoo search. The proposed approach has some additional set of rules for the effective paths generation and prioritization of the basic paths. It can be shown that the proposed approach guarantees full path coverage.

Authors: Jhunjhunuwala K.K., Verma R., Anurag A., Kawatra A., Srivastava P.R.
Title: Test case optimization using mining patterns
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Computer Science and Information Systems Department, BITS, Pilani-333031, India
Authors with affiliations: Jhunjhunuwala, K.K., Computer Science and Information Systems Department, BITS, Pilani-333031, India; Verma, R., Computer Science and Information Systems Department, BITS, Pilani-333031, India; Anurag, A., Computer Science and Information Systems Department, BITS, Pilani-333031, India; Kawatra, A., Computer Science and Information Systems Department, BITS, Pilani-333031, India; Srivastava, P.R., Computer Science and Information Systems Department, BITS, Pilani-333031, India
Abstract: This paper presents the technique for test case minimization and prioritization using data mining techniques and graph theoretic algorithms. The proposed approach uses Frequent Pattern Growth (FP-growth) Algorithm and topological sorting of graphs. It arranges the given requirements and their corresponding test cases in form of a market basket table, and uses FP-growth algorithm to find out the frequent item sets. These frequent item sets are used for generating strong association rules, which gives a minimized test suite. A graph representation from the frequent item sets (minimized test suite) is generated and using topological sorting algorithm test cases are prioritized. The technique is applied on two test suites as two different case studies and the results obtained using this approach have also been included.

Title: Assamese numeral recognition using morphological operations and Artificial Neural Network
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Department of Electronics and Communication Technology, Gauhati University, Guwahati-781014, Assam, India; Department of Electronics and Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Guwahati, Guwahati - 781039, Assam, India
Authors with affiliations: Dutta, K., Department of Electronics and Communication Technology, Gauhati University, Guwahati-781014, Assam, India; Mitra, A., Department of Electronics and Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Guwahati, Guwahati - 781039, Assam, India; Sarma, K.K., Department of Electronics and Communication Technology, Gauhati University, Guwahati-781014, Assam, India
Abstract: Recognition of characters and numerals is an area in which Artificial Neural Network (ANN) is applied as a classifier. Although such work exist but from the stand point of language technology tools, an ANN based Assamese Numerals Recognition system can be developed where the samples are captured with coloured, noise corrupted and complex backgrounds. The major part of the work is to configure and train an ANN by numeral samples of Assamese scripts. The trained ANN can be fed with noise free and noise mixed data to verify if the ANN is able to handle environment induced variations and compensate the ill - effects of the distortion. The work performs the recognition of numerals captured with complex background with support from a set of morphological operations which increases the success rate of the system. The morphological operations are next replaced by an ANN based texture recognition which increases the success rate even further.
Author Keywords: ANN; Edge detection; Feature
Index Keywords: ANN; Complex background; Feature; Language technology; Mixed data; Morphological operations; Numeral recognition; Recognition of numerals; Recognition systems; Texture recognition; Edge detection; Neural networks; Mathematical morphology

Authors: Ramamurthy G., Spoorthy S.
Title: The warped Chirp Z-Transform
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Communications Research Centre, IIIT, Hyderabad, Gachibowli, Hyderabad, India
Authors with affiliations: Ramamurthy, G., Communications Research Centre, IIIT, Hyderabad, Gachibowli, Hyderabad, India; Spoorthy, S., Communications Research Centre, IIIT, Hyderabad, Gachibowli, Hyderabad, India
Abstract: Chirp Z-Transform (CZT) has been found to be computationally efficient in evaluating the z-transform of a finite-length sequence on a spiral contour. CZT provides better spectral resolution of closely spaced poles of a sequence. This algorithm evaluates the signal on equiangular points on the spiral contour. Warped Discrete Fourier Transform (WDFT) is a non-uniform sampling technique which evaluates the z-transform of a finite-length sequence on the unit circle at non-uniformly spaced points. In this paper, we develop the idea of evaluating the CZT of a finite-length sequence at unequally spaced frequency points. This technique is expected to find applications in speech signal and radar signal analysis.
Index Keywords: Chirp z-transform; Computationally efficient; Finite-length sequence; Nonuniform sampling; Radar signal analysis; Speech signals; Unit circles; Warped discrete-fourier transforms; Artificial intelligence; Discrete Fourier transforms; Z transforms

Authors: Rajamani L., Rajamani A.
Title: Application of neural network to detection of cardiac disease
Source title: Proceedings of the 2011 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, ICAI 2011
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Osmania University, Hyderabad-500007, India; Department of Information Technology, Aurora Engineering College, Bhongir, 508116, India
Authors with affiliations: Rajamani, L., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Osmania University, Hyderabad-500007, India; Rajamani, A., Department of Information Technology, Aurora Engineering College, Bhongir, 508116, India
Abstract: This study is primarily aimed at the detection of various heart diseases of a human heart from the information available in electrocardiograph (ECG) signals using artificial neural networks. Data used is the disorders in ECG interpreted due to abnormalities in sinus rhythm, P wave, PR and QT intervals etc., Design and implementation of a neural network to diagnose heart diseases is dealt with in this paper. Seventy nine disorders in ECG are identified and these are used as input to the network. The network output has 36 nodes which correspond to various heart diseases. The network is trained using 180 patterns. The influence of learning rate, network architecture and momentum factor is studied. The accuracy in prediction is observed to be 85 percent.
Author Keywords: Cardiac disease; ECG; Neural networks
Index Keywords: Cardiac disease; Heart disease; Human heart; Learning rates; Momentum factor; P waves; Sinus rhythm; Cardiology; Diseases; Electrocardiography; Network architecture; Neural networks

Authors: Mittal N., Gupta G., Mangal H.
Title: Ontology-based retrieval system using semantic indexing
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: MNIT Jaipur, India
Authors with affiliations: Mittal, N., MNIT Jaipur, India; Gupta, G., MNIT Jaipur, India; Mangal, H., MNIT Jaipur, India
Abstract: The main aim of information retrieval system is to provide most relevant documents to users in minimum possible time. Performance of a search engine depends on how fast the system accesses the documents and retrieves relevant documents. This can be achieved by indexing the all the web documents using the concepts of domain ontology. In this paper a complete ontology-based framework for the extraction and retrieval of semantic information in limited domains with the help of semantic indexing is presented. An indexing structure in which index is built on the basis of context of the document is proposed. Semantic indexing is implemented by identifying instances and their contexts within a document, and linking the words and phrases in document to ontological concepts. Performance of generated system is measured by comparing the search results with search results (generated without implementing context indexing). Semantic indexing enables retrieval from index on the basis of contexts rather than keyword search in large documents repository. This improves the quality of the search results and optimizes the retrieval process.
Author Keywords: Context; Domain ontology; Indexing; Information retrieval; Semantics
Index Keywords: Context; Domain ontologies; Indexing structures; Keyword search; Ontology-based; Relevant documents; Retrieval process; Retrieval systems; Search results; Semantic indexing; Semantic information; System access; Web document; Artificial intelligence; Indexing (of information); Search engines; Semantics; Information retrieval

Authors: Prakash C., Gangashetty S.V.
Title: Fourier - Bessel based cepstral coefficient features for text-independent speaker identification
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Speech and Vision Laboratory, Department of LTRC, International Institute of Technology, Hyderabad - 577 032, Andra pradesh, India
Authors with affiliations: Prakash, C., Speech and Vision Laboratory, Department of LTRC, International Institute of Technology, Hyderabad - 577 032, Andra pradesh, India; Gangashetty, S.V., Speech and Vision Laboratory, Department of LTRC, International Institute of Technology, Hyderabad - 577 032, Andra pradesh, India
Abstract: This paper proposes the Fourier-Bessel cepstral coefficients (FBCC) as features for robust text-independent speaker identification. Fourier-Bessel (FB) expansion is used instead of Fourier transform for representing the signal in frequency domain. FB expansion can be viewed as two-dimensional Fourier transform. Change in the kernel of the transform from exponential to decaying exponentials helps in viewing the speech signal as a linear sum of decaying exponentials. For signals arising out of acoustic tubes, where the signal is subjected to many damping effects, delays in the different components of the signal is inevitable. Representing such signals using FB coefficients helps in able identification of different components present in the signal. The random non-stationary nature of speech signal is more efficiently represented by damped sinusoidal nature of basis function that is more natural for the voiced speech signal since Bessel functions have damped sinusoidal as basis function, so it is more natural choice for the representation of natural signals. Vocal tract is modeled as a set of linear acoustic tubes being cylindrical in shape can be efficiently modeled using FB expansion because Bessel functions are solutions to cylindrical wave equations. The proposed approach to speaker identification is based on FBCC features, and method employ Gaussian mixture for modeling the speaker characteristics. However, we have build the speaker models from the Fourier-Bessel features derived from the speech samples, as an alternative to Mel-frequency cepstral coefficients (MFCC) and linear prediction cepstral coefficients (LPCC) for building the speaker models. An evaluation of the Gaussian mixture model is conducted on TIMIT database which consists of 630 speakers and 10 speech utterances per speaker and white noise signals of TIMIT database having various SNRs of 50, 40, 30 and 20 dB. Using the statistical model like Gaussian mixture model (GMM) and features extracted from the speech signals build a unique identity for each person who enrolled for speaker identification [1]. Estimation and Maximization algorithm is used for finding the maximum likelihood solution for a model with features, to test the later speeches against the database of all speakers who enrolled in the database. Experimental results shows that the FBCC can be used as the alternate feature for the LPCC and MFCC since it can improve the performance of the speaker identification task.
Author Keywords: Bessel coefficients; FBCC; Gaussian mixer model; MFCC; Speaker identification
Index Keywords: Bessel coefficients; FBCC; Gaussians; MFCC; Speaker identification; Acoustics; Artificial intelligence; Bessel functions; Fourier transforms; Loudspeakers; Speech; Tubes (components); White noise; Speech recognition

Authors: Rawat V., Jain A., Shrimali V.
Title: Analysis and assessment of ultrasound images for fetal biometry using morphological operators
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Department of Electronics Engineering, Samrat Ashok Technological Institute, Vidisha, (M.P.), India; Deptt of Training and Technical Education, Govt. of NCT Delhi, Delhi, India
Authors with affiliations: Rawat, V., Department of Electronics Engineering, Samrat Ashok Technological Institute, Vidisha, (M.P.), India; Jain, A., Department of Electronics Engineering, Samrat Ashok Technological Institute, Vidisha, (M.P.), India; Shrimali, V., Deptt of Training and Technical Education, Govt. of NCT Delhi, Delhi, India
Abstract: The Ultrasonography is considered to be one of the most powerful techniques for imaging organs for an obstetrician and gynecologist. Previously one of the authors has been calculated the gestational age of fetus. In this paper a method for the automatic measurement of fetal weight which is very important factor in context of fetal abnormality has been presented. Fetal femur length measurements are used to estimate fetal weight by using the EFW formula. By using a real-time ultrasound system, sonographers currently indicate the femur endpoints on the ultrasound display station with a mouse-like device. The measurements are subjective and have been proven to be inconsistent. The automatic approach described in this paper exploits a prior knowledge of the general range of femoral size and shape by using morphological operators, which process images based on shape characteristics. Morphological operators are used first to remove the background (noise) from the image, next to refine the shape of the femur and remove spurious artifacts, and finally produce a single pixel-wide skeleton of the femur. The skeleton endpoints are assumed to be the femur endpoints. The length of the femur is calculated as the distance between those endpoints and then calculates the EFW. A comparison of the measurements obtained with the manual and with the automated techniques is included.
Author Keywords: Femur length; Fetal biometry; Ultrasonography
Index Keywords: Automated techniques; Automatic measurements; Femur length; Fetal biometry; Fetal weight; Gestational age; Morphological operator; Prior knowledge; Shape characteristics; Size and shape; Sonographers; Ultrasound images; Ultrasound system; Artificial intelligence; Display devices; Musculoskeletal system; Ultrasonics; Ultrasonography; Measurements

Authors: Malakar S., Ghosh P., Sarkar R., Das N., Basu S., Nasipuri M.
Title: An improved offline handwritten character segmentation algorithm for Bangla script
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Dept. of Master of Computer Application, M.C.K.V. Institute of Engineering, Liluah, Howrah, India; Dept. of Computer Science and Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata, India
Authors with affiliations: Malakar, S., Dept. of Master of Computer Application, M.C.K.V. Institute of Engineering, Liluah, Howrah, India; Ghosh, P., Dept. of Computer Science and Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata, India; Sarkar, R., Dept. of Computer Science and Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata, India; Das, N., Dept. of Computer Science and Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata, India; Basu, S., Dept. of Computer Science and Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata, India; Nasipuri, M., Dept. of Computer Science and Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata, India
Abstract: Effective segmentation of offline handwritten word images of unconstrained handwritten Bangla script is a challenging problem in Optical Character Recognition (OCR) application. Presence of a continuous horizontal line called 'Matra' is an important feature of this script. However, in unconstrained cursive handwriting, Matra can be wavy or discontinuous, makes the problem of segmentation difficult. The current work designs a novel technique for identification of potential segmentation points on the Matra for isolating constituent characters from the word image of Bangla script. In the first stage, 8-neighbour Connected Component Labelling (CCL) algorithm is applied to identify connected sub-parts of the word images. These connected components are then classified into either of the two classes, namely 'Segment further' (SF) and 'Do Not Segment' (DNS). In the second stage, the trivial SF and DNS components are separated. Then the remaining components are classified into SF and DNS using a Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) based classifier. Finally, fuzzy segmentation features are used over the SF components to identify potential segmentation points on the detected fuzzy Matra region for extraction of constituent characters or character sub-parts from the overall word images. The present technique has been successfully applied on 500 handwritten Bangla word images and it is also found that the technique performs better than our earlier character segmentation techniques [1-2].
Author Keywords: Bangla script; Character segmentation; Component classification; Fuzzy features; Handwritten word images; OCR system
Index Keywords: Bangla script; Character segmentation; Connected component; Fuzzy features; Fuzzy segmentation; Handwritten words; Multi layer perceptron; Novel techniques; Off-line handwritten; Offline handwritten character segmentation; Remaining component; Word images; Work design; Artificial intelligence; Job analysis; Optical character recognition; Internet protocols

Authors: Srinivasan B., Parthasarathi R.
Title: Mīmāṁsā inspired representation of actions (MIRA)
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Department of IST, CEG Campus, Anna University, Chennai, India
Authors with affiliations: Srinivasan, B., Department of IST, CEG Campus, Anna University, Chennai, India; Parthasarathi, R., Department of IST, CEG Campus, Anna University, Chennai, India
Abstract: This paper endeavors to formalize imperatives that convey actions. Imperatives, unlike propositions, do not hold the value of true or false. Peter Vranas proposed an alternate logical formalism in the literature of imperative logic with three values, namely: Satisfaction (S), Violation (V) and Avoidance (A). Although this formalism takes into account the conditional imperatives, it does not address imperatives from the perspective of actions. According to Mīmaṁsā (one of the six systems of Indian philosophy), the prime motive of an imperative is to carry out action so as to reach the goal. This paper modifies the notion of Vranas' Imperative Logic using Mīmaṁsā principles. The resulting imperative formalism, focusing on action representation, is presented with Syntax, Deduction rules and Semantic tables. The effectiveness of this representation is demonstrated in the area of Artificial Intelligence Planning.
Author Keywords: Action representation; Artificial Intelligence Planning; Conditionals; Conjunction; Disjunction; Imperative logic; Instruction; Mīmaṁsā
Index Keywords: Action representation; Artificial intelligence planning; Conditionals; Conjunction; Disjunction; Imperative logic; Instruction; Artificial intelligence

Authors: Umamaheswari E., Geetha T.V.
Title: UNL based context clustering for news event detection
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Tamil Computing Lab., DCSE and DIST, Anna University, Chennai, 600025, Tamilnadu, India
Authors with affiliations: Umamaheswari, E., Tamil Computing Lab., DCSE and DIST, Anna University, Chennai, 600025, Tamilnadu, India; Geetha, T.V., Tamil Computing Lab., DCSE and DIST, Anna University, Chennai, 600025, Tamilnadu, India
Abstract: Information available on the news paper articles gives news on daily basis. Different news paper articles describe the same event in different perspectives. Hence it will be useful if all this information is gathered and provided as organized information to the user. This paper presents a context based graph clustering for news events. Previous work on context clustering was done based on the similarity of the terms or occurrence of the terms between the documents. Our approach uses a Universal networking language (UNL) as a knowledge base. Those event specific UNL relations are used to identify the event context. The concepts which have these event specific relations are considered as event terms. Hence the effort required to identify the event and non event sentences are reduced. This work considers the event weight score for computing the event context similarity between the documents. The agglomerative clustering is modified by incorporating the event specific relation weight, position score, along with the TF(Term Frequency)-IDF(Inverse Document Frequency) score. The algorithm has been evaluated with the UNL based context clustering approach on the corpus of Tamil newspaper articles and our UNL context based graph clustering approach gives meaningful event specific clusters than the previous approach.
Index Keywords: Agglomerative clustering; Context clustering; Context-based; Event context; Event terms; Event-specific; Graph clustering; Inverse Document Frequency; Knowledge base; News event detections; Term Frequency; Universal networking languages; Weight scores; Artificial intelligence; Knowledge based systems; Text processing; Newsprint

Authors: Sarkar R., Moulik S., Das N., Basu S., Nasipuri M., Basu D.K.
Title: Word extraction from unconstrained handwritten Bangla document images using Spiral Run Length Smearing Algorithm
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata, India; Department of Information Technology, Jadavpur University, Kolkata, India; A.I.C.T.E., Jadavpur University, Kolkata, India
Authors with affiliations: Sarkar, R., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata, India; Moulik, S., Department of Information Technology, Jadavpur University, Kolkata, India; Das, N., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata, India; Basu, S., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata, India; Nasipuri, M., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata, India; Basu, D.K., A.I.C.T.E., Jadavpur University, Kolkata, India
Abstract: Optical Character Recognition (OCR) is the process of electronic conversion of handwritten/printed text into machine-encoded text, which involves various phases ranging from scanning the document, text line extraction, word extraction, character segmentation to character recognition. In the present work, we have proposed a word extraction technique from handwritten Bangla document image. The Run Length Smoothing Algorithm (RLSA) [1] is a very familiar method used in the field of Image Processing. The horizontal and vertical RLSA fails to smear when the neighboring data pixels do not lie in a straight horizontal or vertical line. In this paper, we have modified the standard RLSA technique to devise a new category, called Spiral Run Length Smearing Algorithm (SRLSA), which overcomes some of the shortcomings of the other two categories of RLSA and helps us to achieve a better result in the word extraction stage. We have applied SRLSA technique on the database CMATERdb1.1.1 [2] (freely available at http://code.google.com/p/cmaterdb), which comprises of 100 Bangla handwritten document images. The technique has extracted 86.01% words successfully.
Author Keywords: Bangla script; CMATERdb; Handwritten document image; Spiral RLSA; Word extraction

Authors: Jain P., Pachori R.B.
Title: A new approach for glottal closure instants detection from speech signals
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Signal Analysis Lab., School of Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Indore, 452017 Indore, India
Authors with affiliations: Jain, P., Signal Analysis Lab., School of Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Indore, 452017 Indore, India; Pachori, R.B., Signal Analysis Lab., School of Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Indore, 452017 Indore, India
Abstract: Glottal Closure Instants (GCIs) are defined as time instants of significant excitation of the vocal tract system during the production of speech. Non-stationary nature of excitation source and vocal tract system makes accurate identification of GCIs, a difficult task. All the existing methods for GCI detection require knowledge of voiced activity regions and a rough estimation of pitch frequency. In this paper, we propose a novel method based on time-frequency analysis that can be employed on entire speech signal to detect GCIs without any prior information. The proposed method automatically detects regions of glottal activity and determines an estimate of pitch frequency for each voiced activity region. The proposed method locates GCIs with high accuracy and reliability. Simulations are carried out on speech signals taken from CMU-Arctic database and the short time Fourier transform (STFT) has been used as a time-frequency analysis tool. The performance of the proposed method based on time-frequency analysis is found out to be significantly better than existing methods.
Author Keywords: Glottal Closure Instants (GCI); Non-stationary signal; Pitch frequency; Speech signal; Time-frequency analysis; Voiced activity detection
Index Keywords: Activity detection; Glottal Closure Instants (GCI); Nonstationary signals; Pitch frequencies; Speech signals; Time frequency analysis; Artificial intelligence

Authors: Hanumantharaju M.C., Ravishankar M., Rameshbabu D.R., Manjunath Aradhya V.N.
Title: An efficient metric for evaluating the quality of color image enhancement
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Department of Information Science and Engineering, Dayananda Sagar College of Engineering, Bangalore, India
Authors with affiliations: Hanumantharaju, M.C., Department of Information Science and Engineering, Dayananda Sagar College of Engineering, Bangalore, India; Ravishankar, M., Department of Information Science and Engineering, Dayananda Sagar College of Engineering, Bangalore, India; Rameshbabu, D.R., Department of Information Science and Engineering, Dayananda Sagar College of Engineering, Bangalore, India; Manjunath Aradhya, V.N., Department of Information Science and Engineering, Dayananda Sagar College of Engineering, Bangalore, India
Abstract: This paper describes a new metric for evaluating the quality of the color image enhancement. The image enhancement achieved by algorithms such as histogram equalization, adaptive histogram equalization, homomorphic filtering and Multiscale Retinex with Color Restoration (MSRCR) etc., improves the contrast, luminance and dynamic range compression. However, these algorithms introduces halo artifacts, violates the gray world assumption and edge details of an image is lost. A major concern is that there is no accurate objective criterion for assessing the performance of image enhancement algorithms. Researchers developed some objective criteria such as Peak Signal to Noise Ratio (PSNR), contrast enhancement performance, luminance enhancement performance and Structural Similarity Measurement (SSIM) etc. However, they could not solve the problem satisfactorily, and it often uses visual inspection and subjective criteria to evaluate the performance of these image enhancement algorithms. This paper proposes an objective and effective assessment criterion, Wavelet Energy (WE), to evaluate the performance of the color image enhancement algorithms. The proposed scheme describes both textual and structural information changes in an enhanced image. Numerous experiments were conducted to demonstrate the superiority of the proposed metric over the existing metrics. Experimental results confirm that the WE is an efficient and useful metric for evaluating the quality of the color image enhancement.
Author Keywords: Color image enhancement; Objective metric; Peak signal to noise ratio; Structural similarity measure; Wavelet energy

Authors: Chandra B., Karpade A., Mehta P.
Title: Improved ant clustering algorithm
Source title: Proceedings of the 2011 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, ICAI 2011
Affiliations: Department of Mathematics, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, 110016, India; Department of Industrial and Management Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur, India
Authors with affiliations: Chandra, B., Department of Mathematics, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, 110016, India; Karpade, A., Department of Industrial and Management Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur, India; Mehta, P., Department of Industrial and Management Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur, India
Abstract: Clustering has applications in variety of fields like customer segmentation, credit card fraud detection and medical imaging. Several clustering techniques exist in the literature. Ant Based clustering [2, 4] is intended to improve the quality of clusters as compared to other clustering techniques. However Ant clustering takes lot of time in order to produce good quality clusters. In this paper, Improvements over existing Ant Based clustering algorithm has been proposed by forming a dissimilarity matrix, creating a list of agents based on the sorted dissimilarity values, proper placement of agents and the choice of agents in each iteration based on dissimilarity values in the ant clustering algorithm. It has been demonstrated on fifteen benchmark datasets that the proposed method improves the quality of clusters and reduces the computational time as compared to the standard Ant Clustering algorithm and the widely used K means algorithm.

Authors: Thamburaj F., Ganapathy G.
Title: Tracking evolutionary links among Coronavirus types using self-organizing neural networks
Source title: Proceedings of the 2011 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, ICAI 2011
Affiliations: Computer Science Department, Bharathidasan University, Tiruchirappalli, Tamil Nadu, India
Authors with affiliations: Thamburaj, F., Computer Science Department, Bharathidasan University, Tiruchirappalli, Tamil Nadu, India; Ganapathy, G., Computer Science Department, Bharathidasan University, Tiruchirappalli, Tamil Nadu, India
Abstract: The Coronaviruses are worldwide in distribution and caused an epidemic in China in 2003. The rapidly mutating Coronaviruses spreads fast by taking different forms and infects not only human beings but also cattle, pigs, rodents, cats, dogs and birds. Infighting against these viruses, it is important to elucidate the evolutionary links among the different types of Coronaviruses. This article explores the possible roots of the evolution of Coronaviruses with the help of unsupervised Self-Organizing Map (SOM) neural network. The migration paths of these viruses are analyzed with different Self-Organizing maps based on the different genomic signatures of 50 complete Coronavirus genomes. The results are corroborated with other findings and thus Self-Organizing maps are proved to be fast, efficient, and economical tool to use as initial pointers to detailed phylogenetic analysis. New subgroups are also revealed by clustering these genomes with SOM.
Author Keywords: Abinitio method; Coronavirus; Genome classification; Nucleotide signatures; Pattern recognition; Self-organizing feature map

Authors: Anand D., Bharadwaj K.K.
Title: Tackling the sparsity problem in recommender systems by leveraging on indirect user-user and item-item similarity
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: School of Computer and System Sciences, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi, India
Authors with affiliations: Anand, D., School of Computer and System Sciences, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi, India; Bharadwaj, K.K., School of Computer and System Sciences, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi, India
Abstract: The sparsity problem in Collaborative Filtering (CF) refers to the scarcity of available user ratings which renders the estimation of similarity between most user/item pairs infeasible. The knowledge about such user-user or item-item relationships can aid better collaboration which can help in guessing future user needs better. In this work, we propose to build on the existing user-user/item-item relations inferred from the available preference information to estimate indirect user-user and item-item links. Our approach differs from other approaches, since we propose to utilize not only the existing matches in preferences but also dissimilarity between users or items, which allows us to base the indirect similarity computation on the enhanced information. The proposed approach also factors in the number of paths connecting two entities and the length of the paths while assessing entity closeness. The experiments comparing the proposed approaches to the traditional CF algorithms confirm that the proposed method surpass these methods in terms of both predictive quality and coverage, especially in sparse data scenarios.
Author Keywords: Collaborative filtering; Indirect similarity; Recommender systems
Index Keywords: Collaborative filtering; Indirect similarity; Preference information; Similarity computation; Sparse data; Sparsity problems; User need; User rating; Artificial intelligence; Recommender systems

Authors: Shah R., Chandrayan K., Rao P.
Title: Efficient broadcast monitoring using audio change detection
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay, Powai, Mumbai - 400076, India
Authors with affiliations: Shah, R., Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay, Powai, Mumbai - 400076, India; Chandrayan, K., Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay, Powai, Mumbai - 400076, India; Rao, P., Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay, Powai, Mumbai - 400076, India
Abstract: Digital audio broadcast monitoring is the task of detecting and locating occurrences of specific audio content in broadcast streams. It has important applications in the media industry such as automatic monitoring of the airing of advertisements or commercials. The monitoring is accomplished by searching the streaming audio to detect regions where similarity with the specified audio clips of interest is high. The process involves matching perceptually relevant features extracted by a frame-level analysis of the audio with stored reference templates. The searching of the entire audio stream with sufficiently small time step makes the process very computationally intensive. In this work, a method is proposed to reduce computation time by restricting the search to a limited set of candidate locations obtained using blind audio segmentation. The system is evaluated on real broadcast audio recordings to demonstrate the computational advantage achieved.
Author Keywords: Broadcast monitoring; Fingerprinting; Segmentation
Index Keywords: Audio clips; Audio content; Audio segmentation; Audio stream; Automatic monitoring; Broadcast monitoring; Candidate locations; Change detection; Computation time; Computational advantages; Digital audio broadcasts; Fingerprinting; Media industry; Time step; Artificial intelligence; Image segmentation; Audio recordings

Authors: Basavanna M., Shivakumara P., Srivatsa S.K., Hemantha Kumar G.
Title: A new run length based method for scene text detection
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, Government College (Autonomous), Mandya-Karnataka, India; School of Computing, National University of Singapore, Singapore, Singapore; St. Joseph College of Engineering, Chennai-Tamil Nadu, India; Department of Studies in Computer Science, University of Mysore, Karnataka, India
Authors with affiliations: Basavanna, M., Department of Computer Science, Government College (Autonomous), Mandya-Karnataka, India; Shivakumara, P., School of Computing, National University of Singapore, Singapore, Singapore; Srivatsa, S.K., St. Joseph College of Engineering, Chennai-Tamil Nadu, India; Hemantha Kumar, G., Department of Studies in Computer Science, University of Mysore, Karnataka, India
Abstract: Scene text detection and extraction from images is not as easy as detection of text in plain background document images because scene text images usually have complex background, different fonts, font size, colors, orientation etc. Hence it is an emerging and challenging research area in document analysis. Besides, it is essential for bridging gap between high and low level features to retrieve images accurately and efficiently. To achieve this, we present a new method based on run length algorithm for scene text detection in complex background images. The run lengths are calculated for the Sobel edge map of input image. The run length helps in detecting text because of the fact that when text appears in the image, characters and words have regular spacing between characters and words. This feature is explored to detect text in scene images by introducing run length algorithm in this work. The benchmark database ICDAR 2003 competition is used for evaluating the performance of the proposed method. The result of the proposed method is compared with the result of existing methods to show its superiority over existing methods in terms of f-measure. The robustness of the proposal is also tested by conducting experiments on our own data, captured by high resolution (camera) and low resolution (mobile).
Author Keywords: Complex scene text image; Max-Min clustering; Run length; Scene text detection; Scene text recognition; Sobel edge map
Index Keywords: Complex scenes; Edge map; Max-min; Run length; Scene Text; Algorithms; Artificial intelligence; Benchmarking; Image segmentation; Character recognition

Authors: Bajaj V., Pachori R.B.
Title: Application of the sample entropy for discrimination between seizure and seizure-free EEG signals
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Signal Analysis Lab., School of Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Indore, 452017 Indore, India
Authors with affiliations: Bajaj, V., Signal Analysis Lab., School of Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Indore, 452017 Indore, India; Pachori, R.B., Signal Analysis Lab., School of Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Indore, 452017 Indore, India
Abstract: The electroencephalogram (EEG) is an invaluable measurement for the purpose of assessing brain activities. The detection of epileptic seizures based on EEG signal is very useful in diagnostics. In this paper, we present a new method for discrimination between seizure and seizure-free EEG signals. The proposed method is based on empirical mode decomposition (EMD) process. We investigated that the sample entropy of the intrinsic mode functions (IMFs) generated by EMD process have potential to discriminate seizure from the seizure-free EEG signals. We have shown that the sample entropy measurement of IMFs is able to characterize the irregularity of the seizure EEG signals. The sample entropy measured from the IMFs has been used as a feature in order to discriminate seizure and seizure-free EEG signals. The sample entropy measurement of IMFs has provided better discrimination performance. The proposed approach based on EMD and sample entropy is better than sample entropy based approach for EEG signal discrimination.
Author Keywords: Empirical mode decomposition (EMD); Epileptic seizure; Sample entropy
Index Keywords: Brain activity; EEG signals; Empirical Mode Decomposition; Epileptic seizures; Intrinsic Mode functions; Sample entropy; Artificial intelligence; Entropy; Neurophysiology; Signal processing; Electroencephalography

Authors: Agarwal M., Vig L., Kumar N.
Title: MORCFA: A multiple objective robot coalition formation algorithm
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, University of Delhi, Delhi-110007, India; School of Information Technology, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi 110067, India
Authors with affiliations: Agarwal, M., Department of Computer Science, University of Delhi, Delhi-110007, India; Vig, L., School of Information Technology, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi 110067, India; Kumar, N., Department of Computer Science, University of Delhi, Delhi-110007, India
Abstract: In multiple robot systems, the problem of allocation of complex tasks to heterogeneous teams of robots, also known as the multiple robot coalition formation problem, has begun to receive considerable attention. Efforts to address the problem range from heuristics based approaches that search the subspaces of the coalition structure to evolutionary learning approaches. Conventional approaches typically strive to optimize a single objective function such as the number of tasks executed or the time required to execute all tasks, or a weighted function of such objectives. In real world applications, objectives such as minimizing distance traveled and maximizing the number of tasks completed are often conflicting in nature. The coalition formation problem thus naturally lends itself to a multi-objective optimization approach based on evolutionary learning. In this paper, we formulate the problem of mapping coalitions of robots to a set of tasks as a multi-objective optimization problem and propose a variant of Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm (NSGA-II) to arrive at trade-off solutions. Time deadlines in real life scenarios being generally soft, we refine the model to incorporate fuzzy deadlines. Simulations demonstrate the efficacy of the proposed approach in generating the set of Pareto optimal solutions.
Index Keywords: Coalition formations; Coalition structure; Complex task; Conventional approach; Evolutionary Learning; Fuzzy deadline; Multi objective optimizations (MOO); Multi-objective optimization problem; Multiple objectives; Multiple robot; Multiple robot system; Non-dominated sorting genetic algorithms; NSGA-II; Pareto optimal solutions; Real-world application; Single objective; Tradeoff solution; Weighted function; Industrial robots; Multiobjective optimization; Artificial intelligence

Abstract: In this paper, we propose a robust and an accurate face recognition model which uses the feature extraction capabilities of fractional discrete cosine transform (FDCT) followed by Linear Discriminant analysis (LDA) for compact representation of feature vectors. The proposed model is tested on publicly available standard AT&T and YALE face databases to exhibit the superiority of fractional DCT technique in terms of recognition accuracy.

Title: UNL Deconverter for Malayalam
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011

Abstract: Universal Networking Language (UNL) is an intermediate language used for communication by different language users in an internet or distributed environment. UNL Deconverter for a language can be used to convert an UNL document into that language. UNL Deconverter for Malayalam enables us to read any language document in Malayalam provided the document once it is coded in UNL. This also eliminates the need for developing individual Machine Translation tools for Malayalam from other languages. Paper specifies how to convert an UNL document to Malayalam by maintaining the language rules for word and sentence formation for Malayalam.

Authors: Sarkar A., Saha A., Tudu B., Bhattacharyya N., Bandyopadhyay R.
Title: Discrimination of black tea quality using electronic nose: A GA based approach
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Jadavpur University, Department of Instrumentation and Electronics Engineering, Kolkata-700 098, India; Centre for Development of Advanced Computing(C-DAC), Kolkata-700 091, West Bengal, India
Authors with affiliations: Sarkar, A., Jadavpur University, Department of Instrumentation and Electronics Engineering, Kolkata-700 098, India; Saha, A., Jadavpur University, Department of Instrumentation and Electronics Engineering, Kolkata-700 098, India; Tudu, B., Jadavpur University, Department of Instrumentation and Electronics Engineering, Kolkata-700 098, India; Bhattacharyya, N., Centre for Development of Advanced Computing(C-DAC), Kolkata-700 091, West Bengal, India; Bandyopadhyay, R., Jadavpur University, Department of Instrumentation and Electronics Engineering, Kolkata-700 098, India
Abstract: Genetic Algorithm (GA) based clustering technique is used in this paper for black tea quality discrimination using an electronic nose. An electronic nose is a device which consists of an array of metal oxide semiconductor (MOS) sensors. It discriminates aromas by analyzing moderately discriminating gas sensor array data with pattern recognition methods. Six different grades of tea were considered for the experiment. Genetic algorithm based clustering technique successfully used in discriminating the six different grades of black tea into six different clusters, thus justifying the use of this technique. The separability index of the different clusters has also been considered and a comparative study has been established between GA based clustering and fuzzy c-means (FCM) clustering.

Authors: Vig L., Gupta A., Basu A.
Title: On the relation between hunger, dopamine and action rate
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: School of Copmutational and Integrative Sciences, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi, India; Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Vig, L., School of Copmutational and Integrative Sciences, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi, India; Gupta, A., Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN, United States; Basu, A., School of Copmutational and Integrative Sciences, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi, India
Abstract: A number of conditioning studies use food as reward. Hunger is considered to be a critical factor governing the animal's behavior in such studies. Despite its significance, most theories of animal conditioning fail to take hunger into consideration, while analyzing the behavioral data. In this paper, we analyze the neuroscientific data supporting the hypothesis that hunger and food consumption affect the brain's dopamine system, which in turn governs the animal's behavior. According to this hypothesis, chronic hunger results in a decrease in the extracellular dopamine levels in the animal's brain. This decrease is believed to trigger a series of reactions that increase the responsivity of the phasic dopamine system. A direct consequence of this is an increased vigor of all dopamine-dependent behaviors. The level of extra-cellular dopamine is also modulated by the process of food consumption. Food consumption raises the dopamine above the baseline level. This raise depends on the animals' hunger, such that once the hunger is satisfied, the dopamine level falls back to the baseline. This extra-cellular dopamine governs the response vigor, with an increase in dopamine resulting in a more vigorous response. We present a mathematical model based on this hypothesis. Our model is able to provide a simple explanation for a number of behavioral findings.
Index Keywords: Baseline levels; Behavioral data; Critical factors; Extracellular; Food consumption; Responsivity; Amines; Animals; Artificial intelligence; Food supply; Mathematical models; Neurophysiology

Authors: Sharma S., Markan C.M.
Title: Comparison between two biologically inspired algorithms: 'Cepstral and Phase method' for stereoscopic depth estimation
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Dayalbagh Educational Institute, Agra, India
Authors with affiliations: Sharma, S., Dayalbagh Educational Institute, Agra, India; Markan, C.M., Dayalbagh Educational Institute, Agra, India
Abstract: Binocular disparity refers to the difference in image location of an object seen by the left and right eyes, resulting from the eyes' horizontal separation. Cepstral and Phase method are two biologically inspired algorithms, used for computing binocular disparity maps. Cepstral filtering is a mechanism that applies Fourier Transforms on interlaced portions on an image from the two eyes mapped on the cortex. Such interlacing naturally occurs in the visual cortex in the form of Ocular Dominance Maps. And Phase method, which is based on computing disparity in the image from the two eyes by means of relative responses of even and odd receptive fields found in the Primary Visual Cortex. Both the algorithms exploit only part of the functions used in the biological flow of data to reconstruct the depth perception. The algorithms look different as both follow different procedures and functions. This paper compares these two different claimed approaches and show that in essence they are same. If the computational steps are broken and compared then they are doing the same thing. We demonstrate that each step in both algorithms is same and only the functions used are different as they are just the mathematical way of representation. By comparing both the algorithms, the advantage of one can be benefited by the other. The equivalence condition has also been derived.
Index Keywords: Binocular disparity; Biological flows; Biologically inspired algorithms; Cepstral; Depth Estimation; Equivalence conditions; Image locations; Ocular dominance; Phase methods; Primary visual cortex; Receptive fields; Relative response; Visual cortexes; Artificial intelligence; Binoculars; Depth perception; Fourier transforms; Functions; Algorithms

Authors: Giruba Beulah S.E., Madhan Karky V., Ranganathan K., Suriyah M.
Title: Pleasantness scoring models for Tamil lyrics
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, College of Engineering, Anna University, Guindy, Chennai-600025, India
Authors with affiliations: Giruba Beulah, S.E., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, College of Engineering, Anna University, Guindy, Chennai-600025, India; Madhan Karky, V., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, College of Engineering, Anna University, Guindy, Chennai-600025, India; Ranganathan, K., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, College of Engineering, Anna University, Guindy, Chennai-600025, India; Suriyah, M., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, College of Engineering, Anna University, Guindy, Chennai-600025, India
Abstract: Considerable research is to the fore in the determination of how pleasant a word is. Research on lyric or poem pleasantness concentrates mainly on meter patterns. Pleasantness of a lyric or poem however stems not only from meter patterns but also from the individual phonemes present in the words and their shades. This paper explores phonetic aspects such as voice and manner of articulation, length of articulation that may contribute to pleasantness and projects five models to judge the pleasantness of a word. Of these models, three are language independent and the rest are dependent on the phoneme categorization found in the classical Tamil language. The models are compared against each other and with human judgment. The results and further discussion are reported.

Authors: Barbhuiya R.K., Mustafa K., Jabin S.
Title: Design perspectives of intelligent tutoring system
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, Jamia Millia Islamia (A Central University) Jamia Nagar, New Delhi, India
Authors with affiliations: Barbhuiya, R.K., Department of Computer Science, Jamia Millia Islamia (A Central University) Jamia Nagar, New Delhi, India; Mustafa, K., Department of Computer Science, Jamia Millia Islamia (A Central University) Jamia Nagar, New Delhi, India; Jabin, S., Department of Computer Science, Jamia Millia Islamia (A Central University) Jamia Nagar, New Delhi, India
Abstract: Intelligent Tutoring Systems (ITSs) have come a long way, since their inception decades ago. Its prospects have revolutionized e-Learning, curriculum instructions and workplace training. The field has witnessed significant developments towards many possible directions and as a result, numerous ITSs have been developed to date. Recent tutoring systems have moved from research labs to classrooms [1]. However, it is still a costly affair and lacks established standards. Human learning phenomena are very complex and itself is an ongoing research activity right through the history of mankind. This paper attempts to identify some key instructional/learning aspects that must be addressed while designing a successful tutoring system. In this regard, we have reviewed some of the well-known ITS design principles and report an analysis of their success in modelling the learning/instructional ingredients.

Authors: Renuka Devi S.M., Bhagavati C.
Title: A novel method for long term learning using cluster merging
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Dept. of Computer and Information Sciences, University of Hyderabad, Hyderabad-500046, India; Dept. of Electronics and Communication Engg., G. Narayanamma Institite of Technology and Science, Hyderabad-500008, India
Authors with affiliations: Renuka Devi, S.M., Dept. of Computer and Information Sciences, University of Hyderabad, Hyderabad-500046, India, Dept. of Electronics and Communication Engg., G. Narayanamma Institite of Technology and Science, Hyderabad-500008, India; Bhagavati, C., Dept. of Computer and Information Sciences, University of Hyderabad, Hyderabad-500046, India
Abstract: A rudimentary problem in CBIR is the semantic gap that exists between the low-level features and high-level semantics as perceived by humans. Relevance Feedback is one solution to bridge this gap. Usually relevant images corresponding to a query form many islands in feature space. Also a query has set of relevant images, and vice-versa an image has many queries. This principle is used in formulating our novel method of Long Term Learning(LTL). Here the islands of relevant images corresponding to a query are tagged with query index. These islands of many queries are merged based on some criteria like overlapping, nearness etc., to obtain overall merged clusters with associated tagged query indices. Given a query, the initial retrieval set is obtained by combination of two schemes, one uses RF log that covers search based on nearby concept images and the other is based on simply the Mahalanobis distance of the query with database images. Experimental results illustrate the potential of proposed method of LTL by cluster merging in initial and as well over the iterations. The efficiency of our method is shown using standard Wang database of 1000 images.
Author Keywords: Cluster merging; Connected component; Hausdorff distance; Long term learning; Short term learning
Index Keywords: Cluster-merging; Connected component; Hausdorff distance; Long-term learning; Short term learning; Artificial intelligence; Image retrieval; Merging; Semantics; Query processing

Authors: Joshil Raj K., Nayak V.S., Jayaraman V.K.
Title: Ant miner based intrusion detection system with various feature selection algorithms
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Department of Computer Engineering, D.I.A.T (DU), Pune-411025, India; Armament Research and Development Establishment, Pashan, Pune-411021, India; SECG, CDAC, Pune-411007, India
Authors with affiliations: Joshil Raj, K., Department of Computer Engineering, D.I.A.T (DU), Pune-411025, India; Nayak, V.S., Armament Research and Development Establishment, Pashan, Pune-411021, India; Jayaraman, V.K., SECG, CDAC, Pune-411007, India
Abstract: This paper addresses the issue of identifying important input features in building an intrusion detection system (IDS). Elimination of the insignificant and useless inputs leads to a simplification of the problem, faster and more accurate systems. The aim is to achieve maximum detection accuracy and to minimize computational complexity. We use algorithms like Ant Colony Optimization (ACO), Genetic Algorithm (GA), Recursive Frequent Elimination (SVM-RFE) and Minimal-Redundancy-Maximal-Relevance (mRMR) for identifying important set of features from the IDS data. We have also used information gain and chi square statistics tool of WEKA (machine learning toolset) to rank the features and identified the important ones. Ant Miner is used for classification and prediction of the data after the feature selection. After identification of the relevant features, the input data is taken as per the reduced feature subset and the optimum parameters for Ant Miner are selected. The experiments were performed using KDDCUP-99 dataset, which is the benchmark dataset for intrusion detection. The prediction/detection accuracy achieved and the time taken for training and testing after use of each hybrid system on the data is finally compared.
Author Keywords: Ant Colony Optimization; Feature selection; Genetic algorithm; Intrusion detection systems (IDS); MRMR; Network security; SVM-RFE; WEKA

Authors: Mallikarjuna Rao G., Kumar P., Mittal A., Vijaya Kumari G., Babu G.R.
Title: Exploration of active pixels in intelligent face recognition for constrained mobile systems
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science Engineering, Gokaraju Rangaraju Institute of Engineering and Technology, Hyderabad, India; Computer Science Department, Jawaharlal Nehru Technological University, Hyderabad, India; Department of Computer Science Engineering, College of Engineering Roorkee, Roorkee, Uttaranchal, India
Authors with affiliations: Mallikarjuna Rao, G., Department of Computer Science Engineering, Gokaraju Rangaraju Institute of Engineering and Technology, Hyderabad, India; Kumar, P., Department of Computer Science Engineering, Gokaraju Rangaraju Institute of Engineering and Technology, Hyderabad, India; Mittal, A., Computer Science Department, Jawaharlal Nehru Technological University, Hyderabad, India; Vijaya Kumari, G., Department of Computer Science Engineering, College of Engineering Roorkee, Roorkee, Uttaranchal, India; Babu, G.R.
Abstract: Face recognition is one of the crucial techniques for entertainment applications. With the recent advances in smart phones and its availability, researchers are exploring efficient algorithms for face recognition on mobile devices. The limited memory and processing power on mobile devices pose significant challenge to the satisfactory of popular face recognition algorithms like LBP, ICA, PCA, Neural Networks etc. In this paper, a novel and efficient algorithm is proposed using Active Pixels which can capture essential local information of the facial image. The brody transform makes the approach more robust to rotational, translational invariance's. The experimental was conducted on standard face recognition databases like FGNET age dataset and color FERET dataset. The results demonstrated that our approach reduced memory requirement approximately by 80%, computational time by 70% in comparison with LBP approach while yielding same or even better recognition accuracy.

Authors: Sharmila Kumari M., Shekar B.H.
Title: On the use of phase of the discrete cosine transform for text detection in document images and video frames under variations in illumination
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, P.A. College of Engineering, Mangalore, Karnataka, India; Department of Computer Science, Mangalore University, Mangalore, Karnataka, India
Authors with affiliations: Sharmila Kumari, M., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, P.A. College of Engineering, Mangalore, Karnataka, India; Shekar, B.H., Department of Computer Science, Mangalore University, Mangalore, Karnataka, India
Abstract: In this paper, we have proposed an illumination invariant and an efficient text detection model for document images and video. The proposed model is based on the phase of the 2-D discrete cosine transform of the document image/video frame to overcome the adverse effect of illumination. The proposed model better localize the text blocks present in a document image as the phase of the cosine transform preserves the locations of the edges of a given document image and suitable post-processing mechanism is devised to correctly identify the text blocks. In order to exhibit the performance of the proposed model, we have conducted experimentation on the standard ICDAR-2003 dataset and also on the video frames collected over the internet. The text blocks of video frames possess properties such as varying illumination, fonts, colour, size, languages etc. Extensive experimental comparison and objective comparison is provided to exhibit the performance of the proposed text detection model.
Author Keywords: Discrete cosine transform; Phase spectrum; Text detection; Video indexing
Index Keywords: Adverse effect; Data sets; Document images; Experimental comparison; Illumination invariant; Phase spectra; Post processing; Text detection; Video frame; Video indexing; Artificial intelligence; Cosine transforms; Discrete cosine transforms

Authors: Rawat A., Yadav R.N., Shrivastava S.C.
Title: Beamwidth prediction of DPA smart antenna using support vector machine
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Samrat Ashok Technological Institute, Vidisha, India; Maulana Azad National Institute of Technology, Bhopal, India
Authors with affiliations: Rawat, A., Samrat Ashok Technological Institute, Vidisha, India; Yadav, R.N., Maulana Azad National Institute of Technology, Bhopal, India; Shrivastava, S.C., Maulana Azad National Institute of Technology, Bhopal, India
Abstract: The smart antenna system improves communication system performance in real time scenario. Beamwidth is a representation of the angular range of an antenna's transmitted or received signal. The theoretical beamwidth depends on the geometry of the antenna and the frequency of the signal. Actual beamwidth can be calculated from measurements of the peak power and the angles, to the points where the signal power is half its peak value and nonlinearly depending on feeding detail, frequency as well as array applied. Support vector machine is an optimization technique which can provide solution for beamwidth prediction of antenna array depending upon element and scan angle. Here support vector machine with kernel method is applied to dynamically phased array smart antenna for beamwidth classification.
Author Keywords: Beamwidth; Dynamically phased array smart antenna; Support vector machine

Authors: Akhtar Z., Rizwan M., Kale S.
Title: Performance and security of biometric fusion against spoof attacks
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Dept. of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, University of Cagliari, Italy; Abasaheb Garware College, Pune, India; Department of Electronic Science, University of Pune, India
Authors with affiliations: Akhtar, Z., Dept. of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, University of Cagliari, Italy; Rizwan, M., Abasaheb Garware College, Pune, India; Kale, S., Department of Electronic Science, University of Pune, India
Abstract: Biometrics is essentially a pattern recognition system that recognizes a person using his or her unique anatomical (e.g., face, fingerprint, iris) or behavioral (e.g., signature) patterns. Recent researches show that many biometric traits are susceptible to spoof attacks. Moreover, recent publications showed that, contrary to a popular belief, multimodal biometric systems in parallel fusion mode can be evaded even if only one trait is spoofed. Those results were obtained, using simulated spoof attacks, under the assumption that the spoofed and genuine samples are indistinguishable, which may not be true for all biometric traits. Security of multimodal biometric systems in serial fusion mode against spoof attacks has so far not been investigated. We further empirically investigate the performance and security issue of serial and parallel biometric fusion modes, using real spoof attack samples under different spoof attack scenarios. Preliminary empirical results on real biometric systems made up of face, fingerprint and iris confirm that multimodal biometric systems in both fusion modes are not intrinsically robust against spoof attacks as believed so far. In particular, multimodal biometric systems in serial fusion mode can be even less robust than systems in parallel mode. We also experimentally found that incorporating the biometric sample quality in biometric fusion increases the robustness of the multimodal systems against spoof attacks. In this paper, in the end we study the trade-off between performance and robustness of the biometric systems under spoof attacks.
Author Keywords: Biometric fusion; Biometric sample quality; Biometrics; Multimodal systems; Spoof attacks
Index Keywords: Attack scenarios; Biometric fusion; Biometric systems; Biometric traits; Multimodal biometric systems; Multimodal system; Parallel mode; Sample quality; Security issues; Serial fusion; Spoof attacks; Artificial intelligence; Biometrics; Pattern recognition systems; Security of data

Authors: Purohit A., Bhardwaj A., Tiwari A., Chaudhari N.S.
Title: Handling the problem of code bloating to enhance the performance of classifier designed using genetic programming
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Shri G. S. Institute of Technology and Science, Indore, India; Indian Institute of Technology Indore, Indore, India
Authors with affiliations: Purohit, A., Shri G. S. Institute of Technology and Science, Indore, India; Bhardwaj, A., Shri G. S. Institute of Technology and Science, Indore, India; Tiwari, A., Shri G. S. Institute of Technology and Science, Indore, India; Chaudhari, N.S., Indian Institute of Technology Indore, Indore, India
Abstract: The concept of "bloat" in Genetic Programming (GP) is a well established phenomenon characterized by variable-length genomes gradually increasing in size during evolution. "Bloating makes genetic programming a race against time, to find the best solution possible before bloat puts an effective stop to the search." In this paper we are proposing a special type of crossover operation in order to reduce the problem of bloat. In proposed crossover we are using local elitism replacement in combination with depth limit and size of the trees to reduce the problem of bloat substantially without compromising the performance. To demonstrate our approach we have designed a Multiclass Classifier using GP by taking few benchmark datasets. The use of local elitism in crossover increases the accuracy of the crossover operation and considering the fitness, depth limit and size of the trees after performing the elitism reduces the problem of bloat and further improves the performance of the classifier designed.
Author Keywords: Bloat; Crossover; Elitism; Fitness; Point mutation
Index Keywords: Bloat; Crossover; Elitism; Fitness; Point mutations; Artificial intelligence; Forestry; Genetic programming; Classifiers; Design; Forestry; Problem Solving

Authors: Rajpal P.S.
Title: Reliability modeling and analysis of helicopter operations using discrete-event simulation
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011

Abstract: A discrete-event simulation model using Weibull distribution has been applied to study reliabilities of subsystems and system failures of a helicopter operating unit. The model develops through problem formulation, identification of boundaries, collection and processing of failure data, computational algorithm, model validation followed by experiments on the validated model and subsequent analysis of results that help identify and evaluate development strategies that are likely to improve the system in different situations.

Authors: Jagadish V., Hariharan G., Kathirvel T., Geetha T.V.
Title: Adaptive personalization and Presentation of Recommendations to Learners (APPRL) using Latent Dirichlet Allocation
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2011
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, College of Engineering, Guindy, Anna University, Chennai, India
Authors with affiliations: Jagadish, V., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, College of Engineering, Guindy, Anna University, Chennai, India; Hariharan, G., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, College of Engineering, Guindy, Anna University, Chennai, India; Kathirvel, T., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, College of Engineering, Guindy, Anna University, Chennai, India; Geetha, T.V., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, College of Engineering, Guindy, Anna University, Chennai, India
Abstract: With the evolution of the World Wide Web as a repository of learning objects which can be presented to the learner for his study, the need for personalized e-learning systems has increased manifold. In this research, we present the APPRL (Adaptive Personalization and Presentation of Recommendations to Learners), a novel methodology to deliver appropriate content to a learner in an e-learning system. We make use of a list of prerequisites for a topic from a domain ontology to generate a suitable learning path so that the learner reaches his target knowledge state. The proposed methodology for learning path generation is adaptive as it incorporates the learner's prior knowledge. Having generated the learning path (a sequence of topics to be covered to reach the target knowledge state), APPRL also selects the best documents to recommend to the learner at each topic in the learning path. We exploit the Latent Dirichlet Allocation's capacity as a generative probabilistic model to enable APPRL make personalized recommendations. With regard to the use of LDA for personalization of web content, we believe that this is the first attempt made to the best of our knowledge. Furthermore, we also quantitatively evaluate the effectiveness of our proposed methodology for personalization of e-learning content by a User Specific Content Richness (USCR) measure.
Author Keywords: E-learning; Latent Dirichlet Allocation; Learner path generation; Recommendations; User-centric; World wide web
