Authors: Jain S., Tariwala S., Tiwari N.
Title: Exact grid navigation & collision free offline path planning through wireless channel implementation
Source title: Proceedings of the 2010 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, ICAI 2010
Affiliations: Department of Electronics and Communication Engineering, Medi-Caps Institute of Technology and Management, Indore, Madhya Pradesh, India
Authors with affiliations: Jain, S., Department of Electronics and Communication Engineering, Medi-Caps Institute of Technology and Management, Indore, Madhya Pradesh, India; Tariwala, S., Department of Electronics and Communication Engineering, Medi-Caps Institute of Technology and Management, Indore, Madhya Pradesh, India; Tiwari, N., Department of Electronics and Communication Engineering, Medi-Caps Institute of Technology and Management, Indore, Madhya Pradesh, India
Abstract: This paper presents a novel methodology which provides solution for exact grid navigation by implementation of a robotic agent: "WiCombot". Here, collision free offline path planning has been done for exact grid navigation. The navigation is a major challenge for robotic agents, which comprises static obstacles and a desired goal state. Hence, traversing is considered as a core issue to demonstrate the feasibility of collision free offline line path planning. In addition, a wireless channel has been set up between host computer and robotic agent. In order to deal with these issues successfully; we have proposed a scheme for shortest path determination and navigation with obstacle avoidance mechanism. A wireless map composed of coordinates (trace points, obstacle points and the final target) is transmitted in a wireless manner to the WiComBot from a mainframe computer unit by using the CC2500 wireless communication chip. In the proposed grid traversing system an Optimal Path is planned by the robotic agent in order to reach the final destination. The robotic agent starts from a predefined coordinate and orientation in the grid from where it could head autonomously for the final target in the grid by following the respective trace points and avoiding obstacle points which have been communicated to it in a wireless manner via the host computer.
Author Keywords: CC2500; Grid Navigation; Obstacle point; Offline Path Planning; Trace point; Wireless Map

Authors: Pakray P., Bandyopadhyay S., Gelbukh A.
Title: Dependency Parser based textual entailment system
Source title: Proceedings - International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computational Intelligence, AICI 2010
Affiliations: Computer Science and Engineering Department, Jadavpur University, Kolkata, India; Center for Computing Research, National Polytechnic Institute, Mexico City, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Pakray, P., Computer Science and Engineering Department, Jadavpur University, Kolkata, India; Bandyopadhyay, S., Computer Science and Engineering Department, Jadavpur University, Kolkata, India; Gelbukh, A., Center for Computing Research, National Polytechnic Institute, Mexico City, Mexico
Abstract: The development of a parser based textual entailment system that is based on comparing the dependency relations in both the text and the hypothesis has been reported. The textual entailment system uses the CCG Parser and the Stanford Parser. The Dependency Parser has been run on the 2-way Parser Training and Evaluation (PETE) (SemEval-2010 Evaluation Exercises on Semantic Evaluation Task 12 Parser Evaluation using Textual Entailment) trial set and the dependency relations obtained for a text and hypothesis pair has been compared. Some of the important comparisons are: subject-verb comparison, subject-subject comparison, object-verb comparison and cross subject-verb comparison. Each of the matches is assigned some weight learned from the PETE trial set corpus. A threshold has been set on the fraction of matching hypothesis relations for YES entailment decision based on the PETE trial set. The threshold score has been applied on the PETE test set using the same methods of dependency parsing followed by comparisons. Evaluation scores for Run 1 (CCG Parser output), obtained on the test set show 58.19% precision and 45.51% recall for YES decisions and 52.51% precision and 64.82% recall for NO decisions. Evaluation scores for Run 2 (Stanford Parser output), obtained on the test set show 55.68% precision and 59.61% recall for YES decisions and 52.23% precision and 48.61% recall for NO decisions. Evaluation scores for Run 3 (combining the output from CCG parser and Stanford Parser), obtained on the test set show 57.14% precision and 74.35% recall for YES decisions and 59.18% precision and 40% recall for NO decisions. © 2010 IEEE.
Author Keywords: CCG parser; PETE test set; PETE trial set; Stanford parser; Textual entailment
Index Keywords: CCG parser; PETE trial set; Stanford; Test sets; Textual entailment; Artificial intelligence; Testing; Text processing; Semantics

Authors: Sheikh S., Thakare V.M.
Title: An intelligent Arabic-Urdu Script Recognition system through mouse: A modified approach
Source title: Proceedings of the 2010 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, ICAI 2010
Affiliations: Dept. of Computer Science and Engg., Shri Ramdeobaba Kamala Nehru College of Engineering, Nagpur, India; Dept. of Computer Science, Sant Gadgebaba Amravati University, Maharashtra, India
Authors with affiliations: Sheikh, S., Dept. of Computer Science and Engg., Shri Ramdeobaba Kamala Nehru College of Engineering, Nagpur, India; Thakare, V.M., Dept. of Computer Science, Sant Gadgebaba Amravati University, Maharashtra, India
Abstract: In this paper an automatic mouse gesture recognition system is proposed that recognizes continuous Arabic-Urdu Alphabets scripts through mouse in real-time based on Artificial Neural Network (ANN). The proposed self supervised feed-forward neural network is trained using classic back-propagation algorithm which provides the system with great learning ability and hence, proven highly successful in its training. The performance analysis was based upon a set of data consisting of specimens collected from 5 persons; each specimen consisted of 30 basic Arabic-Urdu Alphabets. The system uses UNIPEN algorithm for mouse movements and incorporates its geometrical principles such as angles and transposition steps. The proposed approach shows an efficient way for extracting the boundary of the script and specifies the area of the recognition alphabets were it has been drawn in an image and then used ANN to recognize the alphabets. A comprehensive Arabic-Urdu Script Recognition (A USR) system (through mouse) is designed and tested successfully. The results based on speed and accuracy was analyzed.
Author Keywords: Artificial neural network; Feature-extraction; Mouse gesture recognition; Normalization

Authors: Bhati R., Maltare N., Mishra D.K., Jain S., Bhati D.
Title: Analysis of parallelism available in different neural networks for face recognition by data flow graph
Source title: International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Pattern Recognition 2010, AIPR 2010
Affiliations: Acropolis Institute of Technology and Research, Indore, India; Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay, Mumbai, India
Authors with affiliations: Bhati, R., Acropolis Institute of Technology and Research, Indore, India; Maltare, N., Acropolis Institute of Technology and Research, Indore, India; Mishra, D.K., Acropolis Institute of Technology and Research, Indore, India; Jain, S., Acropolis Institute of Technology and Research, Indore, India; Bhati, D., Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay, Mumbai, India
Abstract: In this paper we wish to explore limitations of parallelism exploited in training neural network for Face recognition. It is possible to improve performance of recognition significantly by using parallel architecture in these systems. Data flow computing paradigm offers highest degree of parallelism. Here we are analyzing parallelism opportunities available in training of neural networks in face recognition by data flow graph. We give a comparative analysis of performance of back propagation neural network and single layer feed forward neural network. In our approach we use variable learning rate and demonstrate its superiority over constant learning rate. We use different inner epochs for different input patterns according to their difficulty of recognition. We also show the effect of optimum numbers of inner epochs, best variable learning rate and numbers of hidden neurons on training time and recognition accuracy. We run our algorithm for face recognition application using Principal Component Analysis and neural network and demonstrate the effect of number of hidden neurons and size of feature vector on training time and recognition accuracy for given numbers of input patterns. We use ORL database for all the experiments.

Authors: Gopala Krishna M.T., Ravishankar M., Ramesh Babu D.R., Manjunath Aradhya V.N.
Title: Single moving object detection and tracking based on GMM
Source title: International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Pattern Recognition 2010, AIPR 2010
Affiliations: Dept. of ISE, DSCE, Bangalore, India; Dept. of CSE, DSCE, Bangalore, India
Authors with affiliations: Gopala Krishna, M.T., Dept. of ISE, DSCE, Bangalore, India; Ravishankar, M., Dept. of ISE, DSCE, Bangalore, India; Ramesh Babu, D.R., Dept. of CSE, DSCE, Bangalore, India; Manjunath Aradhya, V.N., Dept. of ISE, DSCE, Bangalore, India
Abstract: Automatic moving object detection and tracking is very important task in video surveillance applications. In the present work the well known background subtraction model and use of Gaussian Mixture Models (GMM) have been used to implement a robust automated single object tracking system. In this implementation, background subtraction on subtracting consecutive frame-by-frame basis for moving object detection is done. Once the object has been detected it is tracked by employing an efficient GMM technique. This ensures that any change in the pose of the object does not hinder the tracking procedure. The system is capable of handling entry and exit of an object. Such a tracking system is cost effective and can be used as an automated video conferencing system and also has applications like human tracking, vehicles monitoring, and event recognition for video surveillance. The proposed algorithm was tested on standard database on complex environments and the results were satisfactory.
Author Keywords: Gaussian mixture model; Object detection; Single object tracking; Surveillance; Video conferencing system

Authors: Nitin Singh A., Chaturvedi B.D.K., Singh C.R.K.
Title: A modified error function GNN for load frequency control of multi-area power system
Source title: Proceedings of the 2010 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, ICAI 2010
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Motilal Nehru National Institute of Technology, Allahabad (U.P.), India; Faculty of Engineering, Dayalbagh Educational Institute, Agra (U.P.), India
Authors with affiliations: Nitin Singh, A., Department of Electrical Engineering, Motilal Nehru National Institute of Technology, Allahabad (U.P.), India; Chaturvedi, B.D.K., Faculty of Engineering, Dayalbagh Educational Institute, Agra (U.P.), India; Singh, C.R.K., Department of Electrical Engineering, Motilal Nehru National Institute of Technology, Allahabad (U.P.), India
Abstract: Load frequency control has always been a promising field for researchers over the past one decade. When load perturbations takes place anywhere in any area of the system, it will affect the frequencies of other areas also. From time to time, different controllers have been developed to control the Load Frequency Control problem in power systems. In the recent years, the ANN is used to develop an intelligent load frequency controller. The conventional ANN has various drawbacks, such as large network complexity for complex real life problems, large training time and memory requirements etc. The present work deals with the development of a non linear controller using a generalized neural network. The drawbacks of existing neural network have been overcome in the generalized neuron structure which has been developed for the load frequency problem for single area as well as two area systems [2].

Authors: Dewadkar D.A., Haribhakta Y.V., Kulkarni P., Balvir P.D.
Title: Unsupervised word sense disambiguation in natural language understanding
Source title: Proceedings of the 2010 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, ICAI 2010
Affiliations: Department of Computer Engineering and Information Technology, College of Engineering, Pune, 411005, India; GM-Research, Capsilon India, Kalyani Nagar, Pune, 411 014, India
Authors with affiliations: Dewadkar, D.A., Department of Computer Engineering and Information Technology, College of Engineering, Pune, 411005, India; Haribhakta, Y.V., Department of Computer Engineering and Information Technology, College of Engineering, Pune, 411005, India; Kulkarni, P., GM-Research, Capsilon India, Kalyani Nagar, Pune, 411 014, India; Balvir, P.D., Department of Computer Engineering and Information Technology, College of Engineering, Pune, 411005, India
Abstract: This paper presents an unsupervised learning algorithm for word sense disambiguation (WSD) that, when trained on unannotated English text, rivals the performance of supervised techniques that require time-consuming hand annotations. The motivation for unsupervised algorithm is from Lesk [14] algorithm and by adapting the constraints - which words tend to have one sense per discourse and one sense per collocation. Paper discussion on supervised and unsupervised methods and its results using experimental setup is given and finds the unsupervised WSD is easy and with less manual interventions.
Author Keywords: Natural language processing; Unsupervised; Word sense disambiguation; WordNet
Index Keywords: Experimental setup; Hand-annotations; Manual intervention; NAtural language processing; Natural language understanding; Unsupervised; Unsupervised algorithms; Unsupervised method; Word Sense Disambiguation; Wordnet; Artificial intelligence; Computational linguistics; Learning algorithms; Natural language processing systems

Authors: Kopparapu S.K.
Title: A metric to evaluate robustness of a rule-based system
Source title: International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Pattern Recognition 2010, AIPR 2010
Affiliations: TCS Innovation Labs - Mumbai, Tata Consultancy Services Limited, Yantra Park, Thane(West), Maharastra, Mumbai 400601, India
Authors with affiliations: Kopparapu, S.K., TCS Innovation Labs - Mumbai, Tata Consultancy Services Limited, Yantra Park, Thane(West), Maharastra, Mumbai 400601, India
Abstract: AI based expert systems are often rule based and are used in several commercial applications. Rules are often arrived at based on experts knowledge. The process of deriving rules is often subjective, error prone and inexact. For a given set of true inputs, the performance of a rule based system is usually measured by the correctness of the rules, derived from the experts knowledge, to produce the desired output. In almost all the rule based systems the inputs to the expert system themselves could be erroneous having been generated from another process. In this paper we assume that the the rule base created from the expert knowledge is not erroneous. We formulate a metric to measure the robustness of a rule based system in terms of erroneous inputs to the expert system. We first formulate the metric for measuring the robustness of a rule based system and then show through an example its utility to measure the robustness.
Index Keywords: Commercial applications; Error prones; Expert knowledge; Rule base; Rule based; Show through; Artificial intelligence; Pattern recognition; Expert systems
Correspondence Address: Kopparapu, S.K.; TCS Innovation Labs - Mumbai, Tata Consultancy Services Limited, Yantra Park, Thane(West), Maharastra, Mumbai 400601, India; email: SunilKumar.Kopparapu@TCS.Com

Authors: Rajeswari K., Vivekanandan N., Vathiyanathan V.
Title: Automated detection and classification of smokes using electronic nose and artificial neural network
Source title: Proceedings of the 2010 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, ICAI 2010
Affiliations: Department of Computer Engineering, Pimpri Chinchwad College of Engineering, Pune, India; Department of Mechanical Engineering, Pimpri Chinchwad College of Engineering, Pune, India; Department of Information Technology, School of Computing, SASTRA Deemed University, Tanjore, Tamilnadu, India
Authors with affiliations: Rajeswari, K., Department of Computer Engineering, Pimpri Chinchwad College of Engineering, Pune, India; Vivekanandan, N., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Pimpri Chinchwad College of Engineering, Pune, India; Vathiyanathan, V., Department of Information Technology, School of Computing, SASTRA Deemed University, Tanjore, Tamilnadu, India
Abstract: An Electronic nose is a small electromechanical device that is capable of deciphering a wide variety of smells ranging anywhere from food to human breath to poisonous toxins. This electronic nose is used to classify the smell from three different types of burning materials namely joss stick, mosquito coil and instant benzoin. The counter propagation neural network is applied to train and classify those burning odour. The idea of this project is to make a smart smoke detector in order to detect the harmful burning material precisely before it is too late to stop the fire.
Author Keywords: Counter propagation neural network; Electronic nose; Smokes

Authors: Rao M.R.N., Sujatha K., Kanth P.L., Sridhar G.R.
Title: Artificial neural network for speech-to-text conversion
Source title: Proceedings of the 2010 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, ICAI 2010
Affiliations: CSE Dept., VIIT, Visakhapatnam, AP, India; Lendi Institute of Engineering and Technology, Visakhapatnam, AP, India; Endocrine and Diabetes Center, 15-12-16, Krishna nagar, Visakhapatnam, AP, India
Authors with affiliations: Rao, M.R.N., CSE Dept., VIIT, Visakhapatnam, AP, India; Sujatha, K., Lendi Institute of Engineering and Technology, Visakhapatnam, AP, India; Kanth, P.L., CSE Dept., VIIT, Visakhapatnam, AP, India; Sridhar, G.R., Endocrine and Diabetes Center, 15-12-16, Krishna nagar, Visakhapatnam, AP, India
Abstract: Recognition of human speech has long been a research topic among signal processing and neural networks. Most of current policies for this subject are based on extraction of precise features of voice signal and trying to make most out of them by heavy computations. But this focus has resulted in too much sensitivity to noise and as a result, the necessity of complex noise detection and removal algorithms, which composes a trade-off between fast or noise robust recognition. This paper presents novel approach to Automatic Speech Recognition using Vector Quantization(VQ) algorithm and decisionmaking that ignores noise instead of its detection and removal which results in Artificial Neural Network. The speech spectrogram is converted into a Mel Frequency Cepstral Coefficients(MFCC) and this description is used instead of precise acoustic features. During the training period, VQ finds appropriate definitions, and when these definitions are ready, a simple novel operator makes the recognition.
Author Keywords: Artificial neural network; Automatic speech recognition; Mel frequency cepstral coefficients; Speech recognition; Vector quantization algorithm
Index Keywords: Acoustic features; Automatic speech recognition; Complex noise; Human speech; Mel-frequency cepstral coefficients; Research topics; Robust recognition; Speech spectrogram; Speech-to-text conversion; Vector quantization algorithms; Voice signals; Algorithms; Neural networks; Personnel training; Signal processing; Vector quantization; Speech recognition

Authors: Kakarwal S.N., Deshmukh R.R.
Title: Wavelet transform and thresholding based face recognition
Source title: International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Pattern Recognition 2010, AIPR 2010
Affiliations: P.E.S. College of Engineering, Dr. B.A.M. University, India
Authors with affiliations: Kakarwal, S.N., P.E.S. College of Engineering, Dr. B.A.M. University, India; Deshmukh, R.R., P.E.S. College of Engineering, Dr. B.A.M. University, India
Abstract: In this paper, we propose a Wavelet Transform based analysis method for Face Recognition. This algorithm has been used to extract the features of the FERET face database. Results indicate that the proposed methodology is able to achieve excellent performance with only a very small set of features being used, and its error rate is calculated using FAR and FRR. The choice of the Wavelet transform in this setting is motivated by its insensitivity to large variation in light direction, face pose, and facial expression. In the experiments we used Correlation and Threshold values to assure high consistency of the produced classification outcomes. The encouraging experimental results demonstrated that the proposed approach by using frontal and side-view images is a feasible and effective solution to recognizing faces, which can lead to a better and practical use of existing forensic databases in computerized human face-recognition applications.
Index Keywords: A-wavelet transform; Analysis method; Effective solution; Facial Expressions; FERET face database; Light direction; Practical use; Thresholding; Artificial intelligence; Wavelet transforms; Face recognition

Authors: Vengatakrishnaprabhu M., Vidhya Seethala A.
Title: Partial discharge initiated treeing morphology and pattern recoginition in polymer electrical insulation using neural network
Source title: Proceedings of the 2010 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, ICAI 2010
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, SASTRA University, Thanjavur-613401, Tamil Nadu, India
Authors with affiliations: Vengatakrishnaprabhu, M., Department of Electrical Engineering, SASTRA University, Thanjavur-613401, Tamil Nadu, India; Vidhya Seethala, A., Department of Electrical Engineering, SASTRA University, Thanjavur-613401, Tamil Nadu, India
Abstract: Healthiness of the insulation system of any power apparatus plays vital criteria for its effective performance in power system. Minor flaws in insulation system such as blow-holes, cavities, imperfection on the surface etc are inevitable even during manufacturing stage leading to discharges called Partial Discharge (PD) eventually leading to degradation of dielectric material usually caused by erosion mechanism (tracking and treeing). PD initiated treeing of insulation system has been receiving wide attention by researchers very recently since this mechanism is categorized as a severe case of insulation degradation by electrical utilities. This phenomenon may lead to mal operation of power apparatus. Further exhaustive literature survey carried out in this field has clearly delineated on the close relationship between physics related to the degradation mechanism and nature of flaw (void, cavity etc). Further, since the time between PD initiated treeing and breakdown is much shorter than the time to tree initiation, recognition of such complex and stochastic pattern of PD becomes challenging task even for experts. Standard laboratory models simulating various types of PD initiated treeing is fabricated. An accelerated ageing test method is carried out in testing the laboratory models. PD initiated discharge patterns and treeing patterns are acquired from the direct testing circuits as proposed by IEC 60270:2000. The morphology of the treeing patterns is visually correlated to comprehend the nature of discharge. In addition PD signatures acquired from the PD measurement and acquisition system is trained and tested with neural networks to discriminate tree and PD initiated discharge fingerprints.
Author Keywords: Electrical treeing; Feature extraction; Partial discharge; Pattern recognition; Phase-resolved analysis

Authors: Das S., Bhowmik P., Haider A., Chakraborty A., Konar A., Nagar A.K.
Title: Emotion recognition from facial expression and electroencephalographic signals using vector quantization and support vector machines
Source title: Proceedings of the 2010 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, ICAI 2010
Affiliations: Department of Electronics and Tele-Communication Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata, West Bengal, India; Department of Computer Science and Engineering, St. Thomas' College of Engineering and Technology, Kolkata, West Bengal, India; Department of Computer Science, Computer Science, Liverpool Hope University, Liverpool, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Das, S., Department of Electronics and Tele-Communication Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata, West Bengal, India; Bhowmik, P., Department of Electronics and Tele-Communication Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata, West Bengal, India; Haider, A., Department of Electronics and Tele-Communication Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata, West Bengal, India; Chakraborty, A., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, St. Thomas' College of Engineering and Technology, Kolkata, West Bengal, India; Konar, A., Department of Electronics and Tele-Communication Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata, West Bengal, India; Nagar, A.K., Department of Computer Science, Computer Science, Liverpool Hope University, Liverpool, United Kingdom
Abstract: The paper employs Support Vector Machine and Learning Vector Quantization algorithms to recognize stimulated emotions of subjects from their facial expressions and electroencephalographic signals. The peak and average power at different frequency bands of the EEG signals are taken along with the Kalman filter and wavelet coefficients for the same signals. The fuzzified membership values of mouth opening, eye-opening and eyebrow constrictions are also obtained as facial features. Experiments are conducted with both unimodal and bimodal features to study the relative merits of the above two techniques in emotion classification. Gaussian noise with varying mean and standard deviation is injected on the measured features to study the robustness of the two algorithms. Experimental results confirm that Support Vector Machine is a better classifier than the Learning Vector Quantization algorithm with respect to accuracy in classification of emotions. Experiments also reveal that when facial expression and electroencephalographic signals are used as unimodal inputs to the emotion classifiers, EEG outperforms facial expression in classification accuracy.
Author Keywords: EEG; Emotion recognition; Facial expression; Learning vector quantization; Support vector machine

Authors: Sinha N., Lai L.L., Saikia L.C., Malakar T.
Title: Hybrid bacteria foraging-DE based algorithm for economic load dispatch with non-convex loads
Source title: 2010 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics, ICMLC 2010
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, NIT, Silchar, Assam, 788010, India; Energy Systems Group, City University, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Sinha, N., Department of Electrical Engineering, NIT, Silchar, Assam, 788010, India; Lai, L.L., Energy Systems Group, City University, London, United Kingdom; Saikia, L.C., Department of Electrical Engineering, NIT, Silchar, Assam, 788010, India; Malakar, T., Department of Electrical Engineering, NIT, Silchar, Assam, 788010, India
Abstract: An algorithm based on hybridization of Bacteria Foraging (BF) and Differential Evolution (DE) was developed to solve the problem of finding the optimum load allocation amongst the committed units in a power system with non-convex loads. The performance of the proposed algorithm is evaluated on a test case of 15 units. The performance of the proposed algorithm is compared with BF method. Also, the effect of swarming in performance of the hybrid algorithm is investigated. Results demonstrate that the performance of the hybrid algorithm is much better than BF in terms of convergence rate and solution quality. The swarming effect equips the hybrid algorithm with better search capability as demonstrated on the test case. © 2010 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Bacterial Foraging; Differential Evolution; Economic load dispatch; Floating point genetic algorithm

Authors: Gupta R., Sarawagi S., Diwan A.A.
Title: Collective inference for extraction MRFs coupled with symmetric clique potentials
Source title: Journal of Machine Learning Research
Affiliations: Computer Science and Engineering, IIT Bombay, Powai Mumbai, 400076, India
Authors with affiliations: Gupta, R., Computer Science and Engineering, IIT Bombay, Powai Mumbai, 400076, India; Sarawagi, S., Computer Science and Engineering, IIT Bombay, Powai Mumbai, 400076, India; Diwan, A.A., Computer Science and Engineering, IIT Bombay, Powai Mumbai, 400076, India
Abstract: Many structured information extraction tasks employ collective graphical models that capture interinstance associativity by coupling them with various clique potentials. We propose tractable families of such potentials that are invariant under permutations of their arguments, and call them symmetric clique potentials. We present three families of symmetric potentials-MAX, SUM, and MAJORITY. We propose cluster message passing for collective inference with symmetric clique potentials, and present message computation algorithms tailored to such potentials. Our first message computation algorithm, called a-pass, is sub-quadratic in the clique size, outputs exact messages for MAX, and computes 13/15 -approximate messages for Potts, a popular member of the SUM family. Empirically, it is upto two orders of magnitude faster than existing algorithms based on graph-cuts or belief propagation. Our second algorithm, based on Lagrangian relaxation, operates on MAJORITY potentials and provides close to exact solutions while being two orders of magnitude faster. We show that the cluster message passing framework is more principled, accurate and converges faster than competing approaches. We extend our collective inference framework to exploit associativity of more general intradomain properties of instance labelings, which opens up interesting applications in domain adaptation. Our approach leads to significant error reduction on unseen domains without incurring any overhead of model retraining. © 2010 Evangelos Theodorou, Jonas Buchli and Stefan Schaal.
Author Keywords: Clique potentials; Cluster graphs; Collective inference; Graphical models; Message passing
Index Keywords: Associativity; Belief propagation; Clique potential; Clique size; Cluster graphs; Collective inference; Computation algorithm; Domain adaptation; Error reduction; Exact solution; GraphicaL model; Graphical models; Intra-domain; Labelings; LaGrangian relaxation; Orders of magnitude; Structured information; Graphic methods; Inference engines; Message passing; Structural frames; Clustering algorithms

Authors: Shastri L., Parvathy A.G., Kumar A., Wesley J., Balakrishnan R.
Title: Sentiment extraction: Integrating statistical parsing, semantic analysis, and common sense reasoning
Source title: Proceedings of the National Conference on Artificial Intelligence
Affiliations: Center for Knowledge Driven Information Systems, Software Engineering and Technology Labs., Infosys Technologies Ltd., Bangalore, India
Authors with affiliations: Shastri, L., Center for Knowledge Driven Information Systems, Software Engineering and Technology Labs., Infosys Technologies Ltd., Bangalore, India; Parvathy, A.G., Center for Knowledge Driven Information Systems, Software Engineering and Technology Labs., Infosys Technologies Ltd., Bangalore, India; Kumar, A., Center for Knowledge Driven Information Systems, Software Engineering and Technology Labs., Infosys Technologies Ltd., Bangalore, India; Wesley, J., Center for Knowledge Driven Information Systems, Software Engineering and Technology Labs., Infosys Technologies Ltd., Bangalore, India; Balakrishnan, R., Center for Knowledge Driven Information Systems, Software Engineering and Technology Labs., Infosys Technologies Ltd., Bangalore, India
Abstract: Much of the ongoing explosion of digital content is in the form of text. This content is a virtual gold-mine of information that can inform a range of social, governmental, and business decisions. For example, using content available on blogs and social networking sites businesses can find out what its customers are saying about their products and services. In the digital age where customer is king, the business value of ascertaining consumer sentiment cannot be overstated. People express sentiments in myriad ways. At times, they use simple, direct assertions, but most often they use sentences involving comparisons, conjunctions expressing multiple and possibly opposing sentiments about multiple features and entities, and pronominal references whose resolution requires discourse level context. Frequently people use abbreviations, slang, SMSese, idioms and metaphors. Understanding the latter also requires common sense reasoning. In this paper, we present iSEE, a fully implemented sentiment extraction engine, which makes use of statistical methods, classical NLU techniques, common sense reasoning, and probabilistic inference to extract entity and feature specific sentiment from complex sentences and dialog. Most of the components of iSEE are domain independent and the system can be generalized to new domains by simply adding domain relevant lexicons. Authors: Paek T., Gamon M., Counts S., Chickering D.M., Dhesi A.
Title: Predicting the importance of newsfeed posts and social network friends
Source title: Proceedings of the National Conference on Artificial Intelligence
Affiliations: Microsoft Research, One Microsoft Way, Redmond, WA 98052, United States; Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur, Kanpur 208016 Uttar Pradesh, India
Authors with affiliations: Paek, T., Microsoft Research, One Microsoft Way, Redmond, WA 98052, United States; Gamon, M., Microsoft Research, One Microsoft Way, Redmond, WA 98052, United States; Counts, S., Microsoft Research, One Microsoft Way, Redmond, WA 98052, United States; Chickering, D.M., Microsoft Research, One Microsoft Way, Redmond, WA 98052, United States; Dhesi, A., Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur, Kanpur 208016 Uttar Pradesh, India
Abstract: As users of social networking websites expand their network of friends, they are often flooded with newsfeed posts and status updates, most of which they consider to be ©unimportant© and not newsworthy. In order to better understand how people judge the importance of their newsfeed, we conducted a study in which Facebook users were asked to rate the importance of their newsfeed posts as well as their friends. We learned classifiers of newsfeed and friend importance to identify predictive sets of features related to social media properties, the message text, and shared background information. For classifying friend importance, the best performing model achieved 85% accuracy and 25% error reduction. By leveraging this model for classifying newsfeed posts, the best newsfeed classifier achieved 64% accuracy and 27% error reduction. Authors: Fomin F.V., Lokshtanov D., Raman V., Saurabh S.
Title: Fast local search algorithm for Weighted Feedback Arc Set in Tournaments
Source title: Proceedings of the National Conference on Artificial Intelligence
Affiliations: Department of Informatics, University of Bergen, Norway; Institute of Mathematical Sciences, Chennai, India
Authors with affiliations: Fomin, F.V., Department of Informatics, University of Bergen, Norway; Lokshtanov, D., Department of Informatics, University of Bergen, Norway; Raman, V., Institute of Mathematical Sciences, Chennai, India; Saurabh, S., Institute of Mathematical Sciences, Chennai, India
Abstract: We present a fast local search algorithm that finds an improved solution (if there is any) in the fc-exchange neighborhood of the given solution to an instance of Weighted Feedback Arc Set in Tournaments. More precisely, given an arc weighted tournament T on n vertices and a feedback arc set F (a set of arcs whose deletion from T turns it into a directed acyclic graph), our algorithm decides in time 0(2°(k) n log n) if there is a feedback arc set of smaller weight and that differs from F in at most k arcs. To our knowledge this is the first algorithm searching the fc-exchange neighborhood of an NP-complete problem that runs in (parameterized) subexponential time. Using this local search algorithm for Weighted Feedback Arc Set in Tournaments, we obtain subexponential time algorithms for a local search variant of Kemeny Ranking - a problem in social choice theory and of One-Sided Cross Minimization - a problem in graph drawing. Authors: Khapra M.M., Udupa R., Kumaran A., Bhattacharyya P.
Title: PR + RQ ≈ PQ: Transliteration mining using bridge language
Source title: Proceedings of the National Conference on Artificial Intelligence
Affiliations: Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Powai, Mumbai 400076, India; Microsof T Research India, Bangalore, India
Authors with affiliations: Khapra, M.M., Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Powai, Mumbai 400076, India; Udupa, R., Microsof T Research India, Bangalore, India; Kumaran, A., Microsof T Research India, Bangalore, India; Bhattacharyya, P., Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Powai, Mumbai 400076, India
Abstract: We address the problem of mining name transliterations from comparable corpora in languages P and Q in the following resource-poor scenario: • Parallel names in PQ are not available for training. • Parallel names in PR and RQ are available for training. We propose a novel solution for the problem by computing a common geometric feature space for P, Q and R where name transliterations are mapped to similar vectors. We employ Canonical Correlation Analysis (CCA) to compute the com mon geometric feature space using only parallel names in PR and RQ and without requiring parallel names in PQ. We test our algorithm on data sets in several languages and show that it gives results comparable to the state-of - the-art transliter ation mining algorithms that use parallel names in PQ for training. Authors: Zou J., Gujar S., Parkes D.
Title: Tolerable manipulability in dynamic assignment without money
Source title: Proceedings of the National Conference on Artificial Intelligence
Affiliations: School of Engineering and Applied Sciences, Harvard University, United States; Dept of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, India
Authors with affiliations: Zou, J., School of Engineering and Applied Sciences, Harvard University, United States; Gujar, S., Dept of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, India; Parkes, D., School of Engineering and Applied Sciences, Harvard University, United States
Abstract: We study a problem of dynamic allocation without money. Agents have arrivals and departures and strict preferences over items. Strategyproof ness requires the use of an arrival-priority serial-dictatorship (APSD) mechanism, which is ex post Pareto efficient but has poor ex ante efficiency as measured through average rank efficiency. We introduce the scoring-rule (SR) mechanism, which biases in favor of allocating items that an agent values above the population consensus. The SR mechanism is not strategyproof but has tolerable manipulability in the sense that: (i) if every agent optimally manipulates, it reduces to APSD, and (ii) it significantly outperforms APSD for rank efficiency when only a fraction of agents are strategic. The performance of SR is also robust to mistakes by agents that manipulate on the basis of inaccurate information about the popularity of items. Copyright © 2010, Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence (www.aaai.org). All rights reserved.

Authors: Choudhary A., Sharma G., Chaudhury S., Banerjee S.
Title: Distributed calibration of pan-tilt camera network using multi-layered belief propagation
Source title: 2010 IEEE Computer Society Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition - Workshops, CVPRW 2010
Affiliations: Indian Institute of Technology, Delhi, India; University of Caen, France
Authors with affiliations: Choudhary, A., Indian Institute of Technology, Delhi, India; Sharma, G., University of Caen, France; Chaudhury, S., Indian Institute of Technology, Delhi, India; Banerjee, S., Indian Institute of Technology, Delhi, India
Abstract: In this paper, we present a technique for distributed selfcalibration of pan-tilt camera network using multi-layered belief propagation. Our goal is to obtain globally consistent estimates of the camera parameters for each camera with respect to a global world coordinate system. The network configuration changes with time as the cameras can pan and tilt. We also give a distributed algorithm for automatically finding which cameras have overlapping views at a certain point in time. We argue that using belief propagation it is sufficient to have correspondences between three cameras at a time for calibrating a larger set of (static) cameras with overlapping views. Our method gives an accurate and globally consistent estimate of the camera parameters of each camera in the network. © 2010 IEEE.

Abstract: In images and videos of a 3D scene, blur due to camera shake can be a source of depth information. Our objective is to find the shape of the scene from its motion-blurred observations without having to restore the original image. In this paper, we pose depth recovery as a recursive state estimation problem. We show that the relationship between the observation and the scale factor of the motion-blur kernel associated with the depth at a point is nonlinear and propose the use of the unscented Kalman filter for state estimation. The performance of the proposed method is evaluated on many examples. © 2010 IEEE.
Index Keywords: 3D scenes; Camera shake; Depth information; Depth recovery; Motion blur; Original images; Recursive state estimation; Scale Factor; Unscented Kalman Filter; Unscented transformations; Computer vision; State estimation; Technical presentations; Three dimensional

Authors: Basak J., Kate K., Tyagi V., Ratha N.
Title: QPLC: A novel multimodal biometric score fusion method
Source title: 2010 IEEE Computer Society Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition - Workshops, CVPRW 2010
Affiliations: IBM Research - India, India; IBM TJ Watson Research Centre, United States
Authors with affiliations: Basak, J., IBM Research - India, India; Kate, K., IBM Research - India, India; Tyagi, V., IBM Research - India, India; Ratha, N., IBM TJ Watson Research Centre, United States
Abstract: In biometrics authentication systems, it has been shown that fusion of more than one modality (e.g., face and finger) and fusion of more than one classifier (two different algorithms) can improve the system performance. Often a score level fusion is adopted as this approach doesn't require the vendors to reveal much about their algorithms and features. Many score level transformations have been proposed in the literature to normalize the scores which enable fusion of more than one classifier. In this paper, we propose a novel score level transformation technique that helps in fusion of multiple classifiers. The method is based on two components: quantile transform of the genuine and impostor score distributions and a power transform which further changes the score distribution to help linear classification. After the scores are normalized using the novel quantile power transform, several linear classifiers are proposed to fuse the scores of multiple classifiers. Using the NIST BSSR-1 dataset, we have shown that the results obtained by the proposed method far exceed the results published so far in the literature. © 2010 IEEE.

Authors: Maei H.R., Szepesvari C., Bhatnagar S., Sutton R.S.
Title: Toward off-policy learning control with function approximation
Source title: ICML 2010 - Proceedings, 27th International Conference on Machine Learning
Affiliations: Department of Computing Science, University of Alberta, Edmonton, T6G 2E8, Canada; Department of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore-560012, India
Authors with affiliations: Maei, H.R., Department of Computing Science, University of Alberta, Edmonton, T6G 2E8, Canada; Szepesvari, C., Department of Computing Science, University of Alberta, Edmonton, T6G 2E8, Canada; Bhatnagar, S., Department of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore-560012, India; Sutton, R.S., Department of Computing Science, University of Alberta, Edmonton, T6G 2E8, Canada
Abstract: We present the first temporal-difference learning algorithm for off-policy control with unrestricted linear function approximation whose per-time-step complexity is linear in the number of features. Our algorithm, Greedy- GQ, is an extension of recent work on gradient temporal-difference learning, which has hitherto been restricted to a prediction (policy evaluation) setting, to a control setting in which the target policy is greedy with respect to a linear approximation to the optimal action-value function. A limitation of our control setting is that we require the behavior policy to be stationary. We call this setting latent learning because the optimal policy, though learned, is not manifest in behavior. Popular off-policy algorithms such as Q-learning are known to be unstable in this setting when used with linear function ap-proximation. Copyright 2010 by the author(s)/owner(s).

Authors: Bhadra S., Bhattacharya S., Bhattacharyya C., Ben-Tal A.
Title: Robust formulations for handling uncertainty in kernel matrices
Source title: ICML 2010 - Proceedings, 27th International Conference on Machine Learning
Affiliations: Department of CSA, Indian Institute of Science, India; Yahoo Labs, Bangalore, India; Faculty of Industrial Engg. and Management, Technion, Haifa, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Bhadra, S., Department of CSA, Indian Institute of Science, India; Bhattacharya, S., Yahoo Labs, Bangalore, India; Bhattacharyya, C., Department of CSA, Indian Institute of Science, India; Ben-Tal, A., Faculty of Industrial Engg. and Management, Technion, Haifa, Israel
Abstract: We study the problem of uncertainty in the entries of the Kernel matrix, arising in SVM formulation. Using Chance Constraint Programming and a novel large deviation inequality we derive a formulation which is robust to such noise. The resulting formulation applies when the noise is Gaussian, or has finite support. The formulation in general is non-convex, but in several cases of interest it reduces to a convex program. The problem of uncertainty in kernel matrix is motivated from the real world problem of classifying proteins when the structures are provided with some uncertainty. The formulation derived here naturally incorporates such uncertainty in a principled manner leading to significant improvements over the state of the art. Copyright 2010 by the author(s)/owner(s).

Authors: Hariharan B., Zelnik-Manor L., Vishwanathan S.V.N., Varma M.
Title: Large scale max-margin multi-label classification with priors
Source title: ICML 2010 - Proceedings, 27th International Conference on Machine Learning
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Delhi, 110 016, India; Department of Electrical Engineering, Technion, Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, 32000, Israel; Department of Statistics, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907-2066, United States; Microsoft Research India, Bangalore, 560 080, India
Authors with affiliations: Hariharan, B., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Delhi, 110 016, India; Zelnik-Manor, L., Department of Electrical Engineering, Technion, Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, 32000, Israel; Vishwanathan, S.V.N., Department of Statistics, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907-2066, United States; Varma, M., Microsoft Research India, Bangalore, 560 080, India
Abstract: We propose a max-margin formulation for the multi-label classification problem where the goal is to tag a data point with a set of pre-specified labels. Given a set of L labels, a data point can be tagged with any of the 2L possible subsets. The main challenge therefore lies in optimising over this exponentially large label space subject to label correlations. Existing solutions take either of two approaches. The first assumes, a priori, that there are no label correlations and independently trains a classifier for each label (as is done in the 1-vs-All heuristic). This reduces the problem complexity from exponential to linear and such methods can scale to large problems. The second approach explicitly models correlations by pairwise label interactions. However, the complexity remains exponential unless one assumes that label correlations are sparse. Furthermore, the learnt correlations reflect the training set biases. We take a middle approach that assumes labels are correlated but does not incorporate pairwise label terms in the prediction function. We show that the complexity can still be reduced from exponential to linear while modelling dense pairwise label correlations. By incorporating correlation priors we can overcome training set biases and improve prediction accuracy. We provide a principled interpretation of the 1-vs-All method and show that it arises as a special case of our formulation. We also develop efficient optimisation algorithms that can be orders of magnitude faster than the state-of-the-art. Copyright 2010 by the author(s)/owner(s).
Index Keywords: Data points; Label space; Multi-label classifications; Optimisations; Orders of magnitude; Prediction accuracy; Prediction function; Problem complexity; Training sets; Learning systems; Locomotives; Railroad cars; Optimization

Authors: Gupta R., Patil H., Mittal A.
Title: Robust order-based methods for feature description
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Computer Society Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Engg., Indian Institute of Technology Madras, Chennai - 600036, India
Authors with affiliations: Gupta, R., Department of Computer Science and Engg., Indian Institute of Technology Madras, Chennai - 600036, India; Patil, H., Department of Computer Science and Engg., Indian Institute of Technology Madras, Chennai - 600036, India; Mittal, A., Department of Computer Science and Engg., Indian Institute of Technology Madras, Chennai - 600036, India
Abstract: Feature-based methods have found increasing use in many applications such as object recognition, 3D reconstruction and mosaicing. In this paper, we focus on the problem of matching such features. While a histogram-of-gradients type methods such as SIFT, GLOH and Shape Context are currently popular, several papers have suggested using orders of pixels rather than raw intensities and shown improved results for some applications. The papers suggest two different techniques for doing so: (1) A Histogram of Relative Orders in the Patch and (2) A Histogram of LBP codes. While these methods have shown good performance, they neglect the fact that the orders can be quite noisy in the presence of Gaussian noise. In this paper, we propose changes to these approaches to make them robust to Gaussian noise. We also show how the descriptors can be matched using recently developed more advanced techniques to obtain better matching performance. Finally, we show that the two methods have complimentary strengths and that by combining the two descriptors, one obtains much better results than either of them considered separately. The results are shown on the standard 2D Oxford and the 3D Caltech datasets. ©2010 IEEE.
Index Keywords: 3D reconstruction; Caltech; Data sets; Descriptors; Feature description; Feature-based method; Gaussian noise; Matching performance; Mosaicing; Relative order; Shape contexts; Type methods; Computer vision; Graphic methods; Object recognition; Three dimensional; Computational methods

Authors: Mukhopadhyay A., Maulik U., Bandyopadhyay S.
Title: Discovering coherent biclusters from microarray gene expression data
Source title: Proceedings of the 10th IASTED International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Applications, AIA 2010
Affiliations: Department of Theoretical Bioinformatics, German Cancer Research Center (DKFZ), Heidelberg-69120, Germany; Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata-700032, India; Machine Intelligence Unit, Indian Statistical Institute, Kolkata-700108, India
Authors with affiliations: Mukhopadhyay, A., Department of Theoretical Bioinformatics, German Cancer Research Center (DKFZ), Heidelberg-69120, Germany; Maulik, U., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata-700032, India; Bandyopadhyay, S., Machine Intelligence Unit, Indian Statistical Institute, Kolkata-700108, India
Abstract: Biclustering algorithms aim to identify a subset of genes that are co-regulated in a subset of experimental conditions in microarray gene expression data. Mean squared residue is a popular measure that is optimized by several biclustering algorithms to discover biclusters from the gene expression data. In a recent work, it has been shown that mean squared residue is only good in capturing constant and shifting biclusters. However scaling and coherent biclusters cannot be detected using this metric. In this article a transformationmethod has been proposed that transforms any type of biclusters into constant or shifting biclusters which can thereafter be easily detected using mean squared residue based biclustering algorithms. The proposed technique is utilized to modify some recent biclustering algorithms that minimize the mean squared residue. The effectiveness of the proposed technique has been proved theoretically and validated by experimentation.
Author Keywords: Biclustering; Mean squared residue; Microarray gene expression data; Scaling bicluster

Authors: Ray S., Mahanti A.
Title: Designing accurate trust-aware recommender systems for cold start users
Source title: Proceedings of the 10th IASTED International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Applications, AIA 2010
Affiliations: Indian Institute of Management Calcutta, Kolkata, India
Authors with affiliations: Ray, S., Indian Institute of Management Calcutta, Kolkata, India; Mahanti, A., Indian Institute of Management Calcutta, Kolkata, India
Abstract: For cold start users, trust-aware recommender systems have been shown to be more useful in providing better quality recommendations than traditional systems. By exploiting the concept of trust propagation over the trust network, trust-aware systems are able to make large number of accurate recommendations by utilizing the few trust statements given by the new user. In this paper, we propose intelligent strategies based on efficient heuristics, and examine existing strategies on the basis of which prospective trusted users are selected to be presented before a cold start user. Through experimental evaluation we show that selecting prospective trusted users based on our proposed efficient heuristics i.e. hybrid parameter preference score gives the most accurate recommendations. We also propose a clustering approach to select n users for the final list from the set of prospective users selected by a strategy. Furthermore, our paper also describes a new metric entropy0 to reduce the effort required by a cold start user to evaluate prospective trusted users.

Authors: Anil R., Lau A., Yin C., Küçük O.
Title: PAM face authentication: An opensource security module for linux systems
Source title: Proceedings of the 10th IASTED International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Applications, AIA 2010
Affiliations: BITS Pilani Goa Campus, Hostel AH7, BITS Pilani Goa, Zuarinagar Goa 403726, India; Novell Inc., Beijing, RM3606, Beijing Fortune Plaza, Beijing 100020, China; Pardus Project, TÜBITAK - UEKAE, PK.74 41470, Gebze / Kocaeli, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Anil, R., BITS Pilani Goa Campus, Hostel AH7, BITS Pilani Goa, Zuarinagar Goa 403726, India; Lau, A., Novell Inc., Beijing, RM3606, Beijing Fortune Plaza, Beijing 100020, China; Yin, C., Novell Inc., Beijing, RM3606, Beijing Fortune Plaza, Beijing 100020, China; Küçük, O., Pardus Project, TÜBITAK - UEKAE, PK.74 41470, Gebze / Kocaeli, Turkey
Abstract: PAM (Pluggable Authentication Module) Face Authentication (PFA) is an opensource security module for Linux systems. The PAM framework allows multiple authentication schemes for a single service. PFA integrates well with the Linux environment and can be used for access control during login. PFA can be used as an alternative to or an addition over the traditional password based scheme. The system works fairly well in uncontrolled settings. The PFA system provides users with a training interface to enroll their face. The system uses the cascade between Local Binary Pattern (LBP) with weighted Chisquare distance and Minimum Average Correlation Energy Filter (MACE) with Peak to Sidelobe Ratio (PSR) for authentication. PFA does not require any specialized webcam. PFA can be downloaded from http://pam-face-authentication.googlecode.com/.

Title: Using data mining to identify a consistent set of experts for times series sales forecasting

Abstract: Combining forecasts from different models has shown to perform better than single forecasts in most times series. Recent research in Rank based combining methods have yielded interesting results. The number of methods used by these rank based techniques number almost a million. In the final analysis only few 'K' methods perform well for a given series. This paper presents a novel procedure based on the classical association rule mining algorithm to find the best 'K' methods for a given time series.

Authors: Shrivastava P., Satpathy S.K., Nagwanshi K.K.
Title: Development of an expert system as spiritual Guru
Source title: ICMLC 2010 - The 2nd International Conference on Machine Learning and Computing
Affiliations: Computer Science and Engineering, Rungta College of Engineering and Technology, Bhilai, Chhatisgarh, India
Authors with affiliations: Shrivastava, P., Computer Science and Engineering, Rungta College of Engineering and Technology, Bhilai, Chhatisgarh, India; Satpathy, S.K., Computer Science and Engineering, Rungta College of Engineering and Technology, Bhilai, Chhatisgarh, India; Nagwanshi, K.K., Computer Science and Engineering, Rungta College of Engineering and Technology, Bhilai, Chhatisgarh, India
Abstract: Expert systems have been used in various fields of life like diagnosis and troubleshooting of devices and systems of all kinds, configuration of manufactured objects from subassemblies, planning and scheduling, financial decision making, knowledge publishing, process monitoring and control, design and manufacturing, agriculture, medicine, etc. Similarly these systems are also being used in field of training and education, and consultation because of its structured way of deriving knowledge and its explanation facility. This paper presents development of a web-based expert system as a Spiritual Guru or Guru of Life Ethics. This expert system is to cater those people who ask questions about the life and the world. It answers the questions as a spiritual guru, as a philosopher as well as a scientist. Since the difference between in being a real scientist and being a real spiritual person is only that the scientist doesn't believe in the existence of soul and the spiritual person knows the soul or in the way of knowing it. The knowledge base of the proposed expert system will contain questions and their answers with reasoning. Inference engine will be a mechanism that will fetch keywords from working memory and match it with the questions stored in the knowledge base to answer the questions asked by the user. This paper presents how an expert system can be developed as Spiritual Guru to serve mankind and general work-flow of Spiritual Guru. © 2010 IEEE.

Authors: Sachan M., Ichise R.
Title: Using abstract information and community alignment information for link prediction
Source title: ICMLC 2010 - The 2nd International Conference on Machine Learning and Computing
Affiliations: Computer Science and Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur, Kanpur, India; Principles of Informatics Research Division, National Institute of Informatics, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sachan, M., Computer Science and Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur, Kanpur, India; Ichise, R., Principles of Informatics Research Division, National Institute of Informatics, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Although there have been many recent studies of link prediction in co-authorship networks, few have tried to utilize the Semantic information hidden in abstracts of the research documents. We propose to build a link predictor in a co-authorship network where nodes represent researchers and links represent co-authorship. In this method, we use the structure of the constructed graph, and propose to add a semantic approach using abstract information, research titles and the event information to improve the accuracy of the predictor. Secondly, we make use of the fact that researchers tend to work in close knit communities. The knowledge of a pair of researchers lying in the same dense community can be used to improve the accuracy of our predictor further. Finally, we test out hypothesis on the DBLP database in a reasonable time by under-sampling and balancing the dataset using decision trees and the SMOTE technique. © 2010 IEEE.

Authors: Patil B.M., Joshi R.C., Toshniwal D.
Title: Association rule for classification of type -2 diabetic patients
Source title: ICMLC 2010 - The 2nd International Conference on Machine Learning and Computing
Affiliations: Department of Electronics and Computer Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Roorkee, Roorkee, India
Authors with affiliations: Patil, B.M., Department of Electronics and Computer Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Roorkee, Roorkee, India; Joshi, R.C., Department of Electronics and Computer Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Roorkee, Roorkee, India; Toshniwal, D., Department of Electronics and Computer Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Roorkee, Roorkee, India
Abstract: The discovery of knowledge from medical databases is important in order to make effective medical diagnosis. The aim of data mining is extract the information from database and generate clear and understandable description of patterns. In this study we have introduced a new approach to generate association rules on numeric data. We propose a modified equal width binning interval approach to discretizing continuous valued attributes. The approximate width of the desired intervals is chosen based on the opinion of medical expert and is provided as an input parameter to the model. First we have converted numeric attributes into categorical form based on above techniques. Apriori algorithm is usually used for the market basket analysis was used to generate rules on Pima Indian diabetes data. The data set was taken from UCI machine learning repository containing total instances 768 and 8 numeric attributes.We discover that the often neglected pre-processing steps in knowledge discovery are the most critical elements in determining the success of a data mining application. Lastly we have generated the association rules which are useful to identify general associations in the data, to understand the relationship between the measured fields whether the patient goes on to develop diabetes or not. We are presented step-by-step approach to help the health doctors to explore their data and to understand the discovered rules better. © 2010 IEEE.

Authors: Joshi S., Shenoy D., Vibhudendra Simha G.G., Rrashmi P.L., Venugopal K.R., Patnaik L.M.
Title: Classification of Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease by using machine learning and neural network methods
Source title: ICMLC 2010 - The 2nd International Conference on Machine Learning and Computing
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, MGR University, Chennai, India; Department of Computer Science and Engineering, University Visvesvaraya College of Engineering, Bangalore - 01, India; Defence Institute of Advanced Technology, Pune, India
Authors with affiliations: Joshi, S., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, MGR University, Chennai, India; Shenoy, D., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, University Visvesvaraya College of Engineering, Bangalore - 01, India; Vibhudendra Simha, G.G., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, University Visvesvaraya College of Engineering, Bangalore - 01, India; Rrashmi, P.L., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, University Visvesvaraya College of Engineering, Bangalore - 01, India; Venugopal, K.R., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, University Visvesvaraya College of Engineering, Bangalore - 01, India; Patnaik, L.M., Defence Institute of Advanced Technology, Pune, India
Abstract: Data mining is a fast evolving technology, is being adopted in biomedical sciences and research. Data mining in medicine is an emerging field of high importance for providing prognosis and a deeper understanding of the classification of neurodegenerative diseases. Given a data set of consists of 487 patients records collected from ADRC, USA. Around eight hundred and ninety patients were recruited to ADRC and diagnosed for AD (65%) and PD (40%), according to the established criteria. In our study we concentrated particularly on the major risk factors which are responsible for Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease. This paper proposes a new model for the classification of Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease by considering the most influencing risk factors. The main focus was on the selection of most influencing risk factors for both AD and PD using various attribute evaluation scheme with ranker search method. Different models for the classification of AD and PD using various classification techniques such as Neural Networks (NN) and Machine Learning (ML) methods were also developed. It was found that some specific genetic factors, diabetes, age and smoking were the strongest risk factors for Alzheimer's disease. Similarly, for the classification of Parkinson's disease, the risk factors such as stroke, diabetes, genes and age were the vital factors. © 2010 IEEE.

Authors: Pushpalatha M.P., Nalini N.
Title: Analysis on the convergence of dyadic wavelet based neural network with varying learning rate and resolution for function learning
Source title: ICMLC 2010 - The 2nd International Conference on Machine Learning and Computing

Abstract: This paper presents the analysis of results on the generalisation of dyadic based wavelet neural network which are trained with uniform distribution from input space. The focus is to mainly quantify the significance of learning rate and the resolution so as to ensure an acceptable generalization accuracy for function learning simulations. The proposed network is based on orthonormal basis functions and trained with stochastic gradient algrothim. The simulations of developed dyadic wavelet based architecture and its learning algorithm justifies the effectiveness of the scaling function characteristics. Experimental results reveal that training and tuning the various simulation parameters of the network and its properties has greater influence on the generalization and convergence ability of the Dyadic Wavelet Neural Network (DWNN). © 2010 IEEE.

Authors: Poornima A.S., Amberker B.B.
Title: Agent based secure data collection in heterogeneous sensor networks
Source title: ICMLC 2010 - The 2nd International Conference on Machine Learning and Computing
Affiliations: Dept. of Computer Science and Engg., Siddaganga Institute of Technology, Tumkur, Karnataka, India; Dept. of Computer Science and Engg., National Institute of Technology, Warangal, Andhra Pradesh, India
Authors with affiliations: Poornima, A.S., Dept. of Computer Science and Engg., Siddaganga Institute of Technology, Tumkur, Karnataka, India; Amberker, B.B., Dept. of Computer Science and Engg., National Institute of Technology, Warangal, Andhra Pradesh, India
Abstract: Efficient data collection is challenging in Wireless Sensor Networks. Use of Mobile Agents for various operations like data collection and software updates in Wireless Sensor Networks is receiving significant attention recently as it increases the lifetime of the network. Mobile Agents are privileged hence they are attractive targets. Compromised mobile agents may be used to launch various attacks in turn may compromise the entire network. Also an adversary may deploy some malicious nodes which act as mobile agents. In order to provide security for the network in this paper we are proposing a simple authentication scheme for heterogeneous sensor network which uses mobile agents for efficient data collection. The proposed scheme is used to identify malicious nodes acting as mobile agents. Also we are achieving confidentiality of the data collected using simple key derivation technique which allows a cluster head to encrypt the data every time using a different key which can be easily derived by the base station. © 2010 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Authentication; Cluster head; Common cluster head key; Data collection; Mobile agent

Authors: Sumitha C.H., Geddam K.O.
Title: Implementation of context free languages in turing machines
Source title: ICMLC 2010 - The 2nd International Conference on Machine Learning and Computing
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Karunya University, Coimbatore, India
Authors with affiliations: Sumitha, C.H., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Karunya University, Coimbatore, India; Geddam, K.O., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Karunya University, Coimbatore, India
Abstract: Automata play a major role in compiler design and parsing. Turing Machines are the most powerful computational machines. Turing machines are equivalent to algorithms, and are the theoretical basis for modern computers. Still it is a tedious task to create and maintain Turing Machines for all the problems. The Universal Turing Machine (UTM) or simply a universal machine is a solution to this problem. A UTM simulates any other TM, thus providing a single model and solution for all the computational problems. The creation of UTM is very tedious because of the underlying complexities. Also many of the existing tools do not support the creation of UTM which makes the task very difficult to accomplish. Hence a Universal Turing Machine is developed for the JFLAP platform. JFLAP is most successful and widely used tool for visualizing and simulating all types of automata. © 2010 IEEE.

Authors: Yadav R., Singh M.D., Mahajan N.
Title: Parallelism through dynamic instrumentation at runtime
Source title: ICMLC 2010 - The 2nd International Conference on Machine Learning and Computing
Affiliations: Digital Media Center, Samsung India Electronics Pvt. Ltd., Noida, India
Authors with affiliations: Yadav, R., Digital Media Center, Samsung India Electronics Pvt. Ltd., Noida, India; Singh, M.D., Digital Media Center, Samsung India Electronics Pvt. Ltd., Noida, India; Mahajan, N., Digital Media Center, Samsung India Electronics Pvt. Ltd., Noida, India
Abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to achieve parallelism on multi-core systems out of the legacy software without recompilation. A profiler tool can be enhanced, from identifying the bottleneck areas, to analyzing the instruction set in bottleneck areas. As the instructions along with all data dependencies are available in the running program, heuristics can be applied to detect the candidates for instruction level parallelism. The serial regions can be regenerated into parallel regions for multiple cores using predefined OpenMP calls and instrument dynamically at runtime. We discuss the problems for parallelism 1) Identifying the parallel regions for parallelism from serial code 2) Detailed approach for generating code generation at runtime. © 2010 IEEE.

Authors: Thamarai M., Shanmugalakshmi R.
Title: Video coding technique using swarm intelligence in 3-D dual tree complex wavelet transform
Source title: ICMLC 2010 - The 2nd International Conference on Machine Learning and Computing
Affiliations: GCT, Coimbatore, India; ECE Dept., Karpagam College of Engineering, Coimbatore, India; Dept., of CSE, GCT, Coimbatore, India
Authors with affiliations: Thamarai, M., GCT, Coimbatore, India, ECE Dept., Karpagam College of Engineering, Coimbatore, India; Shanmugalakshmi, R., Dept., of CSE, GCT, Coimbatore, India
Abstract: Video compression plays an important role in video signal processing, transmission and storage. Since the available bandwidth for transmission is very limited, Multimedia Applications such as video conferencing, video on demand, video telephony and remote sensing are not possible without compression. A lot of video compression techniques have been developed and the video signal transmission has followed at data rates below 64kbps.Wavelet transform based motion compensated video codec performs better compression in order to meet the rate and distortion constraint in video transmission for the available bandwidth than the block based techniques, which are followed in standard video transmissions such as H.261 and H.263.But the efficiency of those technique's depends on the way in which it estimates and compensates the object motions in the video sequence. Wavelet based embedded image coder is quite attractive in modern multimedia applications. Wavelet transform, bit plane coding and other techniques make embedded image coder practical and also provide efficient compression. In this paper, we have proposed a novel video coding using swarm intelligence in dual tree complex wavelet transform for video coding. The 3-D DDWT is an attractive video representation because it isolates motion along different directions in separate subbands. However, it is an over-complete transform with redundancy, which is going to be eliminated by choosing optimal subbands with the help of PSO. The proposed video codec does not require motion compensation and provides better performance than the 3D SPIHT (Embedded type)codec, both objectively and subjectively, and the coder allows full scalability in spatial, temporal and quality dimensions. © 2010 IEEE.

Title: A survey of semantic similarity methods for ontology based information retrieval
Source title: ICMLC 2010 - The 2nd International Conference on Machine Learning and Computing

Abstract: This paper discusses the various approaches used for identifying semantically similar concepts in an ontology. The purpose of this survey is to explore how these similarity computation methods could assist in ontology based query expansion. This query expansion method based on the similarity function is expected to improve the retrieval effectiveness of the ontology based Information retrieval models. Various similarity computation methods fall under three categories: Edge counting, information content and node based counting. The limitations of each of these approaches have been discussed in this paper. © 2010 IEEE.

Authors: Gunasekaran S., Revathy K.
Title: Content-based classification and retrieval of wild animal sounds using feature selection algorithm
Source title: ICMLC 2010 - The 2nd International Conference on Machine Learning and Computing
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, University of Kerala, Trivandrum, India
Authors with affiliations: Gunasekaran, S., Department of Computer Science, University of Kerala, Trivandrum, India; Revathy, K., Department of Computer Science, University of Kerala, Trivandrum, India
Abstract: Automatic animal sound classification and retrieval is very helpful for bioacoustic and audio retrieval applications. In this paper we propose a system to define and extract a set of acoustic features from all archived wild animal sound recordings that is used in subsequent feature selection, classification and retrieval tasks. The database consisted of sounds of six wild animals. The Fractal Dimension analysis based segmentation was selected due to its ability to select the right portion of signal for extracting the features. The feature vectors of the proposed algorithm consist of spectral, temporal and perceptual features of the animal vocalizations. The minimal Redundancy, Maximal Relevance (mRMR) feature selection analysis was exploited to increase the classification accuracy at a compact set of features. These features were used as the inputs of two neural networks, the k-Nearest Neighbor (kNN), the Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) and its fusion. The proposed system provides quite robust approach for classification and retrieval purposes, especially for the wild animal sounds. © 2010 IEEE.

Authors: Pandey D., Pandey P.
Title: Approximate Q-learning: An introduction
Source title: ICMLC 2010 - The 2nd International Conference on Machine Learning and Computing
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Jaypee Institute of Engineering and Technology, Guna, India
Authors with affiliations: Pandey, D., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Jaypee Institute of Engineering and Technology, Guna, India; Pandey, P., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Jaypee Institute of Engineering and Technology, Guna, India
Abstract: This paper introduces an approach to Q-learning algorithm with rough set theory introduced by Zdzislaw Pawlak in 1981. During Q-learning, an agent makes action selections in an effort to maximize a reward signal obtained from the environment. Based on reward, agent will make changes in its policy for future actions. The problem considered in this paper is the overestimation of expected value of cumulative future discounted rewards. This discounted reward is used in evaluating agent actions and policy during reinforcement learning. Due to the overestimation of discounted reward action evaluation and policy changes are not accurate. The solution to this problem results from a form Q-learning algorithm using a combination of approximation spaces and Q-learning to estimate the expected value of returns on actions. This is made possible by considering behavior patterns of an agent in scope of approximation spaces. The framework provided by an approximation space makes it possible to measure the degree that agent behaviors are a part of ("covered by") a set of accepted agent behaviors that serve as a behavior evaluation norm. © 2010 IEEE.
