Authors: Jobin Christ M.C., Jagan G., Parwathi R.M.S.
Title: Topological constraints in segmentation of MRI brain images
Source title: Proceedings of the 2009 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2009
Affiliations: Department of Biomedical Engineering, Adhiyamaan College of Engineering, Hosur, Tamilnadu, India; Sengunthar College of Engineering for Women, Tiruchencode, Tamilnadu, India
Authors with affiliations: Jobin Christ, M.C., Department of Biomedical Engineering, Adhiyamaan College of Engineering, Hosur, Tamilnadu, India; Jagan, G., Department of Biomedical Engineering, Adhiyamaan College of Engineering, Hosur, Tamilnadu, India; Parwathi, R.M.S., Sengunthar College of Engineering for Women, Tiruchencode, Tamilnadu, India
Abstract: Topology is the mathematical study of the properties that are preserved through deformations, twisting, and stretching of objects. The topological properties of objects are often very simple, regardless of their geometric complexity. Human anatomy follows this rule, even for extremely convoluted shapes like the cerebral cortex or the vasculature. To achieve accurate and topologically correct delineations of anatomical structures from medical images is a critical step for many clinical and research applications. Excluding pathological cases, most macroscopic brain structures are fully connected and do not possess any topological artifact such as handles or cavities: they have the simple topology of a sphere. Many recent segmentation algorithms are able to identify and precisely locate these structures, although without constraining the topology. Being able to achieve accurate and topologically correct representations of different brain structures is certainly an important goal in medical imaging. In this paper we cover methods for integrating topological constraints into segmentation procedures in order to generate geometrically accurate and topologically correct models, which is critical for many clinical and research applications.

Title: Adaptive classified pattern matching vector quantization approach for compressing images
Source title: Proceedings of the 2009 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2009

Abstract: In this paper, we propose a new, two-stage, adaptive classified pattern-matching algorithm based on residual vector quantization and variable bit rate encoding techniques as they have proved to be very efficient in progressive image transmission and compression rate. Both the intra-block and inter-block correlation properties have been exploited to enhance the compression rate. The innovative aspects of this method are: i) the use of high eigenvalued blocks as initial seeds yielding fast convergence; ii) the use of number patterns as the secondary codebook; and, iii) the generation of number patterns using basic combinatorics without requiring complex calculations; iv) use of variable number of indices.

Authors: Somasundaram K., Kalaiselvi T.
Title: A comparative study of segmentation techniques used for MR brain images
Source title: Proceedings of the 2009 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2009
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Applications, Gandhigram Rural University, Gandhigram, Tamilnadu, India
Authors with affiliations: Somasundaram, K., Department of Computer Science and Applications, Gandhigram Rural University, Gandhigram, Tamilnadu, India; Kalaiselvi, T., Department of Computer Science and Applications, Gandhigram Rural University, Gandhigram, Tamilnadu, India
Abstract: In this paper we present a comparative study of MR brain image segmentation techniques. The aim of this study is to assess the robustness and accuracy of three most commonly used unsupervised segmentation methods k-means (KM), FCM and EM. KM is a well known hard segmentation method for quicker processing whereas FCM and EM are popularly used soft segmentation methods particularly for brain tissue models. Most of the neuroimage analyzing software employ one of these techniques as a preprocessing tool to enrich their subsequent processes. Based on the parameters similarity index and processing time, the performance of the methods on brain tissue segmentation are measured and compared. The similarity index calculation was done by using the 20 normal volumes and their gold standards available from IBSR. The rest of parameters are tested on the normal and abnormal brain volumes collected from scan centers and brain image pools. For normal and noiseless volumes all the three methods produced comparable results. FCM has an excellent performance over the anisotropic nature of volumes that are affected by partial volume effects (PVE) as well as diseased sets and EM was suitable for noisy sets, particularly volumes affected by intensity non-uniformity (INU) artifacts. KM, FCM and EM are rated in the given order in terms of processing time. This study is useful to choose a suitable method for computerizing brain diagnostic system.

Title: Vehicle license plate identification & recognition
Source title: Proceedings of the 2009 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2009
Affiliations: Computer Science Engineering and Information Technology Department, Jaypee Institute of Information Technology University, Noida, India
Authors with affiliations: Goel, S., Computer Science Engineering and Information Technology Department, Jaypee Institute of Information Technology University, Noida, India; Singh, P., Computer Science Engineering and Information Technology Department, Jaypee Institute of Information Technology University, Noida, India; Batra, S., Computer Science Engineering and Information Technology Department, Jaypee Institute of Information Technology University, Noida, India; Jain, A., Computer Science Engineering and Information Technology Department, Jaypee Institute of Information Technology University, Noida, India
Abstract: Existing vehicle license plate identification and recognition systems are potent for either their accuracy or speed but not a combination of both. The algorithm proposed in this dissertation attempts to achieve this fine balance between the accuracy and speed that such a system must posses. The mathematical morphology operators of dilation and erosion are utilized to identify the region within an image which contains the license plate. Using the concept of color coherence vectors, an image recognition algorithm is presented which utilizes this extracted region and compares it as a whole to other images of license plates, in the database. The application developed for the testing of this algorithm works with an accuracy of eighty eight percent and an average processing time of two seconds per image.

Title: Denoising and segmentation of 3D brain images
Source title: Proceedings of the 2009 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2009

Authors with affiliations: Vatsa, M., IIIT, Delhi, India; Singh, R., IIIT, Delhi, India; Noore, A., West Virginia University, Morgantown, United States
Abstract: This paper presents an algorithm for medical 3D image denoising and segmentation using redundant discrete wavelet transform. First, we present a two stage denoising algorithm using the image fusion concept. The algorithm starts with globally denoising the brain images (3D volume) using Perona Malik's algorithm and RDWT based algorithms followed by combining the outputs using entropy based fusion approach. Next, a region segmentation algorithm is proposed using texture information and k-means clustering. The proposed algorithms are evaluated using brain 3D image/volume data. The results suggest that the proposed algorithms provide improved performance compared to existing algorithms.

Authors: Ananthashayana V.K., Jyothirmayi M., Pushpa M.K.
Title: Real time face recognition using single face per person database
Source title: Proceedings of the 2009 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2009
Affiliations: Department of Computer science and Engg., MSRIT, Bangalore, Karnataka, India; Department of Instrumentation Technology, MSRIT, Bangalore, Karnataka, India
Authors with affiliations: Ananthashayana, V.K., Department of Computer science and Engg., MSRIT, Bangalore, Karnataka, India; Jyothirmayi, M., Department of Instrumentation Technology, MSRIT, Bangalore, Karnataka, India; Pushpa, M.K., Department of Instrumentation Technology, MSRIT, Bangalore, Karnataka, India
Abstract: Face recognition is important in today's emerging Biometrics and Video surveillance markets. This paper is addressing a practical real time face recognition system based on single person per database. We present a novel approach for face identification, by capturing the person who comes in the vicinity of the webcam view, with partial occlusion, pose variation and under different illumination constraints and detect the validity of the person. We use a neural network based Independent Component Analysis (ICA), the Infomax algorithm by Bell and Sejnowski and nearest neighbor classifier for recognition. The detection of the face is based on the skin model and face template. We find the system well suited for face recognition in a real time scenario like personal identification and monitoring employee entering the company with little modification to the existing system of swiping the identification cards. We compare the results with PCA and LDA based approaches for our system and find that ICA gives a better and reliable recognition.

Authors with affiliations: Bhattacharyya, K., Department of Electronics Science, Gauhati University, Guwahati, Assam, India; Sarma, K.K., Department of Electronics Science, Gauhati University, Guwahati, Assam, India
Abstract: In an Artificial Neural Network (ANN) based Optical Character Recognition (OCR) System, segmentation is an important component before recognition. Segmentation of words into individual letters has been one of the major problems in handwriting recognition. Despite several successful works all over the world, development of such tools in specific languages is still an ongoing process especially in the Indian context. This work explores the application of ANN as an aid to segmentation of handwritten characters in Assamese - an important language in the North Eastern part of India. The work explores the performance difference obtained in applying an ANN-based dynamic segmentation algorithm compared to projection-based static segmentation.

Authors: Sreenivasulu V., Bhaskar P.U.
Title: Identification of critical erosion prone areas in Upper Indravati reservoir catchment using geographic information systems and remote sensing techniques
Source title: Proceedings of the 2009 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2009
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering, JNT University Kakinada, Kakinada, Andhra Pradesh, 533003, India
Authors with affiliations: Sreenivasulu, V., Department of Civil Engineering, JNT University Kakinada, Kakinada, Andhra Pradesh, 533003, India; Bhaskar, P.U., Department of Civil Engineering, JNT University Kakinada, Kakinada, Andhra Pradesh, 533003, India
Abstract: Soil erosion is a serious environmental problem in the Upper Indravati Catchment, with an area of 2630 km 2. In the present study, Universal Soil Loss equation (ULSE) has been used for estimating the spatial distribution of soil loss. Various parameters of USLE are determined with the help of Geographic Information System (GIS) and Remote Sensing (RS) techniques. The derived soil loss map is classified into six categories ranging from slight to very severe risk depending on the estimated amount of soil erosion. The soil erosion map is linked to elevation thematic layer to identify the areas where soil conservation practices are to be taken up in order to reduce the soil loss. From the model output predictions, it is found that the average erosion rate is 13.73 tons/ha/year, in the Upper Indravati catchment.

Authors: Raj M., Kumar N., Biswas K.K.
Title: Real time hand tracking & gesture recognition
Source title: Proceedings of the 2009 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2009
Affiliations: Army Institute of Technology, University of Pune, India; Indian Institute of Technology, Delhi, India
Authors with affiliations: Raj, M., Army Institute of Technology, University of Pune, India; Kumar, N., Army Institute of Technology, University of Pune, India; Biswas, K.K., Indian Institute of Technology, Delhi, India
Abstract: In this paper we present a very simple real time hand tracking and gesture recognition scheme for Human Computer Interaction. Using video feed as an input from a web cam, we implement a virtual mouse system. Using Bradski's Cam-shift algorithm we track the hand and present simple schemes for recognition of various clicking operations of the mouse. We use dynamic gestures to switch between active and standby modes. We also present an application to draw figures in MS-paint using only hand gestures.

Authors: Kavitha G., Archana Srinivasan V.
Title: Video object extraction based on histogram approach and modified Horn-Schunck algorithm
Source title: Proceedings of the 2009 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2009
Affiliations: Dept. of Electronics Engg., Madras Institute of Technology Campus, Anna University, Chennai, Tamil Nadu, India
Authors with affiliations: Kavitha, G., Dept. of Electronics Engg., Madras Institute of Technology Campus, Anna University, Chennai, Tamil Nadu, India; Archana Srinivasan, V., Dept. of Electronics Engg., Madras Institute of Technology Campus, Anna University, Chennai, Tamil Nadu, India
Abstract: In this work an attempt has been made to extract moving objects from video sequence, by taking its edge features and motion information into consideration. Initially the edge information is determined from the analysis of local histogram of the image. A discriminant function based on local histogram analysis is introduced to construct an edge information map which describes the existence of two or more distinct brightness regions in a window image. Based on the features obtained from the gradient image, the detection step is implemented. Here, Optical flow is used as the primary information for object detection. It gives the displacement of each image pixel in a video sequence. Calculation of optical flow is done by modified Horn-Schunck algorithm. It takes less iteration, produces dense flow vectors and helps to detect exact motion boundaries. After computing the flow vectors, the video object plane is extracted.

Authors: Sanghavi M.R., Rajurkar A.M.
Title: Digital video watermarking based on scene change detection
Source title: Proceedings of the 2009 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2009
Affiliations: Computer Engg Dept., M.G.M, Nanded, India
Authors with affiliations: Sanghavi, M.R., Computer Engg Dept., M.G.M, Nanded, India; Rajurkar, A.M., Computer Engg Dept., M.G.M, Nanded, India
Abstract: We have seen an explosion of data exchange in the Internet and the extensive use of digital media. Consequently, digital data owners can quickly and massively transfer multimedia documents across the Internet. This leads to wide interest in multimedia security and multimedia copyright protection. We propose a digital video watermarking scheme based on the scene change analysis. Our video watermarking algorithm is robust against the attacks of frame dropping, averaging and statistical analysis, which were not solved effectively in the past. We start with a complete survey of current watermarking technologies, and noticed that none of the existing schemes is capable of resisting all attacks. Accordingly, we propose the idea of embedding different parts of a single watermark into different scenes of a video. The effectiveness of this scheme is verified through a series of experiments, in which a number of standard image processing attacks are verified, and the robustness of our approach is demonstrated using the criteria of the latest StirMark test.
Author Keywords: Digital watermarking; Discrete wavelet transform (DWT); Hybrid; Scene change; Video

Authors: Kotecha K.S., Rajurkar A.M.
Title: Content based video retrieval using ordinal measures, motion and color distribution
Source title: Proceedings of the 2009 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2009
Affiliations: Computer Engg Dept., M.G.M, Nanded, India
Authors with affiliations: Kotecha, K.S., Computer Engg Dept., M.G.M, Nanded, India; Rajurkar, A.M., Computer Engg Dept., M.G.M, Nanded, India
Abstract: Today's content-based video retrieval technologies are still far from human's requirements. A fundamental reason is the lack of content representation that is able to bridge the gap between visual features and semantic conception in video. The core research in content - based video retrieval is developing technologies to automatically parse video, extract as well as represent content attributes from video source. Feature extraction is a primary process for video-content analysis. In the proposed scheme a promotion is made on ordinal measures by using motion features and color features beside sum of intensities. New video retrieval system is proposed for similarity matching, which finds the similarity between video sequences with different sizes. Moreover, the system is able to find the similarity between a query video and a part of another video sequence.

Authors: Singh R., Vatsa M., Noore A.
Title: Fingerprint indexing using minutiae and pore features
Source title: Proceedings of the 2009 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2009
Affiliations: IIIT, Delhi, India; West Virginia University, Morgantown, United States
Authors with affiliations: Singh, R., IIIT, Delhi, India; Vatsa, M., IIIT, Delhi, India; Noore, A., West Virginia University, Morgantown, United States
Abstract: In this paper, we propose level-2 and level-3 feature based fingerprint indexing algorithm to improve the speed and accuracy of identification. Indexing parameters are computed using the minutiae and pore features. The identification performance is further improved by incorporating Dempster Shafer theory based match score fusion algorithm. Experimental results on a high resolution fingerprint database show that the proposed algorithm improves the identification performance by at least 10% compared to existing fingerprint identification algorithms.

Authors: Manoorkar J.A.
Title: Color histograms for content based image retrieval
Source title: Proceedings of the 2009 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2009
Affiliations: Department of Computer and IT Engineering, College of Engineering, Wellesely Road Shivaji Nagar, Pune 411005 Maharashtra, India
Authors with affiliations: Manoorkar, J.A., Department of Computer and IT Engineering, College of Engineering, Wellesely Road Shivaji Nagar, Pune 411005 Maharashtra, India
Abstract: Color is a lower level feature, robust in nature and its appearance changes as view angle changes. In color image processing each pixel in image is taken into account. In this paper various measures of color distribution implemented. These are color histograms, color coherence vector (CCV), annular, angular and hybrid histograms and are compared in two different color spaces HSV and HVC using average precision recall. Experiments show that CCV and hybrid histograms produced better results in HSV color space.

Authors: Sakthivel S., Lakshmipathi R., Manikandan M.A.
Title: Evaluation of feature extraction and dimensionality reduction algorithms for face recognition using orl database
Source title: Proceedings of the 2009 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2009
Affiliations: Department of IT, Sona College of Technology, Salem, Tamilnadu, India; Department of EEE, St. Peter's Engineering College, Chennai, Tamilnadu, India; Department of MCA, Sona College of Technology, Salem, Tamilnadu, India
Authors with affiliations: Sakthivel, S., Department of IT, Sona College of Technology, Salem, Tamilnadu, India; Lakshmipathi, R., Department of EEE, St. Peter's Engineering College, Chennai, Tamilnadu, India; Manikandan, M.A., Department of MCA, Sona College of Technology, Salem, Tamilnadu, India
Abstract: Recognizing a face based on its attributes is an easy task for a human to perform; it is nearly automatic, and requires little mental effort. Human can recognize face even when the matching image is distorted, such as a person wearing glasses, and human can perform the task fairly easy. A computer, on the other hand, has no innate ability to recognize a face or a facial feature, and must be programmed with an algorithm to do so. In our work different dimensionality reduction techniques such as Principal Components Analysis (PCA), Kernel principal component analysis (Kernel PCA), Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA), Locality Preserving Projections (LPP), and Neighborhood Preserving Embedding (NPE) are applied in order to reduce the loss of classification performance due to changes in facial appearance. Experiments are designed specifically to investigate the gain in robustness against illumination and facial expression changes. The underlying idea in the use of the dimensionality reduction techniques is firstly, to obtain significant feature vectors of the face, and search for those components that are less sensitive to intrinsic deformations due to expression or due to extrinsic factors, like illumination. The proposed algorithms is tested on face images that differ in expression or illumination separately, obtained from face image databases from ORL. More significant and comparative results are found out.
Author Keywords: Biometrics; Dimensionality reduction; Kernel PCA LDA LPP; NPE; PCA

Authors: Swarnalatha P., Kota M., Resu N.R., Srivasanth G.
Title: Automated assessment tool for the depth of pipe deterioration
Source title: Proceedings of the 2009 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2009
Affiliations: School of Computing Sciences, VIT University, India
Authors with affiliations: Swarnalatha, P., School of Computing Sciences, VIT University, India; Kota, M., School of Computing Sciences, VIT University, India; Resu, N.R., School of Computing Sciences, VIT University, India; Srivasanth, G., School of Computing Sciences, VIT University, India
Abstract: Defects in underground pipeline images are indicative of the condition of buried infrastructures like sewers and water mains. This paper entitled Automated Assessment Tool for the depth of pipe deterioration presents a three step method which is a simple, robust and efficient one to detect defects in the underground concrete pipes. It identifies and extracts defect-like structures from pipe images whose contrast has been enhanced. We propose to use segmentation and feature extraction using structural elements. The main objective behind using this tool is to find the dimensions of the defect such as the length, width and depth and also the type of defect. The detection of defects in buried pipes is a crucial step in assessing the degree of pipe deterioration for municipal operators. Although the human eye is extremely effective at recognition and classification, it is not suitable for assessing pipe defects in thousands of miles of pipeline because of fatigue, subjectivity and cost. Our objective is to reduce the effort and the labour of a person in detecting the defects in underground pipes.
Author Keywords: Contrast stretching; Histogram equalization; Image enhancement; Image segmentation and feature extraction

Authors: Amrutha V., Anthoniraj A.
Title: A block based robust watermarking scheme for information security
Source title: Proceedings of the 2009 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2009
Affiliations: School of Computing Sciences, VIT University, Vellore-632 014, Tamilnadu (TN), India
Authors with affiliations: Amrutha, V., School of Computing Sciences, VIT University, Vellore-632 014, Tamilnadu (TN), India; Anthoniraj, A., School of Computing Sciences, VIT University, Vellore-632 014, Tamilnadu (TN), India
Abstract: This paper presents a highly robust watermarking scheme for color images in spatial domain using block probability with a password authentication technique. There are two main phases; one is Invisible watermarking phase and other is the Password insertion phase inside the image. In the watermarking phase a binary watermark is permuted using a random numbers and converted to gray code, in which each bit of the binary encoded watermark is embedded by modifying the intensities of the 8 *8 blocks and finally inserted into the blue component of the original image. In the Password insertion phase a 16-bit binary key (password) is embedded in the original image along with the watermark. Extraction of the watermark is done by comparing the intensities of watermarked image with the original image. The same watermark has been embedded in four different positions to provide high robustness and it also secure, only the person with the correct password can extract the watermark and also the use of random number (32 *32) as a secret key intensifies the security of the information.
Author Keywords: Digital watermark; LSB; Spatial domain

Authors: Thakkar F., Kher R., Modi C., Kher H.
Title: Selecting most favorable basis function for compressing natural and medical images using wavelet transform coding
Source title: Proceedings of the 2009 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2009
Affiliations: EC Department, G H Patel College of Engineering and Technology, Vallabh Vidyanagar, Gujarat, India
Authors with affiliations: Thakkar, F., EC Department, G H Patel College of Engineering and Technology, Vallabh Vidyanagar, Gujarat, India; Kher, R., EC Department, G H Patel College of Engineering and Technology, Vallabh Vidyanagar, Gujarat, India; Modi, C., EC Department, G H Patel College of Engineering and Technology, Vallabh Vidyanagar, Gujarat, India; Kher, H., EC Department, G H Patel College of Engineering and Technology, Vallabh Vidyanagar, Gujarat, India
Abstract: Wavelet transform is a powerful tool for efficiently compressing an image as the energy retained in the compressed image and hence the energy compaction efficiency are both very high. Thus wavelet based image compression provides excellent image quality even at very high compression ratio (CR). In the present paper, wavelet based image compression scheme using four mother wavelets - Haar, Daubechies (db4), BiorSpline (bior6.8) and Symlet (sym2) has been implemented for natural as well as medical images. In this process wavelet transformed coefficients have been quantized and then encoded using Huffman coding. The comparative study of compression performance of these four mother wavelets is made based on the parameters like root mean square error (RMSE), correlation coefficient (CoC), and peak signal to noise ratio (PSNR). A closer look at these parameters for various natural and medical images indicates that the Haar wavelet excels for medical images whereas the Sym2 wavelet excels for natural images.
Author Keywords: DWT; Huffman coding; Medical images; Natural images; Wavelet transform coding

Authors: Kamthania S., Ali R.
Title: A comparative study of color image compression using SOFM with CDF and without CDF
Source title: Proceedings of the 2009 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2009
Affiliations: Department of Computer Engineering, A.M.U., Aligarh, 202002, India
Authors with affiliations: Kamthania, S., Department of Computer Engineering, A.M.U., Aligarh, 202002, India; Ali, R., Department of Computer Engineering, A.M.U., Aligarh, 202002, India
Abstract: Image compression Schemes aim at reducing the number of bits required to represent the image. Artificial neural networks have been applied to image compression problems due to their superiority over other traditional methods, as they have the ability to preprocess input patterns to produce simpler patterns with fewer components. If the image compression is coupled with Kohonen's Self Organizing Feature Maps then, it may provide sufficient compression rates of the data in question. The performance of the image compression system may further improved if the image pixels are mapped using a Cumulative Distribution Function before feeding them to the Self Organizing Feature Maps Network for training. This leads to faster convergence rate for network and high compression ratio. This paper compares the image compression schemes using Self Organizing Feature Maps with and without Cumulative Distribution Function on colored images.

Authors: Sharma S.S., Chandrasekaran V.
Title: Embedding large watermarks in images using discrete fractional cosine transform
Source title: Proceedings of the 2009 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2009
Affiliations: Department of Mathematics and Computer Science, Sri Sathya Sai University, Prashanthi Nilayam, A.P., 515134, India
Authors with affiliations: Sharma, S.S., Department of Mathematics and Computer Science, Sri Sathya Sai University, Prashanthi Nilayam, A.P., 515134, India; Chandrasekaran, V., Department of Mathematics and Computer Science, Sri Sathya Sai University, Prashanthi Nilayam, A.P., 515134, India
Abstract: The amount of information that can be hidden in an image without any visually noticeable difference and retrieval of this embedded information are the difficulties in watermarking techniques. In this paper we present a novel algorithm for embedding and extracting large digital watermarks in images. This method is inspired by Cox's watermarking strategy. Unlike embedding an image or binary watermarks that are smaller than the host image being watermarked, in our algorithm we demonstrate by embedding an audio watermark which is much larger than the host image to be watermarked. The size of the watermarked image increases only by a fraction after watermarking. The positions where the watermarks are to be embedded, intermediate frequency coefficients and the sequence of the transformation orders comprise the key. The experimental results have shown that the proposed algorithm is of good imperceptibility and security. It is also robust against common attacks like rotation, resizing, filtering and even cropping.

Authors: Sinha R.M.K.
Title: Learning disambiguation of Hindi morpheme 'vaalaa' with a sparse corpus
Source title: 8th International Conference on Machine Learning and Applications, ICMLA 2009
Affiliations: Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur, India
Authors with affiliations: Sinha, R.M.K., Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur, India
Abstract: The Hindi morpheme 'vaalaa' is very widely used as a suffix and also as a separate word. The common usage of this suffix is to denote an activity or profession of a person. This form of the usage has been borrowed in English with the spelling of 'wallah'. However, it has a large number of other interpretations depending upon the context in which it is used. This paper presents an account of different senses in which this morpheme is used in Hindi and presents a strategy for learning their disambiguation based on contextual features with sparse data using a semi-supervised method. We present a new technique of unifying learned instances using supervised training with limited data and computing matching index and bootstrapping the training set to deal with corpus sparseness. This study finds application in machine translation, information retrieval, text understanding and text summarization. © 2009 IEEE.

Authors: Agrawal V., Bhattacharyya C., Niranjan T., Susarla S.
Title: Discovering rules from disk events for predicting hard drive failures
Source title: 8th International Conference on Machine Learning and Applications, ICMLA 2009
Affiliations: Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India; NetApp Advanced Technology Group, Bangalore, India
Authors with affiliations: Agrawal, V., Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India; Bhattacharyya, C., Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India; Niranjan, T., NetApp Advanced Technology Group, Bangalore, India; Susarla, S., NetApp Advanced Technology Group, Bangalore, India
Abstract: Detecting impending failure of hard disks is an important prediction task which might help computer systems to prevent loss of data and performance degradation. Currently most of the hard drive vendors support self-monitoring, analysis and reporting technology (SMART) which are often considered unreliable for such tasks. The problem of finding alternatives to SMART for predicting disk failure is an area of active research. In this paper, we consider events recorded from live disks and show that it is possible to construct decision support systems which can detect such failures. It is desired that any such prediction methodology should have high accuracy and ease of interpretability. Black box models can deliver highly accurate solutions but do not provide an understanding of events which explains the decision given by it. To this end we explore rule based classifiers for predicting hard disk failures from various disk events. We show that it is possible to learn easy to understand rules, from disk events, which have extremely low false alarm rates on real world data. © 2009 IEEE.

Authors: Balakrishnan A.
Title: Development of an ontology of learning strategies and its application to generate open learner models
Source title: 8th International Conference on Machine Learning and Applications, ICMLA 2009
Affiliations: Department of Computer Technology and Applications, Coimbatore Institute of Technology, Coimbatore, India
Authors with affiliations: Balakrishnan, A., Department of Computer Technology and Applications, Coimbatore Institute of Technology, Coimbatore, India
Abstract: The Multi-Strategy Machine Learning System (MSMLS) represents knowledge about each learning strategy and uses this to handle the learning strategy selection problem. This is used to model the students learning strategy (mis)selection. Plausible Justification Trees are generated for the learning strategies, one of which is correct while the others lead to a mis-learning. The mistake by the student is traced back to either a mistake in the application of the subject knowledge or a mistake in the learnt knowledge. Learnt knowledge mistakes are traced to the inappropriate learning strategy being used. The trace through the wrong choice of learning strategy is 'opened' to the student. This will both, correct the particular error and help in changing the errors in the learning behavior of the student. © 2009 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Machine learning; Open learner models; Student modeling

Authors: Carlos C.S., Choudhury M., Dandapat S.
Title: Large-coverage root lexicon extraction for Hindi
Source title: EACL 2009 - 12th Conference of the European Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics, Proceedings
Affiliations: Microsoft Research India, India
Authors with affiliations: Carlos, C.S., Microsoft Research India, India; Choudhury, M., Microsoft Research India, India; Dandapat, S., Microsoft Research India, India
Abstract: This paper describes a method using morphological rules and heuristics, for the automatic extraction of large-coverage lexicons of stems and root word-forms from a raw text corpus. We cast the problem of high-coverage lexicon extraction as one of stemming followed by root word-form selection. We examine the use of POS tagging to improve precision and recall of stemming and thereby the coverage of the lexicon. We present accuracy, precision and recall scores for the system on a Hindi corpus. © 2009 Association for Computational Linguistics.
Index Keywords: Automatic extraction; Morphological rules; PoS tagging; Precision and recall; Text corpora; Computational linguistics; Extraction

Authors: Udupa R., Saravanan K., Kumaran A., Jagarlamudi J.
Title: MINT: A method for effective and scalable mining of named entity transliterations from large comparable corpora
Source title: EACL 2009 - 12th Conference of the European Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics, Proceedings
Affiliations: Microsoft Research India, Bangalore 560080, India; University of Utah., United States
Authors with affiliations: Udupa, R., Microsoft Research India, Bangalore 560080, India; Saravanan, K., Microsoft Research India, Bangalore 560080, India; Kumaran, A., Microsoft Research India, Bangalore 560080, India; Jagarlamudi, J., Microsoft Research India, Bangalore 560080, India, University of Utah., United States
Abstract: In this paper, we address the problem of mining transliterations of Named Entities (NEs) from large comparable corpora. We leverage the empirical fact that multilingual news articles with similar news content are rich in Named Entity Transliteration Equivalents (NETEs). Our mining algorithm, MINT, uses a cross-language document similarity model to align multilingual news articles and then mines NETEs from the aligned articles using a transliteration similarity model. We show that our approach is highly effective on 6 different comparable corpora between English and 4 languages from 3 different language families. Furthermore, it performs substantially better than a state-of-the-art competitor. © 2009 Association for Computational Linguistics.
Index Keywords: Comparable corpora; Cross languages; Document similarity; Empirical facts; Mining algorithms; Named entities; News articles; Similarity models; Algorithms; Computational linguistics; Mints; Natural language processing systems

Authors: Mukherjee A., Choudhury M., Kannan R.
Title: Discovering global patterns in linguistic networks through spectral analysis: A case study of the consonant inventories
Source title: EACL 2009 - 12th Conference of the European Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics, Proceedings
Affiliations: Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, India; Microsoft Research India, India
Authors with affiliations: Mukherjee, A., Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, India; Choudhury, M., Microsoft Research India, India; Kannan, R., Microsoft Research India, India
Abstract: Recent research has shown that language and the socio-cognitive phenomena associated with it can be aptly modeled and visualized through networks of linguistic entities. However, most of the existing works on linguistic networks focus only on the local properties of the networks. This study is an attempt to analyze the structure of languages via a purely structural technique, namely spectral analysis, which is ideally suited for discovering the global correlations in a network. Application of this technique to PhoNet, the co-occurrence network of consonants, not only reveals several natural linguistic principles governing the structure of the consonant inventories, but is also able to quantify their relative importance. We believe that this powerful technique can be successfully applied, in general, to study the structure of natural languages. © 2009 Association for Computational Linguistics.
Index Keywords: Co-occurrence networks; Global correlation; Global patterns; Linguistic networks; Natural languages; Recent researches; Socio-cognitive; Structural techniques; Computational linguistics; Spectrum analysis

Authors: Kanojia S., Tiwari R., Shukla A., Das P.K., Choudhary K.S., Singh H.
Title: VBDO: Voice based drawing objects
Source title: Proceedings of the 2009 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, ICAI 2009
Affiliations: ABV-Indian Institute of Information Technology and Management, Gwalior, India; Indian Institute of Technology, Guwahati, India
Authors with affiliations: Kanojia, S., ABV-Indian Institute of Information Technology and Management, Gwalior, India; Tiwari, R., ABV-Indian Institute of Information Technology and Management, Gwalior, India; Shukla, A., ABV-Indian Institute of Information Technology and Management, Gwalior, India; Das, P.K., Indian Institute of Technology, Guwahati, India; Choudhary, K.S., ABV-Indian Institute of Information Technology and Management, Gwalior, India; Singh, H., ABV-Indian Institute of Information Technology and Management, Gwalior, India
Abstract: Human-Centered Computing (HCC) is a set of methodologies that can apply to any field that uses Computers in any form. Human-computer interaction has become an increasingly important part of our daily lives. Nowadays it is being expected that computers should function in human contexts, rather than requiring people to learn and follow the machine's rules. Our goal is to study social contexts and human behavior, to design and evaluate computer applications. The major focus of work is to develop applications keeping these aspects in mind. We have tried to develop this application as subjects of hands free computing, which is one of the subparts of human centered computing, by using a speech recognition engine to recognize the voice and display the voice data on the screen in the form of text. To make sure that the command is recognized correctly voice command also draws the objects on window forms that gives better understanding too.
Index Keywords: Daily lives; Hands-free; Human behaviors; Human context; Human-centered computing; Social context; Speech recognition engine; Voice command; Voice data; Artificial intelligence; Computer applications; Character recognition

Authors: Anil Kumar K.M., Suresha
Title: Threshold based approach for mining users' opinion on products from web
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Department of Studies in Computer Science, University of Mysore, Manasagangothri Mysore, India
Authors with affiliations: Anil Kumar, K.M., Department of Studies in Computer Science, University of Mysore, Manasagangothri Mysore, India; Suresha, Department of Studies in Computer Science, University of Mysore, Manasagangothri Mysore, India
Abstract: This paper presents a study to highlight how the results of existing search engines can be used to provide a opinion about the particular product. The existing search engines are providing many services such as web search, image search, product search etc. When a user wants to find opinion about the topic from other web user's, search engines provide a set of results that correspond to the topic and a user has to browse through every result to find opinion about the topic. There are some search engines that provide the means to find opinion about the topic by listing a few opinionated sites. We have observed that the opinions obtained from these sites are inadequate and may not represent the entire web community. In this paper an attempt is made to collect opinions about the products from various search engines. We show that, how these opinions vary resulting in ambiguous view of the products. We also provide a summarized opinion of the products to opinion seekers. In our approach we use semantic orientation for finding opinions on products from the results of search engines. We obtain a better result by selecting a suitable threshold value. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.

Title: On the combinatorics of triangular arrays
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Department of Mathematics, St. Joseph's College of Engineering, Chennai - 119, India; Department of Mathematics, Madras Christian College, Chennai - 59, India

Abstract: Combinatorial methods for the analysis of finite words were introduced by Colosimo and de Luca for the study of biological macro- molecules. The method is based on the analysis of (right) special factors of a given word. Iso-arrays and iso-picture languages were introduced in the context of picture generation. In this paper we introduce triangular arrays and we study the sub U-triangular array complexity of U- triangular array (U-array) and consider a combinatorial method for the analysis of U-arrays and their special sub U-arrays. Three recursive relations are derived to find the sub U-array complexity of U-arrays. Maximal complexity theorem is proved. Some results on special sub U-arrays are derived. U-arrays are reconstructed using super boxes. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.
Author Keywords: Equi-triangular array; Maximal boxes and super boxes; Sub U-array complexity

Authors: Bala M., Agrawal R.K.
Title: Decision tree SVM framework using ratio interclass and intraclass scatters
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: School of Computer and Systems Sciences, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi-110 067, India
Authors with affiliations: Bala, M., School of Computer and Systems Sciences, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi-110 067, India; Agrawal, R.K., School of Computer and Systems Sciences, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi-110 067, India
Abstract: Support vector machine is originally designed for binary classification. In literature k-class SVM is constructed using One against All, One against One and Decision tree based SVM using Euclidean and Mahalanobis distance. To maintain high generalization ability, the most separable classes should be separated at the upper nodes of decision tree. The ratio of interclass and intraclass scatters is one of the most commonly used distance measure for class separability in pattern recognition community. In this paper, we propose decision tree SVM framework with class separability measured by ratio of interclass and intraclass scatters. It is shown that the decision tree based SVM requires less computation time in comparison to conventional One against All SVM. Experimental results on UCI repository dataset demonstrates equivalent or better performance of our proposed decision tree scheme in comparison to conventional One against All SVM in terms of classification accuracy for most of the datasets. The proposed scheme outperforms conventional One against All SVM in terms of computation time for both training and testing phase. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.
Author Keywords: Class separability; Decision tree; Euclidean distance; Kernel function; Support vector machine

Authors: John J., Manchanda R.
Title: A computational study on effects of pairing BAPs and EPSPs in medium spiny neurons of nucleus accumbens
Source title: International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Pattern Recognition 2009, AIPR 2009
Affiliations: School of Biosciences and Bioengineering, Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Mumbai, India
Authors with affiliations: John, J., School of Biosciences and Bioengineering, Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Mumbai, India; Manchanda, R., School of Biosciences and Bioengineering, Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Mumbai, India
Abstract: Nucleus accumbens (NAc) or ventral striatum is a major site of action for many drugs of abuse and is implicated in mood disorders and schizophrenia. It is a critical structure of brain reward circuit acting as a limbic/motor interface to decide whether a goal is worth pursuing. Responses of medium spiny (MS) neurons, which constitute the principal cells in striatum, changes during reward related behavior. Because of the tiny structure of these neurons, experimental studies on biophysical properties of these neurons are very sparse (very few in dorsal striatum) and such studies have not yet been conducted in MS neurons of NAc. Here we use a computational model to investigate whether the pairing of excitatory postsynaptic potentials (EPSPs) and backpropagating action potentials (BAPs) results in a non linear calcium influx that is NMDA dependent. It is found that, similar to other central neurons, pairing EPSPs and BAPs results in enhanced calcium entry which is NMDA dependent during normal as well as bursting modes of firing in NAc MS neurons.
Index Keywords: Action potentials; Biophysical properties; Computational model; Computational studies; Critical structures; Excitatory post synaptic potentials; Experimental studies; Nucleus accumbens; Artificial intelligence; Brain; Calcium; Electrophysiology; Pattern recognition; Neurons

Title: Ophthalmology medical expert system using artificial intelligence techniques
Source title: Proceedings of the 2009 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, ICAI 2009

College of Engg., Andhra University, Visakhapatnam-530003, Andhra Pradesh, India; Mrudula, P.; Ramjee, M., Vignan's Nirula Institute of Technology and Sciences, Guntur, Andhra Pradesh, India
Abstract: Artificial Intelligence is a new generation Computing Technology and Capability. An Expert System, a typical AJ system, has a large Knowledge Base (KB) and allows the user to interact and simulates the knowledge and expertise of a human expert. A medical expert system takes the patient details as input and consults the knowledge base and finally displays the diagnosis, recommended treatment and health advice to the patients. This paper 'Ophthalmology Medical Expert System using Artificial Intelligent Techniques' is a rule based expert system developed using backward chaining mechanism and collecting the expert knowledge in the form of rules and facts, from a domain expert. Ophthalmology expert advisoty system using artificial intelligent techniques is a web based java application aimed at providing eye related information, health advice to the rural people at their door steps.

Authors: Mulay P., Kulkarni P.
Title: Incremental learning using incremental clustering based on adaptive closeness factor (ACF)
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Bharati Vidyapeeth University, Pune, India; Capsilon India, Pune, India
Authors with affiliations: Mulay, P., Bharati Vidyapeeth University, Pune, India; Kulkarni, P., Capsilon India, Pune, India
Abstract: Data warehouses provide a great deal of opportunities for performing data mining tasks such as classification and clustering. Typically, updates are collected and applied to the data warehouse periodically in a batch mode. e.g.. during the night. Then, all patterns derived from the warehouse by some data mining algorithm have to be updated as well. Due to the very large size of the databases it is highly desirable to perform these updates incrementally. In this paper, we present the first proposed basic clustering algorithm and then incremental clustering algorithm. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.

Authors: Kranthi R.B., Sarvabhotla K., Varma V.
Title: Classification based approach for summarizing opinions in blog posts
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: International Institute of Information Technology, Hyderabad, India
Authors with affiliations: Kranthi, R.B., International Institute of Information Technology, Hyderabad, India; Sarvabhotla, K., International Institute of Information Technology, Hyderabad, India; Varma, V., International Institute of Information Technology, Hyderabad, India
Abstract: With the growth of web, people are using it as a medium for expressing their opinions, thoughts through blog posts, reviews (in the form of ratings), and forums. Blogosphere is a place where people read, write their views and make comments on others views or thoughts there by exchanging information. It will be very difficult for any business, organization or individual to go through and understand thoughts expressed by others on a product or topic which they are interested in. Hence a summarization system which extracts, analyze and summarize opinions will be useful. Our Summarization system exactly does the same for blog posts. The entire process of summary generation is done in three stages, extract sentences which are sources for opinion (Opinion Mining), then analyze the extracted opinions to determine polarity (Opinion Analysis) and finally ranking the opinion sentences (Opinion Summarization). We present a classification based approach for extracting and analyzing opinions and how we use this approach to rank sentences for generating summary. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.
Author Keywords: Classification; Polarity estimation; Word association
Index Keywords: Blogospheres; Opinion analysis; Opinion mining; Polarity estimation; Summarization systems; Summary generation; Word association; Artificial intelligence; Classification (of information); Blogs

Authors: Ghimire Bholn N.S., Janga Reddy M.
Title: Application of machine learning techniques to predict the suspended sediment load in rivers
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Departmenr of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Powai, Mumbai -400076, India
Authors with affiliations: Ghimire Bholn, N.S., Departmenr of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Powai, Mumbai -400076, India; Janga Reddy, M., Departmenr of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Powai, Mumbai -400076, India
Abstract: This paper presents two recent machine learning techniques namely Model Tree (MT) and Gene Expression Programming (GEP) to predict suspended sediment Loads (SSL) in river. MT is a kind of decision tree, which has the capability to predict the numeric values with linear regression function at the leaves, whereas GEP is an extension of genetic programming which uses population of individuals and "survival of the fittest" concept for its evolution, with one or more genetic operators. By using MT and GEP methods, the relationships between SSL and river discharges are established for a case study. To evaluate the performance of developed models, the model results are compared with the results of conventional methods such as sediment raring curve (SRC) and multiple linear regression (MLR) techniques. The statistical measures (coefficient of determination, R2 and root mean square error, RMSE) show that MT gives good performance as compared to the SRC, MLR and GEP models. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.

Authors: Thomas J., Ghose D.
Title: Strategies for locating multiple odor sources using glowworm swarm optimization
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India
Authors with affiliations: Thomas, J., Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India; Ghose, D., Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India
Abstract: In this paper, we propose a swarm algorithm which acquires information from odor patches and utilizes it to locate the odor source. The algorithm utilizes an intelligent integration of the chemotaxis, anemo- taxis and spiralling approaches, where the chemotactic behavior is im-plemented by the recently proposed Glowworm Swarm Optimization (GSO) algorithm. Agents switch between chemotactic, anemotactic, and spiralling modes in accordance with the information available from the environment for optimal performance. An important feature of the algorithm is the use of maximum concentration encountered in the recent past for navigation, which is seen to improve algorithmic performance significantly. We have shown the simultaneous capture of multiple odor sources by the proposed algorithm. The proposed approach for capturing multiple odor sources is later tested on data obtained from a dye mixing experiment. It is also seen capable of locating odor source under varying wind conditions. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.

Authors: Rai J.K., Negi A., Wankar R., Nayak K.D.
Title: Using machine learning to characterize L2 cache behavior of programs on multicore processors
Source title: International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Pattern Recognition 2009, AIPR 2009
Affiliations: ANURAG, Hyderabad, India; Department of Computer and Information Sciences, University of Hyderabad, Hyderabad, India
Authors with affiliations: Rai, J.K., ANURAG, Hyderabad, India, Department of Computer and Information Sciences, University of Hyderabad, Hyderabad, India; Negi, A., Department of Computer and Information Sciences, University of Hyderabad, Hyderabad, India; Wankar, R., Department of Computer and Information Sciences, University of Hyderabad, Hyderabad, India; Nayak, K.D., ANURAG, Hyderabad, India
Abstract: Contention for shared L2 caches between the programs running on multicores has been a problem degrading the performance. Potential solutions proposed by researchers to alleviate the problem include scheduling policies at the level of operating systems and cache partitioning policies at the level of hardware. At the core of framing policies to manage the contention lies knowing the characteristics of a running program with reference to its utilization of shared L2 caches. In this work we study the L2 cache behavior of the programs by collecting various performance events from hardware performance counters on Intel quad-core Xeon X5482 processor. We used machine learning to derive the model to predict the L2 cache behavior (solo run L2 cache stress) of the program. We obtained the results with correlation coefficient 0.99, mean absolute error 0.75 and root mean squared error 1.24. During the work we observed that the selection of attributes plays a significant role in the success of a machine learning algorithm.
Index Keywords: Correlation coefficient; Hardware performance counters; Mean absolute error; Multi-core processor; Potential solutions; Root mean squared errors; Scheduling policies; Selection of attributes; Artificial intelligence; Cache memory; Hardware; Learning algorithms; Learning systems; Microprocessor chips; Pattern recognition; Multicore programming

Authors: Srivastava P.R., Vijay A., Bariikha B., Senear P.S., Sharma R.
Title: An optimized technique for test case generation and prioritization using "tabu" search and data clustering
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Computer Science and Information System Group, BITS PILANI, Pilani, 333031, India
Authors with affiliations: Srivastava, P.R., Computer Science and Information System Group, BITS PILANI, Pilani, 333031, India; Vijay, A., Computer Science and Information System Group, BITS PILANI, Pilani, 333031, India; Bariikha, B., Computer Science and Information System Group, BITS PILANI, Pilani, 333031, India; Senear, P.S., Computer Science and Information System Group, BITS PILANI, Pilani, 333031, India; Sharma, R., Computer Science and Information System Group, BITS PILANI, Pilani, 333031, India
Abstract: In practice, an available testing budget limits the number of test cases that can be executed over particular software. This paper presents a "Tabu" search algorithm for the automatic generation of software test cases and their prioritization through clustering technique of data mining. The developed test case generator has a cost function for intensifying the search and another for diversifying the search, used when the intensification is not successful. It also combines the use of memory with a backtracking process to avoid getting stuck in local minima. Test case prioritization technique schedules test cases in an order that increases their effectiveness in meeting some performance goal. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.

Title: A rule based medical expert system on cardiology
Source title: Proceedings of the 2009 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, ICAI 2009
Affiliations: Department of CS and SE, A.U. College of Engg., Andhra University, Visakhapatnam-530003, Andhra Pradesh, India; Internal Medicine, Visakhapatnam, Andhra Pradesh, India; Department of Computer Applications, G.V.P. Degree College(A), Visakhapatnam-530045, Andhra Pradesh, India

Degree College(A), Visakhapatnam-530045, Andhra Pradesh, India
Abstract: Expert Systems are intelligent computer applications that provide decision support through acquisition and processing of human expert knowledge. Several sets of rules and facts have been constructed by interviewing the different medical experts in the field of cardiology. The present system takes the patient details as input in the form of queries and interacts with the knowledge base and finally displays the diagnosis, recommended treatment and health advices to the users. It also helps the end user by providing static information about the common diseases, common symptoms, drugs, investigations and health services in the field of cardiology. The information system uses forward chaining mechanism and the advisory system uses the backward chaining. The system was tested by uploading it into www, bharathgramarogya.net website which was launched in the internet.

Authors: Srivastava P.R., Ray M.P.
Title: Multi-attribute comparison of automated functional and regression testing tools using fuzzy AHP
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Computer Science and Information System Group, BITS Pilani, Pilani, 333031, India
Authors with affiliations: Srivastava, P.R., Computer Science and Information System Group, BITS Pilani, Pilani, 333031, India; Ray, M.P., Computer Science and Information System Group, BITS Pilani, Pilani, 333031, India
Abstract: Software Testing is a process used to help in improving quality and efficiency of a software product. In order to make the testing process less time consuming and efficient Automated Testing Tools are being used. The correct choice of an automated testing tool is a critical success factor for the developed product to reach and maintain market leadership. Li the current paper a model for selecting an automated functional and regression testing tool using the Fuzzy Analytical Hierarchy Process (FAHP) is presented. The FAHP is used to compare the Testing Tools. The means of the triangular Fuzzy numbers produced by the experts from different CMM level 5 organizations were successfully used in the pair-wise comparison matrix. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.
Author Keywords: Automated testing tool; Functional and regression testing tool; Fuzzy analytic hierarchy process (FAHP); Multi-criteria decision analysis (MCDA); Software testing
Index Keywords: Automated testing tools; Critical success factor; Fuzzy AHP; Fuzzy analytic hierarchy process; Fuzzy analytical hierarchy process; Level 5; Market leadership; Multi-attributes; Multi-criteria decision analysis; Pair-wise comparison; Regression testing; Software products; Testing process; Testing tools; Triangular fuzzy numbers; Artificial intelligence; Fuzzy sets; Software testing

Authors: Mishra D., Rath A.K., Acharya M.
Title: Finding coherent bi-clusters from microarray data by imitating the ecosystem: An ant colony algorithmic approach
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Institute of Technical Education and Research, Siksha 'O' Anusandhan University, Bhubaneswar, Orissa, India; College of Engineering Bhubaneswar, Bhubaneswar, Orissa, India
Authors with affiliations: Mishra, D., Institute of Technical Education and Research, Siksha 'O' Anusandhan University, Bhubaneswar, Orissa, India; Rath, A.K., College of Engineering Bhubaneswar, Bhubaneswar, Orissa, India; Acharya, M., Institute of Technical Education and Research, Siksha 'O' Anusandhan University, Bhubaneswar, Orissa, India
Abstract: Microarray technology is a powerful tool for geneticists to monitor interactions among teas of thousands of genes simultaneously. There has been extensive research on coherent subspace clustering of gene expressions measured under consistent experimental settings. However, these methods assume that all experiments are run using the same batch of microarray chips with similar characteristics of noise. Algorithms developed under this assumption may not be applicable for analyzing data collected from heterogeneous settings, where the set of genes being monitored may be different and expression levels may not be directly comparable even for the same gene. In this paper, we propose a bi-clustering model that imitates the ecosystem taking into account the features of biological data for mining subspace coherent patterns from heterogeneous gene expression data. We have implemented the system using an Ant Colony algorithm The system decides the number of bi-clusters automatically. The system processes the input biological data, runs the Ant Colony Algorithm, assigns bi-clusters to the genes and conditions simultaneously and displays the output. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.
Author Keywords: Ant colony optimization (ACO); Bi-clusters; Microarray
Index Keywords: Algorithmic approach; Ant colonies; Ant colony algorithms; Ant Colony Optimization (ACO); Bi-clusters; Biological data; Expression levels; Gene Expression Data; Micro-array chips; Microarray data; Microarray technologies; Subspace clustering; System process; Artificial intelligence; Clustering algorithms; Ecosystems; Microarrays; Gene expression

Authors: Ray S.K., Singh S., Joshi B.P.
Title: Question classification - A semantic approach using wordnet and wikipedia
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Birla Institute of Technology, Muscat, Oman; Samsung India Software Centre, Noida, India; Birla Institute of Technology, Noida, India
Authors with affiliations: Ray, S.K., Birla Institute of Technology, Muscat, Oman; Singh, S., Samsung India Software Centre, Noida, India; Joshi, B.P., Birla Institute of Technology, Noida, India
Abstract: Question Answering Systems are providing answers to the users' questions in succinct form where Question classification module of a Question Answering System plays a very important role in pinpointing the exact answer of the question. In literature, incorrect question classification lias been cited as one of the major causes of poor performance of the Question Answering Systems and this emphasizes on the importance of question classification module designing. In this paper, we have proposed a question classification method that combines the powerful semantic features of the WordNet and the vast knowledge repository of the Wikipedia to describe informative terms explicitly. We have trained our method over a standard set of 5500 questions (by UIUC) and then tested over 5 TREC question collections and compared our results. Our system's average question classification accuracy is 89.55% in comparison of 80.2% by Zhang and Lee [17], 84.2% by Li and Roth [7], 89.2% by Huang [6]. The question classification accuracy suggests the effectiveness of the method which is promising in the field of open domain question classification. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.
Author Keywords: And wikipedia; Question answering systems; Question classification; Wordnet
Index Keywords: Informative terms; Knowledge repository; Poor performance; Question answering systems; Question classification; Semantic approach; Semantic features; Wikipedia; Wordnet; Artificial intelligence; Ontology; Semantics; Websites

Authors: Tayal A., Saggi M., Bhattacharjee A., Kumar A., Balasubramaniam R.
Title: A decision theory based multimodal biometric authentication system: Iris and speech recognition
Source title: International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Pattern Recognition 2009, AIPR 2009

Abstract: This paper proposes a multimodal biometric system that exploits the uniqueness of the iris pattern and pitch period estimation using wavelet processing. Through the implementation of Daubechies wavelets (Db3 and Db4) in the analysis of the iris pattern and speech identification we endeavor to develop an authentication system that has a higher success rate than either Iris recognition or Speech Identification individually.

Authors: Phadikar A., Maity S.P.
Title: Image error concealment based on data hiding using dual-tree complex wavelets
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Department of Infomiation Technology, MCKV Institute of Engineering, Liluah, Howrah, 7Yl204, India; Department of Information Technology, Bengal Engineering and Science University, Shibpur, Howrah 711 103, India
Authors with affiliations: Phadikar, A., Department of Infomiation Technology, MCKV Institute of Engineering, Liluah, Howrah, 7Yl204, India; Maity, S.P., Department of Information Technology, Bengal Engineering and Science University, Shibpur, Howrah 711 103, India
Abstract: In this paper, we propose an efficient quantization index modulation (QIM) based data hiding scheme using dual-tree complex wavelet transform (DTCWT) for the application of image error concealment. The goal is achieved by embedding important information (image digest) which is extracted from the original image itself, and is used to introduce sufficient redundancy in the transmitted image. Half-toning technique is applied to obtain image digest from its low-resolution version. At the decoder side, the extracted image digest is used to correct the damaged regions. DTCWT, instead of conventional discrete wavelet transform (DWT), is used to decompose the original image in order to achieve two-fold advantages viz. (1) high embedding capacity due to inherent redundancy that leads to the better reconstruction of high volume missing data, and (2) better imperceptibly after data embedding since DTCWT most closely captures HYS (human visual system) characteristics than conventional DWT. Experimental results duly support the effectiveness of the proposed scheme. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.
Author Keywords: Data hiding; DTCWT; Error concealment; Half-toning; Image digest; QIM
Index Keywords: Data hiding; DTCWT; Error concealment; Halftoning; Image digest; QIM; Artificial intelligence; Discrete wavelet transforms; Steganography; Image processing

Authors: Ghumbre S.U., Ghatol A.A.
Title: Supervised learning approach for prediction of Hepatitis B disease
Source title: Proceedings of the 2009 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, ICAI 2009
Affiliations: College of Engineering, Pune, (COEP), Pune Maharashtra, India; Dr. B.A.T. University, Lonere, Maharashtra, India
Authors with affiliations: Ghumbre, S.U., College of Engineering, Pune, (COEP), Pune Maharashtra, India; Ghatol, A.A., Dr. B.A.T. University, Lonere, Maharashtra, India
Abstract: In spite of all standardization efforts, medical diagnosis is still considered as an art. A great deal of this status is owed to the fact that medical diagnosis requires a proficiency in coping with uncertainty merely not found in today's computing machinery. This research is performed for the search of substitutes to the resolution of complex medical diagnosis where human knowledge is detained in a general fashion. Successful application examples have shown that human diagnostic capabilities are significantly not as good as the neural diagnostic system. For medical problems, a reasonably high-quality solution could be given by the neural network algorithms. Application of artificial neural networks in typical disease Hepatitis B diagnosis has been investigated in this paper. In this work, we presented an intelligent system for Hepatitis B diagnosis using a standard Feed forward network with Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) structure and Back propagation algorithm. The results obtained have revealed that neural network can be successfully used for the diagnosis of hepatitis B. Thus, neural network techniques appear promising in the field of clinical diagnosis, and their applications, particularly in situations with complex data structures, should be investigated with more prominence.
Author Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Back propagation; Hepatitis B; Hepatitis B DNA; Hepatitis B surface antigen (AgHBs); Hepatitis B virus (HBV); Medical diagnosis; Multilayer Perceptron (MLP); Neural networks; Spiders; Spleen palpable

Title: PCA based feature extraction for text classification

Authors with affiliations: Chowdhury, N., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata - 700 032, India; Saha, D., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata - 700 032, India
Abstract: A PCA based feature extraction method for text classification is presented here. The proposed method can classify a set of text documents into a number of classes depending on then contents where the number of such classes is not known a priori. English and Bengali Text documents from various faculties of games and sports are considered for experimentation. The method is found to provide satisfactory results for large size of data. Authors: Tikhe S.S., Khare K.C., Londhe S.N.
Title: Forecasting RSPM using soft computing techniques
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: S. C. O. E., Pune Maharashtra State, India; C. O. E, Pune, Maharashtra State, India; I. I. T, Pune, Maharashtra State, India
Authors with affiliations: Tikhe, S.S., S. C. O. E., Pune Maharashtra State, India; Khare, K.C., C. O. E, Pune, Maharashtra State, India; Londhe, S.N., I. I. T, Pune, Maharashtra State, India
Abstract: Urban air pollution, especially during adverse atmospheric conditions causes acute environmental problems in densely populated cities. Forecasting of air quality parameters is a popular and important area of atmospheric and environmental research now a days due to health concerns caused as a result of exposure to air pollutants in urban air. The accurate models for air pollutant predictions are needed because such models would allow forecasting and diagnosing potential compliance or non-compliance with pollutant concentration standards in both short term & long term aspects. The present study aims at forecasting Respirable Suspended Particulate Matter (RSPM) concentration at one of the populated locations in Pune of Maharashtra state, India with a lead time of one day using the soft computing techniques of Artificial Neural Networks and Genetic Programming. It has been found that both the models work well with reasonable accuracy, for forecasting with Genetic Programming working better than ANN especially at peaks. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.

Authors: Kumar M.K.R.
Title: A two layered bayesian model to prioritize emails
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Birla Institute of Technology and Science, Pilani, Rajasthan, India
Authors with affiliations: Kumar, M.K.R., Birla Institute of Technology and Science, Pilani, Rajasthan, India
Abstract: Unsolicited Bulk Email, or spam, has shocked economies world over and is threatening the productivity. In this paper an attempt has been made to prioritize emails by using a modified Bayesian Cognitive approach for prioritizing emails. Here, a two-layer Bayesian network has been used to categorize emails based on two different kinds of extracted header metadata. Email Metadata like the sender details, subject and origin IP etc. formed the first class: whereas, the content of the Email body was used to generate the other metadata that helped to indicate the Email was spam. In this paper, we propose. Two-Layer Bayesian Classification Network (TLBCN) as a possible solution for reliable spam-filter design. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.

Authors: Prajapati G.L., Chaudhari N.S., Chandwani M.
Title: An improved model for learning context-free grammars based on tree automata
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Department of Computer Engineering, Institute of Engineering and Technology, Devi Ahilya University, Khandwa Road, Indore- 452001, India; School of Computer Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, 50 Nanyang Avenue, Singapore- 639798, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Prajapati, G.L., Department of Computer Engineering, Institute of Engineering and Technology, Devi Ahilya University, Khandwa Road, Indore- 452001, India; Chaudhari, N.S., School of Computer Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, 50 Nanyang Avenue, Singapore- 639798, Singapore; Chandwani, M., Department of Computer Engineering, Institute of Engineering and Technology, Devi Ahilya University, Khandwa Road, Indore- 452001, India
Abstract: We study the problem of learning context-free grammars from positive samples of their structural descriptions based on tree automata model proposed by Sakakibara (1992), where a structural description of a context-free grammar is an unlabelled derivation tree of the grammar. We present a learning scheme for context-free grammars from positive- only examples, and it is shown that it leads to be significantly more efficient compared to the work of Sakakibara in this framework. We also demonstrate examples and present a summary of our experiments carried out to see how our results compare with those of Sakakibara. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.

Authors: Karthikeyani Visalakshi N., Thangavel K., Alagambigai P.
Title: Distributed fuzzy clustering using cluster ensemble
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, Vellalar College for Women, Erode, Tamil Nadu, India; Department Computer Science, Periyar University, Salem, Tamil Nadu, India; Department of Computer Application, Eswari Engineering College, Chennai, Tamil Nadu, India
Authors with affiliations: Karthikeyani Visalakshi, N., Department of Computer Science, Vellalar College for Women, Erode, Tamil Nadu, India; Thangavel, K., Department Computer Science, Periyar University, Salem, Tamil Nadu, India; Alagambigai, P., Department of Computer Application, Eswari Engineering College, Chennai, Tamil Nadu, India
Abstract: The distributed clustering algorithm is used to cluster the distributed datasets without necessarily downloading all the data into a single place. Many applications can benefit from frizzy clustering, where each object is assigned to multiple clusters with membership weight that sum to one. This paper proposes a novel ensemble based distributed frizzy clustering algorithm to produce frizzy clusters among homogeneously distributed datasets. The frizzy C-Means technique is used to cluster local datasets. Two novel approaches of centroid based ensemble methods are introduced to generate global centroid. which is used to generate global frizzy clusters in distributed environment. Their performance is evaluated against traditional centralized clustering approach. The experiments are earned out for various datasets of UCI machine learning data repository. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.
