Authors: Kashid S.S., Maity R.
Title: Hydroclimatological approach for monthly basin scale streamflow prediction using genetic programming
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Powai, Mumbai - 400076, India; Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Kharagpur, Kharagpur - 721302, West Bengal, India
Authors with affiliations: Kashid, S.S., Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Powai, Mumbai - 400076, India; Maity, R., Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Kharagpur, Kharagpur - 721302, West Bengal, India
Abstract: The concept of hydroclimatological teleconnection has been applied for monthly monsoon streamflow prediction, with help of artificial intelligence tool Genetic Programming (GP). The rainfall distribution over the continents is proved to be linked with Sea Surface Temperature (SST) and various large-scale atmospheric circulation patterns across the globe. Hence, the basin-scale streamflow is also expected to be influenced by these large-scale climatological factors, which is investigated in this paper for the Narmada River basin. The basin scale streamflow accumulation process over a catchment is always very complex, which may not be revealed very easily. This complexity is due to the varying spatial distribution of rainfall under different storm events, complex catchment characteristics, different land-use patterns, evapo-transpiration and water retention over the basin, etc. In spite of this complexity, intensity and spatial distribution of rainfall plays a major role behind the streamflow variation, provided the other factors more or less remain constant over a sufficiently small temporal span (say monthly). Oceans happen to be the major source of moisture for the precipitation on continents. The information of El Nino-southern oscillation (ENSO) from the tropical Pacific Ocean and Equatorial Indian Ocean oscillation (EQUIXOO) from the tropical Indian Ocean is investigated for their possible influence behind the monthly streamflow variation of Narmada River Basin. The efficacy of Artificial Intelligence (AI) tool genetic programming, for the prediction of monthly streamflow through the concept of hydroclimatological approach is also studied. The results indicate that GP-derived basin scale monsoon streamflow forecasting models that use historical average of monthly streamflow and the large-scale atmospheric circulation information as inputs are quite satisfactory. The adjusted adjusted r-square value for monthly monsoon streamflow (June through October) in case of Narmada River was found to be 0.808 for training and 0.805 for testing, which is quite promising for such a complex system. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.
Author Keywords: El nino-southern oscillation (ENSO); Equatorial indian ocean oscillation (EQUINOO); Genetic programming (GP); Hydroclimatology; Streamflow prediction
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence tools; Atmospheric circulation; Atmospheric circulation patterns; Basin scale; Catchment characteristics; Climatological factors; El Nino southern oscillation; Equatorial Indian Ocean; EQUINOO; Hydroclimatology; Land-use patterns; Narmada River; R square; Rainfall distribution; Sea surface temperature (SST); Storm events; Streamflow forecasting; Streamflow prediction; Teleconnections; Tropical Indian ocean; Tropical Pacific ocean; Water retention; Artificial intelligence; Atmospheric temperature; Atmospheric thermodynamics; Catchments; Climatology; Forecasting; Genetic programming; Ocean currents; Rain; Runoff; Spatial distribution; Watersheds; Stream flow

Authors: Shekar B.H., Sharmila Kumarr M., Shivakumara P.
Title: SIFT-PCA: An efficient and accurate face representation and recognition model
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, Mangalore University, Karnataka, India; Department of Computer Science and Engineering, P A College of Engineering, Mangalore, Karnataka, India; School of Computing, National University of Singapore, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Shekar, B.H., Department of Computer Science, Mangalore University, Karnataka, India; Sharmila Kumarr, M., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, P A College of Engineering, Mangalore, Karnataka, India; Shivakumara, P., School of Computing, National University of Singapore, Singapore
Abstract: In this paper, a new technique called SIFT-PCA is devised for efficient and accurate face representation and recognition. Discriminative SIFT descriptors are extracted for compact representation. Unlike PCA-SIFT that employs PCA on normalized gradient patch, we employ PCA on smoothed weighted histograms. The proposed model has better computing performance in terms of recognition rate than the basic SIFT model. To establish the superiority of the proposed model, we have experimentally compared the performance of our new algorithm with recently proposed (2D)2-PCA on the benchmark databases: AT&T and UMIST face datasets. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.

Authors: Das D., Bandyopadhyay S.
Title: Analyzing emotion in blog and news at word and sentence level
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata-700032, India
Authors with affiliations: Das, D., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata-700032, India; Bandyopadhyay, S., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata-700032, India
Abstract: Emotion is crucial to identify as it is not open to any objective observation or verification, hi this paper, emotion analysis on blog texts has been carried out for a less privileged language. Bengali and the same system has been applied on the English SemEval 2007 affect sensing corpus containing only news headlines. A set of six emotion tags, namely, happy, sad, anger, fear, disgust and surprise, have been selected towards this emotion detection task for reliable and semi-automatic annotation of blog and news data. Conditional Random Field (CRF) based classifier has been applied for recognizing six basic emotion tags for different words of a sentence. The classifier accuracy has been improved by arranging an equal distribution of emotional tags and non- emotional tag. A score based technique has been adopted to calculate and assign tag weights to each of the six emotion tags. A sense based scoring strategy has been applied to identify sentence level emotion scores for the six emotion tags based on the acquired word level emotion tags. Sentence level emotion tagging has been carried out based on the maximum obtained sentence level emotion scores. Evaluation has been conducted for each emotion class separately on 200 test sentences from each of the Bengali blog and English news data. The system has resulted accuracies of 64.28% and 65.80% for happy. 66.42% and 60.42% for sad, 60.28% and 59.28% for anger, 72.18% and 63.60% for disgust. 67.14% and 67.54% for fear and 66.45% and 61.14% for surprise emotion classes on blog and news test data respectively. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.

Authors: Banati H., Bajaj M.
Title: Feature based implicit user modeling
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Dval Singh College, University of Delhi, New Delhi, India; Department of Computer Sceince, University of Delhi, New Delhi, India
Authors with affiliations: Banati, H., Dval Singh College, University of Delhi, New Delhi, India; Bajaj, M., Department of Computer Sceince, University of Delhi, New Delhi, India
Abstract: The cut throat competitive environment of E-Commerce dictates implicit understanding of user interest and need. The process of collecting storing and representing the user information is known as user profiling User profiling helps in better understanding of user behavior and interest. It enables the organization to provide the right product to the right person according to the user need. The paper proposes a preferential strategy to implicitly estimate the user interest. It presents a dynamic feature based user profile generation method that determines the customer's interest by analyzing the time spent on each product. User's preference for particular feature in particular category is determined by assigning appropriate weights to each feature and category. In an era of changing demand, this approach thus helps in dynamic customization of the system. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.

Authors: Adarsh S., Janga Reddy M.
Title: Chance constrained optimal design of composite channels using stochastic search algorithms
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Bomaby, Powai, Mumabi-400076, India
Authors with affiliations: Adarsh, S., Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Bomaby, Powai, Mumabi-400076, India; Janga Reddy, M., Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Bomaby, Powai, Mumabi-400076, India
Abstract: Optimal design of irrigation channels has an important role in the planning and management of irrigation projects. The input parameters of design of irrigation channels are p|rone to uncertainty and it may cause failure of channels. To improve the overall reliability and cost effectiveness the optimal design of trapezoidal composite channels is performed as a chance constrained problem. The chance constrained model minimizes the cost and maximizes the probability of the channel capacity greater than the design flow. The optimization model is a highly non-linear and non-convex one having multimodal behavior. In this paper, the usefulness of two stochastic search algorithms such as Genetic Algorithms (GA) and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) are investigated to obtain the optimal solutions. The study also considers two site specific cases such as restricted top width and restricted flow depth. Both the algorithms performs equally well in giving optimal solutions and handling the additional constraints. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.

Authors: Marwaha S., Bedi P., Yadav R., Malik N.
Title: Diseases and pests identification in crops - A semantic web approach
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Division of Computer Applications, Indian Agricultural Statistics Research Institute, New Delhi, India; Department of Computer Science, University of Delhi, Delhi, India
Authors with affiliations: Marwaha, S., Division of Computer Applications, Indian Agricultural Statistics Research Institute, New Delhi, India; Bedi, P., Department of Computer Science, University of Delhi, Delhi, India; Yadav, R., Department of Computer Science, University of Delhi, Delhi, India; Malik, N., Department of Computer Science, University of Delhi, Delhi, India
Abstract: Pests and diseases cause major economic losses to the fanners. The estimate loss per annum due to diseases and pests in a country like India touches to billions of Rupees. Most of the time fanners use over dosages of pesticides and fungicides to save their crop and thus cause environmental hazards. In the presented approach an ontology based expert system is designed to help farmers to take appropriate decisions and disseminate need based research find in as to millions of the fanners at a time, which is neither feasible nor practical by conventional system of extension. In conventional architecture of expert system, knowledge engineers along with domain experts build the knowledgebase manually and these expert systems are known to be working within a narrow domain of knowledge. But for building the expert system in agriculture for a vast and diverse country like India, the conventional approaches fail to meet the need of the fanners. Semantic Web with its enriched set of tools promises for such a solution. The presented system has a dynamic knowledgebase and it updates itself from multiple domain ontologies distributed over the Web. The system act as a tool for transferring the site and crop specific knowledge of various domain experts to the farmers. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.

Authors: Bonde S.V., Nandedkar A.V.
Title: Classification of VEP responses containing cognitive component (P300) using reflex fuzzy min-max neural network
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: S. G. G. S. Institute of Engineering and Technology, Nanded, India
Authors with affiliations: Bonde, S.V., S. G. G. S. Institute of Engineering and Technology, Nanded, India; Nandedkar, A.V., S. G. G. S. Institute of Engineering and Technology, Nanded, India
Abstract: This paper proposes a classification method to detect Visual Evoked Potentials (VEP) related to cognitive component P300. Detection of such response is essential in Brain-Computer Interface systems. The transformed (Time-Frequency) domain features of average and single trial VEP signals were extracted for classification. Reflex Fuzzy Min-Max Neural Network is used for this purpose. Experimental results show that features of average VEP signals gives better classification accuracy compared to single trial VEP signals. Moreover it is observed that the transformed domain post-stimulus coefficients on approximate level are sufficient for the discrimination process. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.

Authors: Vasan A., Srinivasa Raju K.
Title: Comparative assessment of non-traditional optimization methods in irrigation planning
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Civil Engineering Group, Birla Institute of Technology and Science-Pilani, Hyderabad Campus, Jawahar Nagar, Shameerpet Mandal, RR District, Andlira Pradesh 500 078, India
Authors with affiliations: Vasan, A., Civil Engineering Group, Birla Institute of Technology and Science-Pilani, Hyderabad Campus, Jawahar Nagar, Shameerpet Mandal, RR District, Andlira Pradesh 500 078, India; Srinivasa Raju, K., Civil Engineering Group, Birla Institute of Technology and Science-Pilani, Hyderabad Campus, Jawahar Nagar, Shameerpet Mandal, RR District, Andlira Pradesh 500 078, India
Abstract: The present paper compares four non-traditional optimization methods, namely, Real-coded Genetic Algorithm (RGA), Differential Evolution (DE), Simulated Annealing (SA) and Simulated Quenching (SQ) in the irrigation planning scenario for the case study of Main Bajaj Sagar Project (MBSP). India. Mathematical model is developed with the objective of maximizing annual net benefits and subjected to number of constraints. Model is tested for 594, 360, 726 and 726 scenarios i.e., various combination of relevant parameters in RGA, DE, SA and SQ for achieving relevant optimal scenario. The CPU time requirements (based on PC with Pentium IV 2.4GHz 256MB RAM/40GB HDD) for achieving optimal scenario in case of RGA, DE, SA and SQ are 108 seconds, 179.14 seconds. 685.38 seconds and 418.99 seconds respectively. It is found that total area irrigated for optimal scenario in case of RGA/SA/SQ and DE is 67736 hectare, 67615 hectare with corresponding net benefits of Rs.113.15 crores and Rs.112.95 crores with net benefits per hectare remains almost same. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.

Title: Unconstrained handwritten character recognition - An approach based on fourier transform and neural networks
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Dept of Computer Science and Engg., Bhaubali College of Engineering, Shravanabelgola, Karnataka, India; Dept of Computer Science and Engineering, Godhavari Institute of Engg and Technology, Rajamundri, Andhra Pradesh, India; MGNIRSA, Gagan Mahal Road, Domalguda, Hyderabad, India; Dept of Studies in Computer Science, University of Mysore, Mysore, India; Dept of ISE, Dayananda Sagar College of Engineering, Bangalore, India

Abstract: In this paper, recognition system for totally unconstrained handwritten characters for south Indian language of Kannada is proposed. The proposed feature extraction technique is based on Fourier Transform and well known Principal Component Analysis (PCA). The system trains the appropriate frequency band images followed by PCA feature extraction scheme. For subsequent classification technique, Probabilistic Neural Network (PNN) is used. The proposed system is tested on Large database containing Kannada characters and also tested on standard COIL-20 object database and the results were found to be better compared to standard techniques. Title: Real time traffic sign recognition system as speed regulator in IAV
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009

Ltd., MPD Towers, DLF Qutab Enclave, Gurgaon-122002, India; Jung, H.G., Mando Coropration Global R and D H.Q., 413-5, Gomae-Dong, Giheung-Gu, Yongin-Si, Kyonggi-Do 446-901, South Korea; Na, H., Mando Coropration Global R and D H.Q., 413-5, Gomae-Dong, Giheung-Gu, Yongin-Si, Kyonggi-Do 446-901, South Korea
Abstract: This paper proposes a Traffic Sign Recognition (TSR) system which can automatically detect and classify the traffic signs in traffic scene images acquired from a moving car. This system first uses color based segmentation and then further refines the segments using two shape detection based techniques. A color description technique is used to extract the sign information from the segmented part which then finally classifies and recognizes as a traffic sign, using a trained feed forward neural network. The result of TSR research is also used as the subsystem of IAV (Intelligent Automated Vehicle) where it provide the facility of automated speed regulation by classifying the speed signs coming in the road way and passing the information to Microcontroller. Authors: Deshmukh K.S.
Title: Color image segmentation using fuzzy c-means clustering
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: M.G.M's College of CS and IT, Nanded (Maharashtra), India
Authors with affiliations: Deshmukh, K.S., M.G.M's College of CS and IT, Nanded (Maharashtra), India
Abstract: Abstract. linage segmentation is an important early vision task where pixels with similar features are grouped into homogeneous regions. An image segmentation system is proposed for the segmentation of color images using fuzzy c-means (FCM) clustering technique. The system uses perceptually uniform CIEL U V color space for segmentation. To speed up the segmentation algorithm and reduce the computational complexity for clustering, prominent pixels are selected. Clusters and their labels are automatically found out using FCM clustering technique. Fuzzy entropy criterion is used to evaluate an error of the system. The image pixels are classified to relevant clusters using minimum Euclidian distance. A post-processing filtering stage is applied to improve the segmentation quality. One of the advantages of this method is that it does not need to specify the priori information to segment color region besides: there is no apparently distortion or color change after segmentation. The proposed system is compared with other clustering techniques. Quantitative analysis of result is demonstrated. An application of the proposed system is presented. Experimental results show that the system has the desired ability for the segmentation of color images in a variety of vision tasks. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.
Author Keywords: Ciel*U*V* color space; Clustering based segmentation; Color image segmentation; Fuzzy clustering

Abstract: A Color and Texture based image retrieval is an approach for retrieving an image efficiently and effectively from Image Search Engine using the descriptions of image regions. In this paper we have implemented the region based algorithm to present the result to the user query. A cluster is a collection of regions that are coherent in their features. The features are the main component of the system to construct the signature and feature ranking. The features are Color, Texture of the clusters centroids. Another aspect of the system is its to support to retrieve the results by precision estimation and display the results in highest ranking order. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.

Title: Audio data mining for indian classical music by extracting raga patterns
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009

Abstract: Audio data mining is a technique which includes converting raw data, in the form of audio signals into a meaningful text/numerical data using digital signal processing techniques and then extracting useful patterns from it for knowledge discovery. The type of data considered for audio mining in our paper are music signals. In this paper, the automatic classification of musical signals into different musical ragas is explored The combination of several notes woven into a composition in a way which is pleasing to the ear is called a Raga or Melody in music.. More specifically, the feature sets for representing pitch content are proposed, which are represented as Matrix called as Note distribution count matrix. Using the proposed feature sets. Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) classification system of 98% for 21 musical ragas is achieved. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.

Authors: Srivastava R., Gore M.M.
Title: Mindex: A relevance measure for interval scaled attributes
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Computer Science and Engineering Department, Motilal Nehru National Institute of Technology, Allahabad-211004, Uttar Pradesh, India
Authors with affiliations: Srivastava, R., Computer Science and Engineering Department, Motilal Nehru National Institute of Technology, Allahabad-211004, Uttar Pradesh, India; Gore, M.M., Computer Science and Engineering Department, Motilal Nehru National Institute of Technology, Allahabad-211004, Uttar Pradesh, India
Abstract: All the attributes of a relation are not relevant for classification. To determine relevant attribute, an attribute relevance measure is required. A large number of attribute relevance measures exist for discrete attributes, but they are not efficient in determining relevance of interval scaled attributes. We propose an attribute relevance measure named Mindex for interval scaled attributes. To calculate Mindex for an attribute, the dataset is efficiently partitioned based on the possible values of the attribute. Partitioning of the dataset is done with the help of micro-clustering. Statistics of these partitions are used to determine relevance of the attribute. The experimental results for A4index on real and synthetic datasets indicate that it is better than the existing measures in determining relevance of interval scaled attributes. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.

Authors: Singh R., Das G.
Title: Optimization of rotary furnace parameters using NGOT
Source title: International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Pattern Recognition 2009, AIPR 2009
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Dayalbagh Educational Institute, Dayalbagh, Agra, India
Authors with affiliations: Singh, R., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Dayalbagh Educational Institute, Dayalbagh, Agra, India; Das, G., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Dayalbagh Educational Institute, Dayalbagh, Agra, India
Abstract: The rising demand for high quality homogenous castings necessitate that vast amount of manufacturing knowledge be incorporated in manufacturing systems. Rotary furnace involves several critical parameters like Excess Air, Flame Temperature, Rotational Speed of the Furnace Drum, Melting Time, Preheat Air Temperature, Fuel Consumption and Melting Rate of the molten metal which should be controlled throughout the melting process. A complex relationship exists between these manufacturing parameters and hence there is a need to develop models which can capture this complex interrelationship and enable fast computation. In the present work, we propose a generic approach where the applicability and effectiveness of Neural Network in function approximation is used for rapid estimation of melting rate and they are integrated into the framework of Genetic Evolutionary Algorithm to form a Neuro-Genetic Optimization Technique (NGOT). A Neural Network model is trained with the experimental results. The results indicate that the NGOT heuristic converges to better solutions rapidly as it provides the values of various process parameters for optimizing the objective in a single run and thus assists for the improvement of quality in development of sound parts. Key Words-Rotary Furnace, Neural Networks (NN), Genetic Algorithms (GA), Optimization, Neuro-Genetic Optimization Technique (NGOT).

Authors: Shelke S., Apte S.
Title: A new feature extraction technique for handwritten marathi character recognition using ANN
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Dept. of Electronics and Telecomm., PICT, Piuie 411 046, India; Dept. of Electronics and Telecomm., RSCOE, Piuie 411 033, India
Authors with affiliations: Shelke, S., Dept. of Electronics and Telecomm., PICT, Piuie 411 046, India; Apte, S., Dept. of Electronics and Telecomm., RSCOE, Piuie 411 033, India
Abstract: Handwritten character recognition has gained lot of attention of the researchers over the recent years due to its wide application areas and the challenges it puts forth. Moreover Indian handwritten languages are more critical to recognize due to their writing style, modifiers which exist above, below and in line with the character. Also two or more characters may be joined to form a conjunct character, making the task more difficult. Here in this paper, we discuss handwritten Marathi character recognition for all basic characters. Two methods were applied for extracting the features and applied to Artificial Neural Network for recognition First method of feature extraction was based on Fourier descriptors. Another new technique developed for extracting the features was based on spatial properties of the character. Results showed that the features derived using new technique gave far better recognition accuracy at a faster rate than the Fourier descriptors. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.

Authors: Venkateswaran J., Ali U.S.
Title: Improving the kNN by evidence theory with simple distance metric based neighborhood
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, Presidency College, Chennai, India; Research and Development Centre, Bharathiar University, Coimbatore, India
Authors with affiliations: Venkateswaran, J., Department of Computer Science, Presidency College, Chennai, India; Ali, U.S., Research and Development Centre, Bharathiar University, Coimbatore, India
Abstract: The k-nearest neighbor rule is one of the simplest and most attractive partem classification algorithm. However, it faces serious challenges when patterns of different classes overlap in some regions in the feature space. In the past, many researchers have developed various methods to improve its performance. In this paper, we propose an improved evidence theoretic kNN algorithm which combines Dempster Shafer theory of evidence and k Nearest neighbouring rale with distance metric based neighborhood. It is shown that the proposed algorithm significantly improves the performance of the k-nearest neighbor rale. In experiments this algorithm performed as well as or better than voting and distance weighted k nearest neighbours algorithms with best k. and it achieved highest performance when number of neighbours considered is seven. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.

Authors: Vig L., Adams J.A.
Title: The effect of coalition imbalance on multi-robot teams
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: School of Information Technology, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi 110067, India; EECS Department, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37212, United States
Authors with affiliations: Vig, L., School of Information Technology, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi 110067, India; Adams, J.A., EECS Department, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37212, United States
Abstract: The notion of coalition imbalance refers to the variance in the individual contributions of team members towards the completion of a multi-agent (robot) task. Until now, the literature has studied imbalance purely from a fault tolerance perspective where more balanced coalitions were shown to be more robust to individual robot failure. However, the effect that balancing has on the overall performance of a multi-robot team still remains unexplored. This paper attempts to identify the relationship between the imbalance level of a multi-robot team and team performance. Experiments were conducted with a simulated multi- robot soccer team to demonstrate that teams lying at the extremities of the performance spectrum tend to have a higher balance level. Latter sections of the paper describe experiments that were conducted to demonstrate how balance information may be utilized to improve overall team performance. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.
Index Keywords: Multi-robot teams; Performance spectrum; Robot soccer; Team members; Team performance; Artificial intelligence; Experiments; Fault tolerance; Multipurpose robots; Industrial robots

Authors: Pradhan S., Patra D.
Title: Unsupervised brain MR image segmentation using biased hidden markov random field model
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Dept. of Electrical Engg., IPCV Lab., National Institute of Technology, Rourkela, India; IEEE, India
Authors with affiliations: Pradhan, S., Dept. of Electrical Engg., IPCV Lab., National Institute of Technology, Rourkela, India; Patra, D., Dept. of Electrical Engg., IPCV Lab., National Institute of Technology, Rourkela, India, IEEE, India
Abstract: Current segmentation techniques of brain MR images improve segmentation accuracy by encoding spatial information through hidden Markov random field (HMRF) model. However, HMRF model has higher computational overhead compared to finite Gaussian mixture (FGM) model but the segmentation results are with no significant difference when applying to cleaner data. In this paper, we propose a novel method to improve the spatial constraints with a weighted neighborhood system of the HMRF model known as biased HMRF model. The segmentation problem is formulated as pixel labeling problem. The biased HMRF model parameters as well as the image labels are assumed to be unknown. This incomplete data problem is solved using the notions of expectation maximization. The expectation step obtains the MAP estimate of the image labels, assuming the availability of parameter estimates. This is achieved by ICM Algorithm. The estimated image labels are used to obtain the estimates of parameters in the maximization step. Eventually, the EM algorithm converges to the desired labelization. Experiments on both synthetic and brain MR images show that the segmentation results of our method have higher accuracy compared to existing solutions. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.

Authors with affiliations: Varshney, R., MIT, Moradabad, India; Varshney, T., MIT, Moradabad, India; Awasthy, N., GCET, Gr. Noida, India
Abstract: In this paper hopfield neural network is used for pattern recognition where numerals (0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 9) and 'block' are treated as patterns of black and white pixels. Network is trained for these patterns. After training, the network can be provided with a noise corrupted input pattern, and will provide an output pattern resembling whichever template most closely matches this input pattern. Finally a comparison has been made between two methods, namely hopfield neural network and centroid method.

Authors: Nagabhushan T.N., Padma S.K.
Title: On the computation of width of gaussian kernels used in auto-configuring RBF networks
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Department of Information Science and Engineering, Sri Jayachamarajendra College of Engineering, Mysore-570 006, India
Authors with affiliations: Nagabhushan, T.N., Department of Information Science and Engineering, Sri Jayachamarajendra College of Engineering, Mysore-570 006, India; Padma, S.K., Department of Information Science and Engineering, Sri Jayachamarajendra College of Engineering, Mysore-570 006, India
Abstract: RBF networks are conventionally trained using two mutually exclusive stages - the unsupervised first stage to fix the position of the Gaussian kernels and their widths and the supervised second stage to learn the weight vector. In literature many works are devoted to the estimation of the position of Gaussian kernels as well the computation of weights. Little focus exists on the estimation of kernel widths. Constructive learning algorithms provide a unified one stage approach for generating RBF network architectures. Positioning RBF kernels at optimal locations and appropriately fixing their widths in such networks differ from those in conventional networks. In this paper we investigate the use of different statistical measures to calculate the widths of RBF kernels and integrate them into our adaptive learning algorithm. Experimental results are presented on different benchmark datasets. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.

Abstract: Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) is a system that allows individual with severe neuromuscular disabilities to communicate or perform ordinary tasks exclusively via brain waves.BCI shows promise in allowing these individuals to interact with a computer using EEG. Brain Computer Interface mainly facilitates or formed a communication channel between human brain and machine or device application. A simple model of bed movement i.e. bed upward and downward movement through eye blinks signal of the patients is proposed and its effectiveness is examined online and offline. © 2009 IEEE.

Authors: Dhanya C.T., Nagesh Kumar D.
Title: Fuzzy association rules for prediction of monsoon rainfall
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India
Authors with affiliations: Dhanya, C.T., Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India; Nagesh Kumar, D., Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India
Abstract: A fuzzy association rule algorithm is implemented to extract the relationship between the atmospheric indices and the Indian Summer Monsoon Rainfall (ISMR). ENSO and EQWIK indices are used as the causative variables. Rules extracted are showing a negative relationship with ENSO index and a positive relationship with the EQWIN index. A fuzzy rule based prediction technique is also implemented on the same indices in order to predict the ISMR. Rules are defined using a training dataset for the period 1958 - 1999 and validated for the period 2000 - 2006. The fuzzy outputs of the defined rules are converted into crisp outputs using the weighted counting algorithm. The variability of the ISMR over the years is captured by this technique, thus proving to be efficient even when the linear statistical relationship between the indices is weak. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.

Title: Simulation of fire rescue with fire spread using autonomous robot swarms
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, College of Engineering, Anna University, Guindy Chennai 600025, India
Authors with affiliations: Mahalakshmi, G.S., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, College of Engineering, Anna University, Guindy Chennai 600025, India; Kannapiran, T., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, College of Engineering, Anna University, Guindy Chennai 600025, India; Babu Santhosh, R., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, College of Engineering, Anna University, Guindy Chennai 600025, India; Prabhu, S., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, College of Engineering, Anna University, Guindy Chennai 600025, India
Abstract: The first few hours after man-made |or natural disaster are the most critical for the survival of victims. This is also the time period when the fewest resources are available to the rescuers. The extent of fire spread affects the rescue operation to a certain extent. When autonomous rescue robots are involved, the pheromone through which the intelligence is shared among the rescue team of robots is largely challenged with the extent of fire in the surrounding region. Such places have higher pheromone evaporation rate and thereby the optimal path to the victim gets dissolved, resulting in a less optimal solution with increased time and effort of the rescue team. This paper demonstrates the potential of using swarms of autonomous mobile robots to help the first responders to a disaster site and to focus their search for victims and increase the probability of finding survivors. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.

Abstract: Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) refers to the task of recognizing linguistic content in a spoken sentence. In this work, the problem of isolated digit recognition is attempted with the help of Mel Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCC) as speech features followed by K-means clustering algorithm for vector quantizer (VQ) and Hidden Markov Model (HMM) as modeling technique for each linguistic class (isolated digits in the present case). The implementation of HMM consists of two major tasks, viz.. building HMM model (using forward-backward algorithm) and recognition of unknown digits (using forward algorithm). The results are obtained for closed set and open set experiments using a 5-state left-right HMM. The objective of the paper is to investigate various implementation issues in design of HMM-VQ based ASR system. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.

Authors: Singh S.P.
Title: Solving facility layout problem using modified genetic search based approach
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009

Authors with affiliations: Singh, S.P., Department of Operations Management and Decision Sciences, Xavier Institute of Management Bhubaneswar, Bhubaneswar-751013, Orissa, India
Abstract: Facility layout problem (FLP) is a well known combinatorial optimization problem and is traditionally formulated as Quadratic Assignment Problem (QAP) which is a NP-hard problem. Therefore, heuristic/ meta- heuristics are used o solve it in polynomial time. This paper proposes a modified hybrid genetic search based approach to solve FLP. Here, a new strategy named as updating strategy and new crossover operator named as swapped crossover is proposed. It is found that the proposed modified approach gives promising solution in reasonable computational time. To validate this, the proposed approach is tested for number of problems available in literature. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.

Abstract: Automatic Index generation consists of identifying important terms and phrases in a document and their location (page number) within the document for easy navigation and searching of relevant material. In this article, we present an approach for automatic index gen-eration for technical articles using a combination of heuristics, linguistic and statistical approach. We describe a system that processes articles in Portable Document Format (PDF) format and performs tasks such as: article boundary detection, region of interest detection, index phrase extraction, phrase filtering using user-defined domain specific exclude list and regular expression patterns, page number detection, phrase grouping and alignment, abbreviation detection and context viewing. Authors: Pise N., Kulkarni P.
Title: Semi-supervised learning with SVM and K-means clustering algorithm
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: College of Engineering, University of Pune, Shivajmagar, Pune-411 005, India; Capsilon Research Labs, Capsilon India, Kalyani Nagar, Pune- 411 014, India
Authors with affiliations: Pise, N., College of Engineering, University of Pune, Shivajmagar, Pune-411 005, India; Kulkarni, P., Capsilon Research Labs, Capsilon India, Kalyani Nagar, Pune- 411 014, India
Abstract: Learning relies on the acquisition of different types of knowledge supported by perceived information. It leads to the development of new capacities, skills, values, understanding, and preferences. Its goal is the increasing of individual and group experience. The paper starts with introduction of learning. Semi-supervised learning addresses the problem of labeled data by using large amount of unlabeled data, together with the labeled data, to build better classifiers. Because semi-supervised learning requires less human effort and gives higher accuracy, it is of great interest both in theory and in practice. The paper discusses various important approaches to semi-supervised learning such as self-training, co-training(CO). expectation maximization (EM) .CO-EM. Then the use of graph-based methods is explained. Finally the use of combination of support vector machines (SVM) and K-means clustering method is explained. The paper concludes with the proposed adaptive learning methodology. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.
Author Keywords: Classifier; K-means clustering; Learning; Methodology; Semi-supervised; SVM; Training
Index Keywords: K-means clustering; Learning; Methodology; Semi-supervised; SVM; Artificial intelligence; Classifiers; Clustering algorithms; Personnel training; Support vector machines; Supervised learning

Authors: Somasundaram K., Kalaiselvi T.
Title: A novel technique for finding the boundary between the cerebral hemispheres from MR axial head scans
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2009
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Applications, Gandhigram Rural University, Gandhi gram, Tamilnadu, India
Authors with affiliations: Somasundaram, K., Department of Computer Science and Applications, Gandhigram Rural University, Gandhi gram, Tamilnadu, India; Kalaiselvi, T., Department of Computer Science and Applications, Gandhigram Rural University, Gandhi gram, Tamilnadu, India
Abstract: We present a robust technique to detect a linear boundary between the cerebral hemisphere using the knowledge of brain features and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) characteristics. We use two approaches to extract the brain from T1 and T2 MR axial head scans to find the brain contour. From the brain contour, we detect the boundary between the hemispheres by joining the edges of the two portions of cleft that corresponds to inter-hemispheric fissure present in the contour. The detected boundary is used to separate the cerebrum into two hemispheres. We tested our method over several scans collected from MRI centre and authorized brain image web sites. The performance was validated with medical experts using both normal and abnormal scans. The predictive accuracy gives the quantitative measure calculated between the hand- stripped and our result and is 99% in normal cases and lowered for abnormal slices. Copyright © 2009 by IICAI.
Author Keywords: Brain contour; Brain extraction algorithm; Cerebral hemispheres; Inter-hemispheric fissure; Knowledge system; Mid-sagittal plane; Slice transformation
Index Keywords: Brain extraction; Cerebral hemispheres; Inter-hemispheric fissure; Knowledge system; Mid-sagittal planes; Slice transformation; Artificial intelligence; Brain; Magnetic resonance imaging; Neuroimaging

Authors: Mannem P., Chaudhry H., Bharati A.
Title: Insights into non-projectivity in Hindi
Source title: ACL-IJCNLP 2009 - Joint Conf. of the 47th Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics and 4th Int. Joint Conf. on Natural Language Processing of the AFNLP, Proceedings of the Conf.
Affiliations: Language Technologies Research Center, International Institute of Information Technology, Gachibowli, Hyderabad, 500032, India
Authors with affiliations: Mannem, P., Language Technologies Research Center, International Institute of Information Technology, Gachibowli, Hyderabad, 500032, India; Chaudhry, H., Language Technologies Research Center, International Institute of Information Technology, Gachibowli, Hyderabad, 500032, India; Bharati, A., Language Technologies Research Center, International Institute of Information Technology, Gachibowli, Hyderabad, 500032, India
Abstract: Large scale efforts are underway to create dependency treebanks and parsers for Hindi and other Indian languages. Hindi, being a morphologically rich, flexible word order language, brings challenges such as handling non-projectivity in parsing. In this work, we look at non-projectivity in Hyderabad Dependency Treebank (HyDT) for Hindi. Non-projectivity has been analysed from two perspectives: graph properties that restrict non-projectivity and linguistic phenomenon behind non-projectivity in HyDT. Since Hindi has ample instances of non-projectivity (14% of all structures in HyDT are non-projective), it presents a case for an in depth study of this phenomenon for a better insight, from both of these perspectives. We have looked at graph constriants like planarity, gap degree, edge degree and well-nestedness on structures in HyDT. We also analyse non-projectivity in Hindi in terms of various linguistic parameters such as the causes of non-projectivity, its rigidity (possibility of reordering) and whether the reordered construction is the natural one. © 2009 ACL and AFNLP.
Index Keywords: Edge-degree; Graph properties; Hyderabad; In-depth study; Indian languages; Linguistic phenomena; Non-projectivity; Planarity; Treebanks; Word-order languages; Computational linguistics; Forestry; Natural language processing systems

Authors: Saharia N., Das D., Sharma U., Kalita J.
Title: Part of speech tagger for Assamese text
Source title: ACL-IJCNLP 2009 - Joint Conf. of the 47th Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics and 4th Int. Joint Conf. on Natural Language Processing of the AFNLP, Proceedings of the Conf.
Affiliations: Department of CSE, Tezpur University, 784028, India; Department of CS, University of Colorado, Colorado Springs - 80918, United States
Authors with affiliations: Saharia, N., Department of CSE, Tezpur University, 784028, India; Das, D., Department of CSE, Tezpur University, 784028, India; Sharma, U., Department of CSE, Tezpur University, 784028, India; Kalita, J., Department of CS, University of Colorado, Colorado Springs - 80918, United States
Abstract: Assamese is a morphologically rich, agglutinative and relatively free word order Indic language. Although spoken by nearly 30 million people, very little computational linguistic work has been done for this language. In this paper, we present our work on part of speech (POS) tagging for Assamese using the well-known Hidden Markov Model. Since no well-defined suitable tagset was available, we develop a tagset of 172 tags in consultation with experts in linguistics. For successful tagging, we examine relevant linguistic issues in Assamese. For unknown words, we perform simple morphological analysis to determine probable tags. Using a manually tagged corpus of about 10000 words for training, we obtain a tagging accuracy of nearly 87% for test inputs. © 2009 ACL and AFNLP.
Index Keywords: Free word order; Morphological analysis; Part of speech tagging; Part-of-speech tagger; Test inputs; Hidden Markov models; Natural language processing systems; Computational linguistics

Authors: Katragadda R., Varma V.
Title: Query-Focused summaries or query-biased summaries ?
Source title: ACL-IJCNLP 2009 - Joint Conf. of the 47th Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics and 4th Int. Joint Conf. on Natural Language Processing of the AFNLP, Proceedings of the Conf.
Affiliations: Language Technologies Research Center, IIIT Hyderabad, India
Authors with affiliations: Katragadda, R., Language Technologies Research Center, IIIT Hyderabad, India; Varma, V., Language Technologies Research Center, IIIT Hyderabad, India
Abstract: In the context of the Document Understanding Conferences, the task of Query-Focused Multi-Document Summarization is intended to improve agreement in content among human-generated model summaries. Query-focus also aids the automated summarizers in directing the summary at specific topics, which may result in better agreement with these model summaries. However, while query focus correlates with performance, we show that high-performing automatic systems produce summaries with disproportionally higher query term density than human summarizers do. Experimental evidence suggests that automatic systems heavily rely on query term occurrence and repetition to achieve good performance. © 2009 ACL and AFNLP.
Index Keywords: Automatic systems; Experimental evidence; Multi-document summarization; Query terms; Computational linguistics; Natural language processing systems

Authors: Das D., Bandyopadhyay S.
Title: Word to sentence level emotion tagging for Bengali blogs
Source title: ACL-IJCNLP 2009 - Joint Conf. of the 47th Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics and 4th Int. Joint Conf. on Natural Language Processing of the AFNLP, Proceedings of the Conf.
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Jadavpur University, India
Authors with affiliations: Das, D., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Jadavpur University, India; Bandyopadhyay, S., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Jadavpur University, India
Abstract: In this paper, emotion analysis on blog texts has been carried out for a less privileged language like Bengali. Ekman's six basic emotion types have been selected for reliable and semi automatic word level annotation. An automatic classifier has been applied for recognizing six basic emotion types for different words in a sentence. Application of different scoring strategies to identify sentence level emotion tag based on the acquired word level emotion constituents have produced satisfactory performance. © 2009 ACL and AFNLP.
Index Keywords: Automatic classifiers; Basic emotions; Emotion analysis; Semi-automatics; Sentence level; Tag-based; Word level; Internet; Natural language processing systems; Computational linguistics

Authors: Kumaran A., Saravanan K., Datha N., Ashok B., Dendi V.
Title: WikiBABEL: A wiki-style platform for creation of parallel data
Source title: ACL-IJCNLP 2009 - Joint Conf. of the 47th Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics and 4th Int. Joint Conf. on Natural Language Processing of the AFNLP, Proceedings of the Conf.
Affiliations: Multilingual Systems Research, Microsoft Research, India; Advanced Development and Prototyping, Microsoft Research, India; Machine Translation Incubation, Microsoft Research, India
Authors with affiliations: Kumaran, A., Multilingual Systems Research, Microsoft Research, India; Saravanan, K., Multilingual Systems Research, Microsoft Research, India; Datha, N., Advanced Development and Prototyping, Microsoft Research, India; Ashok, B., Advanced Development and Prototyping, Microsoft Research, India; Dendi, V., Machine Translation Incubation, Microsoft Research, India
Abstract: In this demo, we present a wiki-style platform - WikiBABEL - that enables easy collaborative creation of multilingual content in many non- English Wikipedias, by leveraging the relatively larger and more stable content in the English Wikipedia. The platform provides an intuitive user interface that maintains the user focus on the multilingual Wikipedia content creation, by engaging search tools for easy discoverability of related English source material, and a set of linguistic and collaborative tools to make the content translation simple. We present two different usage scenarios and discuss our experience in testing them with real users. Such integrated content creation platform in Wikipedia may yield as a by-product, parallel corpora that are critical for research in statistical machine translation systems in many languages of the world. © 2009 ACL and AFNLP.
Index Keywords: Collaborative tools; Content creation; Intuitive user interface; Parallel corpora; Parallel data; Search tools; Source material; Statistical machine translation system; Usage scenarios; Wikipedia; Interfaces (materials); Natural language processing systems; User interfaces; Websites; Computational linguistics

Authors: Gupta P., Ji H.
Title: Predicting unknown time arguments based on cross-event propagation
Source title: ACL-IJCNLP 2009 - Joint Conf. of the 47th Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics and 4th Int. Joint Conf. on Natural Language Processing of the AFNLP, Proceedings of the Conf.
Affiliations: Indian Institute of Information Technology Allahabad, Allahabad, 211012, India; Computer Science Department, Queens College and the Graduate Center, City University of New York, New York, NY, 11367, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gupta, P., Indian Institute of Information Technology Allahabad, Allahabad, 211012, India; Ji, H., Computer Science Department, Queens College and the Graduate Center, City University of New York, New York, NY, 11367, United States
Abstract: Many events in news articles don't include time arguments. This paper describes two methods, one based on rules and the other based on statistical learning, to predict the unknown time argument for an event by the propagation from its related events. The results are promising - the rule based approach was able to correctly predict 74% of the unknown event time arguments with 70% precision. © 2009 ACL and AFNLP.
Index Keywords: News articles; Rule-based approach; Statistical learning; Time argument; Forecasting; Natural language processing systems; Computational linguistics

Authors: Biemann C., Choudhury M., Mukherjee A.
Title: Syntax is from mars while semantics from venus! Insights from spectral analysis of distributional similarity networks
Source title: ACL-IJCNLP 2009 - Joint Conf. of the 47th Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics and 4th Int. Joint Conf. on Natural Language Processing of the AFNLP, Proceedings of the Conf.
Affiliations: Microsoft, Powerset, San Francisco, United States; Microsoft Research Lab, India; Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, India
Authors with affiliations: Biemann, C., Microsoft, Powerset, San Francisco, United States; Choudhury, M., Microsoft Research Lab, India; Mukherjee, A., Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, India
Abstract: We study the global topology of the syntactic and semantic distributional similarity networks for English through the technique of spectral analysis. We observe that while the syntactic network has a hierarchical structure with strong communities and their mixtures, the semantic network has several tightly knit communities along with a large core without any such welldefined community structure. © 2009 ACL and AFNLP.
Index Keywords: Community structures; Distributional similarities; Global topology; Hierarchical structures; Large core; Semantic network; Computational linguistics; Natural language processing systems; Semantics; Spectrum analysis; Syntactics

Authors: Nath J.S., Dinesh G., Raman S., Bhattacharyya C., Ben-Tal A., Ramakrishnan K.R.
Title: On the algorithmics and applications of a mixed-norm based kernel learning formulation
Source title: Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems 22 - Proceedings of the 2009 Conference
Affiliations: Dept. of Computer Science and Engg., Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay, India; Dept. of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India; Faculty of Industrial Engg. and Management, Technion, Haifa, Israel; Dept. of Electrical Engg., Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India
Authors with affiliations: Nath, J.S., Dept. of Computer Science and Engg., Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay, India; Dinesh, G., Dept. of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India; Raman, S., Dept. of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India; Bhattacharyya, C., Dept. of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India; Ben-Tal, A., Faculty of Industrial Engg. and Management, Technion, Haifa, Israel; Ramakrishnan, K.R., Dept. of Electrical Engg., Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India
Abstract: Motivated from real world problems, like object categorization, we study a particular mixed-norm regularization for Multiple Kernel Learning (MKL). It is assumed that the given set of kernels are grouped into distinct components where each component is crucial for the learning task at hand. The formulation hence employs l ∞ regularization for promoting combinations at the component level and l 1 regularization for promoting sparsity among kernels in each component. While previous attempts have formulated this as a non-convex problem, the formulation given here is an instance of non-smooth convex optimization problem which admits an efficient Mirror-Descent (MD) based procedure. The MD procedure optimizes over product of simplexes, which is not a well-studied case in literature. Results on real-world datasets show that the new MKL formulation is well-suited for object categorization tasks and that the MD based algorithm outperforms state-of-the-art MKL solvers like simpleMKL in terms of computational effort.
Index Keywords: Algorithmics; Component levels; Computational effort; Convex optimization problems; Kernel learning; Learning tasks; Mixed-norm; Multiple Kernel Learning; Non-smooth; Nonconvex problem; Object categorization; Real-world datasets; Real-world problem; Convex optimization
Correspondence Address: Nath, J.S.; Dept. of Computer Science and Engg., Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay, India; email: saketh@cse.iitb.ac.in

Authors: Maei H.R., Szepesvari C., Bhatnagar S., Precup D., Silver D., Sutton R.S.
Title: Convergent temporal-difference learning with arbitrary smooth function approximation
Source title: Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems 22 - Proceedings of the 2009 Conference
Affiliations: University of Alberta, Edmonton, AB, Canada; Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India; McGill University, Montreal, QC, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Maei, H.R., University of Alberta, Edmonton, AB, Canada; Szepesvari, C., University of Alberta, Edmonton, AB, Canada; Bhatnagar, S., Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India; Precup, D., McGill University, Montreal, QC, Canada; Silver, D., University of Alberta, Edmonton, AB, Canada; Sutton, R.S., University of Alberta, Edmonton, AB, Canada
Abstract: We introduce the first temporal-difference learning algorithms that converge with smooth value function approximators, such as neural networks. Conventional temporal-difference (TD) methods, such as TD(λ), Q-learning and Sarsa have been used successfully with function approximation in many applications. However, it is well known that off-policy sampling, as well as nonlinear function approximation, can cause these algorithms to become unstable (i.e., the parameters of the approximator may diverge). Sutton et al. (2009a, 2009b) solved the problem of off-policy learning with linear TD algorithms by introducing a new objective function, related to the Bellman error, and algorithms that perform stochastic gradient-descent on this function. These methods can be viewed as natural generalizations to previous TD methods, as they converge to the same limit points when used with linear function approximation methods. We generalize this work to nonlinear function approximation. We present a Bellman error objective function and two gradient-descent TD algorithms that optimize it. We prove the asymptotic almost-sure convergence of both algorithms, for any finite Markov decision process and any smooth value function approximator, to a locally optimal solution. The algorithms are incremental and the computational complexity per time step scales linearly with the number of parameters of the approximator. Empirical results obtained in the game of Go demonstrate the algorithms' effectiveness.
Index Keywords: Approximators; Bellman error; Finite Markov decision process; Function approximation; Gradient-descent; Limit points; Linear functions; Natural generalization; Nonlinear function approximation; Objective functions; Optimal solutions; Q-learning; Smooth functions; TD method; Temporal difference learning; Time step; Value functions; Approximation theory; Learning algorithms; Markov processes; Parameter estimation; Approximation algorithms
Correspondence Address: Maei, H.R.; University of Alberta, Edmonton, AB, Canada
Abbreviated Source Title: Adv. Neural Inf. Process. Syst. - Proc. Conf.

Authors: Chechik G., Sharma V., Shalit U., Bengio S.
Title: An online algorithm for large scale image similarity learning
Source title: Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems 22 - Proceedings of the 2009 Conference
Affiliations: Google, Mountain View, CA, United States; Google, Bengalooru, Karnataka, India; ICNC, Hebrew University, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Chechik, G., Google, Mountain View, CA, United States; Sharma, V., Google, Bengalooru, Karnataka, India; Shalit, U., ICNC, Hebrew University, Israel; Bengio, S., Google, Mountain View, CA, United States
Abstract: Learning a measure of similarity between pairs of objects is a fundamental problem in machine learning. It stands in the core of classification methods like kernel machines, and is particularly useful for applications like searching for images that are similar to a given image or finding videos that are relevant to a given video. In these tasks, users look for objects that are not only visually similar but also semantically related to a given object. Unfortunately, current approaches for learning similarity do not scale to large datasets, especially when imposing metric constraints on the learned similarity. We describe OASIS, a method for learning pairwise similarity that is fast and scales linearly with the number of objects and the number of non-zero features. Scalability is achieved through online learning of a bilinear model over sparse representations using a large margin criterion and an efficient hinge loss cost. OASIS is accurate at a wide range of scales: on a standard benchmark with thousands of images, it is more precise than state-of-the-art methods, and faster by orders of magnitude. On 2.7 million images collected from the web, OASIS can be trained within 3 days on a single CPU. The non-metric similarities learned by OASIS can be transformed into metric similarities, achieving higher precisions than similarities that are learned as metrics in the first place. This suggests an approach for learning a metric from data that is larger by orders of magnitude than was handled before.
Index Keywords: Bilinear models; Classification methods; Fundamental problem; Image similarity; Kernel machine; Large datasets; Learning similarity; Loss costs; On-line algorithms; Online learning; Orders of magnitude; Single CPU; Sparse representation; State-of-the-art methods
Correspondence Address: Chechik, G.; Google, Mountain View, CA, United States; email: gal@google.com
Abbreviated Source Title: Adv. Neural Inf. Process. Syst. - Proc. Conf.

Authors: Krishnan S., Bhattacharyya C., Hariharan R.
Title: A randomized algorithm for large scale support vector learning
Source title: Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems 20 - Proceedings of the 2007 Conference
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore-12, India; Strand Genomics, Bangalore-80, India
Authors with affiliations: Krishnan, S., Department of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore-12, India; Bhattacharyya, C., Department of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore-12, India; Hariharan, R., Strand Genomics, Bangalore-80, India
Abstract: This paper investigates the application of randomized algorithms for large scale SVM learning. The key contribution of the paper is to show that, by using ideas random projections, the minimal number of support vectors required to solve almost separable classification problems, such that the solution obtained is near optimal with a very high probability, is given by O(log n); if on removal of properly chosen O(log n) points the data becomes linearly separable then it is called almost separable. The second contribution is a sampling based algorithm, motivated from randomized algorithms, which solves a SVM problem by considering subsets of the dataset which are greater in size than the number of support vectors for the problem. These two ideas are combined to obtain an algorithm for SVM classification problems which performs the learning by considering only O(log n) points at a time. Experiments done on synthetic and real life datasets show that the algorithm does scale up state of the art SVM solvers in terms of memory required and execution time without loss in accuracy. It is to be noted that the algorithm presented here nicely complements existing large scale SVM learning approaches as it can be used to scale up any SVM solver.
Index Keywords: Data sets; Execution time; High probability; Learning approach; Linearly separable; Random projections; Randomized Algorithms; Real life datasets; Sampling-based algorithms; Scale-up; State of the art; Support vector; Support vector learning; SVM classification; SVM solvers; Learning algorithms

Authors: Yao H., Bhatnagar S., Diao D.
Title: Multi-step linear dyna-style planning
Source title: Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems 22 - Proceedings of the 2009 Conference
Affiliations: Department of Computing Science, University of Alberta, Edmonton, AB T6G2E8, Canada; Department of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560012, India; School of Economics and Management, South China Normal University, Guangzhou, 518055, China
Authors with affiliations: Yao, H., Department of Computing Science, University of Alberta, Edmonton, AB T6G2E8, Canada; Bhatnagar, S., Department of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560012, India; Diao, D., School of Economics and Management, South China Normal University, Guangzhou, 518055, China
Abstract: In this paper we introduce a multi-step linear Dyna-style planning algorithm. The key element of the multi-step linear Dyna is a multi-step linear model that enables multi-step projection of a sampled feature and multi-step planning based on the simulated multi-step transition experience. We propose two multi-step linear models. The first iterates the one-step linear model, but is generally computationally complex. The second interpolates between the one-step model and the infinite-step model (which turns out to be the LSTD solution), and can be learned efficiently online. Policy evaluation on Boyan Chain shows that multi-step linear Dyna learns a policy faster than single-step linear Dyna, and generally learns faster as the number of projection steps increases. Results on Mountain-car show that multi-step linear Dyna leads to much better online performance than single-step linear Dyna and model-free algorithms; however, the performance of multi-step linear Dyna does not always improve as the number of projection steps increases. Our results also suggest that previous attempts on extending LSTD for online control were unsuccessful because LSTD looks infinite steps into the future, and suffers from the model errors in non-stationary (control) environments.
Index Keywords: Key elements; Model errors; Model-free algorithms; Multi-step; Nonstationary; On-line controls; On-line performance; One-step model; Planning algorithms; Policy evaluation; Single-step; Algorithms; Mathematical models
Correspondence Address: Yao, H.; Department of Computing Science, University of Alberta, Edmonton, AB T6G2E8, Canada
Abbreviated Source Title: Adv. Neural Inf. Process. Syst. - Proc. Conf.

Authors: Parsana M., Bhattacharya S., Bhattacharyya C., Ramakrishnan K.R.
Title: Kernels on attributed pointsets with applications
Source title: Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems 20 - Proceedings of the 2007 Conference
Affiliations: Dept. of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore - 560012, India; Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore - 560012, India
Authors with affiliations: Parsana, M., Dept. of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore - 560012, India; Bhattacharya, S., Dept. of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore - 560012, India; Bhattacharyya, C., Dept. of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore - 560012, India; Ramakrishnan, K.R., Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore - 560012, India
Abstract: This paper introduces kernels on attributed pointsets, which are sets of vectors embedded in an euclidean space. The embedding gives the notion of neighborhood, which is used to define positive semidefinite kernels on pointsets. Two novel kernels on neighborhoods are proposed, one evaluating the attribute similarity and the other evaluating shape similarity. Shape similarity function is motivated from spectral graph matching techniques. The kernels are tested on three real life applications: face recognition, photo album tagging, and shot annotation in video sequences, with encouraging results.
Index Keywords: Attribute similarity; Euclidean spaces; Photo album; Real-life applications; Shape similarity; Spectral graph matching; Video sequences; Face recognition

Authors: Bhatnagar S., Sutton R.S., Ghavamzadeh M., Lee M.
Title: Incremental natural actor-critic algorithms
Source title: Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems 20 - Proceedings of the 2007 Conference
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India; Department of Computing Science, University of Alberta, Edmonton, AB, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Bhatnagar, S., Department of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India; Sutton, R.S., Department of Computing Science, University of Alberta, Edmonton, AB, Canada; Ghavamzadeh, M., Department of Computing Science, University of Alberta, Edmonton, AB, Canada; Lee, M., Department of Computing Science, University of Alberta, Edmonton, AB, Canada
Abstract: We present four new reinforcement learning algorithms based on actor-critic and natural-gradient ideas, and provide their convergence proofs. Actor-critic reinforcement learning methods are online approximations to policy iteration in which the value-function parameters are estimated using temporal difference learning and the policy parameters are updated by stochastic gradient descent. Methods based on policy gradients in this way are of special interest because of their compatibility with function approximation methods, which are needed to handle large or infinite state spaces. The use of temporal difference learning in this way is of interest because in many applications it dramatically reduces the variance of the gradient estimates. The use of the natural gradient is of interest because it can produce better conditioned parameterizations and has been shown to further reduce variance in some cases. Our results extend prior two-timescale convergence results for actor-critic methods by Konda and Tsitsiklis by using temporal difference learning in the actor and by incorporating natural gradients, and they extend prior empirical studies of natural actor-critic methods by Peters, Vijayakumar and Schaal by providing the first convergence proofs and the first fully incremental algorithms.

Authors: Banerjee J., Namboodiri A.M., Jawahar C.V.
Title: Contextual restoration of severely degraded document images
Source title: 2009 IEEE Computer Society Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition Workshops, CVPR Workshops 2009
Affiliations: Center for Visual Information Technology, IIIT, Hyderabad - 500032, India
Authors with affiliations: Banerjee, J., Center for Visual Information Technology, IIIT, Hyderabad - 500032, India; Namboodiri, A.M., Center for Visual Information Technology, IIIT, Hyderabad - 500032, India; Jawahar, C.V., Center for Visual Information Technology, IIIT, Hyderabad - 500032, India
Abstract: We propose an approach to restore severely degraded document images using a probabilistic context model. Un- like traditional approaches that use previously learned prior models to restore an image, we are able to learn the text model from the degraded document itself, making the approach independent of script, font, style, etc. We model the contextual relationship using an MRF. The ability to work with larger patch sizes allows us to deal with severe degradations including cuts, blobs, merges and vandalized documents. Our approach can also integrate document restoration and super-resolution into a single framework, thus directly generating high quality images from degraded documents. Experimental results show significant improve- ment in image quality on document images collected from various sources including magazines and books, and com- prehensively demonstrate the robustness and adaptability of the approach. It works well with document collections such as books, even with severe degradations, and hence is ide- ally suited for repositories such as digital libraries. ©2009 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Context models; Degraded document images; Degraded documents; Document collection; Document images; Document restoration; High quality images; Patch size; Super resolution; Text models; Computer vision; Digital image storage; Digital libraries; Image quality; Restoration; Technical presentations; Security of data

Authors: Ravishankar S., Jain A., Mittal A.
Title: Automated feature extraction for early detection of diabetic retinopathy in fundus images
Source title: 2009 IEEE Computer Society Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition Workshops, CVPR Workshops 2009
Affiliations: Indian Institute of Technology Madras, University of Maryland College Park, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, India
Authors with affiliations: Ravishankar, S., Indian Institute of Technology Madras, University of Maryland College Park, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, India; Jain, A., Indian Institute of Technology Madras, University of Maryland College Park, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, India; Mittal, A., Indian Institute of Technology Madras, University of Maryland College Park, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, India
Abstract: Automated detection of lesions in retinal images can assist in early diagnosis and screening of a common disease: Diabetic Retinopathy. A robust and computationally efficient approach for the localization of the different features and lesions in a fundus retinal image is presented in this paper. Since many features have common intensity properties, geometric features and correlations are used to distinguish between them. We propose a new constraint for optic disk detection where we first detect the major blood vessels and use the intersection of these to find the approximate location of the optic disk. This is further localized using color properties. We also show that many of the features such as the blood vessels, exudates and microaneurysms and hemorrhages can be detected quite accurately using different morphological operations applied appropriately. Extensive evaluation of the algorithm on a database of 516 images with varied contrast, illumination and disease stages yields 97.1% success rate for optic disk localization, a sensitivity and specificity of 95.7%and 94.2%respectively for exudate detection and 95.1% and 90.5% for microaneurysm/ hemorrhage detection. These compare very favorably with existing systems and promise real deployment of these systems. ©2009 IEEE.

Authors: Singh R., Vatsa M., Noore A.
Title: Effect of plastic surgery on face recognition: a preliminary study
Source title: 2009 IEEE Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition, CVPR 2009
Affiliations: IIIT Delhi, India; West Virginia University, Morgantown, United States
Authors with affiliations: Singh, R., IIIT Delhi, India; Vatsa, M., IIIT Delhi, India; Noore, A., West Virginia University, Morgantown, United States
Abstract: Variations in pose, expression, illumination, aging and disguise are considered as major challenges in face recognition and several techniques have been proposed to address these challenges. Plastic surgery, on the other hand, is considered as an arduous research issue; however, it has not yet been studied either theoretically or experimentally. This paper focuses on analyzing the effect of plastic surgery in face recognition algorithms. The preliminary study provides an experimental and analytical comparison of face recognition algorithms on a plastic surgery database of 506 individuals. The experimental results indicate that existing face recognition algorithms perform poorly when matching pre and post surgery face images. The results also suggest that it is imperative for future face recognition systems to be able to address this important issue and hence there is a need for more research in this important area. © 2009 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Face images; Face recognition algorithms; Face recognition systems; Plastic surgery; Research issues; Computer vision; Plastics; Surgery; Face recognition
