Authors: Kisku D.R., Tistarelli M., Sing J.K., Gupta P.
Title: Face recognition by fusion of local and global matching scores using DS theory: An evaluation with uni-classifier and multi-classifier paradigm
Source title: 2009 IEEE Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition, CVPR 2009
Affiliations: Dr. B. C. Engineering College, India; University of Sassari, Alghero (SS), Italy; Jadavpur University, Kolkata, India; I.I.T Kanpur, Kanpur, India
Authors with affiliations: Kisku, D.R., Dr. B. C. Engineering College, India; Tistarelli, M., University of Sassari, Alghero (SS), Italy; Sing, J.K., Jadavpur University, Kolkata, India; Gupta, P., I.I.T Kanpur, Kanpur, India
Abstract: Faces are highly deformable objects which may easily change their appearance over time. Not all face areas are subject to the same variability. Therefore decoupling the information from independent areas of the face is of paramount importance to improve the robustness of any face recognition technique. This paper presents a robust face recognition technique based on the extraction and matching of SIFT features related to independent face areas. Both a global and local (as recognition from parts) matching strategy is proposed. The local strategy is based on matching individual salient facial SIFT features as connected to facial landmarks such as the eyes and the mouth. As for the global matching strategy, all SIFT features are combined together to form a single feature. In order to reduce the identification errors, the Dempster-Shafer decision theory is applied to fuse the two matching techniques. The proposed algorithms are evaluated with the ORL and the IITK face databases. The experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness and potential of the proposed face recognition techniques also in the case of partially occluded faces or with missing information. © 2009 IEEE.

Authors: Karthik S., Pulla C., Jawahar C.V.
Title: Incremental on-line semantic indexing for image retrieval in dynamic databases
Source title: 2009 IEEE Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition, CVPR 2009
Affiliations: Center for Visual Information Technology, International Institute of Information Technology Hyderabad, Hyderabad-500032, India
Authors with affiliations: Karthik, S., Center for Visual Information Technology, International Institute of Information Technology Hyderabad, Hyderabad-500032, India; Pulla, C., Center for Visual Information Technology, International Institute of Information Technology Hyderabad, Hyderabad-500032, India; Jawahar, C.V., Center for Visual Information Technology, International Institute of Information Technology Hyderabad, Hyderabad-500032, India
Abstract: Contemporary approaches to semantic indexing for bag of words image retrieval do not adapt well when the image or video collections dynamically get modified. In this paper, We propose an on-line incremental semantic indexing scheme for image retrieval in dynamic image collections. Our main contributions are in the form of a method and a datastructure that tackle representation of the term document matrix and on-line semantic indexing where the database changes. We introduce a bipartite graph model (BGM) which is a scalable datastructure that aids in online semantic indexing. It can also be incrementally updated. BGM uses tf-idf values for building a semantic bipartite graph. We also introduce a cashflow Algorithm that works on the BGM to retrieve semantically relevant images from the database. We examine the properties of both BGM and Cash Flow algorithm through a series of experiments. Finally, we demonstrate how they can be effectively implemented to build large scale image retrieval systems in an incremental manner. © 2009 IEEE.

Abstract: The Multi resolution nature and energy compaction of wavelet transform particularly makes them suitable for analysis of biological features both behavioral and physiological. The paper proposes to use Daubechies 3 and 4 wavelets to analyze the iris pattern and speech samples with the application of Decision theory in case the stand alone systems of speech identification and iris recognition yield conflicting results. © 2009 IEEE.

Authors: Ghanty P., Paul S., Pal N.R.
Title: NEUROSVM: An architecture to reduce the effect of the choice of kernel on the performance of SVM
Source title: Journal of Machine Learning Research
Affiliations: Praxis Softek Solutions Pvt. Ltd., SDF Building, Module 616, Salt Lake City Calcutta - 700 091, India; IBM, India Pvt. Ltd., DLF, IT Park, 4th, Tower C, New Town Rajarhut Calcutta - 700 156, India; Electronics and Communication Sciences Unit, Indian Statistical Institute, 203, B. T. Road, Calcutta - 700 108, India
Authors with affiliations: Ghanty, P., Praxis Softek Solutions Pvt. Ltd., SDF Building, Module 616, Salt Lake City Calcutta - 700 091, India; Paul, S., IBM, India Pvt. Ltd., DLF, IT Park, 4th, Tower C, New Town Rajarhut Calcutta - 700 156, India; Pal, N.R., Electronics and Communication Sciences Unit, Indian Statistical Institute, 203, B. T. Road, Calcutta - 700 108, India
Abstract: In this paper we propose a new multilayer classifier architecture. The proposed hybrid architecture has two cascaded modules: feature extraction module and classification module. In the feature extraction module we use the multilayered perceptron (MLP) neural networks, although other tools such as radial basis function (RBF) networks can be used. In the classification module we use support vector machines (SVMs)-here also other tool such as MLP or RBF can be used. The feature extraction module has several sub-modules each of which is expected to extract features capturing the discriminating characteristics of different areas of the input space. The classification module classifies the data based on the extracted features. The resultant architecture with MLP in feature extraction module and SVM in classification module is called NEUROSVM. The NEUROSVM is tested on twelve benchmark data sets and the performance of the NEUROSVM is found to be better than both MLP and SVM. We also compare the performance of proposed architecture with that of two ensemble methods: majority voting and averaging. Here also the NEUROSVM is found to perform better than these two ensemble methods. Further we explore the use of MLP and RBF in the classification module of the proposed architecture. The most attractive feature of NEUROSVM is that it practically eliminates the severe dependency of SVM on the choice of kernel. This has been verified with respect to both linear and non-linear kernels. We have also demonstrated that for the feature extraction module, the full training of MLPs is not needed.

Authors: Kundu A., Pal A.R., Sarkar T., Banerjee M., Mandal S., Dattagupta R., Mukhopadhyay D.
Title: An alternate downloading methodology of webpages
Source title: 7th Mexican International Conference on Artificial Intelligence - Proceedings of the Special Session, MICAI 2008
Affiliations: Netaji Subhash Engineering College, West Bengal University of Technology, West Bengal-700 152, India; Jadavpur University, West Bengal-700 032, India; Calcutta Business School, Diamond Harbour Road, Bishnupur, West Bengal-743 503, India

Abstract: We propose an advanced method for downloading Webpages from the internet. In this technique, the whole system is considered as a bundle of crawlers which have been created dynamically at execution time. Numbers of crawlers are used depending on the requirement of downloading Webpages. The software module which interacts with WWW to search one or more Webpages is known as crawler. The numbers of crawlers are generated using the hierarchy structure of the Web server from which the data would be downloaded. Webpage downloader is an important issue for downloading Web documents from the internet to facilitate a Web user in terms of knowledge gathering. This type of downloaders are very popular in the 'Information Technology' field. All kinds of public data, accessible throughout the world without any authentication, can be retrieved any time from any geographic location using the downloading methodology. Typically, a downloading technique has been utilized to accumulate Webpages of different domains within a single computer machine one at a time. So, our aim in this paper is to show an advanced technique for downloading a lot of related Webpages with a minimum effort and time using Hierarchical Downloader consisting of several dynamic crawlers. © 2008 IEEE.

Title: Measuring lexical cohesion in a document
Source title: 7th Mexican International Conference on Artificial Intelligence - Proceedings of the Special Session, MICAI 2008

Abstract: Lexical Cohesion is one of the important features in text processing for analyzing document structure and improving the accuracy of text processing. We present a hierarchial graph based model to measure cohesion by grouping lexically cohesive units to gether in a text. Latent semantic analysis is used to construct a relational graph to uncover the hidden semantics from the text by discovering new relations and their weights. Coherence score is derived from the learned weights that are assigned to edges in the graph and number of disjoint partitions in the graph. © 2008 IEEE.

Authors: Desai N., Singh M.P.
Title: On the enactability of business protocols
Source title: Proceedings of the National Conference on Artificial Intelligence
Affiliations: IBM, India Research Lab., Embassy Golf Links, Block D, Bangalore 560071, India; Department of Computer Science, North Carolina State University, Raleigh, NC 27695-8206, United States
Authors with affiliations: Desai, N., IBM, India Research Lab., Embassy Golf Links, Block D, Bangalore 560071, India; Singh, M.P., Department of Computer Science, North Carolina State University, Raleigh, NC 27695-8206, United States
Abstract: Protocols specifying business interactions among autonomous parties enable reuse and promote interoperability. A protocol is specified from a global viewpoint, but enacted in a distributed manner by (agents playing) different roles. Each role describes a local representation. An ill-specified protocol may yield roles that fail to produce correct enactments of the protocol. Existing approaches lack a formal and comprehensive treatment of this problem. Building on recent work on declaratively specifying a protocol as a set of rules of causal logic, this paper formally defines the enactability of protocols. It presents necessary and sufficient conditions for the enactability of a protocol as well as a decision procedure for extracting correct roles from enactable protocols. Copyright © 2008, Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence (www.aaai.org). All rights reserved.

Authors: Shah S., Kothari R., Jayadeva J., Chandra S.
Title: Mathematical modeling and convergence analysis of trail formation
Source title: Proceedings of the National Conference on Artificial Intelligence
Affiliations: Dept. of Electrical Engg., IIT Delhi, Hauz Khas, New Delhi 110016, India; IBM, India Research Lab., Institutional Area, 4 Block C, Vasant Kunj, New Delhi- 110070, India; Dept. of Mathematics, IIT Delhi, Hauz Khas New Delhi 110016, India
Authors with affiliations: Shah, S., Dept. of Electrical Engg., IIT Delhi, Hauz Khas, New Delhi 110016, India; Kothari, R., IBM, India Research Lab., Institutional Area, 4 Block C, Vasant Kunj, New Delhi- 110070, India; Jayadeva, J., Dept. of Electrical Engg., IIT Delhi, Hauz Khas, New Delhi 110016, India; Chandra, S., Dept. of Mathematics, IIT Delhi, Hauz Khas New Delhi 110016, India
Abstract: An ant deposits pheromone along the path that it travels and is more likely to choose a path with a higher concentration of pheromone. The sensing and dropping of pheromone makes it easy to understand the trail forming behavior of ants. The reinforcement tendency of pheromone following behavior ensures selection of the shortest path from a set of paths. The reinforcement tendency of pheromone following behavior also ensures a biased selection of the initially followed paths over a path, which is shorter but discovered through chance at a later point in time. Under what conditions and limits can this initial bias be reversed? In this paper, we answer this question based on a theoretical analysis of the trail forming behavior of ants. We believe our results to contribute to the overall area of understanding how to build scalable systems that evolve to solve complex problems (e.g. point covering or the traveling salesman problem) without the necessity of central command-and-control. Copyright © 2008, Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence (www.aaai.org). All rights reserved.

Title: Image registration using hierarchical approach - Best choice for image mosaicing

Abstract: Image Registration is very important area of research in Computer Vision, Computer Graphics and Image Processing. Image Registration is first step in Image Mosaicing.It is used to find correspondence between the two images. Here we have used Sum of Square Difference Method to register images. Mosaic overcomes the limitations finite field of view of camera by aligning the series of images and pasted them to form an image having larger field of view. With the advancement of personal computing equipment, the creation of image mosaic has entered the consumer market. Thus, automation of the process is an important issue. This paper proposes a method for automatic generation of mosaics using pixel based image registration method using Hierarchical approach. We show the application of our method on planar panoramic mosaics. We provide experimental results in support of our proposed method.

Title: Switched multi stage vector quantization using soft decision scheme
Source title: Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2008
Affiliations: Department of ECE, Govt. Institute of Electronics, Secunderabad, AP, India; Department of ECE, J.N.T.U.CE, Hyderabad, AP, India; Department of ECE, K.L.C E, Guntur, AP, India; Department of ECE, R.V.R and J.C.CE, Guntur, AP, India
Authors with affiliations: Srinivas, K., Department of ECE, Govt. Institute of Electronics, Secunderabad, AP, India; Latha, M.M., Department of ECE, J.N.T.U.CE, Hyderabad, AP, India; Siddaiah, P., Department of ECE, K.L.C E, Guntur, AP, India; Ram, M.S.S., Department of ECE, R.V.R and J.C.CE, Guntur, AP, India
Abstract: This paper investigates the use of switched multi stage vector quantization (SWMSVQ) technique using soft decision scheme for coding of narrow band speech signals. This technique is a hybrid of switched vector quantization technique and multi stage vector quantization (MSVQ) technique. SWMSVQ quantizes the linear predictive coefficients (LPC) in terms of line spectral frequencies (LSF). SWMSVQ provides better trade off between bit rate and spectral distortion performance when compared to split vector quantization (SVQ), multi stage vector quantization and in a comparable manner with switched split vector quantization (SSVQ) techniques, but this is achieved at the expense of complexity when compared to SVQ and SSVQ, memory requirements when compared to SVQ, MSVQ and SSVQ. So in order to improve the spectral distortion performance, to reduce the complexity and memory requirements of SWMSVQ the switching technique is adopted at every stage of SWMSVQ. In order to reduce the computational complexity further a well known technique called the binary search technique is used for searching of the codebooks and the sorting of codebooks is done by using the Quick sort method.

Title: Laser vision based seam tracking system for welding automation
Source title: Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2008

Abstract: PC based machine vision systems can be used for online control of welding process. In this implementation, a seam tracking system which uses high intensity laser source, camera and a PC with MATLAB 7.0 has been developed. The algorithm used is a typical machine vision algorithm. Computationally much faster, custom machine vision algorithm which still solves the purpose is also quoted in the paper. Processing times (time for 1 complete image acquisition, processing and control) of 0.41 seconds for typical and 0.035 seconds for custom machine vision algorithms are achieved. This paper fully describes the implementation and the current work.

Title: A hybrid system based on single and multi-frame techniques for super-resolution of video sequence
Source title: Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2008
Affiliations: Department of Mathematics and Computer Science, Sri Sathya Sai University, Prasanthi Nilayam, India
Authors with affiliations: Arun, R., Department of Mathematics and Computer Science, Sri Sathya Sai University, Prasanthi Nilayam, India; Chandrasekaran, V., Department of Mathematics and Computer Science, Sri Sathya Sai University, Prasanthi Nilayam, India
Abstract: In one of the methods of multi-frame super-resolution, a high resolution video is reconstructed from a low resolution video of a scene by adding the high frequency components estimated from the sub-pixel shift between the frames using pyramidal tracking and iterative back projection algorithms. In contrast, super resolving a single frame low resolution image is called Example-based super-resolution (EBSR). This is achieved by recovering the missing high frequency contents from a large number of example image patches in a database. In this paper we propose a novel hybrid approach to construct a super resolved video sequence which uses the example-based method for the preprocessing of low resolution video frames as input to the multi-frame super resolution. The approach to use EBSR in the preprocessing stage of low resolution frames acts as an image model error correction process. In this paper, we demonstrate that the proposed hybrid technique yields better results than the chosen stand-alone multi-frame technique.
Author Keywords: Example-based super-resolution; Hybrid super-resolution; Iterative back projection; Multi-frame super-resolution
Index Keywords: Back-projection algorithms; Example-based super-resolution; High frequencies; High frequency components; High resolutions; Hybrid approaches; Hybrid super-resolution; Hybrid techniques; Image models; Image patches; Iterative back projection; Low resolution images; Low resolution videos; Low resolutions; Multi-frame super-resolution; Stand -alone; Sub-pixel shifts; Video sequences; Computer vision; Error correction; Imaging systems; Video recording; Optical resolving power

Authors: Chinniah M.
Title: Fuzzy image processing for offline signature verification and interpretation
Source title: Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2008
Affiliations: Department of Computer Centre, Avinashilingam University for Women, Coimbatore, Tamilnadu, India
Authors with affiliations: Chinniah, M., Department of Computer Centre, Avinashilingam University for Women, Coimbatore, Tamilnadu, India
Abstract: Offline Signature Verification and Interpretation is an important part of many business processes and consists of processes for verifying and interpreting the identity of a person by checking the signature against samples kept in a database and helping the user to interpret them. To achieve this objective the proposed system is divided into four components. (i) Data capture - the process of converting the signature into digital form as offline procedure. (ii) Preprocessing -This step is used to reduce noise, to apply filters, to zoom-in/zoom-out an image, etc. The system introduces fuzzy logic to improve the quality of images obtained during preprocessing which greatly enhances the accuracy of the image and significantly helps in refining the image for the process of comparing the signatures. (iii) Feature Extraction and segmentation - to obtain the boundaries and partitioning of the signature. (iv) Comparison and interpretation - matches the input signature with the templates consisting of three sample signatures. The result given as a fit ratio is obtained by thresholding the fit value. Hamming Distance algorithm is used to justify the threshold value used. The comparison process uses edge detection and pixel matching techniques. The result can be further improved by using another threshold value to compensate noises in the captured signatures. The noise would have to be introduced due to changes in the background, varying strokes, etc. The output will interpret whether the signature is accepted or rejected with appropriate explanations. Several approaches to obtain the optimal threshold value from the reference set are investigated.
Author Keywords: Fuzzy preprocessing; Hamming distance; Segmentation; Signature interpretation; Signature verification; Stroke comparison
Index Keywords: Fuzzy preprocessing; Segmentation; Signature interpretation; Signature verification; Stroke comparison; Computer vision; Edge detection; Feature extraction; Fuzzy logic; Hamming distance; Imaging systems; Meats; Image matching
Correspondence Address: Chinniah, M.; Department of Computer Centre, Avinashilingam University for Women, Coimbatore, Tamilnadu, India
Abbreviated Source Title: Proc. Int. Conf. Image Process., Comput. Vis., Pattern Recogn., IPCV

Authors: Vithiya R., Priyadharsini Y., Dharanya S., Narmatha S., Parthiban N.C., Felix L.A.L., Rao M.N.
Title: Depth field computation using perspective projections on various geometrical projection planes
Source title: Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2008
Affiliations: St.Joseph's College of Engineering and Technology, Tanjore, TN, India
Authors with affiliations: Vithiya, R., St.Joseph's College of Engineering and Technology, Tanjore, TN, India; Priyadharsini, Y., St.Joseph's College of Engineering and Technology, Tanjore, TN, India; Dharanya, S., St.Joseph's College of Engineering and Technology, Tanjore, TN, India; Narmatha, S., St.Joseph's College of Engineering and Technology, Tanjore, TN, India; Parthiban, N.C., St.Joseph's College of Engineering and Technology, Tanjore, TN, India; Felix, L.A.L., St.Joseph's College of Engineering and Technology, Tanjore, TN, India; Rao, M.N., St.Joseph's College of Engineering and Technology, Tanjore, TN, India
Abstract: The work related to perspective 2D images of a given 3D environment is mostly confined to its 3D visualization. Computation of actual depth field (Z) using the method of perspective projection with the projection plane of flat geometry (FPP) is reported in the literature. The relation between the depth field (d) as viewed on the FPP and the corresponding Z is highly non-linear. This disagreement is higher for Z values nearer to and far away from the FPP. This behavior is mainly due to the Flat nature of the projection plane. An attempt is made in this paper to use projection planes having Flat, Cylindrical (CPP) and Spherical (SPP) geometry and to investigate the effect of the geometry of the projection plane on the above referred disagreement. Second order equations using the method of least squares are proposed to compute the depth field (Z?) for observed set of values of d, under the three methods. The percent variation of Z' from Z for the set of values of d are computed. Region Segmentation of d having ideal agreement between Z' and Z under each method is proposed. The percent ranges of Z corresponding to above agreement under each method are arrived at. It has been concluded that the SPP method exhibited the maximum percent range of Z for an ideal agreement between Z' and Z.
Author Keywords: Depth field; Flat; Method of least squares; Spherical and cylindrical projection planes
Index Keywords: 2d images; 3-d environments; 3-d visualizations; Depth field; Field computations; Flat; Geometrical projections; Method of least squares; Non-linear; Perspective projections; Region segmentations; Second-order equations; Spherical and cylindrical projection planes; Work-related; Z values; Computational geometry; Computer vision; Curve fitting; Imaging systems; Spheres; Surface plasmon resonance; Three dimensional; Three dimensional computer graphics; Least squares approximations

Authors: Nain N., Agarwal N., Gour P., Talawar R.P., Chandra S.
Title: Face recognition using PCA and LDA with Singular Value Decomposition(SVD)
Source title: Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2008
Affiliations: Department of Computer Engineering, Malaviya National Institute of Technology, Jaipur - 302017, India
Authors with affiliations: Nain, N., Department of Computer Engineering, Malaviya National Institute of Technology, Jaipur - 302017, India; Agarwal, N.; Gour, P.; Talawar, R.P.; Chandra, S.
Abstract: Linear Discriminant Analy-sis(LDA) is well-known scheme for feature extraction and dimension reduction which is based on discrimination between classes. It has been used widely in many applications involving high-dimensional data, such as face recognition. Linear Discriminant Analysis to high-dimensional pattern classification often suffers from "small sample size"(SSS) problem arising from the small number of available training samples. In this paper we present a new variant on Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA) for face recognition by reducing dimensions of input data up to square root of original dimensions using two dimensional representation with the help of matrix and after that using singular value decomposition to reduce dimensions of scatter matrix to remove the singularity problem and SSS problem. Experiments on ORL face database shows the effectiveness of our proposed algorithm and results compared with other LDA based methods shows that the proposed scheme gives comparatively better results than previous methods in terms of recognition rate and reduced time complexity which is almost fourth part of the previous algorithms.
Author Keywords: Face recognition; LDA/QR and singular value decomposition (SVD); Linear discriminant analysis (LDA); Principal component analysis (PCA); Relevance weighted LDA

Authors: Goyal C., Nain N., Laxmi V., Bhadviya B., Pandit A.
Title: Feature point detection for real time applications
Source title: Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2008
Affiliations: Department of Engineering, Malaviya National Institute of Technology, Jaipur, 302017, India
Authors with affiliations: Goyal, C., Department of Engineering, Malaviya National Institute of Technology, Jaipur, 302017, India; Nain, N.; Laxmi, V.; Bhadviya, B.; Pandit, A.
Abstract: This paper presents a new feature point detector that is accurate, efficient and fast. A detailed qualitative evaluation of the proposed feature point detector for grayscale images is also done. Experiments have proved that this feature point detector is robust to affine transformations, noise and perspective deformations. More over the proposed detector requires only 22 additions per pixel to evaluate the interest point and its strength, making it one of the fastest detectors. The accuracy and speed of this algorithm makes it a strong contender for ASIC and hardware implementations and applications requiring real time feature point abstraction.

Authors: Korikana S.K., Chandrasekaran V., Madhumathi D.S.
Title: Robust segmentation and feature extraction for identification of malignant white blood cells
Source title: Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2008
Affiliations: Department of Mathematics and Computer Science, Sri Sathya Sai University, Prasanthi Nilayam, AP, India; Department of Oncology, Kidwai Memorial Institute of Oncology, Bangalore, Karnataka, India
Authors with affiliations: Korikana, S.K., Department of Mathematics and Computer Science, Sri Sathya Sai University, Prasanthi Nilayam, AP, India; Chandrasekaran, V., Department of Mathematics and Computer Science, Sri Sathya Sai University, Prasanthi Nilayam, AP, India; Madhumathi, D.S., Department of Oncology, Kidwai Memorial Institute of Oncology, Bangalore, Karnataka, India
Abstract: Automated detection and classification of white blood cells is a major step in diagnosis of several diseases like Acute Lymphoblas-tic Leukemia(ALL). The traditional procedure requires a haematologist to manually count and classify the cells with the help of a microscope. An automated diagnosis system will alleviate the workload and the influence of subjective factors. Automated detection involves removal of red blood cells and platelets from the background. The main drawback of the existing methods is their inefficiency in handling cell images originating from different sources and environment. In this work, an automated system that segments cell images with varying background and illumination conditions is designed. This is followed by a robust feature extraction technique. The results of classification show the better performance in comparison to the conventional methods.
Author Keywords: Biomedical image processing; Feature extraction; Segmentation; White blood cell detection

Authors: Amudha J., Soman K.P., Vasanth K.
Title: Video annotation using saliency
Source title: Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2008
Affiliations: Department of Information Technology, Amrita Vishwa Vidyapeetham, Coimbatore, Tamilnadu, India; Centre for Computational Engg. and Networking, Amrita Vishwa Vidyapeetham, Coimbatore, Tamilnadu, India; Department of Computer Science, Amrita Vishwa Vidyapeetham, Coimbatore, Tamilnadu, India
Authors with affiliations: Amudha, J., Department of Information Technology, Amrita Vishwa Vidyapeetham, Coimbatore, Tamilnadu, India; Soman, K.P., Centre for Computational Engg. and Networking, Amrita Vishwa Vidyapeetham, Coimbatore, Tamilnadu, India; Vasanth, K., Department of Computer Science, Amrita Vishwa Vidyapeetham, Coimbatore, Tamilnadu, India
Abstract: Recent advances in multimedia technologies lead to a massive storage of multimedia data, which in turn urges us to create the metadata about the data for facilitating a sophisticated search based on their contents among the huge multimedia database. Among these data, video is the most challenging one because of their large size and highly unstructured nature. This paper presents an approach for video annotation based on human perception by annotating the key objects present in the video using the technique combining Bottom up- Saliency based region selection and SIFT.

Authors: Vaishnavi R., Kumar G.V., Selvam M.D., Rani W.P., Thasneem R.H., Dhanasekaran D., Rao M.N.
Title: Visual computing of attributes of geometric solids using color queuing theory and its engineering applications
Source title: Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2008
Affiliations: St.Joseph's College of Engineering and Technology, Tanjore, TN, India
Authors with affiliations: Vaishnavi, R., St.Joseph's College of Engineering and Technology, Tanjore, TN, India; Kumar, G.V., St.Joseph's College of Engineering and Technology, Tanjore, TN, India; Selvam, M.D., St.Joseph's College of Engineering and Technology, Tanjore, TN, India; Rani, W.P., St.Joseph's College of Engineering and Technology, Tanjore, TN, India; Thasneem, R.H., St.Joseph's College of Engineering and Technology, Tanjore, TN, India; Dhanasekaran, D., St.Joseph's College of Engineering and Technology, Tanjore, TN, India; Rao, M.N., St.Joseph's College of Engineering and Technology, Tanjore, TN, India
Abstract: Literature review revealed that, "Color Queuing Theory" (CQT) was applied for analyzing the variation of color intensity of surfaces of moving objects, studying the surface texture of solids etc. However, no reference was made in the literature on the application of CQT for computing the attributes of Geometric Objects. An attempt is made in this paper to investigate the application of CQT for Visual Computing (VC) of attributes of Geometric Objects like straight lines, planes, solids etc and its Engineering Applications. The computed values obtained under the current method are compared with the corresponding values obtained under the conventional method using the principles of orthographic projections and also compared with the theoretical values, to investigate the effectiveness of the current method. It has been concluded that the computed values of attributes under current method are in excellent agreement with the corresponding theoretical values and values obtained using the principles of orthographic projections.
Author Keywords: Color queuing theory (CQT); Moving objects, attributes; Orthographic projections; Visual computing (VC)

Authors: Patel B.V., Meshram B.B.
Title: Content based video retrieval using color-texture features
Source title: Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2008
Affiliations: Computer Technology Department, Shah and Anchor Kutchhi Polytechnic, Mumbai, Maharashtra, India; Department of Computer Technology, Veermata Jijabai Technological Institute, Mumbai, Maharashtra, India

Abstract: Search and retrieval is no longer restricted to traditional database retrieval applications. In order to meet the demands for retrieval of audio-visual contents, there is a need of efficient solution to search, identify and filter various types of audio-visual content of interest of the user using non-text based technologies. In this paper, we propose multimedia data retrieval system by integrating the color and texture features of the video.

Authors: Koduru S.C., Chandrasekaran V.
Title: Random walk based baker maps for chaos based image encryption
Source title: Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2008
Affiliations: Department of Mathematics and Computer Science, Sri Sathya Sai University, Prashanthi Nilayam, India
Authors with affiliations: Koduru, S.C., Department of Mathematics and Computer Science, Sri Sathya Sai University, Prashanthi Nilayam, India; Chandrasekaran, V., Department of Mathematics and Computer Science, Sri Sathya Sai University, Prashanthi Nilayam, India
Abstract: Chaos theory has been applied extensively in the past decade to cryptography. In particular, higher dimensional maps like the 3D Baker and Cat maps have been proposed for chaos based image encryption. In these schemes however, the Baker map traverses the image in a predictable manner - horizontally to the end of the block and then the row above the current row. For better security, we propose a Baker map based on a novel random traversal of the image using the sparse decomposition of images. We demonstrate that this encryption scheme results in the de-correlation of adjacent pixels and histogram flattening, with the added advantage of the random traversal of the image leading to enhanced security.
Author Keywords: Baker map; Chaos; Image encryption; Path generation; Random walk

Authors: Asthana A., Dutta R., Jain A., Gupta D., Goel S.
Title: Content based retrieval system for archaeological images
Source title: Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2008
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Information Technology, Jaypee Institute of Information Technology University (JIITU), Noida, India
Authors with affiliations: Asthana, A., Department of Computer Science and Information Technology, Jaypee Institute of Information Technology University (JIITU), Noida, India; Dutta, R., Department of Computer Science and Information Technology, Jaypee Institute of Information Technology University (JIITU), Noida, India; Jain, A., Department of Computer Science and Information Technology, Jaypee Institute of Information Technology University (JIITU), Noida, India; Gupta, D., Department of Computer Science and Information Technology, Jaypee Institute of Information Technology University (JIITU), Noida, India; Goel, S., Department of Computer Science and Information Technology, Jaypee Institute of Information Technology University (JIITU), Noida, India
Abstract: Most of the existing image retrieval systems take the textual query from the user and utilize the metadata associated with the database images to retrieve the result. However, the results of these systems are substandard. This paper presents a framework for the matching and retrieval of archaeological images based on highly specific visual features. As a result, the potential users of the system (archaeologists, art historians, curators and students) will have a tool to refine the search for digital images. The system incorporates the identification of distinct visual feature vectors, which are extracted from each image in the database through implementation of high level image feature based algorithms such as Robust Invariant Features (RIF), Scale Invariant Feature Transform (SIFT) and low level image feature based Hierarchical Tree Matching (HTM). The detailed comparison of these approaches, by reviewing their current capabilities, limitations, and potential usefulness in the field of archaeology is presented.
Author Keywords: Archaeology; Content based image retrieval (CBIR); Hierarchical tree matching (HTM); Robust invariant features (RIF); Scale invariant feature transform (SIFT)

Authors: C.v. J., Unni R.K.
Title: Fusion of multispectral and panchromatic images using nonsubsampled contourlet transform
Source title: Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2008
Affiliations: Department of Electronics and Communication Engineering, College of Engineering Trivandrum, University of Kerala, Trivandrum, Kerala, India
Authors with affiliations: C.v., J., Department of Electronics and Communication Engineering, College of Engineering Trivandrum, University of Kerala, Trivandrum, Kerala, India; Unni, R.K., Department of Electronics and Communication Engineering, College of Engineering Trivandrum, University of Kerala, Trivandrum, Kerala, India
Abstract: This paper proposes two novel transform domain approaches for fusing a high resolution panchromatic (PAN) image and low resolution multispectral (MS) images using the nonsubsampled contourlet transform (NSCT). The non-subsampled contourlet transform decomposes the image into several directional subbands at flexible resolutions. The directional subbands of the MS image decomposition are modified using the corresponding bands from the PAN image. The inverse transform gives the fused high resolution multispectral (HRMS) image. Best result is obtained when the intensity information from the MS image is also used for merging. In this paper, we also propose the use of parameters like structural similarity and edge stability to measure the quality of the fused image, in addition to the standard parameters like correlation coefficient, PSNR, RASE and ERGAS. The proposed methods show better performance compared to other fusion techniques like Brovey transform, IHS fusion, a trous wavelet fusion and curvelet fusion, especially in terms of structural similarity and edge stability.

Authors: Nain N., Bm D., Kumar D., Gautham B., Baswal M.
Title: Minutiae - Based fingerprint matching
Source title: Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2008
Affiliations: Department of Computer Engineering, Malaviya National Institute of Technology, Jaipur-302017, India
Authors with affiliations: Nain, N., Department of Computer Engineering, Malaviya National Institute of Technology, Jaipur-302017, India; Bm, D.; Kumar, D.; Gautham, B.; Baswal, M.
Abstract: We propose a new minutiae based approach to match fingerprint images using similar structures. Distortion poses serious threats through altered geometry, increases false minutiae, and hence makes it very difficult to find a perfect match. This algorithm divides fingerprint images into two concentric circular regions - inner and outer - based on the degree of distortion. The algorithm assigns weight-ages for a minutiae-pair match based on the region in which the pair exists. The implementation of the algorithm on the standard FVC DB shows robust performance.

Authors: Nain N., Jindal G., Garg A., Jain A., Sikarwar Y.
Title: Dynamic multi-level thresholding based morphological edge detection
Source title: Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2008
Affiliations: Malaviya National Institute of Technology, Jaipur, Department of Computer Engineering, JLN Marg, Jaipur - 302017, India
Authors with affiliations: Nain, N., Malaviya National Institute of Technology, Jaipur, Department of Computer Engineering, JLN Marg, Jaipur - 302017, India; Jindal, G., Malaviya National Institute of Technology, Jaipur, Department of Computer Engineering, JLN Marg, Jaipur - 302017, India; Garg, A., Malaviya National Institute of Technology, Jaipur, Department of Computer Engineering, JLN Marg, Jaipur - 302017, India; Jain, A., Malaviya National Institute of Technology, Jaipur, Department of Computer Engineering, JLN Marg, Jaipur - 302017, India; Sikarwar, Y., Malaviya National Institute of Technology, Jaipur, Department of Computer Engineering, JLN Marg, Jaipur - 302017, India
Abstract: Edges typically exists on the boundary between two different regions in an image. Edge detection is the process of determining where the boundaries of objects fall within an image. It is an important concept, both in the area of object recognition and motion tracking. A dynamic thresholding based edge-detection method using morphological operator as gradient is presented. The novelty of the approach is in the efficient peak detection algorithm which decides the modality of the image and also the usage of morphological operations in the extraction of one pixel thick boundary which is continuous in a segment.

Authors: Kher R., Kher H.
Title: Performance analysis of various constituent wavelets for contextual compression of ultrasound medical images
Source title: Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2008
Affiliations: EC Department, G H Patel College of Engineering and Technology, Vallabh Vidyanagar, Gujarat, India; EC Department, A D Patel Institute of Technology, Vallabh Vidyanagar, Gujarat, India
Authors with affiliations: Kher, R., EC Department, G H Patel College of Engineering and Technology, Vallabh Vidyanagar, Gujarat, India; Kher, H., EC Department, A D Patel Institute of Technology, Vallabh Vidyanagar, Gujarat, India
Abstract: Contextual compression of Ultrasound (US) images aims to compress the diagnostically important region, Region of Interest (RoI), with a much better quality and lesser compression ratio and the unimportant area (background) with poorer quality and much higher compression ratio to attain overall superior compression ratio. In the present work, the RoI and background are separated out and the Wavelet Transform coding has been applied on them. Three constituent (mother) wavelets viz. Haar, Daubechies 3 (db3), and Symlet 2 (sym2) have been applied for compressing the images. The comparison of their compression performance using the well known mathematical parameters viz. mean square error (MSE), peak signal to noise ratio (PSNR) and correlation coefficient (CoC) has been made. The contextual approach of compressing an image gives encouraging results, i.e. the compression ratio (CR) of as high as 52:1 (bpp of 0.155) with extremely good quality of the compressed RoI area and reasonably good quality of the compressed background area.
Author Keywords: Contextual compression; Region of interest (RoI); Ultrasound (US) image; Wavelet transform coding

Authors: Kulkarni G., Kulkarni M.V., Dhore M.L.
Title: Fractal image compression performance analysis with various partitioning methods of square and spiral architecture
Source title: Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2008
Affiliations: Department of Computer Engineering, Vishwakarma Institute of Technology, Pune, Maharashtra, India
Authors with affiliations: Kulkarni, G., Department of Computer Engineering, Vishwakarma Institute of Technology, Pune, Maharashtra, India; Kulkarni, M.V., Department of Computer Engineering, Vishwakarma Institute of Technology, Pune, Maharashtra, India; Dhore, M.L., Department of Computer Engineering, Vishwakarma Institute of Technology, Pune, Maharashtra, India
Abstract: The basic idea of Fractal image compression is to represent images as a fixed point of a contractive Iterated Function System. Till date the method is researched with many partitioning techniques as, fixed partitioning, quad tree partitioning etc. The new development in this field, the Spiral Architecture is a novel image structure on which images are displayed as a collection of hexagonal pixels. But till date there are no available image capture or display devices to support this structure. Hence in order to implement the theoretical results, new mimicking spiral architecture is chosen. This mimic spiral architecture tries to retain image resolution and does not introduce the distortion. This paper tries to compare the results obtained on Spiral Architecture with the traditional square structure with various partitioning methods in terms of peak signal to noise ratio (PSNR) and compression ratio.
Author Keywords: Fractal image compression; Iterated function system; Spiral architecture; Square structure

Authors: Bansal A., Garg D., Gupta A., Jain N., Kumar P.
Title: Offline signature verification: A contour based mechanism using HMM
Source title: Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2008
Affiliations: Department of Computer Engineering, NSIT, New Delhi, India; Newgen Software Technologies Limited, New Delhi, India

Abstract: Offline signature verification can be linked as a biometric classifier problem that categorizes a signature into two classes: genuine and forged. In this paper a HMM based contour matching algorithm has been proposed that takes into account the intrapersonal variations for a user set and authenticates the given sample signature. The model is trained with 8 original signatures and given a test sample; it is validated based on the probabilistic data i.e. matched percentage with the trained model. Results validate the effectiveness of the proposed mechanism.

Authors: Velichety S., Verma A., Tapaswi S.
Title: WADIA: An efficient algorithm for watermarking of images with abrupt intensity variations
Source title: Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Image Processing, Computer Vision, and Pattern Recognition, IPCV 2008
Affiliations: IIITM, Gwalior, Madhya Pradesh, India
Authors with affiliations: Velichety, S., IIITM, Gwalior, Madhya Pradesh, India; Verma, A., IIITM, Gwalior, Madhya Pradesh, India; Tapaswi, S., IIITM, Gwalior, Madhya Pradesh, India
Abstract: The growth of computer networks has propelled the transformation from conventional libraries to digital libraries. At the same time it has also lead to piracy and illegal distribution of the content. This has given rise to the need for the owner of the content to use watermarking. In our paper we present an efficient visible watermarking algorithm for images using DCT (Digital Cosine Transform). We have named it WADIA (Watermarking Algorithm in DCT for Images with Abrupt intensity variations).This algorithm proves to be efficient especially for images with sharp intensity variations and double edges. Also this algorithm uses a Gaussian filter before detecting the edges that reduces the random noise in the image thereby limiting the false edges. For designing this algorithm we have made use of a Human Visual System (HVS) which considers the characteristics of perception of the human eye. We have also presented the experimental PSNR (Peak Signal to Noise Ratio) values of this algorithm along with those of various other algorithms that use first order edge detection methods.

Authors: Mehta S., Anusha K.
Title: Decision support system for health care specialists: A fuzzy data mining approach
Source title: Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, ICAI 2008 and Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Machine Learning; Models, Technologies and Applications
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Information Technology, Jaypee Institute of Information Technology University, Noida, UP, India

Abstract: The Health Care sector is one of the most crucial and real world domains in the globe, with no assumptions being allowed in the actual databases. One of the most challenging tasks that is faced by this sector is to reduce costs while increasing the quality of services delivered. There is vast amount of data at the disposal of the health care facilities. Knowledge Discovery from this data and also timely analysis can lead to efficient decision-making. In this paper we aim at designing a decision support system that incorporates fuzzy data mining approach in critical and dynamic arenas of life like health care to extract useful information from the database. The integration of fuzzy logic with Knowledge Discovery in databases facilitates efficient handling of uncertainty in the health care databases, for the expansion and deeper penetration of health services in the underdeveloped states of India.

Title: A Gene regulatory network approach for failure rate prediction in distributed systems

Abstract: This paper proposes a new paradigm for distributed biologically inspired computing that is derived from gene regulatory networks, for classification problems. Gene regulatory networks are models of genes and dynamic interactions that take place between them. The differential equation representations of such networks resemble both recurrent neural networks as well as idiotypic networks in immune systems, although more complex than either. The proposed method of classification is then applied to predict the failue rate power distribution systems. Results of this study provide further insights into the new scheme.

Authors: Mehta S., Gulati A., Kalra A.
Title: A hybrid model for a search engine
Source title: Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, ICAI 2008 and Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Machine Learning; Models, Technologies and Applications
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, Jaypee Institute of Information Technology University, Noida-201 307, India
Authors with affiliations: Mehta, S., Department of Computer Science, Jaypee Institute of Information Technology University, Noida-201 307, India; Gulati, A., Department of Computer Science, Jaypee Institute of Information Technology University, Noida-201 307, India; Kalra, A., Department of Computer Science, Jaypee Institute of Information Technology University, Noida-201 307, India
Abstract: The large size and the dynamic nature of the Web highlight the need for continuous support and updating of Web based information retrieval systems such as search engines. Due to resource constraints, search engines usually have difficulties in striking the right balance between time and space limitations. In this paper, we propose a simple yet effective model for a search engine. We suggest a hybrid design which brings together the best features that constitute a search engine. To give an overview, the whole mechanism of how a search engine works is provided. Further, the model is discussed in detail. We then demonstrate how the proposed model, which embodies features like Fingerprinting, Compressor, Importance number and Refresher can improve the efficiency of a simple search engine if applied on a large scale.

Authors: Chawla S., Bedi P.
Title: Finding hubs and authorities using Information scent to improve the Information retrieval precision
Source title: Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, ICAI 2008 and Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Machine Learning; Models, Technologies and Applications
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, University of Delhi, Delhi, India
Authors with affiliations: Chawla, S., Department of Computer Science, University of Delhi, Delhi, India; Bedi, P., Department of Computer Science, University of Delhi, Delhi, India
Abstract: Improvement in the effectiveness of Information Retrieval on the Web in one such research area in which efforts are going on to improve the precision by satisfying the user need effectively and efficiently. To improve the precision of Information Retrieval on the Web there is a need to understand the information need of the query issued by user and retrieve the good authorities and hub web pages for a particular information need implied by the query. Good authorities are those pages which are rich source of information for a specific information need. Good Hub pages are those pages which contain link to good authorities for a given information need. This paper identifies the good authorities and hub pages for a particular information need using Information Scent in HITS with query sessions mining. Information scent is used to identify the relevance of the clicked URLs in the query sessions of the user with respect to the information need of the query sessions. The approach proposed in this paper uses information need of query sessions modeled using information scent and content vector of clicked URLs in the sessions to cluster query sessions with similar information need. Each derived cluster is used in HITS algorithm to generate good hubs and authorities pages for each information need represented by cluster using information scent. The input query is then used to select the cluster that contains the high scent authorities and hub page for the information need associated with the input query. Performance of the proposed approach is evaluated with an experimental study of query sessions mining of the "Google" Search engine web history and the experimental results shows the improvement of the Information Retrieval precision.
Author Keywords: Authorities; Clustering; Hub; Information retrieval; Information scent; Search engine

Abstract: Micro fluidics-based biochips, also referred to as lab-on-a-chip (LoC), are devices that integrate fluid-handling functions such as sample preparation, analysis, separation, and detection. This emerging technology with biosensors [1] combines electronics with biology to open new application areas including point-of-care diagnosis, on-chip DNA analysis, and automated drug delivery. Design procedures of digital micro fluidic biochips are suggested [2] with automation and testing techniques to handle increased complexity. The automation of design and testing of digital micro fluidic biochip with systematic droplet routing method can be integrated with biochip synthesis [3J. An expert system design is suggested in this paper for detecting the diseases.

Authors: Praseeda Lekshmi V., Sasikumar M., Naveen S.
Title: PCA based facial expression using wavelets
Source title: Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, ICAI 2008 and Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Machine Learning; Models, Technologies and Applications
Affiliations: College of Engineering Kidangoor (CEK), Kottayam, Kerala, India; Marian Engineering College (MEC), Trivandrum, Kerala, India; College of Engineering Trivandrum (CET), Trivandrum, Kerala, India
Authors with affiliations: Praseeda Lekshmi, V., College of Engineering Kidangoor (CEK), Kottayam, Kerala, India; Sasikumar, M., Marian Engineering College (MEC), Trivandrum, Kerala, India; Naveen, S., College of Engineering Trivandrum (CET), Trivandrum, Kerala, India
Abstract: Face recognition and expression analysis is one of the most challenging research areas in the field of computer vision. Though face exhibits different facial expressions, which can be instantly recognized by human eyes, it is very difficult for a computer to extract and use the information content from these expressions. In this paper we present a method to analyze facial expression from images by using Gabor Wavelets and Principal Component Analysis (PCA) method. Gabor filtering is done on face images and the resulting vectors are projected on to a feature space and the weight vectors are compared to get minimum variation. Our method reliably works even with faces, which carry heavy expressions. This method exhibits a good performance ratio.

Abstract: Cancer is one of leading cause of death [1] throughout the world. Prognostic assessment of cancer patient is indispensable in medical care. It helps the doctor to determine the therapy to be adopted and provides indication regarding quality of life and its possible financial implication. A neural Network based model has been developed for the prognosis of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML). The developed Neural Network has been tested and an accuracy of 90.48% has been observed.

Authors: Bhat S., Anantaram C., Jain H.
Title: An architecture for intelligent email based workflow interface to business applications
Source title: Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, ICAI 2008 and Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Machine Learning; Models, Technologies and Applications
Affiliations: Innovation Lab., Tata Consultancy Services Ltd., Gurgaon, Haryana, India
Authors with affiliations: Bhat, S., Innovation Lab., Tata Consultancy Services Ltd., Gurgaon, Haryana, India; Anantaram, C., Innovation Lab., Tata Consultancy Services Ltd., Gurgaon, Haryana, India; Jain, H., Innovation Lab., Tata Consultancy Services Ltd., Gurgaon, Haryana, India
Abstract: This paper aims to describe an intelligent email based workflow interface. In our work, we concentrate on providing an innovative way of handling the business workflow via email as an interface. The user should be able to pose queries/tasks to the business application via email. The system should process the request received and should further trigger sub-processes at the appropriate level to complete the workflow. In case either the context is not clear or adequate information is not provided, the system should respond seeking clarification or requesting for the complete information. Since the query/task posed via email will be in free format text (English), natural language processing becomes mandatory to extract data from the content of the mail. The architecture described in this paper allows users to carry out a dialog with the system to aid in the retrieval and insertion of relevant information, to complete the workflow.

Title: A Tabu based Neural Network training algorithm for equalization of communication channels
Source title: Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, ICAI 2008 and Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Machine Learning; Models, Technologies and Applications

Abstract: This paper presents a new approach to equalization of communication channels using Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs). A novel method of training the ANNs using Tabu based Back Propagation (TBBP) Algorithm is described. The algorithm uses the Tabu Search (TS) to improve the performance of the equalizer as it searches for global minima which is many a time escaped while Back Propagation (BP) algorithm is applied for this purpose. From the results it can be noted that the proposed algorithm improves the classification capability of the ANNs in differentiating the received data.

Title: Controlling multiple motors using a single microcontroller

Abstract: In today's world of emerging technologies, the recent development in electrical drive technology is motivated by increasing the requirements of industrial applications for higher performance, better reliability and lower cost. These are due to the advances in several areas in power electronics, control theory and microprocessor technology. The performance of digitally controlled drives is constantly improved by using faster microprocessors capable of complex computing. Initially applications like HVAC (Heating Ventilation and Air conditioning) and centrifugal water controller systems having two motors in their system avoided variable speed drives because of their high cost. In the progress of drives technologies this paper shows how control of multiple motors can be achieved without employing more than one controller.

Authors: Mohan C.K., Dhananjaya N., Yegnanarayana B.
Title: Video shot segmentation using late fusion technique
Source title: Proceedings - 7th International Conference on Machine Learning and Applications, ICMLA 2008
Affiliations: National Institute of Technology Karnataka Suratkal, Srinivasnagar, 575 025, Karnataka, India; Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, Chennai - 600 036, India; Internation Institute of Information Technology, Hyderabad - 500 032, India

Abstract: In this paper, a new method for detecting shot boundaries in video sequences using a late fusion technique is proposed. The method uses color histogram as the feature, and processes each bin separately for detecting shot boundaries. The decisions from individual bins are combined later for hypothesizing the presence of shot boundaries. The method provides a certain degree of robustness against illumination and camera/object motion, as it ignores small changes in the bins. While the early fusion techniques rely on the extent of change in color information, the proposed technique relies on the number of significant changes. Experimental results successfully validate the new method and show that it can effectively detect both abrupt and gradual transitions. © 2008 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Early fusion; Late fusion; Shot boundary detection; Video content analysis; Video segmentation

Authors: Saha S.K., Mitra P., Sarkar S.
Title: Word clustering and word selection based feature reduction for maxent based Hindi NER
Source title: ACL-08: HLT - 46th Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics: Human Language Technologies, Proceedings of the Conference
Affiliations: Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, WB 721302, India
Authors with affiliations: Saha, S.K., Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, WB 721302, India; Mitra, P., Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, WB 721302, India; Sarkar, S., Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, WB 721302, India
Abstract: Statistical machine learning methods are employed to train a Named Entity Recognizer from annotated data. Methods like Maximum Entropy and Conditional Random Fields make use of features for the training purpose. These methods tend to overfit when the available training corpus is limited especially if the number of features is large or the number of values for a feature is large. To overcome this we proposed two techniques for feature reduction based on word clustering and selection. A number of word similarity measures are proposed for clustering words for the Named Entity Recognition task. A few corpus based statistical measures are used for important word selection. The feature reduction techniques lead to a substantial performance improvement over baseline Maximum Entropy technique. © 2008 Association for Computational Linguistics.
Index Keywords: Conditional random field; Feature reduction; Machine learning methods; Maximum entropy; Named entities; Named entity recognition; Performance improvements; Selection based; Statistical measures; Training corpus; Training purpose; Word clustering; Word similarity; Computational linguistics; Learning systems; Maximum entropy methods; Feature extraction

Authors: Singh V., Rajpal N., Srikanta Murthy K.
Title: An algorithmic approach based on fuzzy vector quantization and wavelet decomposition for image compression
Source title: International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Pattern Recognition 2008, AIPR 2008
Affiliations: GGSIPU, New Delhi, India; ECE Dept. PESIT Bangalore, India
Authors with affiliations: Singh, V., GGSIPU, New Delhi, India, ECE Dept. PESIT Bangalore, India; Rajpal, N., GGSIPU, New Delhi, India; Srikanta Murthy, K., ECE Dept. PESIT Bangalore, India
Abstract: Due to limitation in storage and transmission capacity, image compression has become inevitable for wide class of applications video conferencing, interactive education and numerous other areas. The objective of the paper is to evaluate the performance of an image compression system based on fuzzy vector quantization, wavelet sub band decomposition and neural network. Vector quantization is often used when high compression ratios are required. The implementation consists of three steps. First, image is decomposed into a set of sub bands with different resolution corresponding to different frequency bands. Different quantization and coding schemes are used for different sub bands based on their statistical properties. At the second step, the wavelet coefficients corresponding to lowest frequency band are compressed by differential pulse code modulation (DPCM) and the coefficients corresponding to higher frequency bands are compressed using neural network. Finally the result of the second step is used as input to fuzzy vector quantizer. Image quality is compared objectively using peak signal to noise ratio along with the visual appearance. The simulation results show clear performance improvement with respect to decoded picture quality as compared to other image compression techniques [29-30].
Index Keywords: Different resolutions; Fuzzy vector quantization; High compression ratio; Image compression techniques; Peak signal to noise ratio; Performance improvements; Statistical properties; Transmission capacities; Artificial intelligence; Differential pulse code modulation; Frequency bands; Image quality; Pattern recognition; Video conferencing; Wavelet decomposition; Vector quantization

Title: Biological early brain cancer detection using artificial neural networks
Source title: International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Pattern Recognition 2008, AIPR 2008

Authors with affiliations: Jagadeesh Kumar, G., Sri Sunflower College of Engg. and Tech., Lankapalli, Challapalli: 521 131, Krishna Dist, Andhra Pradesh, India; Vijay Kumar, G., Department of CSE, Sri Sunflower College of Engg. and Tech., Lankapalli, Challapalli: 521 131, Krishna Dist., Andhra Pradesh, India
Abstract: Computer aided diagnosis systems for detecting malignant texture in biological study have been investigated using several techniques. This paper presents an approach in computer-aided diagnosis for early prediction of brain cancer using Texture features and neuro classification logic. The Tumor mass detection and Cluster micro classification is used as the processing method for cancer prediction. Nine distinct invariant features with calculation of minimum distance for the prediction of cancer are used for the prediction of tumor in a given MRI image. A neuro fuzzy approach is used for the recognition of the extracted region. The implementation is observed on various types of MRI images with different types of cancer regions.

Authors: Ray S., Mahanti A.
Title: Weighted class based hybrid algorithm for TOP-N recommender systems
Source title: Proceedings of the IASTED International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Applications, AIA 2008
Affiliations: Indian Institute of Management Calcutta, Kolkata, India
Authors with affiliations: Ray, S., Indian Institute of Management Calcutta, Kolkata, India; Mahanti, A., Indian Institute of Management Calcutta, Kolkata, India
Abstract: Recommender systems have become a crucial tool for electronic commerce. These systems help in improving customer satisfaction by providing personalized services. Much of the research in recommender systems is done in solving the top-N recommendation problem where the objective is to identify a set of N items the user will most likely prefer. In this paper, we propose a weighted class based hybrid algorithm to solve this problem. Our algorithm combines the strength of both content based and collaborative filtering approaches. In this method, firstly, classes are defined by applying content based and collaborative filtering techniques on ratings data. Subsequently, user's existing profile of items is examined to determine the weightage of each class. Items are then recommended to the user on the basis of weightage attached to each class. We show through experimental results that our algorithm consistently outperforms existing algorithms when applied on MovieLens data set.
Author Keywords: Collaborative filtering; Intelligent data analysis and prediction with expert advice; Recommender systems
Index Keywords: Class-based; Collaborative filtering; Collaborative filtering techniques; Content-based; Data sets; Hybrid algorithms; Intelligent data analysis and prediction with expert advice; Personalized services; Recommender systems; Show through; Algorithms; Artificial intelligence; Circuit theory; Customer satisfaction; Electronic commerce; Signal filtering and prediction; Hybrid systems

Title: Unsupervised hyperspectral image analysis with projection pursuit and MRF segmentation approach
Source title: International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Pattern Recognition 2008, AIPR 2008

Abstract: This work deals with hyperspectral image analysis in the absence of ground-truth. The method adopts a projection pursuit (PP) procedure with entropy index to reduce the dimensionality followed by Markov Random Field (MRF) model based segmentation. Ordinal optimization approach to PP determines a set of "good enough projections" with high probability the best among which is chosen with the help of MRF model based segmentation. The segmented output so obtained is labeled with desired number of landcover classes in the absence of ground-truth. While comparing with original hyperspectral image the methodology outperforms principal component analysis with respect to class separation as exhibited in the illustration of an archive EO-1 hyperspectral image. The technique is not a computational intensive as is usually the case in hyperspectral image analysis. When training samples are available, the segmented regions yields a classified image with any cluster validation technique viz.[12].

Authors: Sarma K.K.
Title: Modified hybrid feature set for anglo-assamese hand written numeral recognition
Source title: International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Pattern Recognition 2008, AIPR 2008
Affiliations: Department of Electronics Science, Gauhati University, Guwahati-781014, India
Authors with affiliations: Sarma, K.K., Department of Electronics Science, Gauhati University, Guwahati-781014, India
Abstract: Neural network based handwritten numeral recognition as an extension of an Optical Character Recognition (OCR) system requires a unique feature set incorporating relevant information of shape, size, morphology etc of the numerals. The work describes the use of modified and trimmed hybrid feature sets derived for handwritten numeral detection of two different language scripts using neural networks. An earlier form of the feature sets have already been applied to the recognition of characters belonging to Assamese - an important language of North East India. The current work uses modified and trimmed versions of the feature set to recognize handwritten numerals of Assamese and English using neural networks in more than one configurations. The work aims to maximize handwritten numeral recognition performance, improve robustness and invariance to shape and size in presence of noise.

Authors: Kotecha K., Shah A.
Title: Ant colony optimization based dynamic scheduling algorithm for real-time operating systems
Source title: International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Pattern Recognition 2008, AIPR 2008
Affiliations: G.H. Patel College of Engg and Tech., Charutar Vidya Mandal, Vallabh Vidyanagar, India; Sardar Patel University, Vallabh Vidyanagar, India

Abstract: The Ant Colony Optimization algorithms (ACO) are computational models inspired by the collective foraging behavior of ants. The advantages of ant-based systems are inherent parallelism robustness & scalability along with simplicity of individual agent. By looking at this strength of ACO, they are the most appropriate for scheduling of tasks in soft real-time systems. In this paper, we propose ACO based scheduling algorithm for real-time operating systems(RTOS), to achieve overall higher system performance and better throughput. During simulation, results are obtained with periodic tasks, measured in terms of Success Ratio & Total Value Archived and compared with Earliest Deadline First (EDF) algorithm in the same environment. It has been observed that the proposed algorithm is equally optimal during underloaded conditions and it performs better during overloaded conditions.
Author Keywords: ACO and EDF; Real-time systems; Scheduling

Authors: Shah D., Shah A.
Title: Fuzzy base management system for color name identification
Source title: International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Pattern Recognition 2008, AIPR 2008

Authors with affiliations: Shah, D., G.H. Patel Department of Computer Science and Technology, Sardar Patel University, Vallabh Vidyanagar - 388 120, India; Shah, A., G.H. Patel Department of Computer Science and Technology, Sardar Patel University, Vallabh Vidyanagar - 388 120, India
Abstract: In this paper, Fuzzy Base Management System (FBMS) is designed to identify colors by their names. As a case, a fuzzy membership function has been discussed to identify colors by their name for color monitors, supporting true color quality. Since, color provides a significant portion of visual information to human beings, it is one of the important parameter for the identification of an object. Moreover, the computer systems identify colors by their color values, whereas human beings identify colors by their names. To represent color values with their names, there is need to have model to associate a range of color values with their specific color names. The proposed system fulfils the same objective and reduces the ambiguity in the selection of colors in diverse application areas.

Authors: Makkithaya K., Subba Reddy N.V., Dinesh Acharya U.
Title: Improved C-fuzzy decision tree with controllable membership characteristics for intrusion detection
Source title: International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Pattern Recognition 2008, AIPR 2008
Affiliations: Dept. Comp Science and Engg., M.I.T., Manipal-576104. Karnataka, India
Authors with affiliations: Makkithaya, K., Dept. Comp Science and Engg., M.I.T., Manipal-576104. Karnataka, India; Subba Reddy, N.V., Dept. Comp Science and Engg., M.I.T., Manipal-576104. Karnataka, India; Dinesh Acharya, U., Dept. Comp Science and Engg., M.I.T., Manipal-576104. Karnataka, India
Abstract: As the number of networked computers grows, intrusion detection is an essential component in keeping networks secure. Various approaches for intrusion detection are currently being in use with each one has its own merits and demerits. This paper presents an improved c-fuzzy decision tree with controllable membership characteristics for intrusion detection. The tree grows gradually by using fuzzy C-means clustering (FCM) algorithm to split the patterns in a selected node with the maximum heterogeneity into C corresponding children nodes. We use a modified fuzzy C-means algorithm with an extended distance measure to include an additional higher order term, as defined in. We also used a hybrid model to select suitable initial points for the FCM. Experimental results have shown that our improved version performs better resulting in an effective intrusion detection system.

Authors: Ramulu M., Anand Kumar S., Murty D.V.R.
Title: Development of expert system for process pump selection
Source title: International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Pattern Recognition 2008, AIPR 2008
Affiliations: Design and Engg. Division, Indian Institute of Chemical Technology, Hyderabad, India
Authors with affiliations: Ramulu, M., Design and Engg. Division, Indian Institute of Chemical Technology, Hyderabad, India; Anand Kumar, S., Design and Engg. Division, Indian Institute of Chemical Technology, Hyderabad, India; Murty, D.V.R., Design and Engg. Division, Indian Institute of Chemical Technology, Hyderabad, India
Abstract: An expert system is the most advanced part of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and had made significant contribution to chemical process monitoring, control and diagnosis. Expert system can be utilized effectively in selection of process equipments and its components. Here an attempt has made to utilize expert system for process pump selection. The selection procedure of a pump to a specific application is very complex because of the involvement of different sizes, types and parameters like fluid properties, compatibilities, operating conditions and environmental emissions etc. Till now the selection of a pump is based on technical literature, pump manufacturer's catalogues / data and knowledge gained by years of experience. This will affect the performance (operation, maintenance and reliability) of the pump. In order to overcome this it is essential to develop an expert system for process pump selection. This paper illustrates the development of expert system comprises of the neural network integrated with an expert system for process pump selection. And also it is used for validating the output of the neural network and taking care of situations where the neural network cannot provide a unique solution. The objective of this work is to concise and optimize the process pump selection by properly considering the key parameters.
