Authors: Bhatnagar S., Borkar V.S., Akarapu M.
Title: A simulation-based algorithm for ergodic control of Markov chains conditioned on rare events
Source title: Journal of Machine Learning Research
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560 012, India; School of Technology and Computer Science, Tata Institute of Fundamental Research, Homi Bhabha Road, Mumbai 400 005, India; Oracle India Pvt. Ltd., Bangalore - 560 029, India
Authors with affiliations: Bhatnagar, S., Department of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560 012, India; Borkar, V.S., School of Technology and Computer Science, Tata Institute of Fundamental Research, Homi Bhabha Road, Mumbai 400 005, India; Akarapu, M., Oracle India Pvt. Ltd., Bangalore - 560 029, India
Abstract: We study the problem of long-run average cost control of Markov chains conditioned on a rare event. In a related recent work, a simulation based algorithm for estimating performance measures associated with a Markov chain conditioned on a rare event has been developed. We extend ideas from this work and develop an adaptive algorithm for obtaining, online, optimal control policies conditioned on a rare event. Our algorithm uses three timescales or step-size schedules. On the slowest timescale, a gradient search algorithm for policy updates that is based on one-simulation simultaneous perturbation stochastic approximation (SPSA) type estimates is used. Deterministic perturbation sequences obtained from appropriate normalized Hadamard matrices are used here. The fast timescale recursions compute the conditional transition probabilities of an associated chain by obtaining solutions to the multiplicative Poisson equation (for a given policy estimate). Further, the risk parameter associated with the value function for a given policy estimate is updated on a timescale that lies in between the two scales above. We briefly sketch the convergence analysis of our algorithm and present a numerical application in the setting of routing multiple flows in communication networks.
Author Keywords: Markov decision processes; Optimal control conditioned on a rare event; Reinforcement learning; Simulation based algorithms; SPSA with deterministic perturbations

Title: Second order cone programming approaches for handling missing and uncertain data
Source title: Journal of Machine Learning Research
Affiliations: Computer Science, Columbia University, New York, 10027, United States; Department of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, 560 012, India; Statistical Machine Learning Program, National ICT Australia, ANU, Canberra, ACT 0200, Australia

Abstract: We propose a novel second order cone programming formulation for designing robust classifiers which can handle uncertainty in observations. Similar formulations are also derived for designing regression functions which are robust to uncertainties in the regression setting. The proposed formulations are independent of the underlying distribution, requiring only the existence of second order moments. These formulations are then specialized to the case of missing values in observations for both classification and regression problems. Experiments show that the proposed formulations outperform imputation.

Authors: Udupa R.U., Maji H.K.
Title: Theory of alignment generators and applications to statistical machine translation
Source title: IJCAI International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence
Affiliations: IBM India Research Laboratory, New Delhi, India
Authors with affiliations: Udupa, R.U., IBM India Research Laboratory, New Delhi, India; Maji, H.K., IBM India Research Laboratory, New Delhi, India
Abstract: Viterbi Alignment and Decoding are two fundamental search problems in Statistical Machine Translation. Both the problems are known to be NP-hard and therefore, it is unlikely that there exists an optimal polynomial time algorithm for either of these search problems. In this paper we characterize exponentially large subspaces in the solution space of Viterbi Alignment and Decoding. Each of these subspaces admits polynomial time optimal search algorithms. We propose a local search heuristic using a neighbourhood relation on these subspaces. Experimental results show that our algorithms produce better solutions taking substantially less time than the previously known algorithms for these problems.
Index Keywords: Local search heuristics; Neighbourhood; NP-hard; Polynomial-time; Polynomial-time algorithms; Search problem; Solution space; Statistical machine translation; Artificial intelligence; Decoding; Heuristic algorithms; Optimization; Polynomial approximation; Linguistics

Authors: Govindu V.M.
Title: A tensor decomposition for geometric grouping and segmentation
Source title: Proceedings - 2005 IEEE Computer Society Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition, CVPR 2005
Affiliations: HIG-25, Simhapuri Layout, Visakhapatnam, AP 530047, India
Authors with affiliations: Govindu, V.M., HIG-25, Simhapuri Layout, Visakhapatnam, AP 530047, India
Abstract: While spectral clustering has been applied successfully to problems in computer vision, their applicability is limited to pairwise similarity measures that form a probability matrix. However many geometric problems with parametric forms require more than two observations to estimate a similarity measure, e.g. epipolar geometry. In such cases we can only define the probability of belonging to the same cluster for an n-tuple of points and not just a pair, leading to an n-dimensional probability tensor. However spectral clustering methods are not available for tensors. In this paper we present an algorithm to infer a similarity matrix by decomposing the n-dimensional probability tensor. Our method exploits the super-symmetry of the probability tensor to provide a randomised scheme that does not require the explicit computation of the probability tensor. Our approach is fast and accurate and its applicability is illustrated on two significant problems, namely perceptually salient geometric grouping and parametric motion segmentation (like affine, epipolar etc.) © 2005 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Computation theory; Computational geometry; Image segmentation; Information analysis; Parameter estimation; Probability; Problem solving; Epipolar geometry; Motion segmentation; Probability tensor; Tensor decomposition; Tensors

Abstract: We introduce a novel algorithm for decision tree learning in the multi-instance setting as originally defined by Dietterich et al. It differs from existing multi-instance tree learners in a few crucial, well-motivated details. Experiments on synthetic and real-life datasets confirm the beneficial effect of these differences and show that the resulting system out-performs the existing multi-instance decision tree learners.

Authors: Srinivasan S.H., Bose J.C.
Title: Regression and integration operations in text mining
Source title: Proceedings of the 2005 International Conference on Machine Learning; Models, Technologies and Applications, MLMTA'05
Affiliations: Applied Research Group, Satyam Computer Services Ltd, SID Block, IISc Campus, Bangalore 560 012, India
Authors with affiliations: Srinivasan, S.H., Applied Research Group, Satyam Computer Services Ltd, SID Block, IISc Campus, Bangalore 560 012, India; Bose, J.C., Applied Research Group, Satyam Computer Services Ltd, SID Block, IISc Campus, Bangalore 560 012, India
Abstract: The amount of text that one encounters in business and personal lives is increasing - email, web pages, documents etc. Identifying interesting patterns having semantic relations in such voluminuos data is an important aspect of text mining. In this paper, we propose a framework called text regression based on string pattern matching that tries to identify the associations between text fragments and show that text regression has several interesting applications. Though the amount of information available in text form is increasing, sometimes, the information is not always available in a format that is required by the user or the information available may be disparate. Integrating information from different sources is called text integration and it forms an important ingredient of text regression.

Authors: Ramakrishnan G., Chitrapura K.P., Krishnapuram R., Bhattacharyya P.
Title: A model for handling approximate, noisy or incomplete labeling in text classification
Source title: ICML 2005 - Proceedings of the 22nd International Conference on Machine Learning
Affiliations: IBM India Research Lab., IIT, New Delhi, India; Department of C.S.E, IIT Bombay, Mumbai, India
Authors with affiliations: Ramakrishnan, G., IBM India Research Lab., IIT, New Delhi, India; Chitrapura, K.P., IBM India Research Lab., IIT, New Delhi, India; Krishnapuram, R., IBM India Research Lab., IIT, New Delhi, India; Bhattacharyya, P., Department of C.S.E, IIT Bombay, Mumbai, India
Abstract: We introduce a Bayesian model, BayesANIL, that is capable of estimating uncertainties associated with the labeling process. Given a labeled or partially labeled training corpus of text documents, the model estimates the joint distribution of training documents and class labels by using a generalization of the Expectation Maximization algorithm. The estimates can be used in standard classification models to reduce error rates. Since uncertainties in the labeling are taken into account, the model provides an elegant mechanism to deal with noisy labels. We provide an intuitive modification to the EM iterations by re-estimating the empirical distribution in order to reinforce feature values in unlabeled data and to reduce the influence of noisily labeled examples. Considerable improvement in the classification accuracies of two popular classification algorithms on standard labeled data-sets with and without artificially introduced noise, as well as in the presence and absence of unlabeled data, indicates that this may be a promising method to reduce the burden of manual labeling.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Classification (of information); Computer networks; Error analysis; Iterative methods; Learning systems; Mathematical models; Parameter estimation; Set theory; Bayesian model; EM iterations; Incomplete labeling; Text classification; Text processing

Authors: Bedi P., Kaur H.
Title: Trust based recommender system
Source title: Proceedings of the 2005 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, ICAI'05
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, University of Delhi, Delhi-110007, India
Authors with affiliations: Bedi, P., Department of Computer Science, University of Delhi, Delhi-110007, India; Kaur, H., Department of Computer Science, University of Delhi, Delhi-110007, India
Abstract: In the community we rely on recommendations from our trustworthy acquaintances to recommend products based on their experience. Recommender systems use opinions of members of a community to help individuals in that community identify information or products most likely to be interesting to them or relevant to their needs. These systems use similarity between user and recommenders or between items to form recommendation list for user. They do not take into consideration social trust network between entities in society to ensure that user can trust recommendations received from system. We have proposed a model where trust network exists between peer agents and recommendations are generated on basis of these trust relationships. The user agent seeks recommendations from trustworthy peers and produces aggregated order of recommendations taking degree of trust on recommenders into consideration. This paper also suggests a method to update trust on recommender based on importance of recommendation for user.
Author Keywords: Degree of trust; Intentional encounters; Recommender system; Unintentional encounters
Index Keywords: Peer agents; Recommender systems; Trust networks; Trust relationship; User agents; Artificial intelligence
Correspondence Address: Bedi, P.; Department of Computer Science, University of Delhi, Delhi-110007, India
Abbreviated Source Title: Proc. Int. Conf. Artif. Intell., ICAI

Authors: Srivastava B., Mediratta A.
Title: Domain-dependent parameter selection of search-based algorithms compatible with user performance criteria
Source title: Proceedings of the National Conference on Artificial Intelligence
Affiliations: IBM India Research Lab, Indian Institute of Technology, Block 1, Hauz khas, Delhi 110016, India
Authors with affiliations: Srivastava, B., IBM India Research Lab, Indian Institute of Technology, Block 1, Hauz khas, Delhi 110016, India; Mediratta, A., IBM India Research Lab, Indian Institute of Technology, Block 1, Hauz khas, Delhi 110016, India
Abstract: Search-based algorithms, like planners, schedulers and satisfiability solvers, are notorious for having numerous parameters with a wide choice of values that can affect their performance drastically. As a result, the users of these algorithms, who may not be search experts, spend a significant time in tuning the values of the parameters to get acceptable performance on their particular problem domains. In this paper, we present a learning-based approach for automatic tuning of search-based algorithms to help such users. The benefit of our methodology is that it handles diverse parameter types, performs effectively for a broad range of systematic as well as non-systematic search based solvers (the selected parameters could make the algorithms solve up to 100% problems while the bad parameters would lead to none being solved), incorporates user-specified performance criteria (φ) and is easy to implement. Moreover, the selected parameter will satisfy φ in the first try or the ranked candidates can be used along with φ to minimize the number of times the parameter settings need to be adjusted until a problem is solved. Copyright © 2005, American Association for Artificial Intelligence (www.aaai.org). All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Parameter estimation; Problem solving; Search engines; Automatic tuning; Parameter selection; Parameter settings; Search-based algorithms; Algorithms

Authors: Srivastava B., Vanhatalo J., Koehler J.
Title: Managing the life cycle of plans
Source title: Proceedings of the National Conference on Artificial Intelligence
Affiliations: IBM India Research Laboratory, IIT, Block 1, New Delhi 110016, India; IBM Zurich Research Laboratory, CH-8803 Riischlikon, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Srivastava, B., IBM India Research Laboratory, IIT, Block 1, New Delhi 110016, India; Vanhatalo, J., IBM Zurich Research Laboratory, CH-8803 Riischlikon, Switzerland; Koehler, J., IBM Zurich Research Laboratory, CH-8803 Riischlikon, Switzerland
Abstract: The scalability of recent planning algorithms allows developers to automate planning tasks, which so far have been reserved to humans. However in real-world applications, synthesizing a plan is just the beginning of a complex life-cycle management process. Plans must be organized in large collections, where they can be grouped along different purposes and are amenable to the search, inspection, evaluation, and modification by human experts or automated reasoning systems. Eventually, plans will outlast their utility and be replaced. We present our solution to plan life cycle management for an autonomic computing application. We focus in particular on the automatic synthesis of plan metadata for plans containing conditional and parallel actions, well-structured loops, and non-deterministic choices. The plans are of unknown origin, i.e., their underlying action model, which could provide us with pre- and postconditions, is not available. New analysis techniques are presented that uniformly generate metadata for plans, thus allowing a system to embed plans into context and organize them in meaningfully structured plan repositories. Copyright © 2005, American Association for Artificial Intelligence (www.aaai.org). All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Automation; Computational complexity; Life cycle; Management science; Automate planning; Automated reasoning systems; Life cycle management; Artificial intelligence

Authors: Gulhane P., Menezes B., Reddy T., Shah K., Soman S.A.
Title: Forecasting using decomposition and combinations of experts
Source title: Proceedings of the 2005 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, ICAI'05
Affiliations: Kanwal Rekhi School of Information Technology, IIT Bombay, Powai, Bombay, 400 076, India
Authors with affiliations: Gulhane, P., Kanwal Rekhi School of Information Technology, IIT Bombay, Powai, Bombay, 400 076, India; Menezes, B., Kanwal Rekhi School of Information Technology, IIT Bombay, Powai, Bombay, 400 076, India; Reddy, T., Kanwal Rekhi School of Information Technology, IIT Bombay, Powai, Bombay, 400 076, India; Shah, K., Kanwal Rekhi School of Information Technology, IIT Bombay, Powai, Bombay, 400 076, India; Soman, S.A., Kanwal Rekhi School of Information Technology, IIT Bombay, Powai, Bombay, 400 076, India
Abstract: We study the effect of decomposing a series into multiple components and performing forecasts on each component separately. The focus here is on sales data - most of the series considered display both seasonality and trend. Hence the original series is decomposed into trend, seasonality and an irregular component. Multiple forecasting 'experts' are used to forecast each component series. These range from different feedforward neural network topologies to Holt-Winter, ARIMA (of various orders) and double exponential smoothing. We compare the forecast errors with and without decomposition. We study the result of combining using the mean/median of all expert forecasts. Since our space of composite experts runs into the thousands, we experiment with more limited cardinalities using greedy elimination and best expert pair.
Author Keywords: Combining techniques; Decomposition; Genetic algorithms; Neural networks; Time series forecasting
Index Keywords: Cardinalities; Combining techniques; Exponential smoothing; Forecast errors; Multiple components; Original series; Seasonality; Time series forecasting; Artificial intelligence; Decomposition; Electric network topology; Feedforward neural networks; Frequency shift keying; Time series; Forecasting

Authors: Bedi P., Marwaha S.
Title: Framework for ontology based expert systems: Disease & pests identification in crops - A case study
Source title: Proceedings of the 2005 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, ICAI'05
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, University of Delhi, Delhi, India
Authors with affiliations: Bedi, P., Department of Computer Science, University of Delhi, Delhi, India; Marwaha, S., Department of Computer Science, University of Delhi, Delhi, India
Abstract: In this paper, we present a framework of ontology-based expert systems. The presented framework is suitable for the semantic web scenario. It provides better results by generating its knowledge base on the fly from the distributed OWL ontologies that exist on the web and maintained by different groups of experts at different geographic locations. Protégé is used to create and maintain OWL ontologies. The system embeds an OWL Transformer for transforming the OWL into Jess ML which is fed to JESS inference engine. The framework does not pose any restriction on the domain experts for regular updating and modifications of these distributed ontologies and is independent of the ontology versions. An ongoing work in the agriculture domain to identify the diseases and pests in different crops using the presented framework is included as a case study to validate the framework.
Author Keywords: Expert systems; JESS; Ontology; OWL; Protégé; Semantic web
Index Keywords: Domain experts; Geographic locations; JESS; Knowledge base; On the flies; Ontology-based; OWL; OWL ontologies; Crops; Data mining; Expert systems; Information theory; Problem solving; Semantic Web; Semantics; Ontology

Authors: Sinha R.M.K.
Title: Dealing with mixing of english verbs in Hindi for machine translation
Source title: Proceedings of the 2005 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, ICAI'05
Affiliations: Computer Science and Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur 208016, India
Authors with affiliations: Sinha, R.M.K., Computer Science and Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur 208016, India
Abstract: It is a common practice in India to mix the words of English in Hindi and vice-versa. There are social, historical and political factors, that have contributed to such an usage. This has become much more prevalent with globalization and movement of people in metropolises. It is observed that the grammatical rules in construction of gender, number, verb-nominalization or forms, conform to that for the language (Hindi or English) used irrespective of their origin. The case of mixing of English verbs in a Hindi sentence is more complex in interpretation as compared to mixing of other parts of speech. In this paper, we present a strategy for translating verb forms that use English verbs in a Hindi sentence. We consider translating to pure Hindi and pure English forms.
Author Keywords: English verb; Machine translation; Mixed hindi; Natural language processing
Index Keywords: Machine translations; NAtural language processing; Political factors; Artificial intelligence; Computational linguistics; Information theory; Natural language processing systems; Speech transmission; Translation (languages)

Authors: Gopalakrishna P.
Title: Data-dependencies and learning in artificial systems
Source title: Workshop on Approaches and Applications of Inductive Programming, AAIP 2005 - In Conjunction with the 22nd International Conference on Machine Learning, ICML 2005
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology - Bombay, Mumbai, India
Authors with affiliations: Gopalakrishna, P., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology - Bombay, Mumbai, India
Abstract: Data-dependencies play an important role in the performance of learning algorithms. In this paper we analyze the concepts of data dependencies in the context of artificial systems. When a problem and its solution are viewed as points in a system configuration, variations in the problem configurations can be used to study the variations in the solution configurations and vice versa. These variations could be used to infer solutions to unknown instances of problems based on the solutions to known instances, thus reducing the problem of learning to that of identifying the relations among problems and their solutions. We use this concept in constructing a formal framework for a learning mechanism based on the relations among data attributes. As part of the framework we provide metrics - quality and quantity - for data samples and establish a knowledge conservation theorem. We explain how these concepts can be used in practice by considering an example problem and discuss the limitations.
Index Keywords: Artificial systems; Conservation theorem; Data attributes; Data dependencies; Data sample; Formal framework; Learning mechanism; System configurations; Learning systems; Learning algorithms

Authors: Banos A., Godara A., Lassarre S.
Title: SAMU (Simulation of Multi-Agents and Urban Modelisation): Contribution to the study of urban anthill
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: SET laboratory, University of Pau, Pau, France; Department of Civil Engineering, Institute of Technology, Banaras Hindu University, 21005 Varanasi, India; GARIG, Institut National de Recherche Sur Les Transpoits et Leur Securite, Arcuiel 94114, France
Authors with affiliations: Banos, A., SET laboratory, University of Pau, Pau, France; Godara, A., Department of Civil Engineering, Institute of Technology, Banaras Hindu University, 21005 Varanasi, India; Lassarre, S., GARIG, Institut National de Recherche Sur Les Transpoits et Leur Securite, Arcuiel 94114, France
Abstract: Developed in the context of artificial intelligence, agentbased simulation has been widely used in the context of traffic simulation. In spite of the fundamental role in the system of urban daily mobilities, walking remains a important mode of displacement well-known. But unfortunately, there are very rare works which have been done in this field, so from this point of view, a virtual urban environment or a simulation software. SAMU is created and is populated with autonomous agents like pedestrians and motorists of multi- agents type. Different constraints, affecting the mobility of the whole system are considered. The model belongs to the microscopic category, where pedestrians/vehicles behave in their environment by making a sequence of decisions. The interaction among vehicles and pedestrians is also incorporated which signifies the accident risk of pedestrians. Netlogo which is a multi agent based modeling language is used as the programming platform for SAMU. Copyright © IICAI 2005.
Index Keywords: Accident risks; Agent based simulation; Modelisation; Multi agent; Multi-agent based modeling; NetLogo; Simulation software; Traffic simulations; Urban environments; Accidents; Artificial intelligence; Automobile drivers; Autonomous agents; Computer software

Authors: Suryanarayana P.V., Mitra S.K., Banerjee A., Roy A.K.
Title: Recognition of car license plate using morphology
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: Dhirubhai Ambani Institute of Information and Communication Technology, Gandhinagar 382009, Gujarat, India
Authors with affiliations: Suryanarayana, P.V., Dhirubhai Ambani Institute of Information and Communication Technology, Gandhinagar 382009, Gujarat, India; Mitra, S.K., Dhirubhai Ambani Institute of Information and Communication Technology, Gandhinagar 382009, Gujarat, India; Banerjee, A., Dhirubhai Ambani Institute of Information and Communication Technology, Gandhinagar 382009, Gujarat, India; Roy, A.K., Dhirubhai Ambani Institute of Information and Communication Technology, Gandhinagar 382009, Gujarat, India
Abstract: Locating the car license plate in an image or video of a car is an important step in car license plate recognition identification application. This problem poses many challenges like locating license plate from images taken in poor illumination and bad weather condition; plates that are partly obscured by dirt and images that have low contrast. This paper presents a method for license plate extraction from car images using morphology. The algorithm uses sequence of morphological operations on the preprocessed, edge images of the vehicles. Characteristic features such as license plate width and height, character height and spacing are considered for defining structural elements for morphological operations. Connected component analysis has also been used to locate the accurate position of license plate within an image and to segment the characters available on the located license plate. The segmented characters of license plates are recognized using template matching. The experimental results with wide variety of a reasonably large set of car images are very encouraging. Copyright © IICAI 2005.

Title: Evolutionary design of inverse dynamics controllers for multiple arm co-operating manipulator systems
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: Institute of Management Technology, Nagpur, India; Indira Gandhi Institute of Teclmology, Sarang, Dhenkanal, India; Department of Automatic Control and Systems Engineering, University of Sheffield, Sheffield, United Kingdom

Abstract: The In this paper a novel hybrid evolutionary algorithm (HEA) method is used to find optimal feedback gains for inverse dynamics controllers. It is shown that HEA efficiently finds the optimal feedback gains to improve the performances of inverse dynamics controllers for end-effector tracking control in highly complex, nonlinear, multi-ami manipulator systems. The feedback gain tuning is studied for constrained, co-operating manipulator systems for both fixed-base and free-floating, multi-arm, space manipulator systems under zero gravity. Authors: Pardede R.P., Kansal M.L.
Title: Application of search techniques in optimal design of water distribution networks
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: Department of Water Resources Development and Management, Indian Institute of Technology, Roorkee 247667, India
Authors with affiliations: Pardede, R.P., Department of Water Resources Development and Management, Indian Institute of Technology, Roorkee 247667, India; Kansal, M.L., Department of Water Resources Development and Management, Indian Institute of Technology, Roorkee 247667, India
Abstract: The physical behavior of a looped water distribution network is described by a set of equations, some of which are nonlinear. Design of such an infrastructure is challenging as the global optimal solution through classical optimization techniques is, in general, next to impossible as one has to select the solution among a vast number of combinations of pipes. To solve the problem, one can model the problem as nonlinear programming problem and use any conventional search techniques such as generalized reduced gradient or using non-conventional search techniques such as genetic algorithms. The present study discusses the suitability of genetic algorithm in searching the global optimum solution for design of water distribution network. The technique is suitable as it can deal with information of market size pipes directly rather than first finding the solution in continuous domain and then rounding off the solution close to available diameters in the market or the split length solution. Copyright © IICAI 2005.
Index Keywords: Classical optimization; Continuous domain; Generalized reduced gradient; Global optimal solutions; Global optimum solutions; Market sizes; Nonlinear programming problem; Optimal design; Physical behaviors; Search technique; Water distribution networks; Commerce; Genetic algorithms; Information analysis; Nonlinear equations; Optimal systems; Water distribution systems; Problem solving

Title: Artificial neural network-based svstem identification for a flotation column
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: Regional Research Laboratory (C.S.I.R.), Bhubaneswar, 751013, India
Authors with affiliations: Samantaray, P.P., Regional Research Laboratory (C.S.I.R.), Bhubaneswar, 751013, India; Mohantya, S., Regional Research Laboratory (C.S.I.R.), Bhubaneswar, 751013, India
Abstract: Artificial neural network (ANN) is a useful tool for system identification- In tins paper therefore, a multilayer perception (MLP) neural network model has been developed for system identification of a flotation column based on data available in literature. The inputs to the network were present and one time step backward values of troth depth (controlled variable), present, one time step and two time step backward values of percentage tailing opening (manipulated variable) and the output was one time step ahead value of froth depth. The network was trained to optimize the weights using error back propagation algorithm. The trained network was then simulated with an unknown sequence of percentage tailing opening to predict the future values of the froth depth. The paper also discusses the properties and limitations of the excitation signals used for the present system, i.e.. the pseudorandom binary sequences. Copyright © IICAI 2005.
Index Keywords: Controlled variables; Error back propagation algorithm; Excitation signals; Flotation columns; Manipulated variables; Multilayer perception neural networks; Network-based; Pseudo-random binary sequences; Time step; Binary sequences; Flotation; Tinning; Neural networks

Authors: Chakraborty A., Saha S., Chatterjee A., Konar A.
Title: Controlling human moods by fuzzy logic
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: Centre for Cognitive Science, Jadavpur University, Kolkata - 32, India; Department of Electronics and Telecommunication Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata - 32, India
Authors with affiliations: Chakraborty, A., Centre for Cognitive Science, Jadavpur University, Kolkata - 32, India; Saha, S., Centre for Cognitive Science, Jadavpur University, Kolkata - 32, India; Chatterjee, A., Centre for Cognitive Science, Jadavpur University, Kolkata - 32, India; Konar, A., Department of Electronics and Telecommunication Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata - 32, India
Abstract: The paper presents a new approach to model the human mood transition dynamics by a difference equation. It studies the scope of positive and negative influences on the transition of moods from one state to another. A fuzzy control of the human mood transition dynamics, tested and verified on j human subjects of various age groups, sex and culture is presented. The main characteristics of the paper are the automatic selection of music, video or textual messages by the fuzzy controller to control the mood transition to a desired state. The experimental results on real humans are encouraging, indicating the importance of the scheme for field use. Copyright © IICAI 2005.
Index Keywords: Age groups; Automatic selection; Fuzzy controllers; Human subjects; Negative influence; Transition dynamics; Difference equations; Dynamics; Fuzzy control; Fuzzy logic

Authors: Bhattacharya U., Chaudhuri B.B.
Title: Processing of struck-out handwriting
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition Unit, Indian Statistical Institute, Kolkata, India
Authors with affiliations: Bhattacharya, U., Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition Unit, Indian Statistical Institute, Kolkata, India; Chaudhuri, B.B., Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition Unit, Indian Statistical Institute, Kolkata, India
Abstract: Struck-out words are often found in handwritten manuscripts. A realistic off-line handwriting recognition system should take care of this common aspect. A simple but efficient approach to this problem is to subject each handwritten word to a two-class classifier in the initial stage. This classifier should take decision to pass the word to a word recognition engine in the next step or discard it as a struck-out/wrong word. In the present work, we studied a stroke analysis based technique, which can classify an input word as a correct or wrong (struck-out) word. We simulated the proposed approach on a database of 466 words collected from handwritten manuscripts of different languages and the results are promising. Copyright © IICAI 2005.
Index Keywords: Handwritten words; Initial stages; Offline handwriting recognition; Two-class classifier; Word recognition; Artificial intelligence

Authors: Bhatia R.K., Kaur N.
Title: Information retrieval from a component based repository using genetic algorithms
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: Computer Science and Engineering Department, Thapar Institute of Engineering and Technology, Patiala-147004, Punjab, India; Thapar Institute of Engineering and Technology, Patiala-147004, Punjab, India
Authors with affiliations: Bhatia, R.K., Computer Science and Engineering Department, Thapar Institute of Engineering and Technology, Patiala-147004, Punjab, India; Kaur, N., Thapar Institute of Engineering and Technology, Patiala-147004, Punjab, India
Abstract: Software reuse has become a topic of much interest in the software community due to its potential benefits, which include improving software development and software product quality and decreased product cost and schedule. One of the most fundamental problems in software reusability is locating and retrieving software components from a large collection, which is called as repository. To reuse a software component, you first have to find it. Retrieval of components should be less time consuming and efficient. This paper addresses the issue of retrieval performance for retrieving components from a component repository. Two step process is used for retrieval of best component from repository. The initial step is Keyword based retrieval for finding all possible components according to the user requirement. This reduces the search domain, which is further refined using Soft computing technique in order to find optimal solution. Soft computing technique we have used is genetic algorithms. Weight vectors associated to attribute vectors are optimized using Genetic Algorithms for getting the best component. A Fitness function is calculated on the basis of weight vectors and attribute vectors which give us the desired result. Copyright © IICAI 2005.
Index Keywords: Attribute vectors; Component based; Component repository; Fitness functions; Keyword-based retrieval; Optimal solutions; Potential benefits; Product cost; Retrieval performance; Softcomputing techniques; Software community; Software component; Software product quality; Two-step process; User requirements; Weight vector; Artificial intelligence; Cost accounting; Genetic algorithms; Soft computing; Vectors; Computer software reusability

Authors: Shiva Nagendra S.M., Khare M.
Title: Computational tools in episodic urban air quality management (e-UAQM)
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering, M. S. Ramaiah Institute of Technology, Bangalore-560 054, India; Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, Hauz Khas, New Delhi-110 016, India
Authors with affiliations: Shiva Nagendra, S.M., Department of Civil Engineering, M. S. Ramaiah Institute of Technology, Bangalore-560 054, India; Khare, M., Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, Hauz Khas, New Delhi-110 016, India
Abstract: Frequent occurrences of episodes as a result of rapid urbanization of the cities have become a cause of concern among the air pollution scientists and urban planners. Therefore, a systematic framework for episodic urban air quality management (e-UAQM") is needed to control pollution levels during adverse dispersion conditions. Mathematical modelling techniques are mostly used in predicting the air pollution dispersion phenomena. However, there exist considerable difficulties in describing pollutant dilution mechanism in urban environment due to its complexity and nonlinearity. Majority of the existing conventional models fail in accurately predicting the air pollutant concentration due to inherent limitations in form of various assumptions. In this paper, the application of conventional deterministic, stochastic, hybrid of deterministic and statistical, and artificial neural network (ANN) based line source models in the management of local air quality of Delhi city is explained. The limitations encountered in modelling of urban air pollution are also presented. Copyright © IICAI 2005.
Index Keywords: Air pollutant concentrations; Air pollution dispersion; Computational tools; Conventional models; Dispersion condition; Inherent limitations; Line sources; Pollution level; Systematic framework; Urban air pollution; Urban air quality; Urban environments; Urban planners; Air quality; Neural networks; Stochastic models; Atmospheric movements

Authors: Rammohan R.E., Kolhatkar Y.Y., Das S.P.
Title: A fuzzy controlled optimum unified power quality conditioner with minimum variable amplitude loading
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur, Kanpur -208016, India
Authors with affiliations: Rammohan, R.E., Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur, Kanpur -208016, India; Kolhatkar, Y.Y., Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur, Kanpur -208016, India; Das, S.P., Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur, Kanpur -208016, India
Abstract: In this paper fuzzy algorithm is employed to control a three phase optimized Unified Power Quality Conditioner (UPQC). The optimum UPQC is the integration of series active and shunt active power filters. The series active power filter is used to compensate for the voltage sag, swell and voltage flicker by injecting the voltage at an optimum angle such that overall variable- amplitude (VA) loading of the UPQC is minimized and voltage at the load end is regulated. The shunt active power filter is used to compensate the reactive power and harmonics in supply current caused by the nonlinear loads. Thus, the source current is almost sinusoidal and maintains unity power factor with source voltage. A fuzzy logic based controller is developed for each of the compensator such that the voltage at load end is maintained constant, current harmonics and reactive power of source current are compensated. The validity of proposed system is verified by extensive simulation results using MATLAB / SIMULINK. Copyright © IICAI 2005.

Authors: Kumar J., Jain A., Srivastava R.
Title: Estimating groundwater pollution source location from observed breakthrough curves using neural networks
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur, Kanpur, India
Authors with affiliations: Kumar, J., Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur, Kanpur, India; Jain, A., Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur, Kanpur, India; Srivastava, R., Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur, Kanpur, India
Abstract: This paper presents the results of a study aimed at estimating groundwater pollution source location from observed breakthrough curves using neural networks. Two different methods of presenting the breakthrough curves to the ANN are investigated. The feed-forward multi-layer perceptron (MLP) type artificial neural network (ANN) models are employed. The ANNs were trained using the back-propagation training algorithm on simulated data. A new approach for ANN training using back-propagation is employed that considers two different error statistics to prevent over-training or under-training of the ANNs. The preliminary results indicate that the ANNs are very efficient tools for estimating the distance of the potential pollution source from the observation well where breakthrough curve is measured. Copyright © IICAI 2005.

Authors: Kumar N., Lagare A.M.
Title: Gene therapy: Selective gene replacement and its application in image processing
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: PESIT, 100 Feet Ring Road, Bangalore 560085, Kamataka, India; Motorola India Electronics Private Limited, 66/1, Bagmane Tech Park, C.V. Raman Nagar, Bangalore 560093, Kamataka, India
Authors with affiliations: Kumar, N., PESIT, 100 Feet Ring Road, Bangalore 560085, Kamataka, India; Lagare, A.M., Motorola India Electronics Private Limited, 66/1, Bagmane Tech Park, C.V. Raman Nagar, Bangalore 560093, Kamataka, India
Abstract: This paper describes a segmentation algorithm for Images using genetic algorithms. We introduce a new concept for reproduction called gene therapy. Chromosomes of average fitness value are selectively modified using a master chromosome. We try to alter the defective genes which cause the low fitness values in normal chromosome so that their performance can be increased. The master chromosome represents the local maxima for all the n-1 previous generations. This method introduces a small amount of discipline in the reproduction process. This reproduction scheme runs in tandem with the classical approach of reproduction. Copyright © IICAI 2005.

Authors: Vivek E.P., Sudha N.
Title: Gray hausdorff distance measures for comparing face images
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, Chennai, 600036, India
Authors with affiliations: Vivek, E.P., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, Chennai, 600036, India; Sudha, N., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, Chennai, 600036, India
Abstract: Human face recognition is considered to be one of the toughest problems in pattern recognition domain. The variations in face images due to differing expressions, pose and illumination are the key issues to be addressed by a face recognition system. In this paper a new measure, namely gray Hausdorff distance, is proposed to compare the gray images of faces directly while the existing Hausdorff distance-based measures are defined for binary images. An efficient computation of this measure in linear time is presented. The performance of this measure is evaluated on benchmark face databases for face recognition. The recognition system based on the new measure is found to be robust to considerable pose and expression variations as well as slight illumination variation. Comparison studies show that the proposed system performs better than the existing ones in many cases. Copyright © IICAI 2005.

Authors: Said S., Kothyari U.C., Arora M.K.
Title: Retrieval of soil moisture from ERS SAR image over bare and vegetated surfaces using neural networks
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Roorkee-247667, Uttaranchal, India
Authors with affiliations: Said, S., Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Roorkee-247667, Uttaranchal, India; Kothyari, U.C., Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Roorkee-247667, Uttaranchal, India; Arora, M.K., Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Roorkee-247667, Uttaranchal, India
Abstract: Soil moisture plays a significant role in partitioning of precipitation into runoff and ground water storage. Thus, it is important to know the spatial distribution of soil moisture. Active microwave remote sensing data are often used for soil moisture estimation beneath the ground surfaces up to 0 to 5 cm depth. In this paper, an artificial neural network (ANN) based algorithm is implemented for soil moisture estimation from ERS 2 SAR image over bare and vegetated surfaces in a portion of Solani river catchment in India. The well known and the most widely used back- propagation neural network is used to retrieve the soil moisture. A total of seven input variables namely SAR digital number (DN) or back scatter coefficient a\ incidence angle, surface roughness, type of land cover, leaf area index, average plant height and plant water content were considered. Six different neural network architectures based upon the type and the number of input variables were designed considering DN as one of the inputs for the first three networks and a0 (instead of DN) as one of the inputs for the other three networks. Coefficient of determination (R~) and root mean square error (RMSE) between the network derived soil moisture and the observed soil moisture via in-situ measurements were used for evaluation. It was observed that for all neural networks, the architectures with <7° (instead of DN) as one of the inputs produced higher R~ 0.9)and lower RMSE. The results also indicated that fewer number of input variables were sufficient to estimate soil moisture with high accuracies. The experiments clearly demonstrated the usefulness of neural networks for soil moisture estimation from microwave remote sensing data. Copyright © IICAI 2005.

Authors: Nanda P.K., Patra D., Pradhan A.
Title: Brain MR image segmentation using tabu search and hidden markov random field model
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Image Processing and Computer Vision Laboratory, National Institute of Technology, Rourkela, Orissa, 769008, India
Authors with affiliations: Nanda, P.K., Department of Electrical Engineering, Image Processing and Computer Vision Laboratory, National Institute of Technology, Rourkela, Orissa, 769008, India; Patra, D., Department of Electrical Engineering, Image Processing and Computer Vision Laboratory, National Institute of Technology, Rourkela, Orissa, 769008, India; Pradhan, A., Department of Electrical Engineering, Image Processing and Computer Vision Laboratory, National Institute of Technology, Rourkela, Orissa, 769008, India
Abstract: In this paper, we propose a hybrid Tabu Expectation Maximization (TEM) Algorithm for segmentation of Brain Magnetic Resonance (MR) images in both supervised and unsupervised framewrok. Gaussian Hidden Markov Random Field (GHMRF) is used to model the available degraded image. In supervised framework, the apriori image MRF model parameters as well as the GHMRF model parameters are assumed to be known. The class labels are estimated using the Maximum a Posteriori (MAP) estimation criterion. In unsupervised framework, the problem of model parameter estimation and label estimation is formulated in Expectation Maximization (EM) framework. The labels are estimated using the proposed Tabu Search algorithm while the model parameters are the maximum likelihood estimates. Our proposed algorithm yields results with arbitrary initial paramater set and thus overcomes the problem of proper choice of initial parameters. The results obtained are comparable with the results obtained by using the algorithm proposed by Zhang et.al. [15] , where the Iterated Conditional Mode (ICJM) algorithm is used for computing the MAP estimates. Copyright © IICAI 2005.

Authors: Jain S.K., Sudheer K.P.
Title: Development of integrated discharge and sediment rating curves using radial basis function neural network
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: National Institute of Hydrology, Roorkee - 247667, India; Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Madras, Chennai - 600036, India
Authors with affiliations: Jain, S.K., National Institute of Hydrology, Roorkee - 247667, India; Sudheer, K.P., Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Madras, Chennai - 600036, India
Abstract: Correct estimation of discharge and sediment volume being carried by a river is very important for many water resources projects. Conventional rating curves, however, are not able to provide sufficiently accurate results. This study aims to investigate the potential of employing a radial basis function (RBF) type neural network for modeling stage-discharge-sediment relationships at gauging stations. The ANN approach is used to establish an integrated stage-discharge-sediment concentration relation for two sites on the Mississippi River. Based on the comparison of the results for two gauging sites, it is shown that the RBF results are much closer to the observed values than the conventional technique and multi-layer feed-forward ANN. The results are promising and suggest that the approach is highly viable. Copyright © IICAI 2005.

Authors: Choudhary A.
Title: Accepting hybrid networks of evolutionary processors with splicing rules and forbidding context
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras Chennai 600036, India
Authors with affiliations: Choudhary, A., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras Chennai 600036, India
Abstract: An accepting hybrid network of evolutionary processors (AH- NEP in short) consists of several language processors which are located in the nodes of a virtual graph and able to perform only one type of point mutations (insertion, deletion and substitution) on the words found in that node, according to some predefined rules. Each node is associated with an input and an output filter, defined by some random conditions. After applying in parallel a point mutation to all the words existing in every node, the new words which are able to pass the output filter of the respective node navigate simultaneously through the network and enter those nodes whose input filter they are able to pass. In this paper, we replace the point mutations in every node with splicing operation, which is a biologically inspired operation. Forbidding context is also added to the splicing rules, where we check for the absence of certain symbols before applying the splicing rules. The new model is called accepting hybrid networks of evolutionary processors with splicing rules and forbidding context (AHNEPSF in short). Algorithms are proposed to two much celebrated NP-complete problems, namely the 3CNF-SAT and the directed Hamiltonian Path Problem (HPP). These algorithms working parallely on AHNEPSF takes linear time. All other resources (size, number of rules and symbols) are also linearly bounded by the size of the given instance of the problem. It is shown that the time for solving HPP does not depend on the number of edges of the given graph. Also, the algorithm that is given here for solving 3CNF-SAT provide all solutions, if any of the given instance of 3CNF-SAT. Copyright © IICAI 2005.
Index Keywords: Biologically inspired; Directed Hamiltonian path problems; Forbidding context; Hybrid network of evolutionary processors; Hybrid networks of evolutionary processors; Input filter; Language processors; Linear time; Output filters; Parallel A; Point mutations; Random condition; Splicing operation; Virtual graph; Algorithms; Artificial intelligence; Computational complexity; Program processors

Authors: Bhuyan M.K., Ghosh D., Bora P.K.
Title: Trajectory guided recognition of hand gestures for human computer interface
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: Department of Electronics and Communication Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Guwahati-781039, India
Authors with affiliations: Bhuyan, M.K., Department of Electronics and Communication Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Guwahati-781039, India; Ghosh, D., Department of Electronics and Communication Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Guwahati-781039, India; Bora, P.K., Department of Electronics and Communication Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Guwahati-781039, India
Abstract: Hand gesture recognition from visual images finds applica tions in areas like human computer interaction, machine vision, virtual reality and so on. In this paper, we present a model-based method based on Hausdorff distance for tracking hand motion in a complex scene, thereby estimating the hand motion trajectories. We use Dynamic Time wrapping (DTW) technique for gesture trajectory time alignment and normalization. Recognition is done by estimating static and dynamic features from the extracted trajectory. Experimental results demonstrate that our proposed trajectory estimator and classifier is ideal for Human Computer Interaction (HCI) platform. Copyright © IICAI 2005.

Authors: Kumar N., Shankara Narayanan G.
Title: Implementation of wireless sensors for landmine detection
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, Hindustan College of Engineering, P.O. Box 01, Padur, Chennai (Madras) - 603103 Tamil Nadu, India
Authors with affiliations: Kumar, N., Department of Computer Science, Hindustan College of Engineering, P.O. Box 01, Padur, Chennai (Madras) - 603103 Tamil Nadu, India; Shankara Narayanan, G., Department of Computer Science, Hindustan College of Engineering, P.O. Box 01, Padur, Chennai (Madras) - 603103 Tamil Nadu, India
Abstract: Landmines lie scattered even today in many third world countries. Detection and disposal have most often involved complex and costly equipment, or the need for human intervention through manual disposal. Equipment lost through detonation of the landmine cannot be replaced easily, and the loss of human life is invaluable. Thus we propose a cheaper and feasible alternative in the form of Smart Dust. Smart Dust are extremely small, Micro Electronic Mechanical Systems (MEMS) engineered devices which are autonomous and can be deployed over a large area to act as remote sensors. These motes are very cheap to manufacture and replacement is easy, even with losses of a huge number of batches to adverse environmental conditions. By using infrared temperature sensors and a wireless communication protocol, we establish that these motes can detect and report the presence or absence of a landmine in a given area. This information can then be collated to map an entire area by a central computer which acts as a mobile base for the motes. Copyright © IICAI 2005.

Authors: Nandedkar A.V., Biswas P.K.
Title: A reflex fuzzy min max neural network for classification and clustering
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur - 721302, India
Authors with affiliations: Nandedkar, A.V., Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur - 721302, India; Biswas, P.K., Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur - 721302, India
Abstract: This paper proposes "A Reflex Fuzzy Min-max Neural network" (RFMN) for pattern classification and clustering. The network is capable to handle labeled and unlabeled point and granular data simultaneously. The network architecture is equipped with a Reflex mechanism similar to the human brain. It is implemented using the concept of compensatory neurons. The data clusters or classes are here represented by the aggregation of the fuzzy hyperbox sets. An important stage in the training phase is to manage the hyperbox overlaps and containments. RFMN takes the help of compensatory neurons that are trained to handle the hyperbox overlap and containment. Inclusion of these neurons with a new learning approach has improved the performance significantly for labeled as well as unlabeled data. Moreover accuracy is almost independent of the maximum hyperbox size. The advantage of RFMN is that it can learn data in a single pass (on-line) and is capable to handle input data in the form of hyperbox granules. The performance of RFMN is compared with "General Fuzzy Min-max neural network" proposed by Gabrys and Bargiela on several datasets. Copyright © IICAI 2005.

Authors: Agrawal A., Jagadish G.
Title: Neuro-fuzzy classification of remotely sensed images: A novel approach
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: Indian Institute of Information Technology, Deoghat, Jhalwa, Allahabad - 211 011, India
Authors with affiliations: Agrawal, A., Indian Institute of Information Technology, Deoghat, Jhalwa, Allahabad - 211 011, India; Jagadish, G., Indian Institute of Information Technology, Deoghat, Jhalwa, Allahabad - 211 011, India
Abstract: This paper proposes a Nonparametric Fuzzy Neural Network model using back-propagation algorithm and trained with outputs of another neural network. Compared to Fuzzy Multilayer Perceptron (FMLP), the proposed method is independent of class distribution of training samples. Experimental results show that Nonparametric Fuzzy Neural Network has better classification accuracy when spectral characteristics of land cover classes are very close. For the IRS-P6 satellite LISS IV image of Allahabad, the percentage of overall accuracy and Kappa coefficient of FMLP are 89.2 and 87.07 respectively while that of Nonparametric Fuzzy Neural Network are 98.9 and 98.75 respectively. Copyright © IICAI 2005.

Authors: Sudarshan T.S.B., Pavankiran P.M., Krishnan S., Raghurama G.
Title: Fuzzy logic approach for replacement policy in web caching
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: Computer Science and Information Systems Group, Birla Institute of Technology and Science, Pilani, Rajasthan, India; Electronics and Instrumentation Group, Birla Institute of Technology and Science, Pilani, Rajasthan, India
Authors with affiliations: Sudarshan, T.S.B., Computer Science and Information Systems Group, Birla Institute of Technology and Science, Pilani, Rajasthan, India; Pavankiran, P.M., Computer Science and Information Systems Group, Birla Institute of Technology and Science, Pilani, Rajasthan, India; Krishnan, S., Computer Science and Information Systems Group, Birla Institute of Technology and Science, Pilani, Rajasthan, India; Raghurama, G., Electronics and Instrumentation Group, Birla Institute of Technology and Science, Pilani, Rajasthan, India
Abstract: The World Wide Web is a distributed system serving as a large storehouse of information maintained as shared data objects. In the recent years, the popularity of the Web has grown explosively, leading to increased network traffic and consequent service latency. Web caching is one of the effective schemes for improving the performance of answering requests on the World Wide Web. Replacement Algorithms play a key role in determining the effectiveness of the web cache. This study exploits the abilities of Fuzzy Logic in devising a sound cache replacement policy. It deals with analysis and implementation of a Fuzzy Algorithm for cache replacement for proxy caching, wherein a set of fuzzy rules is used to decide the web pages to evict from the cache. The performance evaluation of the Fuzzy technique with respect to other conventional replacement techniques such as Least Recently Used (LRU), Least Frequently Used (LFU) and Size-Adjusted Least Recently Used (SLRU) has also been carried out. Copyright © IICAI 2005.
Index Keywords: Cache replacement; Cache replacement policy; Distributed systems; Fuzzy algorithms; Fuzzy logic approach; Fuzzy techniques; Least frequently used; Least recently used; Network traffic; Performance evaluation; Proxy caching; Replacement algorithm; Replacement policy; Service latency; Shared data; Web Cache; Web caching; Algorithms; Artificial intelligence; Cache memory; Fuzzy logic; Fuzzy sets; Proxy caches; World Wide Web

Authors: Thukaram D., Khincha H.P., Khandelwal S.
Title: Artificial neural network approach for estimation of optimal pre-insertion resistance and switching transient peak overvoltages during transmission line energization
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560012, Karnataka, India
Authors with affiliations: Thukaram, D., Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560012, Karnataka, India; Khincha, H.P., Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560012, Karnataka, India; Khandelwal, S., Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560012, Karnataka, India
Abstract: Though not frequently blackout occur in power system due to various reasons, it is important to restore the power supply as soon as possible. At the time of restoration transmission line switching is one of the major cause, which creates overvoltage. Pre-insertion resistance (PIR) is one of the methods to limit switching overvoltages and has been used for many years. Though detailed electromagnetic transient studies carried out to reach the suitable value of PIR, it can vary according to system condition and such studies are not common in a day-to-day operation of power system. This paper presents an Artificial Neural Network (ANN) based approach to estimate the optimum value of PIR and the peak overvoltage generated by switching transients during line energization. In proposed methodology Levenberg-Marquardt method is used to train the multi-layer perceptron. The developed ANN is trained with the extensive simulated results, and tested for an equivalent 36 bus EHV system of Indian Western grid. The simulated results presented clearly show that the proposed technique can estimate the optimum value of PIR and peak values of switching overvoltages with good accuracy. Copyright © IICAI 2005.
Index Keywords: Artificial neural network approach; Day-to-day operations; EHV systems; Electromagnetic transient studies; Levenberg-Marquardt method; Line energization; Multi layer perceptron; Optimum value; Over-voltages; Peak values; Power supply; Simulated results; Switching overvoltages; Switching transient; System conditions; Electric lines; Electrolysis; Estimation; Neural networks; Restoration; Transmission line theory; Transients
Correspondence Address: Thukaram, D.; Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560012, Karnataka, India; email: dtram@ee.iisc.ernet.in

Authors: Janga Redely M., Nagesh Kumar D.
Title: Multi-objective particle swarm optimization for optimal reservoir operation
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore-560 012, India
Authors with affiliations: Janga Redely, M., Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore-560 012, India; Nagesh Kumar, D., Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore-560 012, India
Abstract: In multipurpose reservoir operation, with multiple objectives, developing an efficient operating policy is a complex problem, where it is almost implausible to satisfy all the commitments involved for different purposes. In this context, it is very important to generate various alternatives in order to perceive the effect of a particular decision on the performance of other goals. To provide better understanding of various alternatives, it is highly desirable to optimize reservoir operation problem using multi-objective evolutionary algorithm. This paper aims to develop a robust operation policy by using an evolutionary algorithm based Multi-Objective Particle Swarm Optimization (MOPSO) technique. The solutions of multi-objective PSOs yield a trade-off curve, identifying a population of points that define optimal solutions to the problem. The proposed approach is applied to Bhadra reservoir system in India. The model results show that the alternatives developed by MOPSO are very much useful and can yield better operating policies. Copyright © IICAI 2005.
Index Keywords: Complex problems; Model results; Multi objective; Multi objective evolutionary algorithms; Multi objective particle swarm optimization; Multiple objectives; Multipurpose reservoirs; Operating policies; Optimal solutions; Reservoir operation; Reservoir systems; Robust operation; Trade-off curves; Evolutionary algorithms; Multiobjective optimization; Artificial intelligence

Authors: Shekar B.H., Guru D.S., Nagabhushan P.
Title: Visual learning and recognition of 3-D objects using two dimensional fisher's linear discriminant analysis: A robust and an efficient approach
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: Department of Studies in Computer Science, University of Mysore, Manasagangothri, Mysore - 570006, Karnataka, India
Authors with affiliations: Shekar, B.H., Department of Studies in Computer Science, University of Mysore, Manasagangothri, Mysore - 570006, Karnataka, India; Guru, D.S., Department of Studies in Computer Science, University of Mysore, Manasagangothri, Mysore - 570006, Karnataka, India; Nagabhushan, P., Department of Studies in Computer Science, University of Mysore, Manasagangothri, Mysore - 570006, Karnataka, India
Abstract: Inspired by the conviction that the successful model employed for face recognition [20] should be extendable for object recognition [12], in this paper, a new technique called two-dimensional Fisher's Linear Discriminant analysis (2D-FLD) [11, 21] is explored for 3D object representation and recognition. 2D-FLD is based on 2D image matrices rather than ID vectors so that the image matrix need not be transformed into a vector prior to feature extraction. Image covariance matrix is directly computed using the original image matrices, and its eigen vectors are derived for feature extraction. The experimental results indicate that the 2D-FLD is computationally more efficient besides possessing higher recognition rate than the standard PC A (ID-PCA) [12]. Copyright © IICAI 2005.

Title: Automatic question asking system

Authors with affiliations: Jagadeesh, J., Language Technologies Research Center, International Institute of Information Technology, Hyderabad, India; Prasad, P., Language Technologies Research Center, International Institute of Information Technology, Hyderabad, India
Abstract: In this paper we have presented a system which automatically generates questions from the input text, with the help of shallow parsing and a set of pre-defined question templates. The system mainly generates two kinds of questions, questions defining the different concepts existing in the text and questions generated from sentence structure. The results obtained with the pattern matching strategy are encouraging. The analysis of the questions generated, gave a large scope for improvement. Copyright © IICAI 2005.

Abstract: This paper describes the development of a dialogue management system for the processing of mixed language telephone conversations. The objective of this work is to provide a means to freely converse with a machine through a telephone. The system delivers information over the phone through natural conversation with the user. The system recognizes the user's speech, understands it. formulates a corresponding query, retrieves the answer from the database, generates the natural language text and then replies back the answer using a Text To Speech system. The system is supposed to work in a domain specific environment. The intended domain is TamilNadu Engineering Admissions Enquiry. The system provides support for mixed language telephony speech, with mostly Tamil utterances and a few words in English. It also facilitates session maintenance. Copyright © IICAI 2005.

Authors: Maji P., Das C.
Title: Design of multilayer perceptron based tree-structured classifier for biological dataset
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: Centre for Soft Computing Research, Indian Statistical Institute, Kolkata, 700 108, India; Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Netaji Subhash Engineering College, Kolkata, 700 152, India
Authors with affiliations: Maji, P., Centre for Soft Computing Research, Indian Statistical Institute, Kolkata, 700 108, India; Das, C., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Netaji Subhash Engineering College, Kolkata, 700 152, India
Abstract: This paper presents the design and application of a neural network tree (NNTree) based pattern classifier for finding splice-junction and protein-coding (exon) regions in anonymous sequences of DNA. The idea of the new method is to use the framework of Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) based tree-structured pattern classifier. An NNTree is a hybrid learning model with the overall structure being a decision tree (DT), and each non-terminal node containing a neural network (NN). Extensive experimental results establish that the proposed classifier produces more accurate classifier than that have previously been obtained for a range of different sequence lengths; thereby indicating a cost-effective alternative in splice-junction and protein coding region identification problem. Copyright © IICAI 2005.

Title: Artificial neural network based fault detection, location and identification of transmission line outages in power systems

Abstract: This paper deals with the application of Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) to fault detection, location and detection of line outage in Extra High Voltage (EHV7) transmission lines for high-speed protection using terminal line data and the network sensitivity between load voltages and source voltages. The proposed neural fault detector, locator and line outage identification were trained using various sets of data available from a selected power network model and simulating different cases and different power system networks. The results show that artificial neural networks offer the possibility to be used for on-line fault detection, location and line outage identification in transmission lines and give satisfactory results. Results are presented for a practical 24-bus equivalent EHV7 system to illustrate the method for identifying the transmission line outage. Copyright © IICAI 2005.

Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005

Authors with affiliations: Rama Mohan, S., Department of Applied Mathematics, Faculty of Technology and Engineering, M.S. University of Baroda, Vadodara, Gujarat, India; Yajnik, A., Department of Mathematics, Parul Institute of Engineering and Technology, Limda, Vaghoclia, Gujarat, India
Abstract: This paper deals with the classification of a subset of printed or digitized Gujarati Numerals. Very little work is found in the literature regarding the recognition of Gujarati script. In this paper a fairly representative set of printed Gujarati numerals was chosen and subjected to classification by two Artificial Neural Network architectures. The sample and test images for the Gujarati numerals were obtained from the scanned images of printed Gujarati text and their features were extracted in terms of wavelet coefficients. Multi- Layer Perception (MLP) networks and Radial Basis Function Regularization [1] networks were used for the classification. The paper presents the details of neural network classification of these numeral images characterized by the Daubechie wavelet coefficients. A recognition rate of more than 90% is achieved by both the architectures. Copyright © IICAI 2005.

Authors: Angira R., Babu B.V.
Title: Optimization of non-linear chemical processes using modified differential evolution
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, Birla Institute of Technology and Science Pilani, Rajasthan, 333 031, India
Authors with affiliations: Angira, R., Department of Chemical Engineering, Birla Institute of Technology and Science Pilani, Rajasthan, 333 031, India; Babu, B.V., Department of Chemical Engineering, Birla Institute of Technology and Science Pilani, Rajasthan, 333 031, India
Abstract: Differential Evolution (DE) is an evolutionary optimization technique that is exceptionally simple, fast, and robust at numerical optimization. However, the convergence rate of DE in optimizing a computationally expensive objective function still does not meet our requirements, and an attempt to speed up DE is considered necessary. This paper introduces a Modified Differ-ential Evolution (MDE) that enhances the convergence rate without compromising the robustness. MDE algorithm utilizes only one set of population array as against two sets in original DE at any given generation. This modification improves the convergence rate of DE and at the same time maintains the robustness. The MDE is applied to two benchmark test functions followed by non-linear chemical processes. The simulation results show empirical evidences on the efficiency and effectiveness of the proposed MDE. Copyright © IICAI 2005.

Authors: Namekar S., Kambekar A.R., Deo M.C.
Title: Neural networks to predict scour of piles in the sea
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: University of Hawaii, Manoa, United States; S P College of Engineering, Mumbai, India; Civil Engineering Dept., Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Mumbai (Bombay), India
Authors with affiliations: Namekar, S., University of Hawaii, Manoa, United States; Kambekar, A.R., S P College of Engineering, Mumbai, India; Deo, M.C., Civil Engineering Dept., Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Mumbai (Bombay), India
Abstract: A generalized neural network to obtain the maximum depth of scour hole developed around a pile group in the ocean has been proposed in this work. It requires input of four dimensionless g|roups of parameters, namely, Reynolds number. Keulegan-Carpenter number. Sediment number and Shield's parameter. Two feed-forward networks of traditional multi-layered perceptron (MLP) as well as radial basis function (RBF) are considered. The former is trained using six alternative schemes in order to impart the best possible training. The performance of various training schemes has been compared in terms of their effectiveness and efficiency. Prototype measurements reported in previous literature are used for network training. The testing results showed satisfactory performance of the proposed network. The network yielded better results than the traditional statistical regression indicating its necessity over the latter. Adoption of a different architecture than the traditional MLP did not result in gain in accuracy of the outcome: however switching across different MLP training schemes was found to pay dividends in this regard. Among the different methods of MLP training the Levenberg-Marquardt scheme yielded most satisfactory results, although its training efficiency was less than the other methods. Copyright © IICAI 2005.
