Authors with affiliations: Hui, N.B., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur- 721 302, India; Pratihar, D.K., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur- 721 302, India
Abstract: Camera calibration and image processing, two important issues of mobile robot navigation, are studied in the present work. Image of an object is captured by using a CCD camera and stored in the computer memory with the help of a vision board. Three image processing algorithms such as median filtering, thresholding, and edge detection are applied to analyze the image. The optimal camera parameters and threshold value are determined optimized by using a genetic algorithm to minimize the distorted image plane error (DIPE). A case study is shown. Abstract: Given n objects of various heights, the equal piles problem seeks an arrangement of these objects into k piles such that the heights of the resulting piles are as nearly equal as possible. In this paper we propose two new heuristics for this problem. One is a hybrid steady-state grouping genetic algorithm while the other is a perturbation based local search. Computational results demonstrate the effectiveness of our heuristics. Copyright © IICAI 2005.

Title: Dynamic RDT model for data mining
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: National Centre for Agricultural Economics and Policy Research, New Delhi 110012, India; School of Computers and Systems Sciences, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi 110067, India
Authors with affiliations: Jain, R., National Centre for Agricultural Economics and Policy Research, New Delhi 110012, India; Minz, S., School of Computers and Systems Sciences, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi 110067, India
Abstract: Dynamic RDT is proposed to deal with the real time dataset which may have noise. The paper explores the variants of Rough set based Decision Tree induction (RDT) methods for learning classification rules. The required set of classification rules is aimed to help in identification of the households which are vulnerable to food shortage. The classification rules are desired to be as simple as possible. Classical rough set method. C4.5 algorithm, the hybrid algorithm RDT and its variants as well as dynamic RDT model are used. The experimental results are compared graphically with that of the base algorithms based on the performance parameters classification accuracy, complexity, number of rules and the CS score for the resulting classifier. The new variant of RDT called Dynamic RDT is observed suitable for the real time dataset. Copyright © IICAI 2005.
Index Keywords: C4.5 algorithm; Classification accuracy; Classification rules; Data sets; Decision tree induction; Hybrid algorithms; Performance parameters; Real time; Rough set; Rough-set based; Algorithms; Artificial intelligence; Decision trees; Rough set theory; Data mining

Authors: Vijaya P.A., Narasimha Murty M., Subramanian D.K.
Title: Analysis of leader based clustering algorithms for pattern classification
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore - 560012, India
Authors with affiliations: Vijaya, P.A., Department of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore - 560012, India; Narasimha Murty, M., Department of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore - 560012, India; Subramanian, D.K., Department of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore - 560012, India
Abstract: Clustering is basically an unsupervised learning technique to divide a collection of patterns into groups of similar objects based on a distance or similarity function. Clustering techniques are applied in pattern classification, bioinformatics. data mining, web ruining, biometrics. document processing, remote sensed data analysis, biomedical data analysis, etc., in which the data size can be very large. Incremental clustering schemes which involve very few database (db) scans and re-quire less main memory space arc; preferred for large data sets than other methods as they are scalable. Leader is a one pass, incremental, partitional clustering scheme suitable for large data sets. This paper presents a framework for incremental clustering and analysis of leader based clus-tering schemes and some related theorems. Use of leaders as prototypes is compared with that of using random samples as prototypes. Comparison of different variations of the leader based clustering algorithm and their properties arc; discussed. Based 011 the analysis and the experimental results some; conclusions are drawn. Copyright © IICAI 2005.

Authors: Jana P., Chowdhuiy N.
Title: Finding the natural grouping in a data set using MST of the data set
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: MCKV Institute of Engineering, 243, G. T Road(N), Liluah, Howrah-711204, West Bengal, India; Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata-700032, West Bengal, India
Authors with affiliations: Jana, P., MCKV Institute of Engineering, 243, G. T Road(N), Liluah, Howrah-711204, West Bengal, India; Chowdhuiy, N., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata-700032, West Bengal, India
Abstract: Cluster analysis methods attempt to extract the natural grouping present in a given data set. A lot of scientific effort has already been dedicated in search of efficient cluster analysis methods. This paper has proposed a method to find the number of "natural" groups (or clusters) as well as the groups themselves. The method presented here has three parts. The first part of the method locates the high density regions of a given data set while the second part uses those high density regions "suitably" along with the data points of other regions to result in the clustering. The third pait of the method eliminates noise from the final clustering. Euclidean distance has been used as the similarity measure. The novelty of the method is that it finds the number of clusters automatically. Experimental results on synthetic data in R2 and R3 are provided which show the utility of this method. This method is also applicable to higher dimensional data sets. The proposed method has also found to provide good results for two real life data sets considered for experimentation. Copyright © IICAI 2005.

Authors: Janardhan Rao D.V., Mitra P.
Title: A Rough association rule based approach for class prediction with missing attribute values
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur-208016, India
Authors with affiliations: Janardhan Rao, D.V., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur-208016, India; Mitra, P., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur-208016, India
Abstract: In many real-life classification tasks one often encounters in stances whore values of certain attributes are missing. Rough association rules, extracted from a training data, may be used to predict the class labels of such instances with missing attribute values. The association rules capture the statistical dependency between the feature values. We propose a methodology based on rough set feature selection, association rule mining, and rule matching for prediction of class labels. Experi ments arc performed on two benchmark data sets and a real-life medical diagnosis task. The algorithm is found to provide high class prediction accuracy, even with large number of features missing. Copyright © IICAI 2005.

Authors: Raehuwanshi M.M., Kakde O.G.
Title: Multi-parent recombination operator with polynomial or lognormal distribution for real coded genetic algorithm
Source title: Proceedings of the 2nd Indian International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IICAI 2005
Affiliations: Research and Technology, Rajiv Gandhi College of Engineering, Pin: 442403, Chandrapur, M.S., India; Visvesvarava National Institute of Technology, Nagpur, M.S., India

Abstract: The recombination (or crossover) operation is a method of sharing information anions chromosomes in genetic algorithm(GA). The neighborhood- based crossover operators used in real-coded genetic algorithm (RCGA) are based on some probability distribution. In this paper, we propose MPX (multi- parent crossover with polynomial distribution) and MLX (multi-parent crossover with lognormal distribution) operators. These operators are gene- based parent centric crossover operator. The performance of these operators is investigated on commonly used unimodal and multi-modal functions. It is observed that these operators are capable to solve problems very efficiently. The performance of these operators is compared with the performance of other operators. These operators are performing better than other operators. Copyright © IICAI 2005.

Authors: Prasad M.A., Mohan S.
Title: Fuzzy logic model for multi - Purpose multi - Reservoir system
Source title: Artificial Intelligence Applications and Innovations - IFIP TC12 WG12.5 - 2nd IFIP Conference on Artificial Intelligence Applications and Innovations, AIAI 2005
Affiliations: Environmental and Water Resources Division, Indian Institute of Technology Madras, Chennai - 600 036, India
Authors with affiliations: Prasad, M.A., Environmental and Water Resources Division, Indian Institute of Technology Madras, Chennai - 600 036, India; Mohan, S., Environmental and Water Resources Division, Indian Institute of Technology Madras, Chennai - 600 036, India
Abstract: Reservoirs are built usually to serve multiple purposes, viz. irrigation, municipal and industrial water supply, hydro-power and flood control. Due to high variability of annual rainfall and conflicting demands on scarce water resources, the study and operation of reservoir systems has assumed great significance to meet the short term and long-term requirements. The reservoir managers do not find previous techniques of complex optimization models are difficult to adopt practically. New methods have to be developed which are simple to understand and can be effectively adopted for the existing systems. Any reservoir problem is usually site specific in nature and hence any general modeling methodology cannot be directly applied to study the system behavior. Artificial intelligence approaches are now being adopted to effectively simulate the reservoir system based on the experience of human knowledge and expertise. These methods are simple to understand for the reservoir managers and also may be acceptable since the model is being developed with the output and opinion of experts who are really operating the reservoir system. The Fuzzy rule based systems are very much suitable for inferring developed operating policies. In the present work a rule based fuzzy model is attempted for long-term operation a multi reservoir system. The present model was developed on monthly basis for operation and the model was demonstrated with a case of two serial reservoirs on River Godavari sub system located in South India when they are operated individually. The recent artificial intelligence tools like Genetic programming, Artificial Neural networks and Fuzzy logic are increasingly used as soft computing techniques to address modelling issues. The main advantage of these techniques lies in handling noisy data, addressing non - linear and dynamic systems. These tools also useful when it is difficult to explain the physical relationship are not fully understood in order to enhance the performance of the system. The present paper is aimed to present a fuzzy logic methodology for long-term reservoir operation. In this method a monthly fuzzy rule based model was developed based on the historical operation. The performance of the model was tested with calibrated period and validation period.
Author Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Fuzzy logic; Long-term operation; Reservoirs; Soft computing techniques; System
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence tools; Fuzzy logic methodology; Fuzzy rule-based models; Industrial water supply; Long-term operation; Multi-reservoir systems; Softcomputing techniques; System; Artificial intelligence; Data handling; Flood control; Fuzzy rules; Genetic programming; Management; Managers; Neural networks; Petroleum reservoirs; Soft computing; Water resources; Water supply; Fuzzy logic

Authors: Suthar H.A., Pandya K.B.
Title: Designing Fuzzy Logic controller for inverted pendulum
Source title: Artificial Intelligence Applications and Innovations - IFIP TC12 WG12.5 - 2nd IFIP Conference on Artificial Intelligence Applications and Innovations, AIAI 2005
Affiliations: Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel Institute of Technology, VASAD, Dist. Anand, Gujarat, India

Abstract: In control system, if all the states of the system are measured, then by using state feedback control law we can control the system. As we know that value of feedback gain cannot be found easily, it requires trial and error method for suitable pole locations. In certain applications state variables cannot be measured because of cost considerations or lack of suitable transducers. In such cases, state variables that cannot be measured must be estimated from the ones that are measurable. A device, which estimates states, is known as 'observer' or 'state observer'. To design observer, person has to face mathematical complexities. Here without facing mathematical complexities control system can be controlled using Fuzzy Logic Approach.
Index Keywords: Fuzzy logic approach; Fuzzy logic controllers; Inverted pendulum; Mathematical complexity; State feedback control law; State observer; State variables; Trial-and-error method; Artificial intelligence; Control systems; Fuzzy logic; Observability

Authors: Abdulla M.S., Bhatnagar S.
Title: Solution of MDPS using simulation-based value iteration
Source title: Artificial Intelligence Applications and Innovations - IFIP TC12 WG12.5 - 2nd IFIP Conference on Artificial Intelligence Applications and Innovations, AIAI 2005
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560 012, India
Authors with affiliations: Abdulla, M.S., Department of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560 012, India; Bhatnagar, S., Department of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560 012, India
Abstract: This article proposes a three-timescale simulation based algorithm for solution of infinite horizon Markov Decision Processes (MDPs). We assume a finite state space and discounted cost criterion and adopt the value iteration approach. An approximation of the Dynamic Programming operator T is applied to the value function iterates. This 'approximate' operator is implemented using three timescales, the slowest of which updates the value function iterates. On the middle timescale we perform a gradient search over the feasible action set of each state using Simultaneous Perturbation Stochastic Approximation (SPSA) gradient estimates, thus finding the minimizing action in T. On the fastest timescale, the 'critic' estimates, over which the gradient search is performed, are obtained. A sketch of convergence explaining the dynamics of the algorithm using associated ODEs is also presented. Numerical experiments on rate based flow control on a bottleneck node using a continuous-time queueing model are performed using the proposed algorithm. The results obtained are verified against classical value iteration where the feasible set is suitably discretized. Over such a discretized setting, a variant of the algorithm of [12] is compared and the proposed algorithm is found to converge faster.
Index Keywords: Discounted cost criterion; Finite state spaces; Gradient estimates; Markov Decision Processes; Numerical experiments; Rate-based flow control; Simulation-based algorithms; Simultaneous perturbation stochastic approximation; Algorithms; Artificial intelligence; Markov processes; Queueing theory; Iterative methods

Title: Shock filters based on implicit cluster separation
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Computer Society Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay, Mumbai, 400076, India
Authors with affiliations: Namboodiri, V.P., Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay, Mumbai, 400076, India; Chaudhuri, S., Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay, Mumbai, 400076, India
Abstract: One of the classic problems in low level vision is image restoration. An important contribution toward this effort has been the development of shock filters by Osher and Rudin [15]. It performs image de-blurring using hyperbolic partial differential equations. In this paper we relate the notion of cluster separation from the field of pattern recognition to the shock filter formulation. A kind of shock filter is proposed based on the idea of gradient based separation of clusters. The proposed formulation is general enough as it can allow various models of density functions in the cluster separation process. The efficacy of the method is demonstrated through various examples. © 2005 IEEE.

Authors: Sarawagi S., Cohen W.W.
Title: Semi-markov conditional random fields for information extraction
Source title: Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems
Affiliations: Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, India; Center for Automated Learning and Discovery, Carnegie Mellon University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sarawagi, S., Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, India; Cohen, W.W., Center for Automated Learning and Discovery, Carnegie Mellon University, United States
Abstract: We describe semi-Markov conditional random fields (semi-CRFs), a conditionally trained version of semi-Markov chains. Intuitively, a semi- CRF on an input sequence x outputs a "segmentation" of x, in which labels are assigned to segments (i.e., subsequences) of x rather than to individual elements xi of x. Importantly, features for semi-CRFs can measure properties of segments, and transitions within a segment can be non-Markovian. In spite of this additional power, exact learning and inference algorithms for semi-CRFs are polynomial-time-often only a small constant factor slower than conventional CRFs. In experiments on five named entity recognition problems, semi-CRFs generally outperform conventional CRFs.
Index Keywords: Markov processes; Conditional random field; Constant factors; Exact learning; Inference algorithm; Input sequence; Named entity recognition; Non-Markovian; Semi-Markov chain; Inference engines

Title: A second order cone programming formulation for classifying missing data

Abstract: We propose a convex optimization based strategy to deal with uncertainty in the observations of a classification problem. We assume that instead of a sample (xi; yi) a distribution over (xi; y i) is specified. In particular, we derive a robust formulation when the distribution is given by a normal distribution. It leads to Second Order Cone Programming formulation. Our method is applied to the problem of missing data, where it outperforms direct imputation.

Title: An inexact graph matching technique using genetic algorithms and its application in systems biology
Source title: Proceedings of the Eighth IASTED International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Soft Computing

Authors with affiliations: Hussan, J.R., IBM Software Labs., Golden Enclave, Airport Road, India
Abstract: Graph is a versatile datastructure for representing and processing relational information. Inexact graph matching is the process of determining the best possible match of one graph against another where there is not much correspondence between the graphs. The inexact graph matching problem is NP-hard. This paper proposes a genetic algorithm based technique to find the best possible match between two graphs. The technique is aided by loosely coupled similarity estimation metrics to perform the matching. The technique has been applied to a real world inexact graph matching problem and the results have been provided.

Title: Similarity search in time series databases using moments

Authors with affiliations: Toshniwal, D., Department of Electronics and Computer Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Roorkee, India; Joshi, R.C., Department of Electronics and Computer Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Roorkee, India
Abstract: Similarity search in time series data is an area of active interest in the data mining community. In this paper we introduce a simple and novel approach for performing similarity search over time series data using moments. This technique is based on the observation that similar time sequences will have their centroids close to each other. The proposed technique is capable of handling variable length queries and works irrespective of global scaling and shrinking of time series data. It can also handle vertical shifts. ©2004 IEEE.

Authors: Vasudevan K.
Title: A novel Genetic ARIMA (G-ARIMA) model applied to the financial forecasting problem
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IC-AI'04
Affiliations: Post Graduate Program, Indian Institute of Management, Lucknow, UP, India
Authors with affiliations: Vasudevan, K., Post Graduate Program, Indian Institute of Management, Lucknow, UP, India
Abstract: This paper presents a novel application of the concepts of genetic algorithms to the forecasting problem in order to effectively utilize the time series model for forecasting, monitoring and feedback and feedforward control. A new model namely the G-ARIMA model is presented in this paper, which involves the application of a search based multiphase genetic algorithm to the time series ARIMA model. The backbone concept of this model lies in utilizing the genetic approach effectively for implementing the Auto Regressive (AR) process, a linear stochastic model where the time series is assumed to be a linear aggregation of random shocks. The concept of genetic algorithms is used to transform an initial population of potential solutions into a population that contains solutions approximating the optimal one. A carefully chosen fitness function acts in the capacity of a yardstick to appraise the quality of each "chromosome" to aid the selection phase. The G-ARIMA model was tested on the IBM common stock closing prices given in Box et al using a Pentium IV processor and the residual variances obtained were found to be 20.98% lesser when compared to those of the original Box-Jenkins ARIMA approach. The low run times ensured that the G-ARIMA model could be of practical relevance too. This paper hence opens up a whole new gamut of methodology for estimating coefficients in the ARIMA model using genetic algorithms.
Author Keywords: Auto regressive process; Box Jenkins approach; Financial forecasting; G-ARIMA model; Genetic algorithms; Stock markets

Authors: Hima Bindu M.
Title: Visual semiotics, human emotions and neurotransmitters
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IC-AI'04
Affiliations: Indian Inst. of Info. Technology, Allahabad, India
Authors with affiliations: Hima Bindu, M., Indian Inst. of Info. Technology, Allahabad, India
Abstract: In this paper an effort is made to bring about a close-knit relation between semiotics and the human emotions; an idea that helps us put more of human qualities into our communication. Human thought is inherently emotional and emotions are an essential and productive aspect of human thought and action. Emotions though supposed to be erratic from the early days, are proved to be a mechanism that encompasses readiness to act, expectations, focus to goals, appraisal - of self and others and the resulting reactions. But the question is how do we achieve the recognition of these emotions? Is it only the facial expressions, body pose, changes in metabolism etc., or something more dealing with the physical body and also the mental part of it or the cognitive states of the human mind?

Title: Polarized lexicon for review classification
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IC-AI'04

Authors with affiliations: Sista, S.P., Applied Research Group, Satyam Computer Services Limited, Bangalore 560025, India; Srinivasan, S.H., Applied Research Group, Satyam Computer Services Limited, Bangalore 560025, India
Abstract: Customer reviews of products and services have positive or negative orientation depending on their experience. Determining the polarity of the reviews depend on the orientation of the words in the text, where some words are positive oriented and some are negative oriented. In this paper, we present an approach to build polarized lexicon tables, and then apply these tables to the review polarity classification task. Our results indicate a definite improvement in the classification accuracy when the polarized lexicon tables are used.

Authors: Eswaran U., Ganji M.R., Thakur M.S.
Title: Microprocessor based biosensors for determination of toxins and pathogens in restricted areas of human intervention
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IC-AI'04
Affiliations: Gayathri Vidyaparishad Eng. College, Visakhapatnam 530041, India; Regency Institute of Technology, Yanam 533464, India; CFTRI, Mysore, India
Authors with affiliations: Eswaran, U., Gayathri Vidyaparishad Eng. College, Visakhapatnam 530041, India; Ganji, M.R., Regency Institute of Technology, Yanam 533464, India; Thakur, M.S., CFTRI, Mysore, India
Abstract: Monitoring of food ingredients using enzyme based biosensors is a recent development. Functioning of biosensor device is based on electro-chemical mechanical changes brought about by biomechanical reactions. Their applications in food processing industries are increasing day by day and there are nearly 2500 commercially available enzymes that can be used for biosensor development. Many biotechnological processes for cultivation of microorganisms require carbohydrates as an essential ingredient of the medium for fermentation where biosensors play an important role. Microprocessor based Biosensor for glucose and sucrose was developed at CFTRI Mysore, India using immobilized enzymes and an amperometric detector system. Detection of toxins and pathogens provides safety index in food processing industries, in risky areas of defense and in other polluted environments where human intervention may have to restricted. Neural networks as a tool for identifying microorganism species was evaluated. Considering the methodology of this evaluation procedure as a basis, several look-up tables of various parameters of food samples have been generated for detection of toxicity. These tables, on a concept basis, have been standardized for the purpose of correlation with the data generated by the given food sample using the microprocessor based biosensor. A correlation-based algorithm is designed for identifying the samples that belong to risk area and safety areas with respective threshold levels. The results provide better variances than the conventional methods of biosensor detection systems while micro miniaturization is possible. Considering threshold levels of safety index, the results are observed to be capable of identifying the probabilities of presence of toxins and pathogens.

Authors: Senthil U., Khemani D.
Title: A domain independent algorithm for adapting temporal plans
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, IC-AI'04
Affiliations: AIDB Lab., Dept. of CS and E, IIT Madras, Chennai-600 036, India; Dept. of CS and E, IIT Madras, Chennai-600 036, India
Authors with affiliations: Senthil, U., AIDB Lab., Dept. of CS and E, IIT Madras, Chennai-600 036, India; Khemani, D., Dept. of CS and E, IIT Madras, Chennai-600 036, India
Abstract: Plan adaptation is useful in faster generation of plans. We propose a domain independent algorithm for adapting plans with durative actions. Given a plan which is to be adapted to the new problem, our algorithm retains a portion of the old plan (set of actions) that can be useful in solving the new problem. The actions in the portion of the old plan are adjusted to the new durations. These actions are applied one after another according to their start times, starting from the initial state of the new problem. The state with the lowest heuristic value among the intermediate states obtained after application of each action is selected. A plan is found out from this state to the goal state of the problem and added to the set of actions applied to arrive at this state. The resulting set of actions forms the plan for the new problem. Experimental results show that adapting a temporal plan using our algorithm can be very efficient.
Author Keywords: Plan adaptation; Temporal planning
Index Keywords: Computational methods; Functions; Graph theory; Heuristic methods; Planning; Problem solving; Plan adaptation; Relaxed temporal planning graph (RTPG); Temporal graph plan (TGP); Temporal planning; Adaptive algorithms

Authors: Li Y., Shiu S.C.-K., Pal S.K., Liu J.N.-K.
Title: A rough set-based CBR approach for feature and document reduction in text categorization
Source title: Proceedings of 2004 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics
Affiliations: Department of Computing, Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Kowloon, Hong Kong; Machine Intelligence Unit, Indian Statistical Institute, Kolkata, 700 035, India; Machine Learning Center, Fac. of Math. and Computer Science, Hebei University, Baoding 071002, China

Abstract: In this paper, a novel approach of rough set-based case-based reasoning (CBR) approach is proposed to tackle the task of text categorization (TC). The initial work of integrating both feature and document reduction/selection in TC using rough sets and CBR properties is presented. Rough set theory is incorporated to reduce the number of feature terms through generating reducts. On the other hand, two concepts of case coverage and case reachability in CBR are used in selecting representative documents. The main contribution of this paper is that both the number of features and the documents are reduced with minimal loss of useful information. Some experiments are conducted on the text datasets of Reuters21578. The experimental results show that, although the number of feature terms and documents are reduced greatly, the problem-solving quality in terms of classification accuracy is still preserved.
Author Keywords: Case Coverage; Case Reachability; Case-based Reasoning (CBR); Rough Set; Text Categorization (TC)

Authors: Chopra S., Mitra R., Kumar V.
Title: Identification of rules using subtractive clustering with application to fuzzy controllers
Source title: Proceedings of 2004 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics
Affiliations: Dept. of Electronics Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Roorkee, India
Authors with affiliations: Chopra, S., Dept. of Electronics Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Roorkee, India; Mitra, R., Dept. of Electronics Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Roorkee, India; Kumar, V., Dept. of Electronics Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Roorkee, India
Abstract: The common way of developing Fuzzy controller is by determining the rule base and some appropriate fuzzy sets over the controller's input and output ranges. A simple and efficient approach, namely, Fuzzy Subtractive Clustering is used here. This approach is used to minimize the number of rules of Fuzzy Logic Controllers. The rule extraction method based on estimating clusters in the numerical data; each cluster obtained corresponds to a fuzzy rule that relates a region in the input space to an output region. The rule base is defined on error and change in error of the controlled variable using the most natural and unbiased membership functions. The simulation analysis on a wide range of processes is carried out. The clustering based Fuzzy Logic Controllers is compared with those of conventional Fuzzy Logic Controllers. The Fuzzy Subtractive clustering approach is shown to reduce 49 rules to 8 rules maintaining almost the same level of performance.
Author Keywords: Extraction of Rules; Fuzzy control; Fuzzy Subtractive Clustering
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Computational complexity; Computer simulation; Data reduction; Error analysis; Fuzzy sets; Interfaces (computer); Linear systems; Optimization; Set theory; Data points; Extraction of rules; Fuzzy controllers; Fuzzy subtractive clustering; Fuzzy control

Title: Analysis of patterns in speaker authentication using discrete probability HMMs
Source title: Proceedings of 2004 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics

Authors with affiliations: Varshney, V., Dept. of Comp. Sci. and Engineering, HT Guwahati, Guwahati-781039, India; Malakar, D.J., Dept. of Comp. Sci. and Engineering, HT Guwahati, Guwahati-781039, India; Das, P.K., Dept. of Comp. Sci. and Engineering, HT Guwahati, Guwahati-781039, India
Abstract: The advances in computer hardware combined with innovative Artificial Intelligence (AI) techniques can be a powerful methodology to perform intelligent cognitive tasks. We have investigated Speech Recognition techniques using Hidden Markov Models and successfully classified speakers based on their utterances. This paper proposes a discrete Probability HMMS based approach to successfully classify speakers based on their utterances. The results show that we have got high accuracy in identifying the speakers. This leads us to conclude that Uncertain Reasoning and Learning are vital components of AI that could lead to the development of automated intelligent solutions to various complex and interesting problems.

Authors: Govindu V.M.
Title: Lie-algebraic averaging for globally consistent motion estimation
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Computer Society Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition
Affiliations: HIG-25, Simhapuri Layout, Visakhapatnam, AP 530047, India
Authors with affiliations: Govindu, V.M., HIG-25, Simhapuri Layout, Visakhapatnam, AP 530047, India
Abstract: While motion estimation has been extensively studied in the computer vision literature, the inherent information redundancy in an image sequence has not been well utilised. In particular as many as N(N-1)/2 pairwise relative motions can be estimated efficiently from a sequence of N images. This highly redundant set of observations can be efficiently averaged resulting in fast motion estimation algorithms that are globally consistent. In this paper we demonstrate this using the underlying Lie-group structure of motion representations. The Lie-algebras of the Special Orthogonal and Special Euclidean groups are used to define averages on the Lie-group which in turn gives statistically meaningful, efficient and accurate algorithms for fusing motion information. Using multiple constraints also controls the drift in the solution due to accumulating error. The performance of the method in estimating camera motion is demonstrated on image sequences.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Cameras; Computer vision; Constraint theory; Error analysis; Image analysis; Statistical methods; Epipolar geometry; Image sequences; Video sequences; Motion estimation

Authors: Bhattacharyya C.
Title: Second order cone programming formulations for feature selection
Source title: Journal of Machine Learning Research
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India
Authors with affiliations: Bhattacharyya, C., Department of Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India
Abstract: This paper addresses the issue of feature selection for linear classifiers given the moments of the class conditional densities. The problem is posed as finding a minimal set of features such that the resulting classifier has a low misclassification error. Using a bound on the misclassification error involving the mean and covariance of class conditional densities and minimizing an L1 norm as an approximate criterion for feature selection, a second order programming formulation is derived. To handle errors in estimation of mean and covariances, a tractable robust formulation is also discussed. In a slightly different setting the Fisher discriminant is derived. Feature selection for Fisher discriminant is also discussed. Experimental results on synthetic data sets and on real life microarray data show that the proposed formulations are competitive with the state of the art linear programming formulation. © 2004 Chiranjib Bhattacharyya.
Index Keywords: Classification (of information); Linear programming; Conditional density; Fisher discriminant; Linear programming formulation; Misclassification error; Robust formulations; Second order programming; Second-order cone programming; Synthetic datasets; Feature extraction

Abstract: In this article, we apply the independent component analysis technique for mining spatio-temporal data. The technique has been applied to mine for patterns in weather data using the North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO) as a specific example. We find that the strongest independent components match the observed synoptic weather patterns corresponding to the NAO. We also validate our results by matching the independent component activities with the NAO index. © 2004 Jayanta Basak, Anant Sudarshan, Deepak Trivedi and M. S. Santhanam.

Title: Real-time detection and understanding of isolated protruded fingers
Source title: IEEE Computer Society Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition Workshops

Abstract: Making sense of hand gestures in applications such as novel user interfaces is an active area of research. Many current methods use complex 3D model of non-rigid hands and involved paradigms in solving the general problem. In this paper we look at a subproblem of sign language alphabet recognition where gestures are made with protruded fingers. In contrast to the more intricate schemes, we propose a simple, fast classification algorithm using two dimensional projection of Euler angles. Not only is our scheme novel, it lends itself to a real time implementation. © 2004 IEEE.

Abstract: The present paper provides first the concept and different tasks of case-base maintenance. Then the use of some soft computing techniques, including fuzzy sets, rough sets and fuzzy integral, is described in maintaining the case base completeness. From the experimental results, these techniques are shown to be very effective in the modeling and extraction of the domain knowledge in the case base.

Title: SimpleSVM
Source title: Proceedings, Twentieth International Conference on Machine Learning
Affiliations: Machine Learning Program, National ICT for Australia, Canberra, ACT 0200, Australia; Machine Learning Group, RSISE, Australian National University, Canberra, ACT 0200, Australia; Dept. of Comp. Sci., Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560012, India

Sci., Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560012, India
Abstract: We present a fast iterative support vector training algorithm for a large variety of different formulations. It works by incrementally changing a candidate support vector set using a greedy approach, until the supporting hyperplane is found within a finite number of iterations. It is derived from a simple active set method which sweeps through the set of Lagrange multipliers and keeps optimality in the unconstrained variables, while discarding large amounts of bound-constrained variables. The hard-margin version can be viewed as a simple (yet computationally crucial) modification of the incremental SVM training algorithms of Cauwenberghs and Poggio. Experimental results for various settings are reported. In all cases our algorithm is considerably faster than competing methods such as Sequential Minimal Optimization or the Nearest Point Algorithm.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Competition; Computational methods; Error analysis; Iterative methods; Maps; Matrix algebra; Optimization; Problem solving; Quadratic programming; Bound-constrained variables; Matrix inversion; Support vector machines (SVM); Training algorithms; Computer science

Abstract: Face detection is an important research area having wide applications in man-machine interface, visual surveillance and face recognition. We have proposed an algorithm for face detection using Gradient Vector Flow in gray level images which overcomes the problem for localization and initialization. The algorithm has been tested on various face databases and the result shows an accuracy of 97% with invariance to pose and orientation.

Authors: Krishnapuram R., Chitrapura K.P., Joshi S.
Title: Classification of Text Documents Based on Minimum System Entropy
Source title: Proceedings, Twentieth International Conference on Machine Learning
Affiliations: IBM India Research Lab., Indian Institute of Technology, Block-I, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, India
Authors with affiliations: Krishnapuram, R., IBM India Research Lab., Indian Institute of Technology, Block-I, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, India; Chitrapura, K.P., IBM India Research Lab., Indian Institute of Technology, Block-I, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, India; Joshi, S., IBM India Research Lab., Indian Institute of Technology, Block-I, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, India
Abstract: In this paper, we describe a new approach to classification of text documents based on the minimization of system entropy, i.e., the overall uncertainty associated with the joint distribution of words and labels in the collection. The classification algorithm assigns a class label to a new document in such a way that its insertion into the system results in the maximum decrease (or least increase) in system entropy. We provide insights into the minimum system entropy criterion, and establish connections to traditional naive Bayes approaches. Experimental results indicate that the algorithm performs well in terms of classification accuracy. It is less sensitive to feature selection and more scalable when compared with SVM.

Guwahati, North Guwahati - 781039, India; Tiwari, R., Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Inst. of Technology Guwahati, North Guwahati - 781039, Assam, India
Abstract: The design of tapered roller bearings has a fundamental influence on the performance, life and reliability of the bearings. Consequently, this also affects the operating quality and the economization of machines on which the bearings are used. The responsibility of bearing designers is to select an optimal scheme from all the possible alternative designs, or simply put to make the best choice. A basic requirement for conventional rolling bearings is the maximum dynamic capacity. In this paper we used Genetic Algorithm to search a design for tapered roller bearing, which has maximum dynamic capacity, and the design satisfies all the boundary conditions. The algorithm proceeds with basic objective of increase in dynamic capacity value. At the same time all the constraints are also satisfied.

Authors: Aghila G., Manjula D., Geetha T.V.
Title: Automatic generation of description logic representation of documents
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Artificial Intelligence IC-AI 2003
Affiliations: School of Computer Science and Eng., Anna University, Chennai-600 025, India
Authors with affiliations: Aghila, G., School of Computer Science and Eng., Anna University, Chennai-600 025, India; Manjula, D., School of Computer Science and Eng., Anna University, Chennai-600 025, India; Geetha, T.V., School of Computer Science and Eng., Anna University, Chennai-600 025, India
Abstract: Expressive representation of documents using knowledge representation formalism is needed for the effective retrieval of information from vastly available knowledge sources. This paper discusses the semantic representation of documents using Description Logic, where the descriptions of the content words are formed automatically from the gloss information of each content word from the WordNet. The overall design of the system includes preprocessing of the documents, content word extraction, weight generation of the content word for content word reduction, finding the sense of the content word using Word Sense Disambiguation (WSD) process and automatic generation of description of the content word from the gloss of the content word obtained from the WordNet. In this paper we concentrate on automatically forming the descriptions of the content words of the document which represents the conceptual taxonomy of the documents. Each, document has its own Abox and Abox contains instantiation. Along with the initial available Description Logic hierarchy and the semantic representation of documents using Description Logic, the reasoning services instance checking and subsumption of Description Logic are used for inferencing. The inferenced knowledge can be used in various applications like Information Retrieval (IR) system to retrieve information even though the information available is incomplete or incorrect.
Index Keywords: Content based retrieval; Inference engines; Knowledge representation; Logic design; Semantics; Description logic representation; Semantic representation; Word sense disambiguation process; Information retrieval systems

Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Artificial Intelligence IC-AI 2003

Abstract: Many systematic approaches have been studied to represent documents. One of the approaches, called Phrase based Technique (PHT) uses phrases to represent documents, aiming at capturing the main phrases present in the document. A set of phrases is represented as an ATN. One of the main problems in this approach is to construct ATN that can capture all possible patterns. This paper provides a frame work that is essential for capturing the most of the patterns used in English Language and proposes a way to automatically represent documents. Experiments have been performed on small set of documents and shown that phrases are more effective than keywords in terms of content indicators.

Abstract: In this paper, we present a novel scheme for designing real Gabor filters for texture representation. The novelty of the scheme lies in the systematic approach in determining the parameters of the Gabor filters. In addition, the limitations of this approach are highlighted, and an optimization-based framework is proposed in order to overcome them.

Authors: Sharma R., Raman S.
Title: A phrase-based text representation approach for effective retrieval of web documents
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Artificial Intelligence IC-AI 2003
Affiliations: Dept. of Computer Science and Eng., Indian Inst. of Technology, Madras, Chennai - 600036, India
Authors with affiliations: Sharma, R., Dept. of Computer Science and Eng., Indian Inst. of Technology, Madras, Chennai - 600036, India; Raman, S., Dept. of Computer Science and Eng., Indian Inst. of Technology, Madras, Chennai - 600036, India
Abstract: Internet has facilitated the capability of searching documents on the web irrespective of their physical location. Since most of the documents available on the web are machine-readable but not machine-understandable, the retrieval of relevant information continues to be a difficult task. Essentially, effective text retrieval is an issue related to an efficient text representation also. This paper presents and discusses a phrase-based model for text representation that uses rule-based Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques for extracting key-phrases from the text document by a process of partial parsing. NLP technique has been used to preprocess the documents to extract the content carrying terms, and also to process a user's request to identify important search terms. Phrasal indexing aims to reduce the ambiguity inherent in words considered in isolation, and thus attempts to improve the retrieval effectiveness. The representation approach has been evaluated from retrieval point of view, and the system shows a performance of 81% precision and 83% of recall.
Author Keywords: Name recognition; Phrase-based text representation; Query processing; Stop word removal; Text retrieval

Authors: Sinha R.M.K.
Title: Translating opposing word-pairs with same initial character
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Artificial Intelligence IC-AI 2003
Affiliations: Computer Science and Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur, India
Authors with affiliations: Sinha, R.M.K., Computer Science and Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur, India
Abstract: How does one translate an utterance like 'F stands both for friend and foe'? A human translator uses a number of knowledge sources to make acceptable lexical choices at the target language. This paper presents an algorithm for translating the word-pairs which have opposing meanings and have same initial character. It uses word-nets of both the source and target languages. Illustrative examples have been given from English and Hindi. Examples show that the algorithm generates an acceptable translation where such a solution exists.
Author Keywords: Antonym; Lexical-choice; Machine-translation; NLP; Word-net

Authors: Nagy G., Seth S.C., Mehta S.K., Lin Y.
Title: Indirect Symbolic Correlation Approach to Unsegmented Text Recognition
Source title: IEEE Computer Society Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition Workshops
Affiliations: Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Troy, NY, United States; University of Nebraska-Lincoln, United States; Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur, India
Authors with affiliations: Nagy, G., Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Troy, NY, United States; Seth, S.C., University of Nebraska-Lincoln, United States; Mehta, S.K., Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur, India; Lin, Y., University of Nebraska-Lincoln, United States
Abstract: The new non-parametric approach to unsegmented text recognition builds two bipartite graphs that result from the feature-level and lexical comparisons of the same word against a reference string which need not include the query word. The lexical graph preserves the relative order of edges in the feature graph corresponding to correctly recognized features. This observation leads to a subgraph-matching formulation of the recognition problem. An initial implementation proves the robustness of the approach for up-to 20% noise introduced in the feature-level graph. © 2003 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Computer vision; Pattern recognition; Bipartite graphs; Feature level; Nonparametric approaches; Query words; Relative order; Subgraph matching; Text recognition; Character recognition
Abbreviated Source Title: IEEE Comput. Soc. Conf. Comput. Vis. Pattern Recogn. Workshops

Authors: Kumar M.N.S.S.K.P., Kiran S.S.R., Nayani A., Jawahar C.V., Narayanan P.J.
Title: Tools for Developing OCRs for Indian Scripts
Source title: IEEE Computer Society Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition Workshops
Affiliations: Centre for Visual Information Technology, International Institute of Information Technology, Gachibowli, Hyderabad, India
Authors with affiliations: Kumar, M.N.S.S.K.P., Centre for Visual Information Technology, International Institute of Information Technology, Gachibowli, Hyderabad, India; Kiran, S.S.R., Centre for Visual Information Technology, International Institute of Information Technology, Gachibowli, Hyderabad, India; Nayani, A., Centre for Visual Information Technology, International Institute of Information Technology, Gachibowli, Hyderabad, India; Jawahar, C.V., Centre for Visual Information Technology, International Institute of Information Technology, Gachibowli, Hyderabad, India; Narayanan, P.J., Centre for Visual Information Technology, International Institute of Information Technology, Gachibowli, Hyderabad, India
Abstract: Development of OCRs for Indian script is an active area of research today. Indian scripts present great challenges to an OCR designer due to the large number of letters in the alphabet, the sophisticated ways in which they combine, and the complicated graphemes they result in. The problem is compounded by the unstructured manner in which popular fonts are designed. There is a lot of common structure in the different Indian scripts. In this paper, we argue that a number of automatic and semi-automatic tools can ease the development of recognizers for new font styles and new scripts. We discuss briefly three such tools we developed and show how they have helped build new OCRs. An integrated approach to the design of OCRs for all Indian scripts has great benefits. We are building OCRs for many Indian languages following this approach as part of a system to provide tools to create content in them. © 2003 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Computer vision; Active area; Common structures; Indian languages; Indian scripts; Integrated approach; Semi-automatic tools; Pattern recognition
Abbreviated Source Title: IEEE Comput. Soc. Conf. Comput. Vis. Pattern Recogn. Workshops

Authors: Vishwanathan S.V.N., Smola A.J.
Title: Fast kernels for string and tree matching
Source title: Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems
Affiliations: Dept. of Comp. Sci. and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, 560012, India; Machine Learning Group, RSISE, Australian National University, Canberra, ACT 0200, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Vishwanathan, S.V.N., Dept. of Comp. Sci. and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, 560012, India; Smola, A.J., Machine Learning Group, RSISE, Australian National University, Canberra, ACT 0200, Australia
Abstract: In this paper we present a new algorithm suitable for matching discrete objects such as strings and trees in linear time, thus obviating dynamic programming with quadratic time complexity. Furthermore, prediction cost in many cases can be reduced to linear cost in the length of the sequence to be classified, regardless of the number of support vectors. This improvement on the currently available algorithms makes string kernels a viable alternative for the practitioner.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Forestry; Discrete objects; Linear time; Quadratic time; String Kernel; Support vector; Tree-matching; Trees (mathematics)

Authors: Sen A.K., Bagchi A., Zhang W.
Title: An average-case analysis of graph search
Source title: Proceedings of the National Conference on Artificial Intelligence
Affiliations: Indian Inst. of Management Calcutta, Joka, D. H. Road, Calcutta 700 027, India; School of Management, University of Texas at Dallas, Richardson, TX 75083, United States; Computer Science Department, Washington University, St. Louis, MO 63130, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sen, A.K., Indian Inst. of Management Calcutta, Joka, D. H. Road, Calcutta 700 027, India; Bagchi, A., Indian Inst. of Management Calcutta, Joka, D. H. Road, Calcutta 700 027, India, School of Management, University of Texas at Dallas, Richardson, TX 75083, United States; Zhang, W., Computer Science Department, Washington University, St. Louis, MO 63130, United States
Abstract: Many problems in real-world applications require searching graphs. Understanding the performance of search algorithms has been one of the eminent tasks of heuristic search research. Despite the importance of graph search algorithms, the research of analyzing their performance is limited, and most work on search algorithm analysis has been focused on tree search algorithms. One of the major obstacles to analyzing graph search is that no single graph is an appropriate representative of graph search problems. In this paper, we propose one possible approach to analyzing graph search: Analyzing the performance of graph search algorithms on a representative graph of a cluster of problems. We specifically consider job-sequencing problems in which a set of Jobs must be sequenced on a machine such that a penalty function is minimized. We analyze the performance of A* graph search algorithm on an abstract model that closely represents job sequencing problems. It is an extension to a model widely used previously for analyzing tree search. One of the main results of our analysis is the existence of a gap of computational cost between two classes of job sequencing problems, one with exponential and the other with polynomial complexity. We provide experimental results showing that real job sequencing problems indeed have a huge difference on computational costs under different conditions.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Computational complexity; Graph theory; Heuristic methods; Problem solving; Theorem proving; Trees (mathematics); Job-sequencing problems; Artificial intelligence

Authors: Chakraborty D., Pal N.R.
Title: Making a multilayered perceptron network say - "Don't know" when it should
Source title: ICONIP 2002 - Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on Neural Information Processing: Computational Intelligence for the E-Age
Affiliations: Electronics and Communication Sciences Unit, Indian Statistical Institute, Calcutta, India
Authors with affiliations: Chakraborty, D., Electronics and Communication Sciences Unit, Indian Statistical Institute, Calcutta, India; Pal, N.R., Electronics and Communication Sciences Unit, Indian Statistical Institute, Calcutta, India
Abstract: The response of a multilayered perceptron (MLP) network on points far away from the training data is generally not reliable. Ideally a network should not respond to a data point which lies far away from the boundary of its training data. We propose a new training scheme for MLPs as classifiers, which ensures this. Our scheme trains subnets for each class. Each subnet can decide whether a data point belongs to a certain class or not. Training each subnet requires data from the class which the subnet represents along with some points outside the boundary of that class. For this purpose we propose an easy but approximate method to generate points outside the boundary of a pattern class. The trained subnets are then merged to solve the multi-class classification problem. We demonstrate that an MLP trained by our method does not respond to points which lie outside the boundary of its training sample. Also, our network can deal with overlapped classes in a better manner. © 2002 Nanyang Technological University.
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Approximate methods; Multi-layered Perceptron; Multiclass classification problems; Multilayered perceptron networks; Pattern class; Training data; Training sample; Training schemes; Information science
Correspondence Address: Pal, N.R.; Electronics and Communication Sciences Unit, Indian Statistical InstituteIndia

Authors: Reddy N.S., Krishnaiah J., Kumar Y.K., Acharya N.N.
Title: Modeling of low nickel-chromium steels by using backpropagation neural networks
Source title: ICONIP 2002 - Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on Neural Information Processing: Computational Intelligence for the E-Age
Affiliations: Department of Metallurgical and Materials Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, India; Intelligent Systems Lab., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, India
Authors with affiliations: Reddy, N.S., Department of Metallurgical and Materials Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, India; Krishnaiah, J., Intelligent Systems Lab., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, India; Kumar, Y.K., Intelligent Systems Lab., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, India; Acharya, N.N., Department of Metallurgical and Materials Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, India
Abstract: Steel is the most important and versatile engineering alloy. It finds numerous applications and stands second to cement in its consumption in the world. The properties of steel can be controlled and varied over a wide range by changing the heat treatment and the alloying elements. The relation between the properties and the alloying elements of the alloy is, however, very complex and non-linear in nature. This paper presents the development of a back-propagation (BP) neural network model for prediction of the mechanical properties, and the sensitivity of each element on the properties for a given combination of composition and heat treatment variables for low nickel-chromium steels. The simulation results show that the average output-prediction error by BP network is less than 5 % of the prediction range in more than 95 % of the cases, which is quite acceptable for all metallurgical purposes. © 2002 Nanyang Technological University.

Title: Link between energy and computation in a physical model of Hopfield network
Source title: ICONIP 2002 - Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on Neural Information Processing: Computational Intelligence for the E-Age
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, Chennai -36, India
Authors with affiliations: Kumar, A., Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, Chennai -36, India; Manmohan, V., Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, Chennai -36, India; Uday Shankar, M., Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, Chennai -36, India; Vishwanathan, M., Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, Chennai -36, India; Chakravarthy, V.S., Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, Chennai -36, India
Abstract: Linking information processing and energy flows via thermodynamics, Landauer (1961) proposed that irreversible computational processes have an inevitable "thermodynamic cost". We explore the existence of such a link in case of a neural network model of associative memory. Our simulations with an electronic implementation of the Hopfield neural network showed that enhanced performance of the network could only be obtained by increased dissipation of energy as heat. Contrarily, efforts to minimize energy dissipation led to impaired performance. © 2002 Nanyang Technological University.

Authors: Omkar S.N., Suresh S., Raghavendra T.R., Mani V.
Title: Acoustic emission signal classification using fuzzy c-means clustering
Source title: ICONIP 2002 - Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on Neural Information Processing: Computational Intelligence for the E-Age
Affiliations: Aerospace Engineering Department, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India
Authors with affiliations: Omkar, S.N., Aerospace Engineering Department, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India; Suresh, S., Aerospace Engineering Department, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India; Raghavendra, T.R., Aerospace Engineering Department, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India; Mani, V., Aerospace Engineering Department, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India
Abstract: Fuzzy c-means (FCM) clustering is used to classify the acoustic emission (AE) signal to different sources of signals. FCM has the ability to discover the cluster among the data, even when the boundaries between the subgroup are overlapping, FCM based technique has an advantage over conventional statistical technique like maximum likelihood estimate, nearest neighbor classifier etc, because they are distribution free (i.e.) no knowledge is required about the distribution of data. AE test is carried out using pulse, pencil and spark signal source on the surface of solid steel block. Four parameters-event duration (Ed), peak amplitude (Pa), rise time (Rt) and ring down count (Rd) are measured using AET 5000 system. These data are used to train and validate the FCM based classification. © 2002 Nanyang Technological University.

Title: An artificial neural network guided parallel genetic approach to the routing problem for field programmable gate arrays

Authors: Srinivasan N., Ravichandran V., Chan K.L., Vidhya J.R., Ramakirishnan S., Krishnan S.M.
Title: Exponentiated backpropagation algorithm for multilayer feedforward neural networks
Source title: ICONIP 2002 - Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on Neural Information Processing: Computational Intelligence for the E-Age
Affiliations: Biomedical Engineering Research Centre, School of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore; Department of Electronics and Communication Engineering, Sri Venkateswara College of Engineering, Sriperumbudur, India; Department of Mathematics and Computer Applications, Sri Venkateswara College of Engineering, Sriperumbudur, India; Department of Information Technology, Sri Venkateswara College of Engineering, Sriperumbudur, India
Authors with affiliations: Srinivasan, N., Biomedical Engineering Research Centre, School of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore, Department of Electronics and Communication Engineering, Sri Venkateswara College of Engineering, Sriperumbudur, India; Ravichandran, V., Department of Mathematics and Computer Applications, Sri Venkateswara College of Engineering, Sriperumbudur, India; Chan, K.L., Biomedical Engineering Research Centre, School of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore; Vidhya, J.R., Department of Information Technology, Sri Venkateswara College of Engineering, Sriperumbudur, India; Ramakirishnan, S., Department of Information Technology, Sri Venkateswara College of Engineering, Sriperumbudur, India; Krishnan, S.M., Biomedical Engineering Research Centre, School of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore
Abstract: The gradient descent backpropagation learning algorithm is based on minimizing the mean square error. An alternate approach to gradient descent is the exponentiated gradient descent algorithm which minimizes the relative entropy. Exponentiated gradient descent applied to backpropagation is proposed for a multilayer feedforward neural network. The learning rules for changing weights in the output layer as well the hidden layer neurons in the network are developed. Simulations were performed to explore the convergence and learning of the backpropagation algorithm with exponentiated gradient descent. Accuracy obtained with exponentiated gradient descent back propagation was comparable to the gradient descent back propagation while convergence was faster. The results show that exponentiated gradient descent can be extended to a multilayer feedforward neural network and used in pattern classification applications. © 2002 Nanyang Technological University.

Authors: Bilurkar P., Rao N., Krishna G., Jain R.
Title: Application of neural network techniques for location predication in mobile networking
Source title: ICONIP 2002 - Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on Neural Information Processing: Computational Intelligence for the E-Age
Affiliations: Mahindra British Telecom Ltd., Sharada Centre, Erandwane, Pune, India
Authors with affiliations: Bilurkar, P., Mahindra British Telecom Ltd., Sharada Centre, Erandwane, Pune, India; Rao, N., Mahindra British Telecom Ltd., Sharada Centre, Erandwane, Pune, India; Krishna, G., Mahindra British Telecom Ltd., Sharada Centre, Erandwane, Pune, India; Jain, R., Mahindra British Telecom Ltd., Sharada Centre, Erandwane, Pune, India
Abstract: Over the last few years, the worldwide cellular communication market has undergone exponential growth. This can be attributed to several factors like decreasing prices, improved radio coverage, lightweight and compact terminals. In order to accommodate higher subscriber densities, the standard technique used is to reduce the radio cell size. However, reduction in cell size increases signaling for location management procedure, which reduces the effective bandwidth available for the user traffic. Location management in general and location prediction in particular incorporates procedures with which system can locate particular mobile subscriber at any given time. Number of location prediction algorithms have been developed in the recent past. In this study, an artificial neural network technique has been used for location prediction of a mobile subscriber. Learning methods like backpropagation, backpropagation with momentum, quick propagation and resilient propagation have been applied. Results are compared with the conventional Box Jenkins forecasting technique. © 2002 Nanyang Technological University.
Editors: Yao X.Fukushima K.Lee S.-Y.Wang L.Rajapakse J.C.
Publisher: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers Inc.

Authors: Krishnaiah J., Kumar C.S., Faruqi M.A.
Title: Constructing bifurcation diagram for a chaotic time-series data through a recurrent neural network model
Source title: ICONIP 2002 - Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on Neural Information Processing: Computational Intelligence for the E-Age
Affiliations: Intelligent Systems Lab., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, Kharagpur, WB, India
Authors with affiliations: Krishnaiah, J., Intelligent Systems Lab., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, Kharagpur, WB, India; Kumar, C.S., Intelligent Systems Lab., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, Kharagpur, WB, India; Faruqi, M.A., Intelligent Systems Lab., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, Kharagpur, WB, India
Abstract: The Bifurcation Diagram (BD) of a given dynamical system gives the idea of the behaviour of one of the outputs of that system with different values of one of the control input parameters keeping all the other input parameters constant. It also gives the idea of iterative behaviour of the system for the particular input conditions. Plotting the BD through the mathematical models is popular in control/chaos theory domain. In this work, a methodology to construct the BD from the available time-series data using recurrent neural networks (RNN) and chaos theory has been developed. The ability of the developed methodology is first demonstrated on a time-series data from a mathematical dynamical system and then on a real-life complex system (submerged arc furnace). The model developed for the dynamical system has shown a high sensitivity to the training MSE level of RNN rather than to the network architecture and the recurrence level of the model, etc. © 2002 Nanyang Technological University.
Editors: Yao X.Fukushima K.Lee S.-Y.Wang L.Rajapakse J.C.

Authors: Srinivasan S.H., Narayan A.
Title: Information transfer in neurons with depressing synapses
Source title: ICONIP 2002 - Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on Neural Information Processing: Computational Intelligence for the E-Age
Affiliations: Applied Research Group, Satyam Computer Services Ltd., Bangalore, India; Dept of Computer Science, BMS College of Engineering, Bangalore, India
Authors with affiliations: Srinivasan, S.H., Applied Research Group, Satyam Computer Services Ltd., Bangalore, India; Narayan, A., Dept of Computer Science, BMS College of Engineering, Bangalore, India
Abstract: It has been recently shown that depressing synapses selectively tune to specific frequencies. In this paper we explore the implications of this phenomenon at the network level. We consider three network configurations: feedforward network, two input neuron, and a recurrent network. We show that the frequency tuning is sharper for the feedforward network. Two input synapses have "excitatory" and "inhibitory" regimes and the recurrent network exhibits coherent firing. © 2002 Nanyang Technological University.

Authors: Suresh S., Kumar M.V., Omkar S.N., Mani V., Sampath P.
Title: Neural networks based identification of helicopter dynamics using flight data
Source title: ICONIP 2002 - Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on Neural Information Processing: Computational Intelligence for the E-Age
Affiliations: Aerospace Engineering Department, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India; Rotary Wing Research and Design Center, HAL, Bangalore, India

Abstract: Identification of lateral and longitudinal dynamics of a helicopter using flight data is presented. Neural networks with linear filter also known as Narendra's model and recurrent neural networks with internal memory (memory neuron networks) are used for the purpose. These networks are used for identifying the rate and attitude response of the helicopter to a given longitudinal cyclic and lateral cyclic inputs. The relative effectiveness of these algorithms has been discussed. © 2002 Nanyang Technological University.

Authors: Shalinie S.M.
Title: Design of neuro-fuzzy network for image compression
Source title: ICONIP 2002 - Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on Neural Information Processing: Computational Intelligence for the E-Age
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Thiagarajar College of Engineering, Madurai, Tamil Nadu, India
Authors with affiliations: Shalinie, S.M., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Thiagarajar College of Engineering, Madurai, Tamil Nadu, India
Abstract: The main objective of this paper is to propose a Neuro-Fuzzy based algorithm for Image compression. The inputs to the network are original image data, while the outputs are reconstructed image data, which are close to the inputs. If the amount of data required to store the hidden unit values and the connection weights to the output layer is less than the original data, compression is achieved. The compression ratio achieved in this paper is about 9 with good reconstructed image quality. The proposed network has an additional feature that each addition of a hidden unit to the network will always improve the image quality. Further the user can trade between image quality and compression ratio depending on the application requirement. The results are found to be better than the conventional methods. © 2002 Nanyang Technological University.

Authors: Shalinie S.M.
Title: Neuro-fuzzy pattern classification model with rule extraction based on supervised learning
Source title: ICONIP 2002 - Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on Neural Information Processing: Computational Intelligence for the E-Age
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Thiagarajar College of Engineering, Madurai, TamilNadu, India
Authors with affiliations: Shalinie, S.M., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Thiagarajar College of Engineering, Madurai, TamilNadu, India
Abstract: The main objective of this paper is to design a new method for generating fuzzy rules for pattern classification. To start with, separation hyperplanes for classes are extracted from a trained neural network. The convex existence regions in the input space for each class is approximated by shifting these hyperplanes in parallel using the training data set for the classes. Using the fuzzy rules the numerical input data is classified directly without the need of neural networks. The proposed method is verified for target recognition using radar cross section signals. © 2002 Nanyang Technological University.

Authors: Patil P.M., Kulkarni U.V., Sontakke T.R.
Title: Performance evaluation of fuzzy neural network with various aggregation operators
Source title: ICONIP 2002 - Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on Neural Information Processing: Computational Intelligence for the E-Age
Affiliations: Electronics and Computer Science and Engineering Department, SGGS College of Engineering and Technology, Vishnupuri, Nanded, MS, India
Authors with affiliations: Patil, P.M., Electronics and Computer Science and Engineering Department, SGGS College of Engineering and Technology, Vishnupuri, Nanded, MS, India; Kulkarni, U.V., Electronics and Computer Science and Engineering Department, SGGS College of Engineering and Technology, Vishnupuri, Nanded, MS, India; Sontakke, T.R., Electronics and Computer Science and Engineering Department, SGGS College of Engineering and Technology, Vishnupuri, Nanded, MS, India
Abstract: The modified fuzzy neural network (MFNN) proposed by Kulkarni and Sontakke is an extension of the fuzzy neural network (FNN) proposed by Kwan and Cai. Unlike FNN, the MFNN uses the Yager class of fuzzy union and intersection operators and works under a supervised environment. The paper describes MFNN with its learning algorithm. The MFNN is extended further and its performance is verified using various fuzzy aggregation operators. It is observed that Dubois and Prade operators give highest recognition rates, as compared to other operators for Fisher Iris data. Classification performance of the Hamacher operator is better with less number of neurons for Fisher Iris data, whereas the performance with the min-max operator for Wine data is better. Timing analysis is also performed and training time is found nearly equal for all the operators. The recall time per pattern is significantly less in the case of Schweizer and Sklar, and Hamacher operators. Thus, instead of using min-max or Yager class of operators one can tune the performance of the MFNN classifier to improve generalization performance by proper selection of aggregation operators. © 2002 Nanyang Technological University.
