Authors: Bhardwaj S., Jayadeva
Title: Sequential chaotic annealing neural network for CDMA multiuser detection
Source title: ICONIP 2002 - Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on Neural Information Processing: Computational Intelligence for the E-Age
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauzkhas, New Delhi, India
Authors with affiliations: Bhardwaj, S., Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauzkhas, New Delhi, India; Jayadeva, Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauzkhas, New Delhi, India
Abstract: The optimum multiuser detection problem in the presence of noise is a quadratic integer programming problem which has been shown to be NP-complete. In this paper, we propose a novel neural network based multiuser detector for a direct-sequence code division multiple access system. The proposed detector combines the paradigms of chaotic neural networks and methods from sequential unconstrained minimization techniques. The proposed network is adaptive in the sense that the network "learns" the energy function to minimize. We show that the proposed network outperforms traditional methods such as the Hopfield net as well as as recent methods such as the transiently chaotic neural network. © 2002 Nanyang Technological University.
Editors: Yao X.Fukushima K.Lee S.-Y.Wang L.Rajapakse J.C.
Publisher: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers Inc.
Abbreviated Source Title: ICONIP - Proc. Int. Conf. Neural Inf. Process.: Comput. Intell. E-Age

Authors: Mondal P.P., Rajan K.
Title: Entropy maximization algorithm for positron emission tomography
Source title: ICONIP 2002 - Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on Neural Information Processing: Computational Intelligence for the E-Age
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India; School of Computer Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Mondal, P.P., Department of Physics, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India; Rajan, K., Department of Physics, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, India, School of Computer Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore
Abstract: The expectation maximization (EM) algorithm is extensively used for tomographic image reconstruction based on positron emission tomography (PET) modality. The EM algorithm gives good reconstructed images compared to those created by deterministic methods such as filtered back projection (FBP) and convolution back projection (CBP). However, the computational complexity of EM-based algorithm is high due to the iterative nature of the algorithm. Prior knowledge of the estimate has been added to the basic EM algorithm to improve image quality as well as to reduce the number of iterations required for an acceptable image quality. We have developed an algorithm which produces better quality images in much lesser number of iterations, thereby speeding up the image reconstruction task. © 2002 Nanyang Technological University.
Author Keywords: Conditional Entropy; Conditional Probability; Entropy Maximization; Poisson Process

Authors: Goyal R.D., Nagaraja G.
Title: Generalised brain-state-in-a-box based associative memory for correcting words and images
Source title: ICONIP 2002 - Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on Neural Information Processing: Computational Intelligence for the E-Age
Affiliations: Cyber-CI Technologies (I) Pvt. Ltd., Pune, India; Dept. of Computer Sc. and Engg., Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Mumbai, India
Authors with affiliations: Goyal, R.D., Cyber-CI Technologies (I) Pvt. Ltd., Pune, India; Nagaraja, G., Dept. of Computer Sc. and Engg., Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Mumbai, India
Abstract: Human brain has amazing capability to recall the information if a small but sufficient clue is presented. This is known as content based recall or associative memory. Hopfield nets possess capability to recall the patterns based on their content. However, Hopfield net suffers from certain drawbacks which prevent its wide use as a means of realizing associative memory. The most notable among them are very low capacity (0.15N where N is the no. of neurons) and concomitant presence of very large number of spurious states, the undesired stable patterns. In this paper an approach, which is based on generalised brain-state-in-a-box (GBSB) model has been used to correct misspelled English words (strings). Also, an experiment has been conducted for recalling the original image from the pool of stored images when corrupted image is presented as input. Generalised brain-state-in-a-box (GBSB) is used to store the desired patterns as stable states of recurrent neural network. As the capacity of this associative memory is more than that of Hopfield network having the same number of neurons and connections and the number of spurious states are also quite less, this model provides an effective practical approach for associative recall. © 2002 Nanyang Technological University.
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Associative processing; Information science; Memory architecture; Neural networks; Recurrent neural networks; Associative memory; Associative recall; Brain-State-in-a-Box; Corrupted images; Hopfield nets; Hopfield Networks; Original images; Stable patterns; Associative storage

Authors: Mishra R.R.
Title: Self organizing fuzzy neural network: An application to character recognition
Source title: ICONIP 2002 - Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on Neural Information Processing: Computational Intelligence for the E-Age
Affiliations: Patni Computer Systems Ltd., SEEPZ, Mumbai, India
Authors with affiliations: Mishra, R.R., Patni Computer Systems Ltd., SEEPZ, Mumbai, India
Abstract: Character recognition is a very important field in DSP. Many different methods are used for this purpose. The ANN technique based on back propagation algorithm is very slow as its computational complexity is very high. On the other hand the Self-orthogonal ANN offers less computational complexity but it is not able to deal with the uncertainty associated with the input data sequence. Hence, fuzzy logic is applied in this case. The fuzzy logic based self-orthogonal neural network has been applied to the scale changed and distorted characters only. The problem of invariance to rotation has been discussed using the four layered feed forward fuzzy neural network. © 2002 Nanyang Technological University.

Title: Fuzzy mean point clustering neural network
Source title: ICONIP 2002 - Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on Neural Information Processing: Computational Intelligence for the E-Age
Affiliations: Department of Electronics and Computer Science and Engineering, SGGS College of Engineering and Technology, Vishnupuri, Nanded, MS, India
Authors with affiliations: Patil, P.M., Department of Electronics and Computer Science and Engineering, SGGS College of Engineering and Technology, Vishnupuri, Nanded, MS, India; Kulkarni, U.V., Department of Electronics and Computer Science and Engineering, SGGS College of Engineering and Technology, Vishnupuri, Nanded, MS, India; Sontakke, T.R., Department of Electronics and Computer Science and Engineering, SGGS College of Engineering and Technology, Vishnupuri, Nanded, MS, India
Abstract: Fuzzy mean point clustering neural network (FMPCNN) is proposed with its learning algorithm, which utilizes fuzzy sets as pattern clusters. The performance of FMPCNN when verified with Fisher Iris data, it is found superior to Simpson's fuzzy min-max neural network and fuzzy hyperline segment clustering neural network (FHLSCNN) proposed by Kulkarni and Sontakke. © 2002 Nanyang Technological University.

Authors: Chaudhari N.S., Tiwari A.
Title: Extending ETL for multi-class output
Source title: ICONIP 2002 - Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on Neural Information Processing: Computational Intelligence for the E-Age
Affiliations: School of Computer Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Block N4-02a-32, Nanyang Avenue, Singapore, Singapore; Department of Computer Engineering, Shri G.S. Institute of Technology and Science, 23, Park Road, Indore, MP, India
Authors with affiliations: Chaudhari, N.S., School of Computer Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Block N4-02a-32, Nanyang Avenue, Singapore, Singapore; Tiwari, A., Department of Computer Engineering, Shri G.S. Institute of Technology and Science, 23, Park Road, Indore, MP, India
Abstract: We present a method for extending the expand and truncate learning (ETL) technique for multi-class output. Kim and Park (1995) have given two hints for solving the same problem, but their hints may result in a large sized neural net. Here, we propose another method for the same problem, which is expected to result in a smaller neural net. Our method is based on yet other known technique introduced by Gray and Michel (1992), called the Boolean like training algorithm. © 2002 Nanyang Technological University.

Authors: Varma A., Jayadeva
Title: A novel digital neural network for the travelling salesman problem
Source title: ICONIP 2002 - Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on Neural Information Processing: Computational Intelligence for the E-Age
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Computing Engineering, University of Maryland, College Park, MD, United States; Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Haw Khas, New Delhi, India
Authors with affiliations: Varma, A., Department of Electrical and Computing Engineering, University of Maryland, College Park, MD, United States; Jayadeva, Department of Electrical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Haw Khas, New Delhi, India
Abstract: In this paper, we present a novel neural network solution to the Travelling Salesperson's Problem. In comparison to the Hopfield Neural Network for the task, the proposed network requires N neurons and O(N2) weights to solve a N-city instance. The proposed network is entirely digital, and has been mapped onto a Field Programmable Gate Array. Initial results are encouraging and the FPGA takes under 20 microseconds to solve the task for chosen examples. The re-programmable nature of the FPGA makes the proposed approach a very low cost, reusable hardware approach. © 2002 Nanyang Technological University.

Authors: Jayaraman S., Sitaraman G., Seshadri R.
Title: Blind source separation of acoustic mixtures using time-frequency domain Independent Component Analysis
Source title: ICONIP 2002 - Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on Neural Information Processing: Computational Intelligence for the E-Age
Affiliations: Dept. of Electronics and Communication Engg., P.S.G. College of Technology, Coimbatore, India
Authors with affiliations: Jayaraman, S., Dept. of Electronics and Communication Engg., P.S.G. College of Technology, Coimbatore, India; Sitaraman, G., Dept. of Electronics and Communication Engg., P.S.G. College of Technology, Coimbatore, India; Seshadri, R., Dept. of Electronics and Communication Engg., P.S.G. College of Technology, Coimbatore, India
Abstract: Blind source separation of acoustic mixtures aims at providing a solution to the classical cocktail-party problem. The inherent delays and convolutions in microphone recordings, entails a modification in the independent component analysis (ICA), which achieves separation by making the assumption of statistical independence of source signals that are linearly combined. The proposed algorithm provides a solution for the blind source separation problem by shifting he domain of the problem to time-frequency domain and applying ICA to each of the frequency components individually. Satisfactory results were achieved for Speech-Music as well as speech-speech separation by adopting the time-frequency domain ICA. © 2002 Nanyang Technological University.

Authors: Mercy Shalinie S.
Title: Design of neuro-fuzzy based modular architecture for pattern recognition
Source title: ICONIP 2002 - Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on Neural Information Processing: Computational Intelligence for the E-Age
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Thiagarajar College of Engineering, Madurai, TamilNadu, India
Authors with affiliations: Mercy Shalinie, S., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Thiagarajar College of Engineering, Madurai, TamilNadu, India
Abstract: Many pattern recognition methodologies and design techniques have been developed over the years and new approaches continue to emerge. For the solution of complex problems in pattern recognition and more generally machine intelligence, involving heterogeneous data sources of both numeric and symbolic information, the fundamental design philosophy is to employ hybrid methodologies rather than attempting to produce the solution using a single paradigm. The main objective of this paper is to integrate heterogeneous methodologies for intelligent solution of pattern recognition problems. A modular neural structure where a self-organizing Boolean neural network architecture is used as a front end processor to a feedforward neural architecture based on goal seeking principles is described. Fuzzy logic controller is included to provide decisions in uncertain conditions. The characteristics of the proposed methodology is illustrated by considering its application to a terrain image understanding system from multiple sensors and spatial databases. © 2002 Nanyang Technological University.
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Complex networks; Computation theory; Fuzzy logic; Image understanding; Information science; Network architecture; Boolean neural networks; Feed-forward neural architectures; Fuzzy logic controllers; Heterogeneous data sources; Image understanding systems; Intelligent solutions; Modular architectures; Pattern recognition problems; Pattern recognition

Authors: Pai G.A.V., Sreeram S.
Title: Military target identification using Simulated Annealing
Source title: ICONIP 2002 - Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on Neural Information Processing: Computational Intelligence for the E-Age
Affiliations: Dept. of Computer Applications, PSG College of Technology, Coimbatore, India
Authors with affiliations: Pai, G.A.V., Dept. of Computer Applications, PSG College of Technology, Coimbatore, India; Sreeram, S., Dept. of Computer Applications, PSG College of Technology, Coimbatore, India
Abstract: The application of Simulated Annealing for the identification of Military Targets, images of which can be both noisy and noise free, nominal and transformed, has been investigated in this paper. The images of Military Targets of an enemy are captured by an unmanned reconnaissance spy plane and then are interpreted by an expert. In the absence of an expert, Simulated Annealing can be used to identify the enemy targets. The potential of Simulated Annealing behaving as a Pattern Recognizer to recognize images even when they appear transformed, viz., rotated, translated and scaled, besides noisy, has been studied. Performance of Simulated Annealing during different temperatures has also been studied on experimental cases. © 2002 Nanyang Technological University.

Authors: Prashanth A., Kalra P.K., Vyas N.S.
Title: Surface classification using ANN and complex-valued neural network
Source title: ICONIP 2002 - Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on Neural Information Processing: Computational Intelligence for the E-Age
Affiliations: Dept. of Electr. Eng., Indian Inst. of Technol., Kanpur, India; Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur, India
Authors with affiliations: Prashanth, A., Dept. of Electr. Eng., Indian Inst. of Technol., Kanpur, India; Kalra, P.K., Dept. of Electr. Eng., Indian Inst. of Technol., Kanpur, India; Vyas, N.S., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur, India
Abstract: Complex variable based backpropagation algorithm (CVBP) is a new development in neural networks (ANN). The new tool of approximation is designed to train complex-variable based neural networks (CNN) in which the weights, functions of activation are complex in nature. The CVBP also is developed over a quadratic error function (same as the backpropagation algorithm). The present paper explores the possibility of using different Error Functions and compares the performance of each of them (ANN and CNN over Error Functions) by applying to a surface classification problem. © 2002 Nanyang Technological University.

Authors: Ravindranath V., Rayudu P.V.
Title: Neuroinformatics: Indian perspective
Source title: ICONIP 2002 - Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on Neural Information Processing: Computational Intelligence for the E-Age
Affiliations: National Brain Research Centre, SCO 5,6, and 7, Sector 15(2), Gurgaon, Haryana, India
Authors with affiliations: Ravindranath, V., National Brain Research Centre, SCO 5,6, and 7, Sector 15(2), Gurgaon, Haryana, India; Rayudu, P.V., National Brain Research Centre, SCO 5,6, and 7, Sector 15(2), Gurgaon, Haryana, India
Abstract: Current conception of information in terms of bits cannot accommodate the holistic nature of perceptual information. Category theory, which describes mathematical objects in terms of their relations to other objects, appears to be resourceful enough to capture the holistic nature of perception and memory. Recognizing the potential of category theory, National Brain Research Centre, India, has initiated a research program to bring category theory and higher dimensional algebra to bear on brain research. I will discuss a memory model called Form-Addressed Memory that we are developing. In this model, percepts and memories are modeled in terms of arrows f:Ararr→B, an indivisible whole in category theory. I will also present the work of various Indian scientists: non-classical information theoretic analysis of sensory systems, applying stochastic resonance to neuroimaging and pattern recognition tools to neuroanatomical data, development of federated databases, and plans for databasing drug metabolism pathways and neuroactive drugs from Indian traditional medicine. © 2002 Nanyang Technological University.

Authors: Bhattacharyya C., Sathiya Keerthi S.
Title: A variational mean-field theory for sigmoidal belief networks
Source title: Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems
Affiliations: Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, 560012, India; Mechanical and Production Engineering, National University of Singapore, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Bhattacharyya, C., Computer Science and Automation, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, 560012, India; Sathiya Keerthi, S., Mechanical and Production Engineering, National University of Singapore, Singapore
Abstract: A variational derivation of Plefka's mean-field theory is presented. This theory is then applied to sigmoidal belief networks with the aid of further approximations. Empirical evaluation on small scale networks show that the proposed approximations are quite competitive.
Index Keywords: Empirical evaluations; Small-scale networks; Variational mean-field theory; Mean field theory
